NYU Abu Dhabi, Archives and Special Collections
NYU Abu Dhabi Capstone Archives AD.MC.004 12
3.2 Terabytes comprised of approximately 45,000 electronic files
2014-2022 The Capstone Archives is an accumulating collection of NYU Abu Dhabi undergraduate senior research projects. The archival colletion includes project files primarily comprised of text-based essays, but may also include filmed performances, interactive media files, and supplemental documents submitted by NYU Abu Dhabi graduating seniors, from 2014 to the present. Submitting their senior Capstone project is a required step for students to complete their undergraduate education at NYUAD and collect their diplomas. Users may access the projects by contacting the Library's Archives and Special Collections staff, who will provide temporary, view-only access to open files.
Biographical / Historical
Conducting Capstone research is a significant part of the undergraduate experience at NYU Abu Dhabi, which every student will engage during their fourth year. Marking the final step before graduating, the year-long research endeavor may result in pursuing an important research question or creative idea, which may take the form of an historical narrative, musical composition, performance, invention, documented experiment, scholarly thesis, or other form appropriate to the student's goals.
To prepare for their Capstone research, all students enroll in a Capstone seminar, led by assigned faculty in each major or program. Some student research, particularly within the Engineering Division, may be conceptualized as a group project, and may build upon research that was conducted by members of an earlier Class. No matter the pursuit, as the program description states, the student is in charge and challenged "to enter unmapped terrain and to extend oneself in making knowledge, reframing conventional approaches to an issue or creating something new."
At the end of each spring semester, each of NYU Abu Dhabi's four academic divisions acknowledge and celebrate Capstone Projects in a variety of ways. These celebrations themselves have become traditions. For example, the Division of Arts and Humanities hosts an annual Capstone Festival; the Engineering Division hosts a special website showcase; and various programs and departments across campus celebrate with senior dinners, acknowledgement, and congratulations events. An annual Capstone Projects anthology is also produced and widely shared. As a condition of graduation (as of 2018), students must submit their project to the Library, where the collections is managed as part of the University Archives.
Scope and Contents
One of the most frequently used collections of the University Archives, the Capstone Archives is the University's accumulating collection of submitted Capstone senior research projects, beginning with the Class of 2014 and continuing to the present. Submitting their senior Capstone project is a required step for students to complete their undergraduate education at NYUAD and collect their diplomas.
The collection is a living, growing digital collection that is being preserved by Archives and Special Collections, in the NYU Abu Dhabi Library. The collection represents a diverse sampling of the research, innovation, and creative endeavors of NYUAD undergraduate students.
Project files consist primarily of text-based essays. Some projects also include other products and deliverables such as copies of films, unpublished novellas, and filmed performances; interactive media files such as programmed Virtual Reality, video game software files, mobile apps, or filmed interactive installations; and supplemental documents such as photographs and design files of installations and prototypes. As the projects represent all majors across disciplines, a broad range of topics and research areas are explored across the collection.
In some cases, particularly in the Engineering Division, Capstone projects are group projects, or may continue research that was begun by a previous group under direction of the same faculty member.
Upon submission, students write and provide their own summary abstracts of the project, which are included as "Scope and Content Notes" of each open project described in this guide.
Student creators are given the option to restrict their project for a period of time, and some do choose to do so. There are a variety of reasons why this might happen. For example, some students may wish to continue their research beyond their time at NYU Abu Dhabi, and are not yet ready to make it public. This finding aid represents only unrestricted and open projects. Administration of restricted files is managed by Archives and Special Collections staff and follows a rights management timeline.
In addition to project files, which make up the core of the collection, a series of "Other Capstone Documentation" includes records such as video recordings of students describing their projects; photographs of installations and prototypes taken by campus photographers (as opposed to those submitted by students); and ephemera from Capstone Festivals and events.
This collection is open to the public, and by far its most frequent user group includes NYUAD juniors and seniors who seek out the collection as they embark on their own research. Student researchers browse and read past Capstone projects, for example, for inspiration; to gauge if an idea has been explored before; to carry on previous research; or, as part of a literature review to integrate into the project essay.
Members of the public are also welcome to browse and use the collection for research purposes. The Capstone Archives is an open collection. Please refer to "Conditions Governing Access" and "Conditions Governing Use" in this guide for more information about access and use.
Arrangement
The collection is arranged in series by the four academic divisions: Arts and Humanities, Engineering, Science, and Social Sciences. Within those series, projects are arranged into sub-series by major. Within each major, projects are then listed chronologically by submission year and alphabetically by last name of student within.
Each project is considered a unique project, and all projects will have their own component unique identifier, which is the Capstone Project number or "CP#."
For group projects with multiple authors, the project has one CP#, and the title is listed alphabetically by last name, with all names of participants included. Although each individual student's essay is preserved in the collection, only one CP# is applied and the project will only be listed once.
A fifth series, "Other Capstone Documentation," includes primarily media from divisional Capstone Festivals. This series is minimally processed, but arrangement of the files correspond to Division and CP# and are accessible.
Immediate Source of Acquisition
Capstone Projects and their accompanying supplemental documents are uploaded to an administrative server directly by students, which is managed by NYUAD web and IT team. Instructions and a form are accessible via the NYU Abu Dhabi intranet. Submitted projects are then transferred to Library repositories by the archivists for integration and preservation as part of the University Archives.
Other Capstone documentation, such as Capstone Festival media, is acquired through various means directly from individual programs, via arrangement with Library digital content specialists, or through regular transfer to the archivist.
Conditions Governing Access
Archived Capstone Projects that are open and unrestricted are available for viewing onsite in the Archives and Special Collections reading room, or temporary view-only remote access may be arranged. Each Capstone Project has a unique identifier defined by year of submission and a four-digit number (ex: 2019-0001). When requesting access, this number is needed for retrieval of files.
Conditions Governing Use
Open files in the Capstone Archives are available for research, study, and teaching. Copyright is retained by the student creators. Anyone who wishes to use or quote from a project for publication or commercial purpose, will need to contact the authors directly to obtain further permission.
Processing Information
Processed by Lauren Kata, with assistance from Maria Chaves and student assistants Ian Bryce Hoyt, Muhammad Shehryar Hamid, and Polina Pinskikh. An original container list for 2014-2016 projects was created in Archivists' Toolkit by Nicholas Martin.
During the spring and summer of 2020, a reprocessing project was undertaken to accommodate publishing a public finding aid. Work involved the application of consistent naming conventions, removal of Personally Identifiable Information and implementation of a new "CP#" as component unique identifier, as well as a new arrangement scheme by academic division and major to provide a more accessible browse experience for users. At this time, quality control of the digital files was also conducted, preparing them for future and ongoing preservation processing. This work was a collaborative project between Archives and Special Collections and the Center for Digital Scholarship.
University and Colleges -- Research College students--research
Arts & Humanities Division Projects2014-2021Arab Crossroads StudiesTessen, Alice. Compounding British Interests in Zanzibar: Accounting for Continuities between Sultanate and Protectorate2014-0003642014AD-MC-0042014-0003
Scope and Contents
In the first decades of colonial rule, British imperial administrators abolished slavery in Zanzibar, but their attempts to persuade Arab landowners to embrace wage labor in the place of slave labor fell on deaf ears. The once-powerful Arab clove planters had lost much of their political influence over the course of the 19th century, and many were heavily in debt to Indian moneylenders. The development of this situation is vital to understanding how colonial policies were implemented and how Zanzibaris navigated the changes which occurred in the early colonial period. This thesis analyzes the current state of scholarship on Zanzibar's early colonial history, and argues that there has been a tendency for studies to rely too heavily on casting 1890 as a turning point, which has the effect of downplaying continuities between pre-colonial and early colonial processes of economic, political, and social change. I advocate for a rethinking of temporal boundaries in future research on this subject, and I examine two processes, the slave trade and the British exploitation of Indian merchants, which demonstrate the theoretical benefits that can be derived from crossing the imagined border between the pre-colonial and colonial eras.Colonialism -- History -- Middle EastOmanZanzibarBritish EmpireAgriculture/FarmsEnslavementDebtHennig, Clare Elizabeth. The 'Red Line' Of Journalism: Shifting Visions Of The Media In The UAE2016-000479662016AD-MC-0042016-0004
Scope and Contents
This project focuses on the gap between the vision of journalism in the UAE and the position of the press in practice. The first two chapters piece together a history of journalism in the country alongside a theoretical discussion of the role and responsibilities of the press in society. This is followed by an examination of the UAE's canon of media law and a news analysis of national newspapers. Despite a push to foster journalism in the country, the legal framework has not yet caught up with the purported vision of the press. This dichotomy of informal promises on the one hand and the formal legal cannon on the other is one of the biggest challenges the press currently faces in the UAE. This creates uncertainty in the newsroom, ultimately leading to an inclination towards self-censorship when reporting sensitive issues because of a fear of crossing the 'red line' of journalism.Leathley, Emma. War of Words: How UAE Think Tanks Use War On Terrorism Discourse To Produce Knowledge And Promote Policy.2016-000579782016AD-MC-0042016-0005
Scope and Contents
This project uses discourse analysis of the terrorism literature of four UAE think tanks--Al Mesbar Center for Studies and Research, the Emirates Center for Strategic Studies and Research, TRENDS Research & Advisory, and Hedayah--to examine how think tanks in the UAE use the discourse of the war on terrorism in their policy research. It found that UAE think tanks mimic and adapt various forms and stages of the American discourse on the war on terrorism.Plottel, Louis. "The Lighter Our Task, The Heavier Our Burden" An Ethnography Of Political Dissidence Among Punks And Anarchists In Indonesia.2016-001079792016AD-MC-0042016-0010
Scope and Contents
Punk and anarchism, as lived practices that espouse anti-authoritarianism and prefigurative politics as their guiding principles, share a close affinity. Yet, the political value of punk has tended to be overlooked in favor of the punk "identity." This paper considers the overlapping politics of anarchists and punks in Yogyakarta, Indonesia, through ethnographic description of the everyday practice of political dissidence. I approach punk from an anarchist point of view, analysing it as an expression of prefigurative politics. Drawing upon fieldwork with members of a newly formed anarchist website, anarkis.org, and a punk squat in the north of the city, I show how political dissidents in Indonesia are fostering connections to global punk and anarchist movements through their everyday lives. I contend that punks play an important role in the embodiment of anarchism as a political way of being, while revealing the contours and complexities of radical political movements in Indonesia.Levinson, Melissa. Constructing an Enemy: Representations of the Middle East and Islam in U.S. Textbooks2018-00072018AD-MC-0042018-0007
Scope and Contents
My project investigates the dominant portrayals of Arabs and Muslims in history textbooks in the United States. Specifically, my study concludes that world history textbooks perpetuate the notion of a "rise and fall" of the Middle East and Islamic faith and present Arabs and Muslims as antithetical to American values. My research further seeks to determine why these representations came about. In other words, what political, economic, and social forces have influenced the negative portrayals we see in American textbooks? I have found that these representations are in part due to a rise of conservative voices in educational curricular development since the 1980s that has created an education system that narrowly defines the American nation by its white, Christian roots and seeks to preserve the notion of American exceptionalism.Burlin, Carl Alexander. "A New Paradigm" for Syrian Refugees?: Development, Displacement Management and (Dis-)Empowerment in Jordan2019-00022019AD-MC-0042019-0002
Scope and Contents
This paper examines the extent to which development planning can provide solutions to protracted displacement crises by looking at the case of the "Jordan Compact," a multi-stakeholder policy agreement that promised to turn the Syrian "refugee crisis" in Jordan into a "development opportunity." Drawing on fieldwork conducted in Jordan over the summer of 2018 I argue that the Jordan Compact failed to reach target outcomes due to a number of structural implementation challenges, including policy decontextualization and a competitive development architecture. In terms of the empowerment of Syrian refugees, however, the failure of the Jordan Compact was not so much a question of flawed implementation as it was of the "anti-politics" of development-based refugee policy. Syrians in Jordan do not just suffer from "underdevelopment," but also from a weak protection regime that circumvents the question of durable solutions and facilitates exploitation, discrimination, and abuse. In this way, a critique of the Jordan Compact should first and foremost highlight the political failure of the compact to strengthen refugee protection and offer a durable, long-term solution to the refugee crisis.Mikhalkovich, Alena. Perceptions and Practices of Emirati visitors at Louvre Abu Dhabi2019-00272019AD-MC-0042019-0027
Scope and Contents
This research studies Louvre Abu Dhabi and the "Roads of Arabia" exhibition, its role in nation-building and UAE branding, and its reception by the local population. Firstly, I examine the museum's reconciliation of local and universal heritage, the UAE nation-building and branding. Secondly, I study Emiratis' reception of such big Western-style museum projects. I argue that Louvre Abu Dhabi brand becomes regionalized and appropriated for UAE nation-branding and regional diplomacy. At the same time, I demonstrate that Emiratis, despite appreciation of the universal narrative, view the museum primarily as a branding project and a tourist-oriented establishment, disapproving its emphasis on the Western culture and insufficient reach out to the local population. Hence, Emiratis desire bigger representation of the local heritage at Louvre, seeing it as worthy of being part of the universal narrative. In addition, I argue that Louvre Abu Dhabi apart from mitigating the nation-building and branding contradictions, gives a way for a young educated upper- and middle-class Emiratis to practice and express their elitist cultural identity in contradistinction to the older, less educated, and religiously conservative Emiratis.Plaschke, Jakob. LGBT+-Activism in Tunisia: Brokering Progressive Politics Independently2020-0001Monica Marks2020AD-MC-0042020-0001
Scope and Contents
Based on two fieldwork trips and extensive interviewing, this capstone looks broadly at how LGBT+-activist organizations function in the political context that is contemporary Tunisia. The capstone consists of four main chapters, each contributing separately to the existing literature on the topic, but also coming together as a whole. The first chapter is a historical account of LGBT+-activism in Tunisia, identifying important periods and ruptures. The second chapter is a contemporary mapping of the Tunisian LGBT+-activist community, focused on organizations' differences, interplay and conflicts. The third chapter argues that Tunisian LGBT+-activists are doing a good job at navigating complex political structures to their benefit and also details the concrete work being carried out. The final chapter argues that if Tunisian LGBT+-activists continue to self-evaluate and improve their ability to assert influence, they have a unique chance to become brokers of broad political alliances over progressive social policies. This is in part due to the fact that LGBT+-rights are not a politically polarizing issue and in part because the organizations are not tainted by affiliations with the Ben Ali dictatorship.
Queer, activism, LGBT, Tunisia, North Africa, MENA, politics, history, TunisQueerPolitical activistsTunisiaNorth AfricaLGBTYoung Kim, Ji. Never كافي: Understanding Emirati Youth Subculture development in Abu Dhabi Specialty Cafes2020-00022020AD-MC-0042020-0002
Scope and Contents
With the increased number of specialty cafes in Abu Dhabi, Emirati youth have appropriated cafes as a space of sociability. Through field interviews and ethnographic research, this paper investigates how the influx of specialty cafes has developed the practice of sociability between young Emiratis, and how these spaces of sociability affect their modes of identification. I argue that Abu Dhabi youth transform specialty cafes into a young people's place that is socially acceptable while encouraging them to expand their social circle beyond their family. By doing so, they not only create a subculture inside this social space but also reconstruct social norms to fit the category of the youth. I discuss the themes of anonymity, privacy, gender hierarchy and the performance of identity. Just like the title indicates, there is "never enough" layers and information on how cafes can be understood Abu Dhabi.
Abu Dhabi, Youth Culture, Specialty Cafe, Anonymity, Subculture, GenderAmmagui, Nada. Aesthetic Assertion: Taste-Making at the Sharjah Biennial2020-00032020AD-MC-0042020-0003
Scope and Contents
Art has long served as a platform for cultural exploration, representation, and exchange, particularly in the space of international art fairs and biennials (Althuser 2008; Kirshenblatt-Gimblatt 2007). From souqs and Kalba Nature Reserve to canopied saris and dancing chess pieces, the Sharjah Biennial, the first art biennial in the Arabian Penninsula, takes visitors on a physical trip through Sharjah and an ideological journey through global contemporary artistic forms and themes. How does the Sharjah Biennial's juxtaposition of local traditions and internationally relevant concerns shape local aesthetic tastes? How do spatial and aesthetic discourses affect these tastes? This capstone paper investigates the effect of these discourses, grounded in local historical narratives, on the creation of aesthetic preferences. With this research, I challenge hegemonic rhetoric on modernization and identity retro-formation in Gulf art scenes by arguing that the Sharjah Biennial draws on local histories to shape its future. I fill a gap in contemporary art and biennial literature by offering the first academic paper on the Sharjah Biennial and by shedding light on the roles of art events in the shaping of local aesthetics, contributing to a wider understanding of contemporary Gulf cultures.
Sharjah, UAE, contemporary art, biennials, aesthetics, anthropology, habitus, milieu, exhibitionGarcia, Sussan. Kafala and Binding are Synonyms: A Consequence of Capitalist Class Formation in Ethnic Regimes in the United Arab Emirates and Israel2020-00042020AD-MC-0042020-0004
Scope and Contents
This capstone questions the lack of nuance present in the critiques aimed at the kafala system I observed as a student at Abu Dhabi, which was highlighted during my time in Israel, which has a remarkably similar binding system. Unsatisfied by reports that dismissed the kafala as a product of unique Gulf historical or cultural factors, I conducted a comparative historical study of Israel and the United Arab Emirates to determine what forces led to the creation of these privatized visa sponsorship systems. I conclude that universal forces behind capitalist class formation in these ethnic regimes led to the creation of their contemporary labor migration regimes; this is further reinforced by their different scales of labor migration population, which speaks to the longevity of their respective labor migration regime. This capstone compiles labor migration histories of Israel and the United Arab Emirates, and establishes one of the few robust comparisons of these two countries.
United Arab Emirates, Israel, kafala, migration, labor migration, bindingDuborg, Christian. Ideologies of Persuasion: an Examination of the Political Rhetoric of Gamal Abdel Nasser in Egyptian and International Media, 1958-19652020-00052020AD-MC-0042020-0005
Scope and Contents
The goal of this capstone is to use a case study of Nasser's Egypt to examine how governments use the media for political persuasion. Using speeches broadcast over Radio Cairo and interviews given to foreign media outlets by President Nasser himself, the study examines the language, subject matter, and rhetorical strategies employed to persuade the audience to support him and his government. Additionally, the study provides an analysis of historical context, popular discourse, and intended audience to provide a better understanding of the strategic persuasive choices made by the government, as well as an analysis of the nature and role of ideology in Nasser's appeals. Finally this dissertation uses this evidence to provide a characterization of Nasser himself as a politician, orator, and key figure in the development of political mass media in the Middle East.
Egypt, Nasser, Media, Propaganda, History, Politics, Pan-Arabism, IdeologyPruett, Everett. One for One and All for Themselves: The Role of Individual Emirates' Considerations in the Formulation of Emirati Foreign Policy2021-00022021AD-MC-0042021-0002
Scope and Contents
Analysts and scholars have frequently framed Emirati foreign policy formation as a highly centralized story, where political interests and sub-national considerations play little or no significant role. This narrative has traditionally depicted Emirati foreign policy formation as being the sole creation of the capital and wealthiest emirate, unimpeded by the considerations of the other six emirates. This capstone seeks to problematize this narrative as overly simplistic and incomplete. Through investigation into the history and current dynamics surrounding UAE foreign policy formation, this capstone highlights the numerous considerations that affect Emirati foreign policy. It does this by examining three cases: Emirati policy towards Islamism, towards Iran, and Emirati foreign economic policy. Under Sheikh Zayed al-Nahyan, each emirate had limited freedom to formulate foreign policy concerning other states. Since Sheikh Zayed's passing, his son and the de-facto leader of the UAE, Sheikh Mohamed bin Zayed al-Nahyan, has worked to centralize the federal government under himself. Understanding Emirati foreign policy as more than just driven by Abu Dhabi is important for any policymaker or academic whose work relates to the UAE.
Author provided keywords: United Arab Emirates, Islamism, Iran, Foreign Policy, Political Economy, ParadiplomacyRyu, Iris Seunga. Bridging the Gap between Expectation and Reality: Urban Planning and the Public Bus System in Abu Dhabi2021-00012021AD-MC-0042021-0001
Scope and Contents
This paper analyzes Abu Dhabi government's initial goals of establishing the public bus system, the efficiency of the currently implemented bus system, and real users' experiences and social meanings of public transport in Abu Dhabi. While Abu Dhabi Department of Transport (DoT) constructed the urban transportation system to facilitate economic activities and comply to the idealized version of modernity, the public buses are evaluated to be inefficient and reinforce social stratification, further creating social isolation and sense of unbelonging. Moreover, the government's implementation of the transport system seems inefficient and people find strategic ways to navigate the city that challenge or even subvert the intentions of the DoT. Therefore, this paper argues that state-led urban planning and goals often differ from the actual implementation and utilization by residents, a gap commonly found in processes and outcomes of urban planning and transport infrastructure on a global level.
Author provided keywords: urban planning, infrastructural development, public transportation, public bus systemArt & Art HistoryBaltaji, Bouthayna Mohammad Issa. Bina'a Al Bee'ah Al Mahalee'yah Al Fen'nee'yah (The Building of the Local Art Community)2014-0010902014AD-MC-0042014-0010
Scope and Contents
My capstone project seeks to address the issue of introducing the museum experience to a generation of children and parents who are relatively new to the museum culture. Abu Dhabi's biggest legacy in the realm of the arts may be the introduction of innovative museums like the Louvre Abu Dhabi (2015), the Norman Foster designed Zayed National Museum (2016), and the Guggenheim Abu Dhabi (2017). However, prior to their public openings a need exists to expose the general community to "museum culture." To address that process, I have completed working on an arts education initiative that focused on building a museum going society. I have worked in collaboration with the Abu Dhabi Tourism and Cultural Authority and Abu Dhabi Education Council on this project and I have developed and conducted workshops with private and international schools in the emirate for 150 students. The works produced during these workshops were exhibited from May 4th, 2014 until May 25th, 2014 at the Manarat Al Saadiyat.WorkshopsExhibitionsMuseumsSchools/EducationCommunitySchools/EducationArtFlores, Cassandra Elizabeth. The Not-So-New Kid: The Changing Relationship to National Representation in the National Pavilion of the United Arab Emirates at the Venice Biennale, 2009-20132014-00132014AD-MC-0042014-0013
Scope and Contents
This paper explores the brief history of the United Arab Emirates (UAE) at the Venice Biennale. It addresses the recent and rapid development of the UAE's cultural infrastructure and the history and significance of the Venice Biennale art fair. Due to its continued use of national pavilions, the Venice Biennale acts as a space in which art is presented within a narrative of national identity and representation. However, in recent years many countries have shown pavilions that question or reject the nation-based format. In its time at the Venice Biennale the UAE Pavilion has demonstrated a shift away from overt and largely promotional national representation, in turn towards a critical engagement with the country's history and development, and finally towards an examination of nationhood itself. The alignment of this transformation with prevalent Biennale trends may imply, particularly within the context of the Venice Biennale, a greater appreciation for and emphasis on art on the part of the UAE.Hunt, James Baxter IV. D-WR2014-0017912014AD-MC-0042014-0017
Scope and Contents
D-WR encompasses the globe. Sourced from an international community, the project depicts events that punctuate four years of global travels. The events reveal themselves through visual translation into several thousand "reactions", that is, images, movements, and the like painted, drawn, or etched into the canvas in their appropriate geographical positions. Pictures taken over the duration of the paintings' creation record each instance, frame by frame, into a condensed animation. Both the canvas and the animation, shown side by side, serve to answer questions about both the formation and experience of cultural memory, by revealing in the absolute terms of geography the indeterminate movement of human recollection. They serve, in particular, for the community whose movements and inputs inspired and informed the work, to reveal a collection of memories, and those memories power to shape worldviews when shared.Stop-motion filmsCollective memoryPaintingsMeekhof, Erin Katherine. Special Identity2014-0016922014AD-MC-0042014-0016
Scope and Contents
Special Identity is a project to develop and implement a corporate identity for the Ability Center, a local school for students with special needs. By working with the students, faculty, and caregivers, I created a narrative, visual identity, and set of materials that reflects the Ability Center's particular strengths and offerings as a place of enabling community. The brand gives the Ability Center the agency to define their own identity and engage supporters, future students, and the community of Abu Dhabi. Please visit www.adabilitycenter.org to learn more about the Ability Center.DisabilitiesTrademarksCorporate identityCorporationsArtPinto Miguel, Alejandra del Carmen. Reencuentros is a webpage that displays the lives of three Salvadorian visual artists that worked during the Civil War and created an active art scene in El Salvador.El SalvadorWarsArtArtistsAl Ali, Amal. Collision2015-000133822015AD-MC-0042015-0001
Scope and Contents
I was driven to create the sculptural series Collision due to the psychological shift I experienced once I began driving. Suddenly I was forced to see and react to every stimulus. I became overwhelmed by what was out of my control and what surrounded me. In order to regain control, I created objects that attempted to negotiate this fear. Collision is a series of aluminum sculptures created through a cathartic performance that attempts to reconcile my fear of experiencing road traffic trauma. Collision negotiates the opposing forces and the promise of survival beyond trauma.Car accidentsCubeSculptureAluminumBushra, Sarah Abdu. This project is an investigation of in-between areas as places of temporary habitation to distinguish the idea of "being-in" from the concept of "insideness". I have chosen the state of madness as a ground for exploring a mental oscillation between counterparts within a mirrored space, created by alienating the consciousness from the self, thereby individualizing the reflection from the reflected. I attempt to trace and illustrate the topography of this mental state from history surrounding the ship of fools, existential theories, Literature, and my personal experience through the creation and curation of an exhibition.Ship of foolsTeleportationMirrorsHauser, Grace Michael. A Feast for the Eyes: Pictorial Conspicuous Consumption in the Cornucopia of Food, Flora, and Fauna of 17th-century Dutch Still Life2015-000633982015AD-MC-0042015-0006
Scope and Contents
During the 17th century, the artistic genre of Dutch still life can be divided into two distinct trends. The first half of the 17th century is characterized by a monochromatic trend, using restrained colors and subject matter due to an economic slump and Calvinist ideology. During second half of the 17th century, due to trade and Dutch colonialism, rare goods and luxurious commodities pour into the Netherlands, and become objects of admiration and become subject of the pronkstillleven genre (show-off still life). With this surplus of wealth, a consumerist attitude is born instilling an urge to conspicuously display one's wealth. I analyze the contrast between the two trends and discuss how and why this change took place. Through the analysis of four works of still life comparisons and contrasts will be drawn that mark these opposing artistic trends.Still-life painting |y 17th centuryStill-life painting, DutchThe NetherlandsArt -- HistoryConsumption (Economics)Seventeenth centuryKarpova, Olga. ДОМА | DOMA2015-001833752015AD-MC-0042015-0018
Scope and Contents
Home. This words means many things to people around the world. A bed at parent's house, a particular street, or neighbourhood, or even a smell can be associated with home. The project Home Feeling investigates what happens with the meaning of home in cosmopolitan settings. The writing describes the stages of the project starting from the origins and inspirations to the process, challenges that were faced during different stages.
It is explained how through painting, sculpture and installation the artist expressed the feeling of home, which, in a globalised world, turned into a mixture of connectivity to places, people and memories.
The paper is concluded by the explanation of how the project turned out to be about identification, home, and feelings. It is discussed how the difficulties and challenges helped to develop the project, and which conclusions were made from a year long process of its realisation.Viewers (observers)ArtsInstallations (Art)PaintingsKurkova, Anna. Psychogeographica2015-001033932015AD-MC-0042015-0010
Scope and Contents
This paper goes through a chronological documentation of my capstone project, Psychogeographica. This is a yearlong research project that delves into my personal experience of Abu Dhabi, and particularly how this experience involved me feeling alienated by the space of the city, but not knowing exactly why this reaction had occurred. I recognize that this was because I felt no semblance of time passing – there was no evidence of decomposition or aging within the buildings, streets, sense of place and consequently within myself as I existed within the city. As such, the paper follows the process that led to my collecting found objects and sourced objects in order to create artworks that attempt to reveal the existence of time in Abu Dhabi. The reader is implicated in the mental processes that I faced whilst involved in this yearlong endeavor. There is also an assumption that the reader has encountered the work either in person or through images (which will accompany the archive).United Arab EmiratesAbu Dhabi, United Arab EmiratesFound objects (Art)SculpturePsychogeographySmits, Cleo. PROBE: an investigation of contemporary institutional critique2015-000433922015AD-MC-0042015-0004
Scope and Contents
"Institutional critique" is a term used to describe art that is reflective about its positions in institutions and systems within the art world. Institutional critique typically takes the practices that allow art to be exhibited, circulated, exchanged, and sold as the subject of the artwork. This kind of artwork encourages the viewer to reflect on the idea of "the institution" by addressing it both directly and indirectly. This exhibition explores three contemporary examples of artists engaging in institutional critique and considers their artwork in relationship to one another, in an historical framework. The exhibition investigates the methods used by artists to identify and address different institutions. This exhibition is a curatorial Capstone project. As a student project, it lies outside the typical framework of "the art institution." Still, the university can be understood as a cultural institution. Thus this project is, ultimately, an experiment in curating institutional critique from within an institution.Institutional Critique (Art movement)Art -- HistoryContemporary artCuratingExhibitionsKuroda, Mariko.Ramadan Recipes: Ten Ideas For Iftar Meals 2016-001279632016AD-MC-0042016-0012
Scope and Contents
A 68-page full color book featuring illustrations and photographs, Ramadan Recipes proposes ten iftar recipes to break the fast for each day of Ramadan. Every recipe in the book was passed on to the author through interviews with Muslim families living in the UAE. Using Ramadan as a unifying element, the book weaves together stories for each dish, including not only its history but also memories associated with the meal as shared by the Muslim families. Ramadan Recipes celebrates the cultural diversity of Abu Dhabi and explores the heart of the Islamic faith. Most importantly, the book seeks to teach readers about the value of food and community, and encourages them to cook and gather around the dining table with their friends and families. Through recipes and stories, Ramadan Recipes presents food as a giver of life, a gem of family tradition, and a place of gathering.Arni, Sophie. Rethinking the East/West Binary: Transcultural Porcelain, 16th-21st Century2017-00072017AD-MC-0042017-0007
Scope and Contents
How does the binary of East and West affect the history, analysis and display of transcultural works of art? More particularly, how does the binary affect the analysis of porcelain, a medium that emerged from trade exchange and has been widely appropriated to suit various cultural tastes? Through three case studies transcultural dialogues embedded in porcelain, I reveal the shortcomings of polarizing eastern and western influences and provide alternative theoretical frameworks for studying cross-cultural exchange. The first exchange, a Jingdezhen bottle gilded in London in 1585, will be defined through its framing abilities. The second, a Sèvres chinoiserie basin from c.1790, will be understood through its mimetic faculty. The third, a Jingdezhen vase commissioned by Lebanese artist Raed Yassin in 2012, will be analyzed through its simulation processes. I argue that the East/West binary is the product of, rather than the process of, transcultural exchanges in global art practices.Filova, Evgenija. points of potential2018-00222018AD-MC-0042018-0022

points of potential is an installation work exploring the state of simultaneously knowing and being unable to know in the context of denied spaces. Reinforcing how queer spaces subvert hegemony, the installation captures the processes of unbeing and the unbecoming. Wings of Resistance2018-00342018AD-MC-0042018-0034
Scope and Contents
Wings of Resistance is an Escape the Room-inspired installation piece. It consists on two parallel escape rooms, meant to be experienced by two teams of 3-4 people each. The teams are led blindfolded to the rooms, where they must find clues and solve puzzles in order to find their reward and successfully complete the game. Although each team is in their own room and may believe they are the only ones taking part on the experience, eventually they unlock a video feed to connects them to the parallel room and the second team. Wings of Resistance is not only a test of wit, bit also of trust and cooperation. Some puzzles in the rooms require the exchange of information between teams, leading to the final reward. Before the final puzzle, the teams are presented a Prisoner's Dilemma-like scenario: finish the game alone at the cost of the other team, or trust them and cooperate. However, this is also a test, as betrayal leads to instant disqualification - the only way to succeed is through cooperation. Successful teams are awarded a pin for them to remember the experience.Wardi, Souhail. Modern Ghosts2018-00192018AD-MC-0042018-0019

The Portrayal of Vincent Van Gogh's Artwork Through Cinema2019-00392019AD-MC-0042019-0039
Scope and Contents
Van Gogh lives, just like Elvis. He lives both in popular culture and high art. The number of films and television series featuring Vincent van Gogh (1853¬–1890) as a character has long since exceeded one hundred. This thesis questions the difference of seeing reproductions of his paintings on screen rather than the originals in museums or reproductions in books or online. The narrative and accessibility of film medium allows a wider audience to see his paintings in places where his paintings have not been previously exhibited. While translating painted images to the filmic medium cannot reproduce the experience of seeing the originals, van Gogh continues to entice filmmakers from different generations to render different stories about van Gogh and his art on screen. By examining the first major Hollywood film on the artist, Lust for Life (1956), and later Vincent and Theo (1990), and the first fully painted animated film Loving Vincent (2017), I argue how over time technological differences allowed filmmakers to shed new light on the van Gogh myth and his artwork by using film as a means for reaching different audiences.You, Lauren. Shik-gu: The People Who Eat Together2019-00322019AD-MC-0042019-0032
Scope and Contents
Shik-gu: The People Who Eat Together is a socially engaged art project and a platform for people of NYU Abu Dhabi to connect and provide company for one another through sharing a meal online. In two months, eight different students broadcasted their dinner live as @eating_at_nyuad on Instagram.With menus ranging from ramen to KFC to half a gigantic watermelon, these students talked about long distance, insecurities, well-being, and body image in the company of their friends and family who followed the account and joined the livestream. This artwork responds to our community's concerns and offers a platform for conversations, at once intimate and public, that otherwise might remain unexpressed.It explores the vulnerability of putting ourselves online in a meaningful way, of mitigating the loneliness that is amplified by eating on one's own. It connects us to others also participating in the livestream and brings us together as a temporary "family."Al Nuaimi, Hessa. The Cultural Foundation in Abu Dhabi, 1981-20082020-00082020AD-MC-0042020-0008
Scope and Contents
If you were to ask any person who grew up in Abu Dhabi in the 1980s or 1990s, how they spent their free time, they most probably will mention their trips to the Cultural Foundation (CF). While there were other cultural centers in the United Arab Emirates (UAE), none compared to the CF. Located in the heart of the city, it attracted people from all over Abu Dhabi and other Emirates because of its reputation as a nexus for writers and artists. The CF played a significant role in the development of Abu Dhabi's art and culture ecosystem. Most importantly, it had sustained engagement with its surrounding community and activated a space for all to be a part of. To this day, many have described the CF as their second home where they attended lectures, workshops, poetry nights, and movie screenings.This paper examines the CF's first active period 1981-2008 and its relationship with the Abu Dhabi's community. The three main questions addressed in this paper are: Why was the CF so popular amongst the community? How was that achieved and what can be learned from that experience?Ali Al Fardan, Fatema. The Past is Present: The Collection and Exhibition of Modern and Contemporary Egyptian Art at the British Museum2020-00072020AD-MC-0042020-0007
Scope and Contents
The world's interest in modern and contemporary art from WANA (West Asia and North Africa) regions is increasing: the art market is growing, and many major museums—including the British Museum and the Met, as well as the Victoria and Albert Museum and Tate Modern—have recently hired curators who specialize in modern and contemporary works from the WANA regions. My capstone project analyzes the changing perception and reception of modern and contemporary art from the WANA region over the last thirty years, with a focus on the collecting and display of these works in the British Museum. My research investigates the British Museum's collection strategies and exhibition patterns for modern and contemporary art from the WANA regions, with a special emphasis on works created in Egypt. This paper will trace this recent history and provide a broader historical context for this shift in the curation, collection and exhibition of modern and contemporary Egyptian art at the British Museum.Rouhani, Salman. Scope and Contents
For my undergraduate thesis, I am creating a card deck that sources from Sri Lankan visual imagery as a way of reclaiming colonial erasure. Though there are many facets of colonialism, I am focusing on how day to day objects define our post-colonial existence. For example, Sri Lankans often wear jeans and T-shirts, even though our sarongs and kurtas are more appropriate for tropical weather. We design our billboards and store signs in English, despite Sinhala and Tamil being more common languages. It is this ubiquitous occurrence, the things that we do not think twice about, that define our colonial legacy. Card decks and card games are other aspects of this ubiquity. The standard card deck references French royalty, textiles, and patterns, and though we play card games frequently in our culture, we are using a seemingly irrelevant set of cards. When we look at them, they do not reference our own rich, complex, and diverse history. I aim to change that.Afaneh, Aya. Astral2021-00092021AD-MC-0042021-0009
Scope and Contents
'astral' conveys the relationship between artist flow and the spiritual and creative process. Artist flow is not ignoring the realities of the world, but rather, the ability to use one's being and experiences to enter a meditative space. Subsequently, work is born from an unexplored place within the self. 'astral' consists of a series of prints, paintings, ceramics and other three-dimensional work that embody the discovery of new universes within one's artistic and spiritual self. Personally, creating art is a spiritual experience which is influenced by an interest in witchcraft. The series of work also explores what it means to navigate the world in the female body, and both the pleasure and pain it endures — self-inflicted or otherwise. The creative process leads to psychedelic effects in the works, which can only be described as a result of artist flow. 'astral' is, as such, inspired by the intrinsic, ethereal connection each of us has to the universe; art is simply a means to understand it.

This Website Dies2021-00062021AD-MC-0042021-0006
Scope and Contents
As the usage of the Internet becomes more invasive in every day life, people are increasingly building more Internet personas for themselves, building more lives, leading double, triple lives on various social networks. The accumulation of all that personal information, behavior, emotions, data, and visual imagery flocks and fill up spaces in servers everywhere. Yet since these data embodies people and rely on people to inhabit, maintain, and add to them, it was fascinating for me to explore the scenario when immense amounts of data is left uncared-for, will they continue to exist or disappear? will they live in some other form? will they ever get erased from data servers at all? And there is also the other side of the equation too: the scenario when people intentionally cut themselves off from this information architectures/personas/ that they have spent time and effort building. In short, my capstone project focuses on the mortality and immortality of digital data, in relation to human life.
Website: https://vananhbui.com/thiswebsitedies Cappelletto, Niccolo Acram. Time is Out of Joint at La Galleria Nazionale: From the Historical to the Ahistorical Display2021-00052021AD-MC-0042021-0005
Scope and Contents
After renovation works, La Galleria Nazionale in Rome marked its reopening in 2016 by rearranging the permanent collection in the exhibition Time is Out of Joint. Under the guidance of the new director, Cristiana Collu, the new display shuffles the artworks from different time periods drawn from the museum collection of art from the 19th to 21st century. The rehang questions previous displays based on linear art history and proposes an experiential encounter with the collection. Since the early 2000s, similar innovative curatorial strategies have been adopted by museums in Europe and elsewhere to address the role of institutions in society with consideration to visitor engagement. By using Time is Out of Joint as a case study, this paper aims to review the original vision of the "national museum" in Italy through the examination of the institutional history in relation to the new display of the permanent collection at the Galleria Nazionale. The analysis of the curatorial approach of Time is Out of Joint contributes to the wider discussion about the relationship between museums, displays, and history. At the same time, the paper will explore how the rehang engages with a new idea of the contemporary art museum.Cho, Mingu. The Capstone research and project, entitled Spaces in Hyphen: Of Present-Absence and Absent-Presence, is a series of photographs that documents spaces around the NYU Abu Dhabi campus. With hints of human labor and activities featured in the compositions, the photographs communicate a human presence, without having people appearing in the frame. In particular, the man-made environment of Saadiyat Island is explored, highlighting the thresholds or ambiguities that delineate the natural versus artificial elements of a space. The documentation of these juxtapositions often appears ironic and incongruous to suggest the complexities of such heavy-handed interventions.Choi, Lucy. My capstone examines the case of the female monster through a series of paintings. The monstress is often depicted as transgressing from the narrow bounds of an idealized femininity, displaying a power that is threatening. They are commonly antagonists of the stories in which they feature and thus, serve as a warning, policing women who stray outside acceptable limits of female power, sexuality, or control. Despite this, there is a complexity in the space that the female monster occupies that is compelling. As monsters, women can have complicated emotions and rich internal lives. By centering a narrative on the female monster, I want to create space for deviations and nuance in models of femininity.Vu, Hoang Anh Thu. The Currency of Chanoyu (茶の湯): Theorizing the Performative Aspects of the Japanese Tea Ceremony 2021-00102021AD-MC-0042021-0010
Scope and Contents
Chanoyu (茶の湯) is the highly aesthetic and ritualized practice of preparing powdered green tea, or matcha, in the Japanese tradition. This paper examines the aesthetic, philosophical, political and socio-economic aspects of the tea tradition from its origins to contemporary expressions. Under the influence of Shintō beliefs, Zen Buddhism, Daoist philosophy and Japanese aesthetics, the drinking of tea developed into "The Way of Tea" replete with disciplined rituals, a code of ethics, an aura of spirituality, requisite implements and sophisticated aesthetics. The tradition of chanoyu was fluid over time, shifting from the exclusive circles of the nobility, clergy and warrior elite to the interested populus. The merchants through tea trade were conduits for the dissemination of tea culture. This commercial component accounts for the spread of the tea cult from Japan across the world. This analysis explores how the Japanese tea ceremony or chanoyu tradition remained distinctive and coherent while flexible and responsive to change throughout its dynamic evolution. For this reason, I argue, "The Way of Tea" is a significant source of inspiration and creativity for contemporary artists and designers globally.Film & New MediaAlsaied, Amani. Abstract: Typing…SYRIA is a socio-artistic performance piece where any subscriber can witness a conversation between two Syrian characters unfold on WhatsApp for 30 days. Drawing from the vocabulary of a collage of news articles on Syrian refugees, the advertisement of this project echoes the international community attitudes towards refugees. In experimenting with appeals of exclusivity, intimacy, and hints of tragedy, Typing…SYRIA addresses questions of voyeurism, the ethics of witnessing, and the role of the international media's "gaze" towards the Syrian experience in light of the civil conflict. The performance also invokes prolonged exposure as well as social engagement, as subscribers document their emotional experience throughout the month by contributing screenshots of impactful moments of the conversation, alongside a short written commentary. At the end of the month, subscribers will be left with not only their own archive of the Syrian voices, but will also have access to the archive of other participants' experiences, comments, and reflections.WhatsAppRefugeesPerforming ArtsSyriaDigital mediaNagy, Kristian. The Separation Defense Paper2016-000979752016The Separation is a short narrative film that complicates incorrect perceptions and representations – of gender, clothing, family, and ways of life – of Arabs and the Arab World in Western media by depicting their impacts and consequences. It is a story about a young Arab boy on his first day in a Western school, and his experience of being treated negatively by his new classmates. The narrative is an exploration of identity – particularly, children's – and how it is shaped by attitudes and mentalities about race, religion, and culture influenced largely by Western media. The Separation aims to raise, rather than answer, these questions: What are assumptions about Arabs and the Arab World that are so familiar to children that they might not register as prejudice? When these assumptions influence and impact children and their behavior, what does this say about society? And, how can we then reverse these damaging effects?AD-MC-0042016-0009

Unlearner Defense Paper2016-000779762016Inspired by true events, namely the 1972 exodus of Asian Ugandans ordered by Idi Amin, Unlearner attempts to comprehend the extent to which forced migration can damage families and individuals. The film identifies past and present conflicts of coexistence between ethnic Ugandans and Asian Ugandans. Although during the reign of Idi Amin, there was a major political exploitation of Indophobia, Unlearner unfolds socio-economic pressures that manifest contemporarily within the Ugandan society. Unlearner explores a young Ugandan man's existence when he is removed from this specific context. Arthur Makoli, moves to work in the UAE as a security guard. Arthur's journey allows him to meet his newly discovered half-sister who fled Uganda with her Indian mother during the exile. Despite trying to build an emotional attachment with Huda, he feels threatened by her and he truly believes that she would reject him as a brother. Throughout his time in Abu Dhabi, Arthur personifies a clash between the two groups.AD-MC-0042016-0007

Longing for Ukraine: Oleksandr Dovzhenko's World War II documentary cinema2018-00182018This Capstone investigates why Oleksandr Dovzhenko's love of his people was considered nationalism by the Soviet regime. Looking at The Battle for Our Soviet Ukraine (1943) and Victory on the Right Bank Ukraine (1944), I examine limitations to articulating Ukrainian national identity under Soviet rule and documentary film's ability to convey contested political histories. I ask whether it is possible to understand Dovzhenko as a Soviet director or also as a Ukrainian one, and to what extent this question remains political in the contemporary context of Russian imperialism. Due to censorship, Dovzhenko's expression of Ukrainian identity in these documentaries emphasizes Ukraine as distinct from other nations within the USSR, particularly Russia, in indirect ways that differ from strategies used by Ukrainian nationalist movements. My research builds on emerging scholarship on Ukrainian cinema that seeks to understand artistic practices suppressed by the Soviet regime and omitted by generations of scholars.AD-MC-0042018-0018
Scope and Contents

Restrained by Freedom: Perestroika Cinema as an Overlooked Transition from Soviet to Russian Filmmaking2018-00252018This paper analyzes how political changes and artistic freedom during the Perestroika ("restructuring") period of 1985–1991 reflect a crucial transitional moment between Soviet and Russian cinema often dismissed as unimportant, especially genre of chernukha, due to its low production values and sensational stories. The freedom from censorship that came with Perestroika often resulted in permissiveness in content that became destructive of State ideology and film industry, rather than constructive. At the same time, relaxed censorship allowed films that were never widely released, such as Andrei Tarkovsky's The Mirror / Зеркало (1974), to be screened in cinemas for the first time. By analyzing the style, main plot conflicts and character types in Perestroika films, I elucidate an overlooked moment of transition from Soviet to Russian society and cinema that was popular with audiences but considered failure by critics.AD-MC-0042018-0025
Scope and Contents

The Phantoms of Projection // Afterlife: an audiovisual performance2018-00312018A joint Capstone in Film & New Media and Theater, this project combines research and audiovisual performance to investigate ways that light and projected images have been tied with representations of life after death. Popular during the 18-19th century, magic lantern phantasmagoria shows were spine chilling theatrical experiences that utilized the pre-cinematic technology of the magic lantern, an early slide projector, to create the illusion that there were ghosts in the room. The technologies and performances anticipate video jockeying, a form of live performance that emerged in 1980s club culture, that uses video to heighten club atmosphere. Based on this research, Afterlife utilizes video jockeying to reimagine a phantasmagoria show and investigate the concept of afterlife as a state of intermediacy. Remixing and improvisation become central to exploring notions of time and light as disembodiment by using the techniques of VJing to play, alter and remix projected visual content in real-time.AD-MC-0042018-0031
Scope and Contents

Put on the Virtual Reality goggles and get ready to experience the identity of a delivery truck loader. You are standing in front of a conveyor belt and the only thing you can rely on while the packages keep coming and coming is your judgement. Or is it your biases? If you got through the challenge of keeping your job, you can compete to earn a high score. Pressed by time, your boss, and political correctness you will need to face decades of biases that are ingrained in your subconscious from misrepresentation in the media, your country and your upbringing. In the end you will not only figure out which parcel is shipped to which country but you will also interact with your unconscious biases. The film shows how religion is something that is shaped by each individual in a personal manner, according to their own beliefs and values. I want to show that following a religion word by word will not make you a better person if you do not feel good with yourself. I want to demonstrate that it is possible to discover that there can be a personal way to follow a religion, without being constrained and scared by the rules imposed by religious "authorities", or any other sort of rule. A day before his first confession, Enzo fears the worst after stealing a motorcycle emblem. This narrative film is derived from real stories of interviewed women who have been victims of arranged marriages in their childhood. It is dedicated to all the young girls who are subjected to the backward practices that define our lives. In conservative, sexist, and patriarchal societies in the Middle East, many girls are betrothed after menstruation when they are considered 'ready' to fulfill their purpose in life. The narrative follows a mother's strife by both perpetuating and fighting the patriarchal society in which she is trapped. As a result, this film aims to show hardships women face in a patriarchal society without villainizing anyone, by demonstrating the struggle the mother goes through when deciding to either succumb to or break out of said society.

Women's Oppression, Feminism, Patriarchy, Arabic, Singular DramaPekuse, Liene. How We Leave2020-00122020AD-MC-0042020-0012
Scope and Contents
The feeling of getting older is familiar to everyone, but still each of us live through it in our own unique way - depending on the experiences we have had and what we have done with them. Identity is fleeting and nothing throughout our lives stays the same. That might be the only consistent thing in it. How We Leave is a short narrative film that shows a day in two girls' lives, in which they have to learn how to grow up. The story examines the way children deal with trauma and perceive adults, what it does to their friendship. Fear follows them no matter how far away from everyone they go, because the biggest monsters truly are hidden within ourselves. Growing up doesn't mean that fear goes away, it means that the person learns how to keep moving forward while being afraid. And it looks like it is much easier to do so if there is a friend on your side.
Short-Film, Children, Aging DesertPeterson, Hunter. |2020-00142020AD-MC-0042020-0014
Scope and Contents
My piece titled "|" is an artistic endeavor exploring the concept of existence through a memoiristic abstraction of reality and realities. Through a series of films in an online format, my piece explores themes of sexuality, love, family, religion, and death as the film follows an unnamed woman who killed herself at a young age. Her older self, however, continues to experience various realities of what her life could have been. The viewer is put into control as to how they experience this narrative as they interact with an online exhibition. This exhibition, through showcasing vignettes of the main character's life, explores a universal yet individualistic existential questioning of the purpose of one's life. The space in which the character exists in the four rooms emulates the concept of a void, showcasing what could have been, while forcing the audience member to come to terms with their own reality of how their interaction with the narrative actually is.
http://whatcouldhavebeen.net/

Scope and Contents
Show Me AD is a short video guide hosted by senior NYUAD student, Emma. She enlists the help of a few of her friends to show her around Abu Dhabi. The catch: they have a student budget! The resulting videos will be posted on the NYUAD official youtube channel, targeted towards the incoming NYUAD students. It was inspired by Emma's own experience moving to Abu Dhabi, and feeling overwhelmed by the city and the different logistics and possibilities that revolved around finding things to do. This series is designed to help the students who may also arrive feeling out of depth, to give them a head start regarding places to go, things to see, and how to get there.
NYUAD, Film, Abu DhabiAkinyi, Ivy. Sister2021-00132021AD-MC-0042021-0013
Scope and Contents
Sister is an episodic fictional narrative that recognizes the effects of UAE's working spaces on an African migrant's every day experience. It looks at the dynamic between two African women working at a boutique hotel in Abu Dhabi, and how the space subtly affects their psychological experience. The research process for the film was set off by an article published by Khaleej Times in 2019 detailing the court case of a young Kenyan female who was raped by an Emirati student and allegedly taken to the scene by a male Cameroonian friend. The film's narrative is shaped by interviews conducted with African female migrants in Abu Dhabi along with a written interview with Prof. Yaw Nyarko of NYUAD, whose work focuses on the economic effects of UAE's labor system(s). Other applied sources include testimonials drawn from online articles, book chapters and YouTube videos. Most of these contents reflected the invisibility or otherwise, the victimhood of the African female perspective in migrant narratives seen in both the media and the spaces they occupy within the Gulf.

Website: https://sites.google.com/nyu.edu/akinyi-capstonesite/homeGala, Sakshi and Yagmur Unal. Breakout Rooms 2021-00152021AD-MC-0042021-0015
Scope and Contents
This defense paper examines how the short film Breakout Rooms is a project that revolves around abruptions created in the online and offline spaces that we occupy, especially in light of a pandemic that has forced the entire world to grapple with the implications of a newfound, 'virtual' reality that is both real and a counterfeit. It operates on two levels that speak to each other to create the overarching narrative of the film— the first level is the 'online' context of Zoom, where the characters interact on rectangular screens and attempt to build a fleeting relationship. The second level is the 'offline' context of the UAE, a country where migrants make up the majority of the population and are often temporary inhabitants in the region. This paper addresses the various narrative and cinematic strategies used to highlight that both a Zoom breakout room and the migrant experience in the Gulf are temporary.
Author provided keywords: Gulf, Migration, Pandemic, DisconnectionHagedorn, Sienna. A City Gone to Sleep2021-00162021AD-MC-0042021-0016
Scope and Contents
A City Gone to Sleep is a documentary detailing the impact of Covid-19 on the restaurant industry in New York City. At its core, the film is a commentary on the crucial role of restaurants in the social, historical, and economic architecture of the city. The restaurant industry employs over 300,000 New Yorkers in over 24,000 locations, many of which have been around for decades. It is a primary employer of immigrants, many of whom have also set up their own establishments. Whether you have been to New York or not, many of us have an image of what New York is supposed to be. Restaurants give character to the streets of New York and serve as reminders of the city's rich diversity. The pandemic has forced us to reflect on what the loss of these spaces will mean for New York City for years to come.
Author provided keywords: The restaurant industry, Covid-19, NYCHajee, Kaashif. Gair (outsider)2021-00182021AD-MC-0042021-0018
Scope and Contents
Eager to fit in with his high school friends in Abu Dhabi, Armaan distances himself from his parents and his Indian identity. Ali, a taxi driver, yearns for his family in Pakistan as he struggles to make ends meet and provide for his daughter's education. One day, when Armaan plans to go partying with his friends, their divergent lives serendipitously intersect, unravelling questions of identity, position and privilege in Abu Dhabi. Through Armaan and Ali, who represent two sides of the South Asian migrant experience in the UAE, the film explores the themes of identity, belonging, and masculinity. I spent three months writing the script, two months on pre-production, and three days on production in fall 2020. In spring 2021, I worked extensively on post-production, tightening the film and working on sound design. What started as an 18-page script eventually became a 10-minute film.

Website: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=spQhbzGWd4sIkeda, Vitoria. POSERS2021-00122021AD-MC-0042021-0012
Scope and Contents
POSER takes place in Abu Dhabi, an environment where its expatriate population outrageously outnumbers its national population. It's a city where many young people develop a third culture kid identity – those who grow up for a majority of their youth in countries outside those of their nationality. Specifically, the film is set in a skatepark, where many teenagers living in Abu Dhabi come to meet and socialize. However, often the reality of being a third culture kid is the fluctuating nature of friendship, as expats continue to leave for various reasons. This begs the question: how does this uncertainty of their next years affect their behavior and personality? What does it mean to develop strong relationships with the temporary people around you? How do TCK's react to goodbyes? How did the Covid-19 pandemic further affect these temporary people? POSER attempts to capture the bittersweetness of goodbyes by following two young TCK's, who have unspoken feelings for each other, as they spend one last morning together. Through the use of a rapidly developing yet relaxed skate culture in Abu Dhabi, POSER explores the meaning of home and youth.
