Bubbles of Happiness tells a story of a bond between two unlikely people that share a mutual appreciation for karak. Coming from different socioeconomic backgrounds, the film explores social expectations, cultural traditions, and belonging that ultimately determines the fate of the friendship.
Author provided keywords: Film; karak; Abu Dhabi; cafeteria; culture; social classKochar, Nandini. Umalis Si Maama (Migrant Mother)2021-00192021AD-MC-0042021-0019
Scope and Contents
Umalis Si Maama (Migrant Mother) is a semi-ethnographic documentary which follows three domestic workers on their day-off in Abu Dhabi. Documented over four months, the film attempts to capture the dualities of love and separation, community and longing, leisure and labour, which permeate the lives of migrant mothers. Grounded in a practice of self-reflexivity and ethical inquiry, this film intends to raise questions about gaze, positionality and power. Who gets to tell whose story? What does nuanced and ethical representation look like? How do we begin to disrupt the ethnographic gaze? By combining observational footage and informal interviews with Whatsapp photo archives and amateur video-making, this project aims to expand and experiment with the documentary form, and open space for agency and self-expression.
Author provided keywords: ethnographic; documentary; domestic work; female migration; work; womenLuque, Rodrigo. The Nine Circles2021-00172021AD-MC-0042021-0017
Scope and Contents
In the enticing thought experiment of "The Floating Man" (On the Soul: The Floating Man, 1037), philosopher Ibn Sina wondered what a mind would experience if it was suddenly born disconnected from all physicality and devoid of all senses. The goal of The Nine Circles is to explore this concept through an audiovisual approach. For most of history people have believed that a spiritual or mental part of us remains after physical death. Thus, the most direct way for us to explore the "floating" mind is to imagine what the post-death experience could be. My film opens with the death of the protagonist, and what follows is an exploration of that mind, unlinked from physical reality. First the mind feels lost in the dark, but then it slowly learns how to imagine and navigate in a new world of its own. This experience ultimately becomes akin to our own 'living' reality. I hope the journey of this floating mind can open new ways of imagining this inevitable destiny of ours which we refer to as 'death.'
Author provided keywords: Consciousness; Afterlife; Phosphene; Animation; Creation; ImaginationZhuang, Fay. Next to Normal2021-00112021AD-MC-0042021-0011
Scope and Contents
Three short scripts which are interconnected: The superstitious and reckless attempts of a desperate mother to meet her dead son again are doomed to fail. After realizing the impossibility of receiving unconditional love, a teenage boy decides to use his suicide as a protest to his parents. A young immigrant tries to build his identity, swaying between a family of oppressed elders and a homosexual lover he just met.
Author provided keywords: unconditional love, identityHistoryLloyd, James. "More Often Now He Suggests or Advises": The Changed Relationship Between Britain's Representatives and the Sheikhs of the Arabian Gulf, 1947-19712014-0018702014AD-MC-0042014-0018
Scope and Contents
Major: History
Abstract: Britain exerted power over the Persian Gulf between 1820 and 1971 through personal relationships between British representatives and the local Gulf rulers. From 1947, the tone of those relationships changed substantially, from authoritarian to more collaborative. Recent scholarship suggests that this change was due to a diversification of the educational backgrounds of the British representatives: prior to 1947, all of them had attended public schools, which imbued them with highly imperialistic attitudes. However, after 1947, their education was more diverse, and no longer propagated such an imperial ideology; thus, the British representatives were no longer as authoritarian.
This thesis offers a more nuanced version of this argument, by taking into account the prevailing attitudes towards Empire in Britain, as well as pressures on Britain's position in the Gulf from powers in the region. Ultimately, I argue, educational background merely contributed to the change in the relationship; more significant were regional pressures that forced the British representatives to effect policy that necessitated greater collaboration with the local rulers, and thus a change in the nature of the relationship.Arabian/Persian GulfBritish EmpireGreat BritainHistoryUnited Arab EmiratesManela, Caroline Victoria. Violence and Exchange: Middlemen of the Sixteenth- and Seventeenth Century Mediterranean2014-0012712014AD-MC-0042014-0012
Scope and Contents
Major: History
Abstract: Historians of the pre-modern Mediterranean have challenged the argument that the sixteenth- and seventeenth-century Mediterranean ceased to exist as a frontier of fruitful cross-religious contact between Christian Europeans and Muslim North Africans. This thesis supports that position by showing that amidst violence, specific types of middlemen, including corsairs, captives, slaves, and diplomats, continued to live in connection with both Christian Europe and Muslim North Africa. I argue for an understanding of religious violence that accepts its tragic and harmful consequences while acknowledging it as an avenue through which cross-cultural and religious knowledge was facilitated. Within this framework, I explore the physical violence of piracy and captivity as well as the concept of structural violence in connection with the career of the Jewish merchant and diplomat Samuel Pallache. Finally, I turn to consider an anti-Christian polemical work that has received limited scholarly attention: Ahmad ibn Qasim al-Hajari's Kitab nasir al din 'ala 'l-qawm al-kafirin (The Supporter of Religion Against the Infidel). The violent language in Kitab nasir al-din was the only way in which al-Hajari could convey stories of his respect and admiration for Christians to his Muslim North African audience.ViolenceMediterranean SeaReligionTattersall, Jessica Joan. The Doctor as Biographer: The Politics of Intimacy in Historical Biographies of Winston Churchill and Mao Zedong2014-0019722014AD-MC-0042014-0019
Scope and Contents
Major: History
Major: This thesis compares the politics of intimacy in two biographies written by doctors: Churchill: The Struggle for Survival 1940-1965 (1966) by Charles Wilson (known by his honourary title of Lord Moran), and The Private Life of Chairman Mao (1994) by Li Zhisui. Both Moran and Li spent over twenty years serving as the personal physicians of Winston Churchill and Mao Zedong respectively, forming extremely close relationships in the process.
All biography written by personal associates raises the question of how such relationships affect not only the content of the work, but also its reception. However, research regarding this question is surprisingly thin, and in turn the question remains largely unanswered. This thesis, by comparing biographical traditions in both England and China, and by examining biographies of Winston Churchill and Mao Zedong, offers specific answers to this question. I argue that a comparative analysis, mindful of the distinctive features of Chinese and English biographical traditions, reveals that the politics of intimacy in historical biography is greatly shaped not only by historical context, but also by present day values.BiographiesChinaEngland, UKHistoriographyEvans, Laura May. Internalising Identities: Internment Camps in Australia in World War II as a Tool of Nation Building2015-00433882015AD-MC-0042015-0014
Scope and Contents
Major: History
Abstract: The internment of foreign nationals in Australia during World War II is one example of exclusionary practices used in Australian history to define in and out groups in Australian society. This example often disappears from dominant narratives of Australian military and social history, or internees' experiences are written about in isolated categories of nationalities. This study examines internees' own stories from the Tatura and Loveday internment camps in conjunction with official histories and different trends in writing Australian history. In addition, this study looks at ways internees were forced to confront their own identities through internment and how on exit from the camps, internees were pressured to adopt attitudes in line with Anglo-Australia and internalised their internment experience. Finally, this study shows that recent trends in Australian history have focused on finding space for non-white others and that internment camps need to be incorporated in these histories to understand the forces that have constructed white Australian identities and subsequent politics.International migrationMigrationHistoriographyRaceWorld War IIInternment campsAustraliaIdentityDinan, Cian. Dying Among the Geraniums: Madness in the Congo Free State.2016-000379712016At the turn of the 20th century, violent conditions in the Congo Free State colony of Belgian King Leopold II sparked international outcry. Reformist literature surrounding the London-based Congo Reform Association (CRA) criticized the King and his colony by inverting imperial discourse, identifying Leopold's State with excess, savagery, and madness. Through this mode of critique, CRA writers perpetuated an imperialist ideology based on a masculine ideal of the colonizer. In reworking these accusations of madness, modern literary and historical adaptations of the history of the State and the CRA repeat an ultimately unproductive discourse of violence, rooted in ideals of imperial masculinity. This paper examines the gendered nature of this discourse, and attempts to move away from hegemonic representations of violence through historical-literary analysis of three distinct moments. The paper tracks the trope of madness through the interweaving stories of the CRA, the trial and execution of British consul Roger Casement, and Jean Boenga's account of the suicide of a colonial officer's suicide, and reads these moments for alternative representations of violence.AD-MC-0042016-0003

Crossing Mountains: Tea Trade and State Building in the Sino-Tibetan Borderlands.2017-00082017For over a thousand years, Tibetans relied on China for the supply of a dietary necessity – tea. As both a revenue-making and a state-building tool for the Chinese state, tea trade continued to connect Tibet and China across formidable mountains even as state power failed to do so during the Republican period (1912-1949). This capstone examines the relationship between tea trade and state building in the Sino-Tibetan borderlands as China struggled to create a modern nation from the ruins of an empire. Drawing on both archival and published sources, the author uncovers the divergent paths taken by two Chinese provinces – Sichuan and Yunnan – as they continued to supply tea to Tibet amidst ongoing border conflicts after the Qing Empire collapsed in 1911. Imperial legacies of taxation, complex frontier politics, and the successful integration of the Sino-Southeast Asian trade networks into the Sino-Tibetan tea trade all contributed to this divergence.AD-MC-0042017-0008

Conesting Aboriginality in mid-20th Century Sydney.2017-00022017This capstone charts the development of the concept of Aboriginality in Sydney, Australia during the 1950s and 1960s. As the federal government and the states adopted policies designed to assimilate the Aboriginal population, official publications promoting this administrative strategy, as well as internal classification schemes used by the state of New South Wales, produced contradictory understandings of Aboriginality. Grass-roots activists associated with the Aboriginal-Australian Fellowship sought to create a distinct Aboriginal identity that could be integrated within a multi-ethnic Australian nation. Their compromise position would be challenged as Aboriginal people began to demand land rights, challenging the sovereignty of the Australian state. Debates over the place of Aboriginality in Australian society were played out at the local level as Aboriginal activists sought to claim a space within the city of Sydney, against opposition from other residents and government agencies. Exploring Aboriginality in an urban context in this period reveals how local governments, community organisations and Aboriginal leaders laid claim to their own understandings of Aboriginality. In shaping this contested concept as these varied historical agents responded both to local social and economic conditions and to broader international movements for racial justice.AD-MC-0042017-0002

"A Hero Appears!": The Many Manifestations Of Musa Ibn Abi Ghassan In Orientalist Literature and Muslim Televangelist Programming2018-00012018This study traces the development of the story of Musa Ibn Abi Ghassan's, from early 19th century Washington Irving's romantic Conquest of Grenada to its "discovery" by mid 20th-century Arab academic historians. It examines how Muslim Televangelist programmes make parallels between Abi Ghassan's stories and the 21st-century Muslim predicament, focusing on the necessity of educating the Muslim youth in Abi Ghassan's story as an essential precursor to a religious and cultural renaissance. The programmes extract often contrasting lessons from Abi Ghassan's story, as a representation of loyalty to the state, a "genuine" Islamist movement leader, and/or as a lost example of cultivating a proper work ethic in Muslim and Arab youth.AD-MC-0042018-0001

The Birthplace of the UAE: The Legacy of the First Permanent Hospital in Abu Dhabi2018-00292018My capstone project explores the emergence and foundational period of the Oasis Hospital Al Ain, the first permanent hospital in Abu Dhabi. The project examines the political, social and cultural underpinnings that brought a Protestant missionary hospital to Al Ain. In doing so, it traces the history of Christian medical missionaries in the Trucial States/UAE, namely the Protestant Evangelicals of the Reformed Church in America (RCA) and is therefore part of the wider history of Christian missionaries in the Gulf. Utilizing missionary letters and oral history interviews, this project considers how the Al Ain Oasis Hospital has become a crucial part of UAE's history. Furthermore, this capstone also provides historical context for the current environment of religious tolerance and freedom that has been perpetuated by the UAE government today.AD-MC-0042018-0029

A Wok Through The Redefinition of Qingzhen (Halal) Dietary Practices Among Chinese-Muslims In Republican China2018-00042018Sometime in 1935, Yang Lisheng, a teacher in a Muslim Primary School in the town of Neixiang, located in China's Henan province, fielded the following question from one of his students: "Why don't you Muslims eat pork?" Yang's answer: "Pigs are filthy animals, and since we are very particular about hygiene and the nature of health, we don't eat it." In his 1936 treatise, "Why Muslims Do Not Eat Pork", Yang attempts to formulate a more comprehensive answer to that question; one that includes notions of hygiene and health. This provides us with a window into the questions and challenges teachers working in Islamic schools in China faced during the first half of the twentieth century, and to how they addressed those challenges by reframing their teachings to include social issues of the time.AD-MC-0042018-0004

A Center by Its Own: Multifaceted Life of a Native Mu Elite in Lijiang, 1499-15532018-00022018This capstone examines the perspectives of Mu Gong (1499-1553), a native elite in Lijiang, on his and his family's relationship with the neighboring powers, including the Ming Chinese state. Mu Gong was a patriarch of the Mu family, whose succeeding generations had held positions of authority in Lijiang since at least 1253. Lijiang, a historical border region that intersects China and Tibet, has remained a marginal space in conventional area studies and a geographical periphery with an ambiguous political status. Analyzing the written works from Mu Gong, this capstone argues that Mu Gong identified and facilitated different forms of relationship between himself and the neighboring powers in cultural, political, and military aspects; during this process, the Ming Chinese state played an important yet only partial role. For example, he was a committed follower of Chinese literary culture, an independent politician who valued his family's historical legacy in Chinese statecraft, and a powerful military leader who kept an intricate balance with neighboring forces, including China and Tibet, while expanding his own territory for economic gain.AD-MC-0042018-0002

Self-representation; Women; War; Environment; Insurgency; Autobiographies; Malaysia; SoutheastAsiaHoyt, Ian. Institutionalized Personalization: Carter's Ambassadors-at-Large for Middle East Peace2021-00202021AD-MC-0042021-0020
Scope and Contents
This project examines the special diplomatic office of Ambassador-at-Large as a window into the organization and institutional tensions of the US foreign relations ecosystem. As a case study, it analyzes the three Ambassadors-at-Large employed by President Carter (1977-1981) during the Israeli-Egyptian peace process. Situating this case within the broader history of the position, the shifting responsibilities of the Ambassador-at-Large exemplify long-standing tensions over Presidentialization, Personalization, and Professionalization in US foreign relations. Highlighting the contradictions of an institutionalized mechanism designed to circumvent its own institutions, the project presses for a reexamination of special diplomats as reflective of the structures that produce and employ them.
Author provided keywords: Institutions, Diplomacy, Foreign Policy, Egypt, Israel, Special EnvoyMcGarry, Zachary Christopher. Memory of Monarchs: The Shaping of 15th - 17th Century Christian Ethiopia through Dynastic Memory2021-00232021AD-MC-0042021-0023
Scope and Contents
This thesis examines the role of historical memory in the Christian Ethiopian Solomonic monarchy from roughly 1434 CE to 1632 CE. Using evidence from the Ethiopian Royal Chronicles, hagiographic literature, and European sources, this project claims that the actions, policies, and religiopolitical attitudes of the 17th century Christian Ethiopian king Susǝnyos were shaped by the dynastic memory of his 15th century ancestor Zä'ra Ya'ǝqob. This project explores the internal religious and political history of 15th to 17th century Christian Ethiopia from the height of the Ethiopian medieval period until the end of the Jesuit Period while touching upon the wider intersecting global histories which affected the Christian Kingdom and that Ethiopia affected in turn. By studying Christian Ethiopia through the lens of memory, this capstone reexamines the role of history making in general, and medieval Christian Ethiopia in particular, reflecting upon the impact of royal education on political and religious policies implemented by the emperors of medieval Christian Ethiopia.
Author provided keywords: Ethiopia; Africa; Memory; Monarchy; History; Christianity; Dynasty; Historiography; ReligionThomas, Thais. Tracing Black Power: Revolution and Memory in Trinidad and Tobago2021-00212021AD-MC-0042021-0021
Scope and Contents
In February of 1970, the Black Power Movement took over the streets of Trinidad and Tobago, taking inspiration from contemporaneous movements in the wider Caribbean, North America, the United Kingdom and beyond. This capstone argues that the Movement in Trinidad and Tobago was a transnational exercise in shared blackness which manifested in varied ways that were specific to the Trinbagonian experience. This capstone does not frame global Black Power as emanating from a North American core, but as a Movement in which underling connections created an environment of collective radical black action in the late 60s and 70s. It uses memory as a lens into the 1970s, and also as a connector to the complicated contemporary Trinbagonian experience with blackness, specifically in the Movement's 50th anniversary. Based upon the oral testimony of individuals who lived through the Movement, the project illuminates various transnational themes such as black consciousness, black ideology and black cultural practices. Parallel to these connections, it looks at the localised manifestations of Black Power in organisations, cultural artforms and in spirituality to demonstrate that Trinbagonian Black Power arose out of the particular historical experience of Black persons in the Caribbean.Vavrova, Tracy. Opposing the EU: Historical Legacies of Eurocriticism and Euroscepticism in France, 1950-19922021-00222021AD-MC-0042021-0022
Scope and Contents
The project chronicles the evolution of Eurocritical and Eurosceptic sentiment in France between 1950 and 1992 to determine whether Eurosceptic ideas in the country today appeared in public and political discourse prior to the Maastricht Treaty referendum in 1992. Scholarly consensus denotes the referendum as the first time in French history when Euroscepticism affected French political outcomes. Contrarily, this study demonstrates that French foreign and national policy has consistently displayed Eurocritical attitudes since 1950. Such sentiment has significantly affected political outcomes on a national and EU level, culminating in the rise of Eurosceptic political parties and policies long before 1992. The study synthesizes numerous newspaper articles, speeches, interviews and public opinion polls to reveal several frequently cited concerns regarding national sovereignty, the gradual loss of French influence over European affairs and complex relations with Germany and the United States. The project demonstrates that France's foreign policy interests have consistently been at odds with the European integration process. Exploring this tension reveals a historical legacy of French hesitation towards the EU; one firmly ingrained in political and public discourse and one playing a key role in French and European political outcomes.

Simulacra2020-00202020AD-MC-0042020-0020
Scope and Contents
How can we find comfort in a society dominated by spectacle? How can meaningful interactions help to create this comfort? These are the two overarching questions my Capstone project addresses. Informed by key ideas from Situationist International and Sherry Turkle, my Capstone seeks to react to these theorists' concepts by considering them in relation to our current situation with social media. Overall, composed of two experiences: a social media daring game and an interactive installation, my Capstone invites people to reconsider their relationship with social media and their use of it as well. As subjects to the attention economy that drives and monetizes social media, it is imperative for social media users to be aware of its implications and to have some critical understanding of the dynamics at play. In light of this, the two components of my Capstone project strive to facilitate this understanding.

Website: https://www.surrealplastics.com/Medina, Aleksandra. Mischievous Algorithm2021-00242021AD-MC-0042021-0024
Scope and Contents
Built using p5.js and javascript, Mischievous Algorithm is a networked program that gives instructions to two or more users working real-time to create a collaborative drawing. However, there is a twist. A third 'hidden' player is the Mischievous Algorithm, which introduces uncertainty by bringing in new elements or changes into the users' work. Accessed through a link hosted on a service called Ngrok, users are presented with an interface similar to Windows Paint, but built using p5.js. The program has three areas: a set of instructions, a canvas for drawing and a minimal tool set derived from common drawing apps, which includes a color picker, the ability to change brush size and an eraser. While users are interacting with each other through the canvas, on the backend there is the Mischievous Algorithm that changes the users' work in ways that only a computer could do.The project reverses the expected behavioral roles of human vs. machine through an interface where the user follows direct instructions to create a piece of digital art, while the interfering code creatively and unexpectedly modifies it.
Author provided keywords: algorithm, interactive media, digital art, machine, game, p5.jsNguyen, Vince. Bodily Particles2021-00302021AD-MC-0042021-0030
Scope and Contents
Bodily Particles (NYUAD Air) is a sci-art installation that provides a looking-glass into the deadly world of microscopic particulate matter in the air. Situated within the sub-urban setting of the NYUAD campus, it challenges our perceived sense of comfort and cleanliness: just because we don't see smoke-churning factories or polluting vehicles near us, it does not mean the air we breathe is safe. The installation addresses this neglected issue by offering two intertwined components on NYUAD campus. The first component is a socially distanced outdoor installation that makes invisible air pollution hypervisible, allowing us to see ourselves in relationship with the microscopic particles we breathe in. The second component is a network of air quality monitoring stations across campus (Campus Center, Dining Hall, and outside of Arts Center), providing real time air quality data and health suggestions.

Scope and Contents
BlockIt! is a mobile game that prompts users to create a 3D model of a given noun using simple shapes while whoever they are playing with must guess what they are creating. Once a user creates this 3D model, a marker is dropped at the user's current longitude and latitude position onto an in-game map. Other users of the application can travel to this location, tap on the marker, view the model that the user created and guess what this object is. The capstone sits between being a case study in effective interaction design for mobile experiences and a project that explores user agency and their ability to create with the tools and affordances provided to them through the application. The application uses augmented reality as a tool for designing, exploring the potential for the technology to be used effectively for 3D design.

Website: http://stevenwyks.com/blockit.htmlLegal Studies (2020 - )Toor, Maha. Considering Constitutional Gaps in the UK2020-00212020AD-MC-0042020-0021
Scope and Contents
I plan to investigate how the absence of a formalized or written constitution in the United Kingdom (UK) is compensated for within the legal system, other laws and treaties. Because a large portion of these laws come from the EU or international conventions that have been brought into local legislation, primarily the Human Rights Act of 1998, I want to study the implications Brexit may have on an uncodified and EU derived conception of Human Rights. Aside from theoretically analyzing this through the law and bills and acts, I aim to survey UK residents or citizens- i.e. those who the laws and possible change in the provision of human rights in the UK impact. In my survey, I will try to understand whether the subjects know about how their rights are provided in the UK, whether they feel a gap due to the uncodified nature of the constitution and whether they know the impact Brexit may have.
Human rights, UK, Constitution, Unwritten ConstitutionPearce, James. The Ethical Ramifications of Artificial Intelligence in the Legal Profession2020-00212020AD-MC-0042020-0022
Scope and Contents
Artificial intelligence is disrupting most traditional industries, and the legal sphere is no exception. Artificial intelligence offers the potential to greatly increase access to the law, particularly for low-income clients, but raises many serious ethical questions. These questions include, first, the extent to which artificial intelligence can offer competent legal representation, and second, whether additional regulation is required to protect individuals from incompetent representation or breaches of confidentiality. Artificial Intelligence will alter the relationship between lawyer and client, and require from lawyers a keen understanding of developments in this nascent field. These ethical concerns give rise to issues of regulation and legal education. Author provided keywords: Environment, United Arab Emirates, Capitalism, climate chance, sustainability, NorwayAl Khoori, Hamda. Nepotism in the Arab World. Case Study: Money Laundering and Nepotism in Kuwait; Ramifications for Criminal Law2021-00352021AD-MC-0042021-0035
Scope and Contents
The capstone project thesis is: nepotism and money laundering have corrupted Kuwait's judicial and democratic system by preventing the law from operating the way it should. It weakened the enforcement of the law and thus, justice was not served properly due to intervention from powerful authorities. The thesis explores the meaning of nepotism; its history and origins with a contrast between Confucianism and Islam. It discusses nepotism in other countries and considers current responses to nepotism in various countries. Nepotism in Kuwait is the focus of the thesis. The following factors of Kuwait are considered: legal system, National Assembly, politics and the Al Sabah family, the meaning of money laundering, Kuwait's law on money laundering, Malaysian Fund Case, Social Media Influencers case, and Bangladesh MP Shahid Islam case. The thesis concludes with an analysis of the three cases and possible remedies.
Author provided keywords: Nepotism, Kuwait, Money LaunderingBenhayoune, Ghita. Examining Islamic Triple Talaq in India through the Perspectives of Gender and Human Rights2021-00322021AD-MC-0042021-0032
Scope and Contents
This research project focuses on the issue of Triple Talaq – also known as Talaq-e-biddat or Muslim instantaneous divorce – in India and the analysis of reforms related to the issue from the perspective of gender and human rights. This paper will be structured in two parts. The first examines the issue of Triple Talaq in India from a legal perspective, bringing forward landmark cases in the matter and relevant statutes. The second examines the issue and particularly, the reforms undertaken (including the landmark case Shayara Bano v. Union of India and Others and the Muslim Women (Protection of Rights on Marriage) Act of 2019) from the lens of gender and human rights. The focus will be on gender equality, as a human right and framework of analysis. To do so, the research will engage cross-disciplinary interpretations and reconciliate the aforementioned perspectives with broader socio-legal analysis, including methodologies within feminist jurisprudence, to critically evaluate the amendments on Triple Talaq in India.

This paper presents the hypothetical independence of Catalonia from the rest of Spain. The different sections create a journey through the history of internal and external conflicts in the region to understand the historical memory, an explanation of the functioning of national and local institutions as well as the formation of the so-called Historical Communities. The document explores what Catalonia would be like if it decided to become independent and what conditions the institutions and citizens of a new Catalan state would have to face.

Anxious Omnivores: Animal Ambivalence and Meat Ambiguity in Animals, Life of Pi, and The Year of the Flood2014-0011742014AD-MC-0042014-0011
Scope and Contents
Major: Literature
Abstract: This thesis examines the cultural politics and ethics of meat and meat-eating in three contemporary Canadian novels: Don LePan's Animals, 2009; Yann Martel's Life of Pi, 2001; and Margaret Atwood's The Year of the Flood, 2009. I argue that each novel contains a specific anxiety over whether—and under what conditions—eating meat is ethically justifiable, and that in each case this anxiety stems from questions about how humans draw distinctions between their own species and nonhuman animals. Each novel also demonstrates an awareness that these boundaries, both between humans and nonhumans and between different species of animals, are often arbitrary and subject to change. Fundamental human ambivalences in how to relate to different species of animals lead to the physical ambiguity of meat; acknowledging these ambivalences results in a "cannibal anxiety", or anxiety over whether eating nonhuman flesh is any different than eating human flesh. I will examine how these novels reveal or suggest ways of dealing with these ambiguities and their resultant anxieties, and how they challenge the reader to rethink both their meat-eating practices and their wider relationships to nonhuman animals in general.CanadaMeatAmbiguityAnxietyAnimalsJames, Katherine Delia. Feminism, West African Fiction, and the Problem of Genre in Buchi Emecheta's "The Rape of Shavi"2015-001533792015AD-MC-0042015-0015
Scope and Contents
Major: Literature
Abstract: From Chinua Achebe to Buchi Emecheta, African writers have tended to write in a realist style. In creating realist narratives of resistance to colonialism and neocolonialism, these writers have implicitly cooperated with western literary critics who insist on reading literary works by African-born writers as anthropological accounts of life in "Africa." Nigerian-born author Buchi Emecheta's critical reputation was built around her early realist fiction, which critics continue to read as anthropological accounts of a universally African female experience. This paper reads Emecheta outside this critical paradigm by focusing on her only work of speculative fiction, The Rape of Shavi. Ultimately, reading Emecheta's work in relation to The Rape of Shavi suggests new modes of reading the canon of African women's fiction.AnthropologyRealismNigeriaWest AfricaFeminismKelani, Naila Hafiz. On leaving a little smarter: Navigating space and a "minor" identity in transvergent post-beur cinema.2015-001633962015AD-MC-0042015-0016
Scope and Contents
Major: Literature and Creative Writing
Abstract: Cinéma beur has traditionally been treated as a sociological cinema documenting the 'real' French-Maghrebi experience. The young protagonists of Jacques Audiard's Un Prophète (2009) and Mohamed Hamidi's Né Quelque Part (2013) navigate between Frenchness, Arabness, and Muslimness in ways that render their complex identities institutionally irreconcilable. Throughout the films' narratives, they encounter changing conceptions of their overlapping identities in the context of their movements through spaces via temporal and metaphorical journeys within (and without) the French Republic.
Borrowing Will Higbee's notion of 'post-beur' cinema, I argue that these films resist being read through the realist, sociological, and postcolonial lenses that differentiate, if not the films themselves, then the analyses that they invite, from the "beur" generation. They mark a departure towards a transvergent cinema that deconstructs notions of center and margins, incorporating Deleuze's rhizome towards a reading of how the features and inconsistencies of a racialized French society serve as catalysts towards these characters "becoming" minoritarian.AlgeriaFranceBeur cinemaNorth AfricaLeith, Sachi. Unsettling Nomadism: Becoming-Minor in Galsan Tschinag's Die Rückkehr2015-001933872015AD-MC-0042015-0019
Scope and Contents
Major: Literature, History
Abstract: The study of non-ethnic German authors, of increasing importance to German literature, has traditionally focused only on those within Germany. The enigmatic work of Galsan Tschinag, however, a Tuvan Mongolian shaman and author of thirty books in German, provokes a radical re-imagination of the contours of German literary and linguistic history. His fictionalized autobiography Die Rückkehr: Roman meines Lebens [The Return: Novel of my Life], the most aesthetically self-conscious of his texts, invokes Mongol, Soviet, Tuvan, and European literary forms to weave together Central Asian and European histories. I read Die Rückkehr in conversation with Deleuze and Guattari's Toward a Minor Literature, whose emphasis on language as a deterritorialized, dynamic space of imagination, rather than an entity circumscribed by national boundaries, allows me to analyze Tschinag's work within the broader contexts of German and Mongolian literatures, and of minor literatures in general. The text's formal experimentation and staging of autobiographical truth through fiction allow the author to comment on both post-socialist Mongolia and contemporary Germany. By revealing the various traditions that converge in his work, I argue for a more integrated understanding of Eurasian history via German as a global language.German languageGerman WritingGermanyPostsocialismDeterritorializationPostcolonialismMongoliaShamansNomadsMinor literatureSutherland, Jamie Alexander. 'The Time-Devouring Nightingale': Toward A Borgesian Conception of World Literature 2015-000833902015AD-MC-0042015-0008
Scope and Contents
Major: Literature
Abstract: Many of Jorge Luis Borges's works reject linear understandings of time, allowing him to rewrite history and tradition. Borges uses translation to reshape his literary heritage, as well as his own national history. This practice is exemplified by his 1925 translation of the last page of James Joyce's Ulysses in the publication Proa, which recreates Ulysses in Buenos Aires and, when published, challenged conceptions of what Argentine literature should look like. His Antología de la literatura fantástica ('Anthology of Fantastic Literature'), which includes other translated portions of Ulysses, upsets traditional understandings of the canon, periods of literary history, and traditional practices of translation. My project explores Borges's unconventional understanding of chronology to consider how his literary texts unsettle orthodox understandings of world literature, as well as of Argentine history and literary tradition. An alternative conception of world literature based on a non-linear sense of time elucidates Borges's own works, as well as Joyce's Ulysses, and suggests how current dominant models of world literature could be reimagined.|a Joyce, James, |d 1882-1941. |t UlyssesSpanish languageWorld literatureArgentinaHu, Zoë. Disorderly Time in Jhumpa Lahiri and Amitac Ghosh: Narrative Studies as a Strategy for Reading Migration Novels.2016-001879802016This project relies on the field of narrative studies to demonstrate how migration novels by Lahiri and Ghosh espouse conceptions of migration temporalities that stray from the irreversible, often times oppressive, model of linear time. Employing concepts of narrative temporality, I argue that these texts attribute more agency to the fictional migrant and promote an optimistic sense of migration in which the homeland can be recovered from a shifting, malleable experience of time. This project thus highlights narrative form as a productive site where new conceptions of time and migration in literature can thrive and converge.AD-MC-0042016-0018

Ra7ala 2017-00052017Ra7ala is a semi-autobiographical novella, that follows Leila, a young Egyptian woman who has recently re-discovered her Palestinian roots, as she goes to Palestine in search of her great-grandmother's house. This journey brings Leila face-to-face with her family's history and with questions about identity, loss, and diaspora. Leila's story also illustrates the nature of privilege, in that Leila is able to go on this journey with the thought that she will be able to return, and that she is able to determine for herself how she wants to be defined.AD-MC-0042017-0005

Angels of History: Feminist Politics of Autobiography and Historiography in Maja Haderlap's Angel of Oblivion and Assia Djebar's Fantasia: An Algerian Cavalcade.2017-00042017Using Maja Haderlap's 2011 Angel of Oblivion and Assia Djebar's 1985 Fantasia: An Algerian Cavalcade, this paper articulates a theoretical paradigm that rethinks subjectivity and temporality in order to affirm autobiographical narratives of grief as sites of historical revisionism. Reading the novels as autobiographies reveals the transformation of forms that dissolve the individual subject and give voice to the collective heritage of silenced women. The project draws on Walter Benjamin's notion of messianic time to call attention to the ways in which the novels interrupt patriarchal and imperialist productions of history. Bringing together these feminist and postcolonial autobiographies from disparate contexts elaborates an ethics and aesthetics of individual and collective mourning practices that force us to reexamine how we think about "history."AD-MC-0042017-0004

Wesam's Sister2018-00322018The novella centers around questions of faith, self-discovery, and the difficulties confronting a Muslim family as it tries to preserve their Muslim identity in a Western city. This story is told from the perspective of Zahra Alim, an Iraqi-British eighteen-year-old returning to Edinburgh to clean out the dorm room of her sister, Dua, who has disappeared from college without a trace. Zahra stumbles upon a stack of letters Dua had written just before her disappearance and discovers that Dua lived a whole other life unbeknownst to her family. As she reads through the letters, Zahra faces the dilemma of whether or not to tell her parents about her sister's secret life. • My novella begins with "She looks at herself" – That is essentially what this whole project is about: self-discovery, reflection, but not only so, my novella is about looking back and understanding, empathizing and recognizing the struggles and actions of one's family – more specifically, a Muslim family in a Western society.AD-MC-0042018-0032

Tayeb Salih's Season of Migration to the North Across Its Intertexts2018-00322018This capstone studies the intertextual relationships within Tayeb Salih's Season of Migration to the North. As a postcolonial narrative, the novel straddles Eastern and Western literary traditions and uses these literary references to strategically resist any one reading. Intertextuality becomes a game under the hand of the novel: it is cognizant of the global literary landscape that it must participate in, with these various literary references becoming a performative exercise in striking the balance between disparate influences and cultures that a postcolonial novel comes out of. Gérard Genette's classification of transtextuality has been useful in understanding how different modes of intertextuality can work within the same space. Aamir Mufti's conception of World Literature highlights the cultural dynamics that underlie such references. Thinking with both highlights the need to re-evaluate how intertextuality fits within these new literary contexts. Season of Migration to the North seems to be anticipating space for a kind of postcolonial intertextuality, which owes a debt to theories of intertextuality while highlighting how such a technique becomes a strategic tool for a novel to insert itself into a universal library.AD-MC-0042018-0028

Writing as a Case of Performative Translation: A Reading of Valeria Luiselli's Fiction and Non-Fiction2018-00352018This Capstone Project is an analysis of the fiction and non-fiction works of Mexican contemporary writer, Valeria Luiselli. This analysis seeks to conceptualize "performative translation" as a new term that refers broadly to the ways in which translation is built into the form and content of a text in its "original" iteration. The project operates on an understanding of translation as a creative practice. Finally, in proposing this new concept, the project emphasizes the relevance of Luiselli's work in introducing academic and non-academic works that encourage a rethinking of translation's capaciousness as an analytical concept and creative strategy for writing.AD-MC-0042018-0035

Erasure as Resistance: HOMO Sapienne in/as Contemporary Greenlandic Literature2018-00112018I propose that through a radical contextualization of HOMO Sapienne—which considers the literary historical trajectory into which the novel inserts itself, the rhetorical disparagement of contemporary Greenlanders by their historical colonizers, and the market-facing considerations Korneliussen and her publisher might make to slate the novel for wider circulation among those former colonizers—we discover a unique rhetorical strategy in HOMO Sapienne that other postcolonial may emulate to maximize their readership without mollifying the potential anger of or discontent in their texts: Rather than verbalize any anger she may feel with Greenland's pre-post-colonial wounding by its former colonizers, Korneliussen writes Denmark out of existence, provincializing the former colonizing country and using erasure and non-representation not just to sublimate HOMO Sapienne's anger, but to amplify poignancy and impact.AD-MC-0042018-0011

June2018-00172018Life is lived at the fingertips. Through touch, through material, tactility. From building looms for my great-grandmother to quilting baby blankets and typing on a laptop, from weaving merino wool to rubbing the thin pages of the Bible between my fingers and holding my mother's hand as she holds the blanket I wove for her. The entirety of my life is nothing more than the story of my fingertips, what they have held, what they have transformed, and what they have yet to touch. Poetry is made by touch, either your fingers on a keyboard or holding a pen, and is experienced through touch on a page. The language of poetry is material and tactile, makes something from nothing, enacting change on the world around it; and thus, language is performative. My poetry reflects the things I have touched and the things that have touched me. June enacts the theoretical framework of anti-memoir in order to tell the story of a life through the tactile qualities of poetry and weaving.AD-MC-0042018-0017

This capstone is a speculative fiction work and is a hybrid between a screenplay and prose. It follows the story of a young African American man named Noah who grows up in Reality 6, where slavery never happened. He discovers Reality 12 (our reality), where slavery was a part of history, and the more he learns about the inadequacies of his world, the more he becomes frustrated about his own Black identity. Encouraged by his mentor Harriet, he decides to leave Reality 6 and venture to Reality 12. However, he gets trapped there. What was initially supposed to be a quick visit turns into a journey of Noah discovering what a black identity looks like to him and uncovering more about himself than he thought possible.Siu, Diana. Preserving Hong Kong's Postcoloniality: An Analysis of Leung Ping Kwan and Louise Ho's Poetry2019-00292019AD-MC-0042019-0029
Scope and Contents
For ages, Hong Kong was known as a "cultural desert" that merely took on the culture of its British colonizer. It was only when Hong Kong identity faced the "double trauma of the signing of the Sino-British Joint Declaration of 1984 followed by the Tiananmen Massacre of 1989" did people realize that "the Hong Kong way of life with its mixture of colonialist and democratic trappings was in imminent danger of disappearing" (Abbas 6-7). The 1997 Handover, which, marked the return of Hong Kong to Chinese rule, then, became a deadline against which the city's writers utilized different strategies to preserve Hong Kong's postcolonial identity, to resist the imminent threat of identity decolonization and potentially, recolonization. This thesis specifically will investigate the specific strategies used by Leung Ping Kwan and Louise Ho in their poetry to preserve Hong Kong's postcolonial identity, looking towards yet another deadline in 2047- when the "One Country, Two Systems" arrangement that currently governs Hong Kong is set to expire.Zhang, Eva. Strings is a novella-length character study of a fictional figure, Hamza. It comes as no surprise that Hamza could not stay. He was born a 'stringless' child, without an umbilical cord, that was a sign. When he sets off to New York in pursuit of his long-lost youth, he never looks back. His estranged son endangers Hamza's new life plan when he gets into legal trouble and needs his father's help. A tale about fatherhood and escapism, it is a story about a man that tries to untangle himself from the life he's been prescribed.
novella, fiction, khaleeji, emirati, fatherhood, belonging, surreal, family, experimentalGerodias, Louise. The Blunt Edge of Modern Sports Manga: Ironic Medium of Female Realities2020--00282020AD-MC-0042020-0028
Scope and Contents
Modern sports manga rarely features female characters as main protagonists; they are almost always on the sidelines. When they take on a more active role in the narrative, it is to be in the service of others. This capstone project sought to understand the nature of sports manga's "soft power" in contemporary culture through exploring the connection between the conservatism of sports manga's gender politics and its popularity. This conservatism is the lingering legacy of Japan's encounters with Western attitudes and ideals, especially in terms of athleticism and womanhood, which have been adapted into Japanese cultural norms. Examples included deference to hierarchy and images of masculine strength. The prevalence of such norms, as evidenced by its representation on the pages of modern sports manga like Furudate Haruichi's Haikyū!!, this project's case study text, hinders modern manga from realizing its full potential to be progressive.
"sports manga," Japan, manga, Haikyū!!Golovakova, Ria. The Trouble with Utopias and Humans: Posthumanism in Politics and Folklore in Arkady and Boris Strugatsky's Monday Starts on Saturday and Tale of the Troika2020-00312020AD-MC-0042020-0031
Scope and Contents
"Like all science," says Roman Oira-Oira. "Our work deals with human happiness." Oira-Oira, one of the most respected employees of the National Institute for the Technology of Witchcraft and Thaumaturgy (NITWiT), announces this claim in the first chapter of Arkady and Boris Strugatsky's utopian novel Monday Starts on Saturday (1965). Within the text, his statement is not hyperbolic: the fictional Institute is centered around improving the human condition and contains a Department of Linear Human Happiness, a Department of the Meaning of Life, and a Department of Eternal Youth. This project examines different ideas of utopia – political, scientific, and literary – within a cycle of hope and disillusionment as the narration shifts from the realistic to the fantastical in both Monday Starts on Saturday and its sequel Tale of the Troika (1968). I look at how different conceptions of human nature intertwine and conflict with utopian visions within the Soviet communist ideology, expressed through representations of folkloric characters and magic systems. By zooming in on the mechanics behind the fantastical, this project crafts an analytical approach to deconstructing utopia and understanding human nature.
Strugatsky, Soviet literature, science fiction, utopia, posthumanism, folkloreGutierrez Carrera, Julian. The Liminality of Visual Novels2020-00272020AD-MC-0042020-0027
Scope and Contents
Visual novels are a form of video game that occupy an odd space within the label of "video games," but there is something odd about them: although they are considered video games, most of the gaming experience consists of reading and experiencing a narrative. Gameplay usually consists of choice-making moments where the narrative flow stops for the player to make a decision, and the choice will alter how the story plays out. Since VNs have this gameplay factor in them, they have never been theorised as part of Literature. But since their gameplay is limited and most of their focus is on story, they are not theorised as part of Game Studies either. Through three analyses, I find a way to read visual novels using elements from both literary analysis and game analysis but enabling for a better reading of visual novels as forms of art.

"Hawak" is a novella about an aswang, a local monster from Filipino urban legend that feeds on unborn children, that awakens in modern-day Baguio city. It is a story about female communities and bridging gaps between women of different social backgrounds through the body of the monster. It seeks to retake ownership over the figure of the aswang that has long been transformed after years of colonization in order to address modern issues that women face today. "Hawak" also serves as a response to Filipino Literary History that hopes to expand the role of women and their characterization, transitioning from the domestic and expanding outwards into the world.

If you have ever lived in Al Ain then you know it's not really a place. Al Ain is an event in your life and once it's over you look back on it with the same incredulous wonder that you might consider a vivid dream. My capstone is a novel that explores Al Ain and the unseen djinn city that exists on the other side of it: Na'ila. Harper is a young woman from Canada who escapes her small-town life by agreeing to study for a semester at a university in Al Ain. Aisha is a young djinn who has just received her visa to enter Na'ila where she'll be working as a maid for one of the most powerful djinn families: the Raaeds. Their stories intertwine when Aisha begins to visit Al Ain and Harper falls in love with Majed-- one of the Raaed brothers. When Harper finds out she's pregnant the Raaeds decide the baby belongs to them. Aisha might be the only one who can keep Harper and the baby safe.Raj Pandey, Chiran. "In accord with more universal vibrations": Totality, Race, and Gender in Teju Cole's Open City2020-00262020AD-MC-0042020-0026
Scope and Contents
My capstone offers a reading of the 2011 novel Open City by Teju Cole through the lens of aesthetic theory and the concept of novelistic totality. The problem animating my paper is the rape of Moji Kasali, a Nigerian acquaintance of the novel's narrator, Julius. Moji accuses Julius of having raped her when he was fourteen and she fifteen. My capstone is shaped by Moji's accusation. In my paper, I consider Moji's rape to be the founding rupture of the novel: Open City arises, in other words, in response to this disastrous event in Moji's and Julius's lives. Troubled by the rape — which he has forgotten — and by its reminder through Moji's accusation, Julius, I suggest, writes Open City as an attempt to recreate the innocent, pre-lapsarian wholeness that was lost when he raped Moji. Along the way his attempt at totality is disturbed by race, gender, history, all three embodied foremost by Moji.

Scope and Contents
Cranes is a collection of poetry and creative non-fiction bridging cosmopolitanism and women of color (WOC). Spanning four sections – taking off, flight, orbit, and land – the book follows the voice of a flâneuse, navigating different "cosmopolitan" cities like Abu Dhabi, New York, and Paris. But all cities have histories, which have created different unjust systems that affect the WOC's mobility and conception of self today. How can her body then exist with difference, and still keep and construct her own autonomous identity, intact? I argue for love, the creative space, and community as solutions, spaces where the WOC can rebuild a self on her own terms.

Amani is a young adult novella about three girls who share the same soul. Amani is a middle-class 17-year-old who stumbles upon a BuzzFeed quiz that asks whether she's curious about her fate. Curious, Amani starts a free trial that embarks her on a journey of seeing and constructing her alternate lives: Naima and Amina. As the trial counts down, Amani decides and observes a snapshot of an event that happens every year in each of the girls' lives. The trial is counting down, and Amani has to decide her favorite fate. Which will she decide? And what will it be based on? This novella digs deep into how privilege and choice come in various shapes and forms and highlights the reality of how humans react to the environments they find themselves in.
Author provided keywords: Amani, BuzzFeed, Naima, Amina, Egypt, Class, Destiny, Free TrialAbi Samra, Tom. Between and Across the ʿAjāʾib, Riḥla, and Kommentaranthologie Traditions: Toward an Encyclopedic Reading of Yūsuf al-Shirbīnī's Hazz al-quḥūf (fl. 1686)2021-00432021AD-MC-0042021-0043
Scope and Contents
In this thesis I propose to read Yūsuf al-Shirbīnī's Hazz al-quḥūf (fl. 1686) in light of the encyclopedic ethos that permeated the postclassical period (13th–18th centuries) in Arabic literary history. In the introduction, I show that scholars have considered it either a historical text or a literary one—but never both (or neither). I situate Hazz in the ʿajāʾib and riḥla traditions to explore questions of fact, fiction, ethnography, and, ultimately, encyclopedism. I read al-Shirbīnī contra Evliya Çelebi's Seyahâtnâme. This reading reveals a textual epistemology that is not concerned with fact per se, but with truth-value. Next, I turn to the questions of structure and genre; I explore the structure of Hazz. I draw on Gilles Deleuze and Félix Guattari's notion of the rhizome to theorize the structure of the Kommentaranthologie. I also engage Jacques Derrida's discussion of the "supplement" and his "law of genre" to theorize how Hazz exceeds the genre it situates itself in. I then speculate about the possible social purpose of the text's structure. Finally, I reflect on this thesis's contribution to undoing the problematic inḥiṭāṭ narrative, and explore alternative pathways to problematize this paradigm by situating the text within (a) Mediterranean literary history.

This capstone project is a comparative analysis of two recent and extremely popular standup comedy specials, The Bird Revelation by Dave Chappelle and Nanette by Hannah Gadsby. My analysis uncovers how these comedians engage with the #MeToo movement using standup comedy and highlights the comic strategies they use to make their argument onstage and off. A hallmark of these specials is the willingness of the comedian to make the audience feel uncomfortable, which results in quite unique comedy specials that make several formal innovations. Ultimately, what the comedians argue in their specials has consequences for how we consider standup comedy and its potential for social reform in the #MeToo era.

This short story collection is a personal project that reflects on and records specific moments that I have experienced during my time at NYUAD, but in fictionalized form. It is a diary that records striking or overwhelming memories that have pushed me to reevaluate what to hold on in life. By writing these tales, I aimed to move away from the memories that each character manifests, and towards an afterwards; the fact that there exists such an afterwards—that I got to step away from the past and materialize snippets of valuable thoughts and feelings on paper—is what matters. The project consists of a lyric poem and five short stories that are different in setting, narrative style and form, and point of view. While each story centers on the keyword of "after-life," it also stretches for something bigger than the boundaries of an afterlife. Each character encounters some experience with death, but more so, find themselves alone and isolated from the rest of the world. Join these vulnerable characters on a journey of loneliness and fragility, as they navigate and grapple their way through life and contemplate what is to be left afterwards.

Scope and Contents
This submission from my novella is inspired by the mythology of the small village of Thozupadam in the state of Kerala, India. At the centre of the lore and legends lies the Poothan and Thira, an artistic ritual performance that has been around for over 200 years. This novella aims to reflect the village's growing concerns about religious and cultural heritage disappearing, by following the life of a boy named Kutty and his family who have inherited the ritual. When prompted by a choice between preserving tradition and promising opportunities outside the village, Kutty's beliefs in the village gods, demons, and magic stagger as he grows. The ghouls of the village send one of their own, Poothan, on a task to regain Kutty's faith. The supernatural entities must ensure that the boy fulfils his fate of inheriting the ritual himself so that the cycle of tradition is undisrupted, and so that their survival is not threatened, even if revival requires unorthodox means.
Author provided keywords: Folklore, Kerala, Heritage, Fiction, Ritual, TraditionNirmala Dious, Aathma. Thoo!2021-00382021AD-MC-0042021-0038
Scope and Contents
In an alternate timeline, the city of Abu Dhabi is made out of buildings controlled by the PES, a mechanical system that expels residents from their apartments when it is their time to leave. The fictional novel follows Anaswara, a Malayali expat woman born and brought up in this city. Anaswara is now a 25-year old researcher who digs deeper into her childhood home and writes about her life in the PES. However, her past comes crashing into the present when an old friend, Nourah, contacts her to help with an investigation that connects together a series of deaths from 2008, to the PES system crash in 2015—the same one that forced Anaswara and her family out of Abu Dhabi. This capstone is a novel-in-progress and what you read is about 1/3rd of the complete novel.
Author provided keywords: Creative Writing, novel, speculative fiction, Abu Dhabi, Gulf LiteratureTalavera, Leanne. Writings of Oceania: Examining Postcolonial Identity in Satendra Nandan's "The Wounded Sea"2021-00452021AD-MC-0042021-0045
Scope and Contents
Oceanian studies, particularly under Epeli Hau'ofa, has traditionally looked at identity through the ocean and land— land as the root of Oceanian history and culture, ocean as an extension of those roots. Additionally, the field has been characterized by its rejection of misconceived Oceanian "smallness," which has belittled the region socio-politically and geographically. But if scholars such as Epeli Hau'ofa refer to Oceanian lands as the root of Oceanian identity, then what of those who, under colonialism, were forcibly brought to labor on that very land? This paper seeks to expand upon such frameworks of Oceanian postcolonial studies in regard to identity and "smallness," and aims to examine them through an analysis of Satendra Nandan's "The Wounded Sea". Firstly, this paper argues that "The Wounded Sea" explores Oceanian identity on the national and regional level; and, that the novel not only interrogates the pillars of Oceanian identity— land and ocean— but also renders them active agents in reasserting Indo-Fijian belonging. Secondly, this paper argues that the "The Wounded Sea" is an Oceanian novel that pushes back against conceived Oceanian "smallness," by engaging in wider discourses of literature and genre, and ultimately situating itself in a larger postcolonial literary tradition.
Author provided keywords: Oceania, identity, indigenous, Indo-Fijian, postcolonialism, literature, historyUy, Jamie. Star Wars and the Eco-Politics of Survival2021-00442021AD-MC-0042021-0044
Scope and Contents
From the scrappy Millennium Falcon to barren, backwater planets, the Star Wars universe revolves around junk, trash, and waste. Through the perspective of material ecocriticism, however, representations of so-called "dead" matter in Star Wars reveal how nonhuman elements of the environment are never truly inanimate. These representations prompt us to recognize the surprising "force of things," an experience which Jane Bennett summarizes as "thing-power," or "the curious ability of inanimate things to animate, to act, to produce effects dramatic and subtle" (Vibrant Matter 6). This capstone expands the boundaries of material ecocriticism, which has demonstrated relatively little interest in the thing-power of media, while bringing material ecocriticism to popular cinema. I analyze stereotypically inanimate matter or "lesser" life-forms (such as the Tusken Raiders, the Death Star, and carbonite) to argue that Star Wars casts the nonhuman as agentic across its sprawling storyworlds. Along the way, I track how eco-philosophy evolves throughout almost fifty years of Star Wars history. Analyzing Star Wars as a global transmedia phenomenon illuminates how our media environments and natural environments are enmeshed, embedded, and continuously interact. Ultimately, Star Wars advocates for an eco-politics of survival by expanding the definition of the "Anthropos" in the Anthropocene.

Music, Voice, and Agency: Response Mechanisms of Politically Marginalized Groups and the Case of the Rastafari Minority in Ethiopia.2016-001779672016This research project uses Minorities at Risk (MAR) data and an original ethnographic dataset to examine how politically marginalized groups respond to exclusion. Drawing on Albert Hirschman's theory of exit, voice, and loyalty, my analysis reveals global patterns in minority responses, while my case study of the Rastafari provides insight into the complex politics of inclusion and exclusion in Ethiopia from the 1950s to the present. Both these datasets demonstrate that groups who are excluded establish political agency through different modes of voice, which, in Rastafari communities, takes the form of Ethiopian reggae music. Although my research indicates that groups with political representation are more likely to express dissent through pressure group tactics, it suggests also that music can serve as an important platform for envisioning and negotiating political and cultural inclusion in the absence of formal representation.AD-MC-0042016-0017

Unheard Of: Creating Cinematic Soundscapes2017-00032017Unheard Of: Creating Cinematic Soundscapes comprised of developing all audio components for the following four film capstones: Alma (Jime Reyes), Acheevment (Gergő Varga), Mahaa (Yunbo Wu), and Thirty (Yi Yi Yeap). These audio components included my assumption of all the following roles: • Production Sound Mixer, Boom Operator, Sound Editor • Producer, Sound Designer, Music Supervisor • Composer, Performer, Recording Engineer • Foley Supervisor, Foley Artist, Foley Mixer • ADR Supervisor, ADR Mixer • Mixing Engineer The motivation of the capstone project came from my desire to explore further my previous experiences in designing music and sound for films and theater performances, specifically the notion and conscious use of silence (or lack thereof) in creating an effective sonic ambience. The question of using silence with emotional impact is in response to film director Henri Colpi's quote, "Above all, no gaps or holes, cry filmmakers with alarm. And if hole there be, plug it up with music," and offers a counterexample of using non-musical elements – in line with musical elements – to elicit similar emotional response.AD-MC-0042017-0003

Symbolic Oscillations: Using Feedback to Augment Parameter Relationships in Digital Music Systems2018-00272018This paper suggests that the implementation of tactile feedback works towards restoring embodied cognitive relationships in digital music systems. I ask whether we may use tactile feedback in another manner, for example, to augment symbolic relationships by physicalizing the relations between sound variables and synthesis processes in digital music systems. This departs from the discussion of how digital instruments engage users in hermeneutic processes of cognition, in contrast to processes of embodied cognition, more typical of the relationship established with acoustic instruments. Finally, I propose the design and construction of an interactive digital synthesizer system to explore and test the ideas discussed in this paper.AD-MC-0042018-0027

Sonido Bogotano2018-00262018This ethnography follows closely the lives and works of young upper-middle class men who are a part of what is understood to be the emerging "alternative music" scene of Bogota, Colombia. Based on four months of fieldwork, this ethnography tells the story of what it is like to be a struggling musician in a large city with ever-growing cultural offers. In my work, I theorize scene building in the context of popular music, and explore the relationship between art, place, and the imagination. Ultimately, I propose that the city of Bogota is the main character in a popular music scene that is otherwise characterized by its musical heterogeneity.AD-MC-0042018-0026

Romanian Folk Music and Dubstep: Recontextualizing Folk Styles in Contemporary Forms2019-00312019AD-MC-0042019-0031
Scope and Contents
Fusions of music styles are happening all over the world, to the extent that it oftentimes becomes questionable to which genre a certain piece pertains. Intermixtures between contemporary styles and folk music are important because of their ability to revive old genres that are not as present in the lives of today's generations anymore. This paper explores ways to create such fusions between Romanian folk music and the Electronic Dance Music genre "Dubstep" through three versions of the Romanian folk song "Ca pe luncă" created in the Digital Audio Workstation Logic Pro. The first version is simply a recreation of "Ca pe luncă" with digital and recorded instruments. The second version was created with the intention of keeping a larger amount of the Romanian piece intact, preserving its meter and tempo. The last version was made to preserve the meter and tempo of the Dubstep genre, thus keeping more of its main characteristics.Vaidya, Himag. Through this capstone I aim to examine how music production can act as a medium to de-contextualize and re- contextualize a piece of music and affect its expressive value by influencing its composition, lyrics, arrangement and sonic characteristics. I will do so by producing the same song 5 different ways and reflecting upon the expressive transformation that occurs.Alblooshi, Safeya. Narrated Liquid Contaminants2021-00482021AD-MC-0042021-0048
Scope and Contents
Narrated Liquid Contaminants is a 15-speaker sound installation divided into 4 zones, each following a theme of contamination; from E-waste to human-caused pollution, naturally caused contamination, and viral contaminants. Each zone has dedicated contaminated bottles with touch sensors at the bottom which once triggered, initiate visual projection and soundscapes. The audience then interacts with photoresistors on the bottles by casting a shadow over the projection, altering the soundscapes of curated field recordings. This project embodies a form of situated listening that addresses topics of contaminated waterbodies and the effect they play on the environment. Water is used as a medium to conceptually portray flows of contamination, replicating those existing in the natural environment, and sound as a channel of narration, accompanied by video. The mediums connect with each other once interacted with via physical touch or shadow movement, letting the installation act as a means of situating the audience in an altering soundscape by participating in the narrative rather than being passive observers; a reflection on our co-existent relationship and active contribution to our surrounding environments.

Scope and Contents
This Capstone Project occupies the domain of practice research, in that its key questions are posed through an engagement and intermingling of my own practice, others' practice/s, and the supporting musicological and philosophical literature. My key area of problematicity is concerned with notions of authenticity in Hungarian folk music, and especially folk music involving vocal performance. It considers folk music as an evolving tradition that is not restricted by a modern-day understanding of geographical borders; time period; or performance practice. Such a conception challenges the notion of folk music as a 'fixed', 'pure', and 'authentic' form of music, and consequently a static performance practice; a perception that is still surprisingly commonly held by some scholars, performers, and audiences in parts of Hungarian society today. My Capstone work aims to draw from the past by previewing the future, placing folk songs in a perpetual present that is constantly adapting, influencing, and being influenced.
Author provided keywords: Traditional Hungarian folk music, authenticity, evolutionCiocca, Vera Renjifo. Towards a sustainable career as a post-millennial singer/songwriter: A Step-by-Step Guide to Independence in the Music Business2021-00492021AD-MC-0042021-0049
Scope and Contents
Success in the music industry is not the same as it was a few generations ago. Building a career as an independent artist is changing with shifting expectations from all the stakeholders in the music business. Additionally, the emergence of multimedia, streaming platforms, and blockchain technologies, create more complex environments for emerging artists to navigate. In this study, I present a roadmap that will facilitate the process of releasing music for post-millennial independent sing/songwriters with consideration for all new variables in the market. In developing this roadmap, I analyze recent developments in the most important domains that an independent singer/songwriter needs to know about. These domains include (i) legal frameworks in the music business, (ii) marketing and distribution strategies, and (iii) monetization in the music business. I also analyze my experience in composing, producing, and releasing two songs in the form of contributions to this work to demonstrate where important domains overlay in practice. My goal, through this step-by-step guide, is to support emerging artists starting from zero to promote their music independently and who want to develop a sustainable career in Pop music.

Abstract: This paper applies the structure of Bayesian confirmation theory to new questions in theoretical physics, in particular to those surrounding the observations that have led to the hypothesis of dark matter. I argue that observations used as evidence for dark matter are relevant examples of Duhem's problem in confirmation theory. Using Bayesian analysis, I calculate the conditional probabilities of several different ways of accounting for the unexpected observations, and attempt to discern which are justified as explanations. I conclude that relatively unpopular alternatives to dark matter theories, like modified Newtonian mechanics (MOND), deserve greater scrutiny in light of these calculations.Dark matter (Astronomy)Duhem-Quine thesisConfirmation theoryBayesianismKahn, Amelia Ruth. Abstract: This thesis examines James R. Beebe's statistical solution to the generality problem for process reliabilism. Beebe's solution employs concepts from cognitive science along with a mechanism of statistical relevance to pick out a unique process type. I argue that Beebe's view cannot rule out process types defined by periods of time, and because of this, the view falls victim to a trivialization. Beebe's view yields the result that true beliefs are maximally justified and false beliefs are maximally unjustified. I explore several strategies to avoid the temporal types trivialization and ultimately find them to be unsatisfactory.Externalism (Philosophy of mind)EpistemologyGenerality problemReliabilismStatisticsTrivializationShirley, Joshua Cameron. Major: Philosophy
Abstract: My capstone is an argument against concept empiricism as presented by the philosopher Jesse Prinz. Concept empiricism is a claim that all concepts are perceptually based. I explore what it means to be perceptually based and then offer two main arguments against concept empiricism.
In my first argument I explore how the modular nature of face processing hints at the existence of an innate and complex 'face' concept. I argue how and the innate nature of this complex 'face' concept poses a threat to concept empiricism.
The second line of argument is the more common strand of arguing against concept empiricism. I argue that there might be non-innate complex concepts that we learn about later on in our lives that can't possibly be perceptually based. I demonstrate this argument using the example of Minkowski Space-Time.Space and timePerceptionFaceEmpiricismConceptsMinkowski spaceMcMahon, Connor. Abstract: Supervaluationism posits that a vague statement is true if it is true on all admissible precisifications of its vague terms. However, many prominent philosophers have often punted on giving a concrete theory of what 'admissible' means, often leaving it a primitive term and at best associating it with 'appropriate' or 'correct'. I suggest two alternative theories for defining 'admissible', which overcome some of the problems that primitive concepts of it encounter, such as higher-order vagueness and inaccessibility of meaning facts. I finally compare these alternative theories, a polling view and a core traits view of 'admissible', with the primitive conceptions to show that it is worth exploring more concrete theories of admissibility in order to improve supervaluationism.AdmissibilitySupervaluationismVaguenessVagueness (Philosophy)Arseculeratne, Anishka. Is Neutrality Possible? State Neutrality and the Liberal-Communitarian Debate2016-000679622016We are surrounded by views of all kinds, especially when it comes to the good life and what it constitutes. This poses a problem for states who want to cater to everyone's views. For liberal states that try to respect individual liberty, a plurality of views means it is harder for states to act while keeping their commitment to catering to all the views in their society. Liberals nonetheless claim to have the answer to this problem - state neutrality. However, the idea of state neutrality has come under intense scrutiny by thinkers known as communitarians, sparking off the liberal-communitarian debate. I will examine the arguments by communitarians in this debate and use them to assess models of justifying state coercion put forward by various liberals.AD-MC-0042016-0006

Time Travel and Leibniz's Law2016-001579702016Leibniz's Law can be summed up in the following: if a is identical with b, every quality of a will be a quality of b. Time travel, which is possible according to our best physics, entails that the same thing can be in two places at the same time. If we go back to Leibniz's Law, it tells us that the same thing cannot be in two places at the same time because that entails having different qualities (namely, being in different locations). Leibniz's Law and time travel seem to be incompatible. More broadly, time travel represents a complex case of the problem of change while Leibniz's Law constitutes the foundation of material identity. In my capstone project, I examine different philosophical views that attempt to resolve the broader tension between the problem of change and material identity in Leibniz's Law. I evaluate these views based on whether they are able to explain the specific case of time travel and offer a potential refinement.AD-MC-0042016-0015
