Unlocking Strawson: An Analysis of an Interpretation of Locke's Theory of Personal Identity2017-00062017John Locke's theory of personal identity was revolutionary in many ways at the time it was published. For the first time in the Western philosophical tradition it was argued that the connections that make a person the same person across time are essentially psychological. However, there have been many interpretations of Locke's theory. One of the most recent is Galen Strawson's. Strawson argues that Locke's theory of personal identity works as a theory of moral accountability. My capstone is a close reading of Galen Strawson's take on Locke, questioning whether it makes sense to think of Locke's account of personal identity primarily in terms of moral responsibility.AD-MC-0042017-0006

Bringing together elements from philosophy of mind, psychology, neuroScience, and Buddhist tradition, my capstone uses depersonalization to address questions of selfhood and normativity behind "losing" our experience of being a self. Depersonalization, a phenomenon which entails feeling estranged from how we normally experience ourselves, is typically understood as a mental disorder; as harmful, disruptive, and negative. However, a central motivation in Buddhist philosophy is to demonstrate the illusory nature of the self, and to rid ourselves of its grip through certain practices. Consequently, my project analyzes the differences between depersonalization and the Buddhist practices, backing each up with neuroscientific data when possible, to explain how each bears on our experience of ourselves as selves. Additionally, I weigh both accounts against philosophical criteria of what constitutes a mental disorder, drawing conclusions which separate depersonalization and Buddhist practices both in terms of the underlying processes, and the normativity behind each experience.Chapman, Taj. Ethics of Zakat: Comparison of Islamic Ethical Approaches on the Example of Zakat2019-00132019AD-MC-0042019-0013
Scope and Contents
Zakat, meaning almsgiving, is a form of charity compulsory for all Muslims. Considering that the Qur'an provides a minimal amount of information on the specifics of paying and receiv- ing zakat, Muslims had to rely on theological and ethical interpretations. Inevitably authors had disagreed not only on the specifics of the zakat tradition but also on the reasons and frameworks backing the Islamic pillar. Thus, this paper presents three frameworks of zakat in detail: Al-Ghaz- ali's Mysteries of Almsgiving, Al-Qaradawi's Fiqh al-Zakah, and Maliki's Al-Muwatta. To prove the significant disparity between these frameworks, each of them is compared to a different west- ern normative ethical perspective: virtue ethics, consequentialism, and deontology(respectively). Furthermore, these frameworks are situated into their Islamic historical background, to portray the history of each specific ethical tradition within its context. Conclusively, I present the varying ethical justifications of the different frameworks Muslims need, for the application of the specific methodology of paying zakat. Overall, this paper contends that each of the authors had a significant personal influence on the interpretations.Huang, Alice. Normative theories tell us what we ought to do or believe. But if you're not sure which normative theory is correct, how should you act or believe? Philosophers have proposed various higher order normative theories. I argue that the theories all suffer serious problems. In turn, I propose and defend Proportional Choice--following the recommendations of the theories you believe in proportion to how much you believe them--as the correct higher order theory for normative uncertainty.Shukla, Sugandha. Causal (In)dependence in Counterfactual Analysis: Deterministic and Indeterministic Worlds2019-00092019AD-MC-0042019-0009
Scope and Contents
A need for invoking causal independence when evaluating counterfactuals under David Lewis's standard possible-worlds semantics has been argued for by many. This paper aims to present a comprehensive account of the philosophical discussions on the role of causal dependence in counterfactual analysis, argue for the significance of causal considerations in both deterministic and indeterministic worlds and shed light on some problems with incorporating these causal considerations in the semantics. I present counterexamples to Lewis's standard semantics and discuss how these counterexamples suggest a need for invoking causal independence. I reject the premise—that Morgenbesser counterfactuals are true—based on which Schaffer and Edgington claim that Morgenbesser cases pose a problem for the standard semantics in the first place. I argue that when the indeterministic nature of Morgenbesser cases is accounted for, the counterfactuals comes out to be false. However, I contend that considerations of causal dependence are nevertheless significant in counterfactual analysis for both deterministic and indeterministic scenarios. In the end, I argue that the degree to which one event causally depends on another factors into whether the counterfactual in question is evaluated as true or false. Therefore, notions of causal relevance in the current causal independence approach need to be fine-grained.Chiu, Emma. This capstone weighs the moral and prudential weight of property rights with other rights, when conflicts of rights arise. Conflicts of rights occur when a situation only allows one right to be preserved at the expense of another. This capstone discusses specifically, situations where the right to life might seem to trump the moral and prudential force of property rights. Through a series of arguments, I will end with Ruth Barcan Marcus' discussion on moral dilemmas, where I demonstrate that property rights have the ability to generate genuine moral dilemmas.

My capstone examines premise 1 of Sarah McGrath's epistemological argument against moral knowledge in "Moral Disagreement and Moral Expertise." I incorporate the Higher-Order Evidence framework so that moral disagreement counts as a piece of higher-order evidence threatening our moral knowledge. I examine different strategies to defeat this higher-order evidence. I argue that whether numbers have epistemic significance in moral disagreement is crucial to defeating the higher-order evidence of moral disagreement. I hypothesize that numbers do not have epistemic significance in the moral context.
Author provided keywords: Moral disagreement, moral epistemology, metaethics, peer disagreementValle, Tona Carapia. Educational Justice Adequacy, Equality, and Leveling Down2021-00502021AD-MC-0042021-0050
Scope and Contents
My capstone explores the philosophical area of distributive education justice which looks to find the best way of distributing resources destined to education. Looking at theories of equality and adequacy we find that arriving at an answer of how best to distribute resources is no easy task. On the one hand, the equality view tells us that the distribution should be done in a fair and comparative way. On the other hand, the adequacy view tells us that resources should be distributed to ensure every individual reaches a certain threshold. Specifically, I delve deeper into the controversial but seemingly plausible idea that prohibiting parents from privately investing in their own children's education is morally justified. This is the problem of leveling down, and the focus of my capstone.
Author provided keywords: Philosophy of Education, Equality, Leveling Down, AdequacyXinyi, Zou. Indoctrination2021-00512021AD-MC-0042021-0051
Scope and Contents
In discussions of contemporary education, the term "indoctrination" often appears as an accusation or criticism, describing education that poses detrimental threats to students' learning and personal development. This negative connotation of the word influences our perception of it: when we use the word "indoctrination," it is almost certain that we are not describing any admirable goal of education, but a kind of "bad" education. This project investigates various philosophical accounts that describe worrying cases of indoctrination. This thesis concludes that a successful philosophical theory of indoctrination has two components. The first step consists of either the intentions-based view or the outcome-based view which evaluates the relationship between the indoctrinator and the indoctrinated individual. The second step, the system-based view, lifts some, if not all, of the moral responsibility of indoctrination off the teacher's shoulders. I argue that the decision between the intentions-based view and the outcome-based view does not rest upon the details of the two theories, but a broader decision one has to make regarding whether indoctrination is a kind of morally wrong action type or state of affairs.

Abstract: This project dissects my return to the womb; it is the culmination of my research project in Cali, Colombia. I travelled to my mother's homeland in search of everything that hurt me in being attached to it. I looked for the pain in my mother tongue, in family memories, and in the grave of my grandmother. This yoking together informs the environment, performance, and dramaturgical structure of the piece. It examines how the Pygmalion-Galatea myth is performed through different forms that allow the Galatea figure to express subjectivity and exercise agency in different ways. Devour is a game/performance piece that experiments with the game form's potential to address constructions of American race: a dinner table game in which players attempt to successfully role play stereotypes of their own races while also engaging in conversations about various news and cultural topics.Bagot, Alexandre. can we talk? A Staging of Loneliness and the Difficulties of Communicating in the Digital Age2017-00012017can we talk? paints a portrait of one man's self-imposed isolation in the face of interpersonal difficulties. Through the use of projection and found footage, the work raises questions about the omnipresence of media in the modern world, and its possibly deleterious effects on human interaction. As a silent monologue, the piece garners influences from dance theater and one-man shows, and investigates the relationship between socialization and mental health. It explores ideas of dreams, of memories, of space, and of bodies, and attempts to dive into some of the actor's personal anxieties.AD-MC-0042017-0001

Drowning in Cairo2018-00102018Drowning in Cairo follows the lives of three Egyptian gay men from different walks of life, whose fate forces them together time and again over a 20 year period. The play is set between 1997 and 2017 as Moody, Khalid and Taha age from 13 to 33 and the political system and queer life transform around them. In eleven episodic scenes, Drowning in Cairo chronicles the contemporary history of the queer community's relationship to the law and public space in Egypt.AD-MC-0042018-0010

Re-encounters: Exploring Diasporic Homecoming and Geographies of Identity through Performance in Ghana2018-00242018This paper examines the 2017 iteration of the Pan-African Historical Theatre Project (PANAFEST), a bi-annual theater festival that takes place in Accra and Cape Coast, Ghana. Initiated by the legendary playwright and cultural visionary, Efua T. Sutherland, who understood the link between theater and national development in post-independent Ghana, PANAFEST explores both the traumatic legacies of the transatlantic slave trade and contemporary socio-political issues that impact people across the continent and the diaspora. Recognizing that the Festival is complex and layered, I specifically explore how dance, speeches, and rituals engage with the idea of diasporic homecoming and demonstrate the importance of using the arts to construct and cultivate a sense of unity and interconnectedness among African and African diasporic peoples.AD-MC-0042018-0024

A Woman's Prize2018-00052018There's an old story we have all forgotten. Shakespeare's infamous woman-tamer Petruccio has just remarried the sweet, demure Maria after he murdered his first wife, Kate. Maria reveals quickly that she is not all he deems her to be, and through understanding her own nature, sets out to claim her legacy against his oppression. A Joint-Capstone, directed by Sebastian Grube and written by Arianna Stucki, A Woman's Prize is a 30-minute play that utilizes song, Old Irish, and immersive storytelling. This play asks us all to consider an alternative narrative in which women reclaim and reshape their mythologies, remembering the female names and stories lost to history.AD-MC-0042018-0005

Patch 1.0 2018-00202018Melancholia can be described as an unresolvable state of longing, for something lost that can never be recovered or replaced. Studies into some diasporic groups refer to a melancholia that arises from being caught between the longing for their old home and estrangement from their new home. Patch 1.0 was a series of rehearsal experiments aiming to question the systems of belonging that are embedded in our cultures, with the goal of producing a show. This goal was not reached however, and what was instead produced was an archive of theatrical investigations into how interactivity and performance can be used to articulate these ideas.AD-MC-0042018-0020

Tango Palace, an abridged adaptation of the play by Cuban-American playwright Maria Irene Fornes, is an intimate exploration of two people and their relationship to one another within a strange and limited world. Leopold, an earnest youth, wakes to find himself locked in a room with Isidore, an androgynous clown, who rules with a sword and magically printed index cards. My project seeks to explore the relationship between social intimacy and the analog. It does so through a series of one-on-one portrait-drawing sessions with approximately 80 students from the NYUAD community, during which participants are invited to take on the role of observer and observed. These sessions produce physical artifacts in the form of drawings which will be taken in conjunction with written reflections on the conversations had during the interaction to produce a study of the components that generate meaning within social interactions. The documentation of these sessions will be accompanied by a book of compiled research and images on the topics of social interaction, intimacy, and their artistic resonances. Sült is a 30-minute one-man show that attempts to state the truth about my Hungarian identity through the embodiment of different characters. I am performing a series of short stories that tackle questions regarding socio-political responsibility, personal and inherited memories. The fictive and semi-fictive monologues are triggered through the ritual of frying chicken, a significant activity that reminds me of my mother. From Stonewall to Mar Mikhaël: A Case Study of Beirut Pride and the Implications of Pride in the Arab World2019-00162019AD-MC-0042019-0016
Scope and Contents
Over the past 50 years, Pride has grown from a localized celebration of queerness to a global gay phenomenon. Founded in 2017, Beirut Pride has been heralded as the first "Pride" in the Arab World. However, this raises the question what does "Pride" mean for Beirut and how does Beirut perform a "Pride"? In this paper, I argue that Beirut Pride has a dual effect of creating advocacy and safe spaces for Beiruti citizens while also reshaping Western narratives of the Middle East and Pride as a whole. By looking at Pride as a performance of queer visibility and community building both locally and in a larger global discourse, Beirut Pride calls into question the ways in which visibility is manifested while creating a physical space for the local community.Niko, Marika. memory is a partial victory over death2019-00222019AD-MC-0042019-0022

memory is a partial victory over death is a site-specific dance performance in the A5 Atrium that occurs over the course of sunset. Drawing upon the relationship between memory and materiality, the work invites the audience to witness two performers attempting to pursue, find, and ultimately reimagine each other's images on the window reflections that fade through time. The piece was inspired by how my grandmother, who has frequent memory loss, talks about her childhood memories. While I have an urge to materialize memories as a response to my fear of forgetting, the conversation with her allowed me to consider how memories can be remembered and worked on through immateriality. Facing the inevitable conditions of material disintegration, the two performers pay close attention to the urgency of the present as well as the repeated actions in order to archive memories.Sadarjoshi, Ankita. Theater architecture as an expressive language: A case study of theThéâtre du Soleil in La Cartoucherie de Vincennes 2019-00402019AD-MC-0042019-0040
Scope and Contents
The Cartoucherie, home of renowned theatre company Théâtre du Soleil since 1970, is located in the Bois de Vincennes, on the outskirts of central Paris. This paper argues that the layout and designation of the Cartoucherie as a physical space intersects with and underlays the work of the Théâtre du Soleil to raise consciousness on social issues such as migration - asking how human beings should live together in a culturally diverse and global society. The static view of architecture as the permanent presence of structures is complicated by the utilization of space for theatrical purposes. Events that take place within theatrical spaces allow the structure, the architecture, to become a laboratory for modelling society and experimenting with creative forms of reality, especially so when these spaces double as contact zones for multicultural communities, who are themselves products of movements through space as is the case with the Cartoucherie.Szantho, Orsolya. nature(.c)ode2019-00242019AD-MC-0042019-0024
Scope and Contents
The interactive installation "nature(.c)ode" is a piece that invites the audience on a sensory journey to explore the possibility of organic coexistence between nature and technology. Structured around two large wooden structures, the installation offers the audience an opportunity to test how their responses to technology change when usual, synthetic surfaces of interaction are replaced by natural textures and organic materials. Designed as a ten-minute experience, the installation guides the audience in the space through its light design. As the lights continually shift, moving from the front to the back, shining on different sides of the two central structures at different times, the audience is invited to move through the space in a similar manner. The two cuboid-shaped central pieces, which serve as the interfaces of interaction, reflect a similar linear progression. By touching different wooden and plant attachments on these structures, the audience plays different tones, creating music together. While the front side of the first structure is covered in more technological tones, these gradually soften towards the back, where they are even accompanied by a light-interaction when the interaction occurs through plants.Wilkes, Simon. Spectra2019-00342019AD-MC-0042019-0034
Scope and Contents
Spectra' is a comic book- play adapted from Stan Lee and Jack Kirby's Amazing Fantasy #15, the origin story of Marvel Comics' character, The Amazing Spider- Man. Conceived as a 'comicbook- play,' 'Spectra' was developed through a series of rehearsal laboratories and writing workshops. Spectra explores playwrighting as a collaborative process and engages the visual form of comic books as a mode of playwrighting. In doing so, 'Spectra' experiments with ways of developing script, where text functions as an icon for language and image, as in the form of comic books. 'Spectra' explores the effects of internal and external violence upon the fractured psyche of a superhero seeking to reconcile the trauma of the past with their desire to wield power in the name of a greater good. By engaging with studies on feminism, tricksterism, transformative justice and queer theory, 'Spectra' seeks to question patriarchal notions of masculinity in order to redefine what it means to be a superhero. 'Spectra' seeks to reframe the vision of the superhero as the sole author of violence in the name of an absolute moral authority and proposea model for the superhero as existing within and accountable to a community of care.Arun, Archita. SAFAR| सफ़र2020-0039AD-MC-0042020-0039
Scope and Contents
SAFAR| सफ़र is a site-specific walk that investigates female sacrifice and performance of femininity across three generations of women in my family: paati→ amma and chiti→ me. By understanding my body as a site that has inherited language, memories and music, I seek to re(connect) with my amma, chiti and paati through this work. SAFAR is my journey through spiritual time and physical space that employs the practices of oral history, documentary theater and embodied writing to create a discontinuous historical narrative highlighting these three women and their sacrifices . Nine participants are invited to meditate, recuperate and celebrate in the space as they descend together. The walk is location-driven and ends in front of a 120 by 57 centimeter storage unit that became sacred to me during my four years here. The only objects left behind during this SAFAR are the sacrificial objects brought by participants into the space.

Author provided keywords: site-specific, femininity, intergenerational, female sacrifice, music, basementAlejandro Paez Gonzalez, Carlos. Safety, Impact, Communication, Expressivity, and Agency: Finding New Ways to Understand Participation in Live Performance2020-00402020AD-MC-0042020-0040
Scope and Contents
Every audience member in every event of live performance always participates in some way in creating the full theatrical event. Considering the many experiments that have taken place in the art world over the past century, it seems that there is not yet a clear vocabulary for speaking clearly about audience participation. By drawing from both theoretical research and having carried out several practical art experiments, this paper proposes a new model for understanding participation based on five distinct aspects: Safety, Impact, Communication, Expressivity, and Agency. This capstone project also brings together lessons from the field of Game Design by exploring the ideas of Fun, Flow, Meaningful Play, Verbs, Objects and Systems. This capstone also consisted of a 2 hour long Game-Theater piece titled "Paperclips and Power". This piece is a post-apocalyptic nation-builder simulator where up to 30 audience members must find a way to survive in a world where the main resource is paperclips. The piece functions through several mechanics that create a system that allows for emergent stories to take place, allowing the audience to express their political views through the actions that they take during the piece.

Scope and Contents
This theater practice capstone aimed to create a devised performance from the stories of two industrial disasters: the 1931 Hawks Nest Tunnel Tragedy and the 1984 Bhopal Gas Leak. A single company operated both the West Virginia tunnel project and the Bhopal gas plant: Union Carbide. The performance was built out of documentary materials from Bhopal and a poetry collection entitled 'The Book of the Dead' by the poet Muriel Rukeyser which chronicles the West Virginia disaster. The project explores how the documents and poetry can be embodied, bringing to life the historical linkages between the tragedies, exploring and interrogating the corporate practices that allow these disasters to occur with minimal consequences. The capstone also explores how performance can be used as a medium to mobilise the voices of the dead in order to confront systems of oppression and participate in acts of collective healing.

Scope and Contents
Novena is an original autobiographical performance piece exploring the impact of religious social scripts on the performance of the female body. Borrowing aesthetic imagery from Catholic performance practices and rituals, Novena depicts a recluse bride who isolates herself in a church to atone for her sins. In the piece, she attempts to reconcile her feelings of transgressional guilt in contention with her instinctual pleasures. This piece is devised from a combination of archival text from my journals, observational research conducted in Manila, Philippines, and anecdotal contributions from various women of color. Exploring the impact of religious structures on a woman's coming of age through prose, song, and dance, Novena dramatizes the process of interrogating and outgrowing institutional beliefs ingrained in the female psyche.

Scope and Contents
"Deliberately and In Cash" is a 30 minutes virtual performance that explores the practice of collecting Diya (blood money) in the Gulf, and how this practice evolved and persisted over time from pre-islamic times till today. The piece looks closely at how the practice exists today in the gulf by featuring the case of Hidaya Al Sultan and her Diya which is considered one of the highest ever collected in the history of the practice in the region. Hidaya, the Kuwaiti journalist was murdered in 1991 for writing an article about women of a certain tribe working as paid dancers. The piece argues that was makes this practice persist is that it provides a mechanism to distribute the responsibly and punishment of the crime on the society that allowed the murder to happen, and invites the audience to think about how this mechanism can be used in order to reduce potential violent acts.

pillowfort is an interactive theatrical project about radical care. Taking Shaheen Bagh as its point of investigation, the piece attempts to shake the academic boundaries around the discourse about citizenship to aim at having a more visceral conversation about what it feels like to be Indian in the wake of hateful, discriminatory citizenship laws coming into existence. Can we go beyond the intellectual and the academic, and see ourselves being a community that centers care in the face of fear and apprehension? Can we show up for each other, even when we don't fully understand? Can we remember what it's like to be together above everything else? Can I hold your hand through it all?Engineering Division Projects2014-2021Civil EngineeringCostales, David Ponce and Juma, Joseph Bwerwa. Design of Economical Rapid Deployable Structures2014-0032982014AD-MC-0042014-0032
Scope and Contents
Major: Civil Engineering
Abstract: Joseph Juma. The forceful displacement of people due to warfare, natural disasters or even persecution presents a pressing need for immediate housing solutions. Presently available rapid deployable structures are part of the solution to this problem. Even so, due to the limited resources that refugees have at hand, these structures are either too expensive or do not meet the pressing needs of the issue. For this reason the scope of this project is the design of an economical rapid deployable structure in an attempt to provide a fast response to refugee situations.
The present report documents the design process towards the final proposed structure. For the scope of this report an economical rapid deployable structure is a sub-division of structural systems characterized by the ability to be assembled, dissembled and transported to a different site without losing its functional and structural characteristics. Additionally the design must remaining cost efficient.
The present document explores different techniques of design, as well as a variety of materials. The design process continues with geometrical and material optimization through an iterative approach. Numerous trials in computer aided design software are shown in the optimization process as well as empirical testing of the cross section.
Scope and Contents
Major: Civil Engineering
Abstract: David Consales. Refugee situations call for immediate housing needs. With the numbers of refugees rising worldwide aid organizations have limited resources to assist efficiently and uniformly. Given that the problems behind the displacement of people are difficult to tackle, economical rapid deployable structures are a necessity. For this reason this project goes through the design process of such structure from conception to the manufacturing of a live scale prototype. The final design was evaluated against several criteria including structural stability, cost, transportability, portability, ease and speed of deployment and of collapse, protection from the environment and aesthetics. Additionally the proposed solution effectively solves problems such as overcrowding providing comfortable housing. The shape allows for modular, close packing in a macro scale. This allows concentration of structures without overcrowding the living space. The structural framework is designed of aluminum with a resistant and light cross section providing durability, strength and making the structure light. Additionally the material can be reutilized for other structures as a recycled, modular component. The textile exterior is designed of Polycotton canvas making it cool and waterproof. The proposed solution has efficiently met most of the set benchmarks with a structurally stable, low-cost, rapid deployable structure.DesignStructural stabilityCivil EngineeringCost effectivenessSustainabilityConstructionRefugeesYang, Songyishu. Design for Sustainable Urban Agriculture in Abu Dhabi2014-0037962014AD-MC-0042014-0037
Scope and Contents
Major: Civil Engineering
Abstract: In an age of booming population and rapid urbanization, the lack of agricultural labor, shortage of arable land, and the increasing dominance of large food corporations all pose great challenges on the sustainability of urban food system. Urban agriculture might be a potential solution to these challenges. Farming in urban areas addresses at least three critical issues facing urban food infrastructure: food security, food quality and energy use as represented by food miles. Additionally, urban farming is socially beneficial in terms of ecological health, community development, and food awareness. In current practice, however, urban agriculture lacks three crucial building blocks: 1. Empirical economic studies to prove its economic viability (Glaeser). 2. Scalable business model to attract potential stakeholders from both public and private sectors. 3. Engineering smart and innovative farms that are adaptive to urban setting. This project is offers a design for a well engineered urban farms that are adaptive to the conditions and constraints of cities. Innovative water management, structural, environmental and traffic systems that are compatible with existing standards of safety and comfort, are proposed. The design allows a cost that will be competitive in the marketplace and acceptable to government.HydroponicsCivil EngineeringTrafficFoodWaterAgriculture/FarmsEnergyUrban agricultureAndargie, Maendot Solomon, and Mingzhu Hou. Rapid Replacement Bridge Design2015-002734032015AD-MC-0042015-0027
Scope and Contents
Major: Civil Engineering
Abstract, Maedot Andargie: We are designing a rapid replacement bridge located in Upstate New York. The design philosophy we are following is American Association of State Highway and Transportation Officials (AASHTO) and Load and Resistance Factor Design (LRFD). The AASHTO LRFD Bridge Design Specifications are intended for use in the design, evaluation, and rehabilitation of bridges, and are mandated by the Federal Highway Administration (FHWA) for use on all bridges using federal funding. These Specifications employ the Load and Resistance Factor Design (LRFD) methodology using factors developing from current statistical knowledge of loads and structural performance. The computer software programs that we are using include SAP2000 and AutoCAD 2015. SAP2000 is an integrated software for structural analysis design developed by Computers & Structures, Inc. AutoCAD is a design and documentation software developed by Autodesk, Inc. We use SAP2000 to do analysis and design and AutoCAD to produce the final drawing. The calculation methods that we adopt include the method of joints, design for tension, design for compression, design for joints, concrete footing design, pavement design, and traffic analysis and design. The outcome of the capstone project will be a complete design of a replacement bridge, with specifications in a drawing produced using AutoCAD.

Designing Sustainable, Urban Housing in Abu Dhabi, UAE 2016-002080082016The aim of this capstone project is to design a sustainable, urban housing complex. For this project, we have chosen to focus on UAE and in particular, the emirate of Abu Dhabi. This is because Abu Dhabi is one of the most expensive cities in the world in terms of rent and property prices. For this reason, it is difficult to obtain decent and affordable housing. In 2006, the UAE was announced as the nation with the largest per capita Ecological Footprint.After a close examination of the current housing situation in the UAE, we chose to focus our project in the Mussafah area. We will design an urban complex that will be sustainable, aesthetically pleasing and foster a sense of community amongst its residents. Our project will focus on four key areas: structural design, foundation design, transportation design and sustainability. The building will be designed to withstand all the relevant design loads and to meet the strength limits and the serviceability limits outlined in the ACI and AISCI Steel Construction Manual. It is also aimed to have a sustainability rating of LEED Silver and Estidama Pearl 2.AD-MC-0042016-0020

Water Treatment Facility in the Northern Emirates 2017-00122017Maryam AlMansoori, James Gardner: The Northern Emirates faces unique and challenging water resourcing; with some of the most limited availability in ground water, and a water usage of twice the world average at 550 L per person per day, the UAE must have highly efficient waste water recycling systems. This project outlines a detailed design of a recycled wastewater treatment facility treating 225,000 m3 of water per day located in the Northern Emirates of the UAE. The scope of the design includes the water treatment process, structural housing, and road access ways with parking facilities. This document includes design drawings and analysis alongside project management methods undertaken to complete the project. The design chosen is a multistage water treatment process modelled on a traditional sewage treatment plant; wastewater undergoes primary, secondary and tertiary treatment in the form of coagulation, flocculation and sedimentation, a plug flow reactivated sludge line, and dual media filtration plus UV treatment. These processes were selected as best practices across the industry. Treated water is at a standard to allow for restricted irrigation as per the Dubai Municipality codes. This water is ready for distribution and use for irrigation in non-raw crops and landscaping.Paul Ha: The UAE must have highly efficient waste water recycling systems. This project outlines a recycled wastewater treatment facility treating 225,000 m3 of water per day located in the Northern Emirates. The scope of the design includes the water treatment process, structural housing, and road access with parking facilities. The design chosen is a multistage water treatment process modelled on a traditional sewage treatment plant; wastewater undergoes primary, secondary and tertiary treatment in the form of coagulation, flocculation and sedimentation, a plug flow reactivated sludge line, and dual media filtration plus UV treatment. These processes were selected as best practices across the industry. Treated water is at a standard to allow for restricted irrigation as per the Dubai Municipality codes. This water is ready for distribution and use for irrigation in non-raw crops and landscaping. Designs were carried out in accordance with the Abu Dhabi Municipal Standards, the Dubai Municipality Standards, Environmental Protection Agency (EPA), American Society of Civil Engineering (ASCE), the American Concrete Institute (ACI) and the American Institute of Steel Construction (AISC) codes.AD-MC-0042017-0012

Sustainable Low-income Housing Design2018-00472018The project had two main objectives which were to produce a low cost and sustainable design for a 1 story house in Abu Dhabi. Through extensive research, material testing and conscious architectural design which efficiently uses the space allocated to the project these two objectives were met. The proposed house design costs 47% less than an average house of a similar size in the USA, excluding labor cost since it varies greatly across the world. Moreover, the materials proposed and tested provide a more sustainable and low cost alternative to the conventional building materials used. Not only do they decrease the running costs of the house, but they also reduce the amount of energy consumed by the household mainly through decreasing cooling costs.AD-MC-0042018-0047

The increasing costs in all aspects of manufacturing have led to significant increase in construction costs. This, alongside with a number of environmental concerns over the traditional construction practices, calls for an active investigation in new and innovative ways of designing structures. Thus, comfortable study conditions for the occupants are met while boosting the building performance and minimizing its carbon footprint. Room Design for Effective Evacuation under Escape Panic2019-00582019AD-MC-0042019-0058
Scope and Contents
The standards of evacuation design have not changed much in the past half a century. Any progress that is being made is so insignificant in value that the adoption of the ideas globally is not a priority. The 21st century is about minute detail optimization to achieve maximum efficiency. It is this search that is explained in the capstone where we try and understand the details and try to morph obstacles so as to help us achieve designs that lead to the goals we have set. In order to do this, inspiration from Dirk Helbing's work from 2001 was taken that discusses the possibility of improving evacuation rates by introducing obstacles in the pathway of an exit. The project delves further into this concept by trying to employ one or all of the following; deep neural networks, reinforced learning, and VISSIM. Based on the results obtained by Helbing, we expect that there is a certain design of obstacles that can improve the flow of pedestrians in an emergency evacuation. To answer this question, our research found that introducing funnel-shaped exits with a central kite-shaped obstacle produce the most efficient room design for evacuation.Okoth, Victor, Raitis Pekuss, and Ylber Roka. Analysis of PWPB Algorithm for Incremental CAV Market Penetration Rates2019-00482019AD-MC-0042019-0048
Scope and Contents
Connected and Autonomous Vehicles are widely expected to revolutionize urban transportation. Their increased presence is expected to mitigate traffic congestions, environmental hazards presented by vehicles, reduce the number of accidents while also increasing the throughput of traffic networks. However, these benefits will become apparent gradually corresponding to the gradual market penetration rates of CAVs. This paper studies traffic intersection control of mixed vehicle traffic that consists of CAVs as well as human driven vehicles. Specifically, we analyze the Position Back Pressure algorithm which is studied to outperform SCOOT - a widely accepted real-time adaptive traffic control method - in terms of delays for both low and high demand traffic conditions. We address the underlying assumption in the algorithm that all the information about vehicles in the network is known. Such a scenario is only possible with a 100% market penetration of CAVs and, therefore, does not reflect the real life conditions. To address this we vary the amount of known and, consequently, estimated data, which is then fed into the traffic simulation. As the result of this we can understand how sensitive is PWBP to inputs with varying levels of real and estimated data.Avci, Dogukan, and Meredith Raymer. Design of an Optimal Public Transit Network Using Evolutionary Algorithms2020-00482020AD-MC-0042020-0048
Scope and Contents
Public transit design has been optimized through minimization of an objective function made up of the user and agency costs. However, societal costs, such as the environmental impact of congestion, has not been fully studied. With increasing environmental concerns, assessing the external cost of all transportation modes on the environment is important. In this paper, a cost function was created that takes into account the agency and user costs as well as the environmental impacts of the transportation system. Through use of covariance matrix adaptation evolution strategy, a methodology for the design of public transit networks that minimizes this cost was created and implemented using SUMO(Version 1.3.1; Institute of Transportation Systems, 2018) to reflect traffic scenarios that were input to the cost function for 5 routes and a headway of 10 minutes. When the optimization was initiated with random stops, a minimum value of $3,418,128 was found. When the optimization was started with sequential stops, a minimum value of $1,087,693 was found. Both are higher than the benchmark solution of $734,395. Since this methodology did not find a solution more optimal than analytical methods, further research on the applicability of CMA-ES to transit design is needed.

Waste is defined as the unwanted materials produced by any activity. Waste-to-energy technologies provide the necessary tools to redefine waste as a raw material or resource, that plays a crucial role in the development of a circular waste economy. Currently, landfilling is the most widely practiced waste management strategy which has a large and wide range of environmental impacts. This project proposes a sustainable WTE facility design with MIPG as its core technology to convert MSW into energy and slag. The circular economy created through the facility mimics that of the environment in which resources discarded by one organism are used by another organism. The proposed solution can be retrofitted on top of existing waste management or WTE systems. The design aims to transform waste management into a sustainable and ecologically friendly process. The target location selected for the plant is in the Emirate of Abu Dhabi. The design of the WTE plant includes aspects of structure, transportation, and waste processing which are required to produce energy from waste. The design is further supported by an Environmental Impact Assessment that evaluates compliance of the plant with UAE rules and regulations.

Three Dimensional (3D) Printing With Low-Carbon Cement-Based Materials 2021-00672021AD-MC-0042021-0067
Scope and Contents
There is an increasing interest in the 3D printing of cementitious construction materials among civil engineering fields. Recent research has defined 3D printing as one of the fastest, most efficient and most cost-effective methods of building. 3D printing ensures quick repeatability of the construction process as well as lower labor costs since a machine now does the work. While this new technology has many advantages, it also poses a great risk to the environment due to the high use of Ordinary Portland Cement (OPC) in the 3D printing construction industry. Approximately 900 kg of CO2 are emitted for every production of 1 ton of cement. This makes up more than 8% of the man-made emissions of CO2, a potent greenhouse gas. This capstone project aims to find alternative sustainable solutions to OPC that would meet the 3D printing standards as defined by American Standard of Testing and Materials (ASTM) as well as the Portland Cement Association while also reducing the amount of CO2 emission required during production. Moreover, the project will involve 3D printing different prototypes using the proposed alternative cementitious materials and testing and optimizing the materials' strength, flow and microstructure.
Author provided keywords: 3D, Ordinary, Limeston, Calcinated Clay, Sustainable, NanoclaySohn, Sungmin. Designing Graphical Visualization of the Maximum Congestion Propagation Speed at the Network2021-00622021AD-MC-0042021-0062
Scope and Contents
The Macroscopic Fundamental Diagram (MFD) is a graphical representation that relates the weighted flow and density of the urban network. Among several uses of the MFD for network traffic analysis, this capstone project focuses on the slopes of the MFD's two branches. The left branch of the MFD represents the free-flow speed of the network while the right branch shows the speed at which the congestion propagates and/or dissipates in the network. Since the introduction of MFD, the main focus of the estimation methods of the MFD was on the left branch (free-flow speed). As a result, the right branch of the MFD representing the congestion propagation and/or dissipation speed in the network has not yet been fully comprehended. The understanding of the right branch of the MFD is important because the maximization of the dissipation speed at the network is desired to mitigate traffic congestion. Hence, my goal for this capstone is to design a graphical visualization tool that could show the relationship between the links and the network in terms of the congestion propagation speed.

Major: Computer Engineering
Abstract: Integrated circuits are extensively and universally utilized. Their applications vary from consumer products to mission critical electronics, creating a spectrum of susceptibility towards defects that accompany the manufacturing process. Thus, each electronic chip undergoes testing that determines whether the chip is defective or defect-free upon being manufactured. The testing process encompasses the application of carefully selected test patterns that produce an output which is observed and compared to an expected output. There are number of fault models that guide the testing process. This project aims to create an Automatic Test Pattern Generation Tool, a software tool, targeting the transition delay fault model. The test patterns generated by the software tool will then be used in the hardware component of the project. The test patterns will be applied to a desired circuit uploaded to an FPGA board to verify the output responses. The output will be verified by observing the output response to the expected output given the circuit under test. This is the test application phase of the project.Testing chipsTransitional delay faultsComputer engineeringAutomatic Test Pattern Generation (ATPG)Chen, Jeffrey. Abstract: This capstone project aims to design an intelligent framework for addressing such challenging issues from ever-growing 3D datasets. We intend to develop a system that takes 3D objects and presents them in various robust analytical models. Specifically, the proposed framework seeks to develop a cohesive and consistent shape analysis pipeline system that can correctly identify and preserve the important features of shapes. These important shape features will be processed and modelled into shape correspondences for 3D shapes registration, shape descriptors to evaluate the geometric similarities between shapes for 3D shape retrieval, and a clustering paradigm for discerning parts for 3D shape segmentation. The overall shape analysis pipeline is intended to deliver a standard process for capturing 3D object information from different analytical perspectives for further field-specific interests, such as categorization, detection, and representation. These perspectives are based in one-to-one, one-to-all, and introspective object comparisons that provide deep yet generally important understanding of shape features, opening them to further studies in matching, relating, and labelling.Computer engineeringGeometry3DAlhosani, Hamdan Ahmed, and Hazem Ibrahim. SFLL-HD Logic Locking Framework2018-00442018IC netlists are valuable assets by nature since it holds the basic design of electronic chips. However, the process of manufacturing chips is complicated as there are multiple threats from untrusted users and fabricators. Logic Locking has been perceived as a promising and reliable defense mechanism against intellectual property piracy, reverse engineering and overbuilding attacks. Stripped Functionality Logic Locking, or SFLL, is proven to be resilient to all types of hardware attacks on a netlist in the paper Provably Secure Logic Locking: From Theory To Practice. [1] SFLL strips some of the functionality of the circuit and hides it in the form of a secret key(s). Thereby, rendering the on-chip implementation functionally different than the original netlist. Currently, implementing any logic locking framework on a given netlist is complicated. In this paper, we propose a software framework that implements SFLL on any Verilog netlist. The software will produce a secured netlist that can thwart multiple attacks such as, SAT attack, removal attack and sanitization attack. In addition, verification of the correct implementation of SFLL security will be completed to ensure the validity of the software framework.AD-MC-0042018-0044

In the field of neuroScience, there has been recent research on the reconstruction of visual working memory during the representation of items from the activity of neuronal populations, particularly focusing on oscillatory activity in the alpha band (8-12 Hz). The objective of this project is a real time (i.e., less than 500ms) functional hardware implementation of memory reconstruction by feeding Magnetoencephalography (MEG) or electroencephalography (EEG) of neural oscillations to a Nexys 4 Artix-7 Field Programmable Gate Array (FPGA) Trainer Board. This can be realized by converting the time-series to frequencies in the alpha region. In this proposal, a Hilbert transform with an iterative-pipelined hybrid architecture is chosen to achieve the most optimal results in terms of speed, complexity, and available hardware resources amongst various other solutions.Gamil, Homer, and Steffen Holter. Advancements in the field of big data have brought on the need for new tools to understand the underlying properties of all this information. Data visualization presents one of the most productive ways of tackling this problem. Our solution focuses on extracting the key features that effectively describe the dataset and visualizing this information on an interactive display.The fundamental aspect of this design is creating a means for high performance dimensionality reduction. Whilst many solutions exist that use principle component analysis (PCA) or non-parametric algorithms, they struggle with generalizing to more complex manifolds and sparse data. Therefore, our approach instead makes use of a deep learning architecture. By creating a complex neural network hierarchy, we aim to optimize the solution and create a data describing mapping that corresponds to the intrinsic dimensionality of the data itself.Annor, Prince, Sampanna Bhattarai, and Alison Waterman. Collaborative Control Design for a Drone Swarm2020-0462020AD-MC-0042020-0046
Scope and Contents
Simultaneous localization and mapping (SLAM) allows a drone to navigate and perceive its surrounding environment. In the past, drone systems have employed many technologies to perform relative localization, including various motion detection systems. With the reduced cost of high-resolution cameras and increased computational capabilities of on-board computers, computer vision techniques are now being investigated as additive sensors to inertial measurement unit systems. Several computer vision techniques employ fiducial markers with a recognizable pattern to perform pose estimation between the camera and the attached markers in the collaborating drones. This concept is used for relative drone localization while each drone performs SLAM using cameras, LiDAR and an IMU. In this project, a multi-sensor integration of a LiDAR sensor and a spherical-lens camera is used along with a wireless ad-hoc communication channel to assist in a collaborative control design for a drone swarm for visual aerial coverage purposes. Using simulations, a real-time Voronoi tessellation of the area in NYUAD's Robotics lab for two of the designed drones flying at the same height is also derived and the area coverage is achieved by commanding each drone to move towards the centroid of its assigned Region of Responsibility.
Author provided keywords: Visual Area Coverage, Simultaneous Localization and Mapping, Drone SwarmLoy, Brandon, and Daria Zahaleanu. Private Reality Framework Design2020-00532020AD-MC-0042020-0053
Scope and Contents
In the digital world, the average user works with a large amount of personal data on a daily basis that is processed into countless websites and applications, which include social media, banking, education and medical services. This data, encrypted or unencrypted, is often stored in the user's personal devices. When these devices are connected to the internet, there is an opportunity for third parties to digitally access such data without the user's permission, which compromises privacy. In the first half of 2019, more than 3,800 publicly-disclosed data breaches in companies have been recorded, exposing 4.1 billion compromised records. This project serves to build a framework using a head-mounted display (HMD) to enable privacy-preserving applications by allowing the user to handle his or her unencrypted data without using digital communication. An application was developed in the HMD in which data transmission was carried out over the visual spectrum, using photons as information carriers to eliminate the need for digital connections. It enables the user to scan visually encoded ciphertext on a computer screen and view the plaintext in the HMD.
Author provided keywords:, cybersecurity, encryption, privacy, communication, ocr, qr, visual spectrum analog communication, head mount display, decryption, ciphertext, Android applicationAswani, Nishant and Barkin Simsek. ramen: Design and Development of a Raft Consensus Algorithm Coupled With a IEEE 802.11 Based Mesh Network for Embedded Systems2021-00662021AD-MC-0042021-0066
Scope and Contents
Consensus is a fundamental problem in fault tolerant distributed systems and involves multiple nodes arriving at a coordinated decision. Reaching a consensus is challenging if the system is dynamic and makes decisions in real time (such as in autonomous vehicles and mobile sensor networks). Consensus algorithms ensure that a cluster of devices can cooperatively complete its tasks even if the cluster loses its leader. However, when a consensus algorithm is built upon a typical hub spoke network topology, the algorithm may be rendered useless if the singular network access point fails. A mesh network is a non hierarchical topology for local networks where devices can directly communicate amongst themselves without a central node for coordination, making them resilient to a single point of failure. Our capstone project implements Raft, a distributed consensus algorithm, atop a mesh network for use in low power embedded systems. We developed an open source software library and prototyped it on a custom printed circuit board. Our compiled software library consumes 0.33MB of flash memory and is capable of supporting over 100 nodes. During elections, it takes an average of 300ms to elect a new leader with insignificant variation as the network size grows.
Author provided keywords: consensus, mesh, raft, embedded, IEEE 802.11, 42Jeyakumar, Praggya. Design of a Machine Learning System to Quantify Haptic Experience2021-00592021AD-MC-0042021-0059
Scope and Contents
The objective of the capstone project is to design a system to quantify aspects of user haptic experience using brain signals from EEG. We aim to use EEG data collected from a previous study at the Applied Interactive Multimedia lab (AIMlab) to quantify haptic experience using EEG data and machine learning, in particular the haptic delay. Our final machine learning model achieves an accuracy of 83.2 ± 0.573% (reported within a 95% confidence level) in detection of a haptic delay in the user experience from a single trial EEG data stream using a light gradient boosting machine. Using EEG data to quantify haptic experience renders our model more accurate, and objective, which will have many applications in designing haptic electronics, attention rehabilitation, and neuroscience research.

Scope and Contents
With more than 1.2 billion cars on the roads worldwide, traffic congestion is one of the biggest transportation problems in cities. Congestion has serious economic costs; for example, in the United States alone, the freight sector loses more than $74 billion annually due to congestion, and costs to individual drivers exceed $88 billion. Intelligent Transportation Systems (ITS) produce large amounts of traffic data that can be used to monitor, assess, and improve the performance of those same transportation systems. Since generated data are largely abstract, unstructured, and high-dimensional, it is difficult for researchers to interpret and analyze them. Visualization tools can effectively represent data, reveal hidden patterns, and enable to combine human capabilities with machine intelligence in deducing new patterns. The product of this Capstone project is a novel easy-to-use, scalable visualization tool that preprocesses and organizes traffic data, aggregates them into selected levels of abstraction (links, nodes, or hexagon grid cells of variable size), and visualizes their properties in effective ways at user request.

Abstract: This final report is made for the Senior Capstone Design Project of New York University Abu Dhabi. It outlines a proposed solution to overcome a large part of the difficulties that hearing-impaired people face when they need to communicate. As a second benefit, the solution also facilitates education of sign-language. It also contains information related to the progress in implementing the solution.
Currently there are no affordable solutions on the market, and previous results are either lacking in quality or highly limited in usability. With the help of the next generation of hardware sensors, the proposed solution is aimed to greatly improve on these shortcomings while bearing an affordable price tag. In addition, the proposed solution is the first known of its kind that focuses on Arabic sign language, an area where current awareness is low and the room for improvement is vast.
The solution consists of an affordable hardware sensor available on the market and software algorithms designed in order to process the data acquired by the sensor. Together they set up a system that is robust, user-friendly and also possesses the potential for a wide reach through its low price point.Schools/EducationHearing impairmentsDisabilitiesCommunicationSign languageKinect (Programmable controller)Electrical engineeringAbe, Yilkal. FPGA Based Network for Fast Microprocessor Simulation2016-002679922016Simulation and verification are important stages in the manufacturing of modern day microprocessors. As digital design systems increase in complexity, the task of running an effective software simulation of these systems becomes computationally expensive and prohibitive. Such designs contain billions of transistors, while a typical workload executes in several million-clock cycles. Thus, workload software simulation to completion is infeasible in lower levels of abstraction. In order to bypass the slow software simulation speed, a simulation using a network of FPGAs is proposed. FPGAs are reconfigurable devices that can implement a digital design. They have hardware speed and reliability and don't incur on the large price required for ASIC design. This makes FPGAs ideal for implementing simulation of digital devices. However, the size of the digital design that each FPGA can simulate depends on the limited number of configurable blocks available and the total number of IO located on its banks. In this project, a network of FPGAs will be developed that will efficiently simulate a modern microprocessor. A scalable system was built and a simulation speed up of 20x software simulation has been achieved.AD-MC-0042016-0026

Development of a Red-Team-In-a-Box hardware platform2017-00142017The modernization of critical infrastructure has enabled advanced monitoring and control capabilities, through the inclusion of microprocessor computing systems using commercial-off-the-shelf integrated circuits and commonly used protocols. Therefore, these systems are susceptible to cyber-attacks. The aim of the project was to identify possible entry points in order to fortify said systems. An advanced sensing platform was developed, which could facilitate physical penetration testing of industrial control systems. The platform had its own processing capabilities and operated on a battery in order to achieve autonomy. The sensors used were integrated on a custom-built PCB. The goal was to maximize the information collected by the platform, while minimizing the power consumption and the cost. The resulting platform was able to fingerprint industrial devices, eavesdrop on communications and collect other information needed to generate a detailed map of the surrounding environment of the industrial control system.AD-MC-0042017-0014

Design of Secure and Testable Chips2017-00202017Integrated circuit production facilities cost upward of $1billion to build and maintain, which is why semiconductor companies are shifting into a more effective fabless model. In this system, chip designers create circuit floorplans, but do not manufacture the chips in house. Instead, external foundries produce the chip. The purpose of the capstone project was to conduct an implementation from RTL to silicon, while addressing concerns of a fabless design process. As most chip foundries are substitutable, the IP of chip designs is the core value driver in the industry. Thus, the project focused on integrating new functionalities with an existing design of an ARM CortexM0 chip. To ensure that the chip is easily testable after manufacturing, we enriched it with a JTAG test module for functional and scan chain testing. Since providing the chip design to foundries around the world raises concerns about illegal chip overproduction and tampering, we applied the SARLock logic encryption method. Lastly, we conducted rigorous physical implementation. We implemented the physical chip from the RTL description of the ARM CortexM0 Microprocessor to the GDSII format.AD-MC-0042017-0020
Scope and Contents
Integrated circuit production facilities cost upward of $1billion to build and maintain, which is why semiconductor companies are shifting into a more effective fabless model. In this system, chip designers create circuit floorplans, but do not manufacture the chips in house. Instead, external foundries produce the chip. The purpose of the capstone project was to conduct an implementation from RTL to silicon, while addressing concerns of a fabless design process. As most chip foundries are substitutable, the IP of chip designs is the core value driver in the industry. Thus, the project focused on integrating new functionalities with an existing design of an ARM CortexM0 chip. To ensure that the chip is easily testable after manufacturing, we enriched it with a JTAG test module for functional and scan chain testing. Since providing the chip design to foundries around the world raises concerns about illegal chip overproduction and tampering, we applied the SARLock logic encryption method. Lastly, we conducted rigorous physical implementation. We implemented the physical chip from the RTL description of the ARM CortexM0 Microprocessor to the GDSII format.Aberra, Aida and Siba Siddique. Automated Fetal kick Monitoring Belt2018-00382018Monitoring fetal well-being is a crucial procedure in modern obstetrics. Among the many methods of checking fetal well-being, fetal movement detection is widely used to identify changes in fetal activity and reduce the possibility of fetal distress and stillbirth. Doctors also recommend pregnant women to use fetal kick counting as a way to monitor their baby's health beginning from the third trimester. Fetal movement counting is a method by which pregnant women quantify the movements they feels to assess the condition of their baby. While fetal kick can vary on daily bases, a significant deviation from the normally expected value, which is 10 kicks in 2 hours, indicates that the woman should consult her medical provider. While fetal movement can be observed using ultrasound imaging, a non-invasive and home based monitoring system is still in development to enable pregnant women perform self-administrated monitoring. In this project, an Automated Fetal Kick system will developed by integrating an array of force sensors in a maternal belt, and sends information about the number of kicks and the frequency to a cell phone via wireless communication.AD-MC-0042018-0038

Improving Wi-Fi for High Density Environments2018-00402018Due to the improvements made to the wireless standard in the past two decades, wireless has overtaken wired as the dominant form of communication today. To meet the future data traffic needs, the Wi-Fi standard of today will need to be significantly improved in both the quality of service and security. Since the number of Wi-Fi networks in both residential and enterprise environments is increasing rapidly, the interference between geographically collocated networks is becoming one of the significant issues of Wi-Fi. happens because access points of different Wi-Fi networks operate independently. A device located at the overlap of two or more networks may not be able to receive data because access points from various networks are interfering. This is called the hidden terminal problem. Given that the hardware processing capabilities are increasing, in the future, the signal detection threshold of CSMA/CA may become a dynamic value. In this paper, we propose using a dynamic CSMA/CA signal detection energy thresholds instead of the currently static one. The signal detection threshold will utilize the signal strength received from the access point to solve the hidden terminal problem more effectively.AD-MC-0042018-0040
Scope and Contents

A device located at the overlap of two or more networks may not be able to receive data because access points from various networks are interfering. This is called the hidden terminal problem. Handwriting Learning Platform2018-00392018Many studies have shown that incorporating haptic stimulus into education tools expedites the handwriting learning process and improves retention. The first prototype of the haptic handwriting device was developed in the Applied Interactive Media Lab and experiments conducted on the device showed the effectiveness of the tool in teaching non-Arabic speakers how to write Arabic letters. The setup consisted of a Novint Falcon Device, which manipulated a pen moving over the letters displayed on a monitor. Feedback collected from these experiments pointed to some hardware shortcomings, which showed the device had significant room for improvement. Feedback fit the following three categories; obstruction of line of sight, limited usability to right-handed users and different planes of operation of the display and pen movement. This capstone project is aimed at revising the hardware design and software GUI to tackle these problems and to develop a ready to use haptic learning device for children. The second-generation device will then be tested through a revised experimental procedure and the results will be compared to the results collected with the first-generation device.AD-MC-0042018-0039
