Design of a Jacket System Displaying Thermal and Vibration Feedback2019-00552019AD-MC-0042019-0055
Scope and Contents
In this capstone project, the design of a thermo-vibration actuation jacket is proposed to display synchronized vibration and thermal cues for interpersonal communication. There has been several thermal jackets on the market most of which focuses on controlling ambient temperature. In this report, a vibro-thermal actuation jacket is designed where simultaneous simulation of temperature and vibration is possible. Major implementations included wiring up the jacket and including the vibration and thermal actuators with control board for the actuators. The wiring of the jacket was successful and thermal and vibration activation was successful in the process. The psycho physicalstudy enabled us to determine the perceived thermal states (cold, cool, neutral,warm and hot) that corresponds to an actual temperature within 15 to 40 degree Celsius temperature range.Afzal, Muhammad Muneeb, Fahad Ahmad, Muhammad Osama Khan, and Fathur Said. Deep Learning Approaches for Self-Driving cars in an Adversarial Environment2019-00512019AD-MC-0042019-0051
Scope and Contents
"The robustness of the deep learning models YOLO and CurveNet to two types of adversarial attacks (one-pixel attack and physical perturbation attack) was investigated in this capstone project. The main contributions and findings of this work include the following: • A novel curved lane detection algorithm CurveNet was designed. • One-pixel attack on the YOLO object detector was found to have a higher success rate compared to the physical perturbation attack. • Our lane detection algorithm CurveNet was found to be robust to both one-pixel and physical perturbation attacks."Almarri, Noora, Maha AlMazroui, and Henok Guluma. Designing A Framework for Dental Simulation using Virtual Reality2019-00572019AD-MC-0042019-0057
Scope and Contents
Dental education has evolved through the years as various technologies were developed to provide a smooth transition from the classroom to clinical practical settings. Through the years, Virtual Reality (VR) simulators are becoming an essential part of modern dental education. Our project aims to design, develop, and evaluate a framework for simulating dentist-patient interaction using VR. Our project focuses on designing a three-dimensional model, through MakeHuman software, that is animated with different facial expressions, body movements, and vocal responses that can tell the dentist more about how the patient is feeling. The goal of our system is to present dental trainees with the basic communication skills and treatment acts that is required to deal with patients. The simulation we created is composed of three parts: pre-treatment, during treatment, and the post-treatment. There is a smooth transition between these scenarios, where the trainee is being tested on his or her dental performance accordingly. The dental simulation offers dentist-patient scenarios that include audio communication, visual communication, and an overall evaluation of the dentist's performance. The system was built on 3D Unity Game Engine, and was later tested on a group of dental students from the University of Sharjah (UOS), Sharjah, United Arab Emirates.Chirita, Daniel. Learning-Based Visual Tracking: Using PTZ Cameras to Track Commercial UAVs2019-00622019AD-MC-0042019-0062
Scope and Contents
The goal of this capstone is to create a visual processing routine that detects and tracks airborne drones for security applications in airports, air bases, and other drone frequented locations. The produced platform will realize this function with a pan-tilt-zoom mounted Full HD camera for data acquisition and a computer with a discrete graphical processing unit (GPU) for image processing. Such camera systems have use in automatic surveillance in both indoor and outdoor locations. By embedding the zoom into the tracking routine, this project aims to extend functionality to over 100 m. The system is broken down into dynamic object detection, object identification, tracking, and camera controller components. The project aims to provide an integration of existing algorithms in each category to realize the outlined goal. Results suggest that the framework allows for efficient visual servoing. Unlike most visual servoing routines, the proposed mechanism can leverage object detection to expand re-detection capabilities.Mehta, Pranav. Muon-Ra: A Cosmic Ray-based Quantum Random Number Generator2019-00632019AD-MC-0042019-0065
Scope and Contents
Muon decay is a natural phenomenon based on the collision of cosmic radiation with Earth's atmospheric particles. A Cosmic Ray Detector can be used to ionize muons striking the surface of the detector, thus conveying information about a given muon's position of hit, angle of hit and time interval between subsequent hits. Muon strikes are non-deterministic and the information they yield can be used as seeds to a True Random Number Detector (TRNG). In this work, a Quantum TRNG is proposed that translates position and angle of muon strikes into random numbers. Several designs are created and evaluated on the basis of the ability of the output to pass randomness tests and rate of throughput. The most robust design is incorporated as an online service that can be used to generate random numbers in real time.Gebremedhin, Ruth, Ken Iiyoshi, and Mahrukh Tauseef. Design of a Haptic-Audio-Visual Tele-Dental Training Simulation 2020-0472020AD-MC-0042020-0047
Scope and Contents
Over the past two decades, high-speed communication technologies have revo- lutionized applications of Tactile Internet (TI) by allowing low-latency data transfer. This has led to the emergence of haptic-based medical simulations that have numer- ous technical and ethical advantages in medical training. Since dental training is a highly haptic task, tactile internet has the potential to improve the current dental training techniques by allowing communication of motor skills as haptic media. This project designs and implements a detailed, virtual-reality based simulation of a peri- odontal procedure using haptic technology and a realistic 3D model of the oral cavity. A communication system that allows low-latency transmission of haptic and audio- visual data over a network was developed. The local-hosted communication network performed with minimal overhead; an average delay of 0.62 ms and jitter of 0.53 ms for haptic data, and round trip time of less than 30 ms for audio-visual data. This system enables effective supervised training over a physical distance and is more interactive than commonly used non-haptic computer simulations.
Author provided keywords: Tactile Internet, WebRTC, 5G, Tele-operation, Dental Simulation teleoperation, haptics, tactile internet, communication, dental procedureAhmad, Baleegh, Sohail Bagheri, Prajna Soni, and Antony Tahan. Designing a Predictive Model of Mangrove Health using Remote Sensing in Mumbai2020-00502020AD-MC-0042020-0050
Scope and Contents
This project provides a novel solution of consolidating aerial imagery and predictive modeling as functions of changes in the built and natural environment to provide data-driven predictions to help conserve mangrove health in Mumbai's Thane Creek. The final model design will provide a better understanding of how pollutant flow information can supplement satellite imagery data to better identify sources of polluted discharge that impact mangrove health. The project tracks mangrove cover in the region using unsupervised classification on satellite imagery through color cluster analysis. identifies a trend line for seasonal variation in mangrove cover, thus allowing for deviations due to anthropogenic activities to be identified. A trend line with an error margin of 17.9% was calculated, therefore any decrease of mangrove cover greater than the critical point would be flagged, allowing the instance to be investigated further. The project stems from the lack of an appropriate tool that is able to quantify the effect that changes in the local environment can have on mangroves. The proposed tool is envisioned to help marine biologists, researchers, and governments understand where pollutants flow from and what path they take to impact mangrove health negatively.
Author provided keywords: Mangrove, Mumbai, Remote Sensing, Computation Fluid Dynamics, Environmental Modeling, Predictive ModelingAzzam, Youssef, and Mariam Raslan. Designing Haptic Effects for Touch-Screen Devices2020-00512020AD-MC-0042020-0051
Scope and Contents
Abstract, Youssef Azzam: The design of haptic effects caters to the touch-screen market and its users worldwide. The goal of our capstone project is to introduce tactile interaction to touch-screen devices by designing haptic effects for Graphical User Interface (GUI) elements on touch-screen devices and conducting a series of human studies to evaluate them. The design concept includes developing a library of haptic effects that are easily integrable to GUIs based on analyzing touch interactions and user evaluations. The haptic effects library focuses on how users perceive the effects in terms of multi-task interactions with touch-screen devices. The library generated via our gradient-based technique (friction control) and audio waveforms (click effects) allows better identification of GUI elements, hence, meeting our criteria for testing realism and affordance. User evaluation was not achieved due to the impact of COVID-19 on this project, however, expert evaluation cross-checked the affordance of physical interactions. Usability and performance should be carried forward and tested in person for better results. Through the implementation of our project, we aim to bring back life to touch-screen devices through haptic technology.
Abstract, Mariam Raslan: The goal is to introduce tactile interaction to touch-screen devices, as the design of haptic effects is presented to cater for the touch-screen market and its users worldwide. Our project entails designing haptic effects for Graphical User Interface (GUI) elements on touch-screen devices and conducting a series of human studies to evaluate them. The design concept includes developing a library of haptic effects that are easily integrable and applicable to GUI elements based on analyzing touch interactions and user evaluations. Throughout the course of this project, the haptic effects library developed focuses on how users perceive the aforementioned effects in multi-task interactions with the touch-screen device. The haptic feedback effects library generated via our gradient based technique (friction control) and audio waveforms (click effects) allows better identification of GUI elements, meeting our realism and affordance criteria. User evaluation was not achieved due to the COVID-19 impact on this project, however, expert evaluation and testing cross checked the affordance of physical interactions. Through the implementation of our project, we aim to bring back life to touch-screen devices through haptic technology.Ibrahim, Lujain, Munib Mesinovic, and Kai-Wen Yang. Multi-Sensor System for Monitoring Acute Myocardial Infarction using Machine Learning. 2020-00522020AD-MC-0042020-0052
Scope and Contents
Cardiovascular disease is the number one cause of death globally, and in the UAE specifically, Acute Myocardial Infarction (AMI) takes more lives than any other health condition. One of the major approaches towards tackling this formidable public health epidemic is by raising awareness and developing early-detection mechanisms so that people have enough time to preemptively tackle this health challenge. Our Capstone Design Project seeks to gather the physiological signals our body exhibits leading up to an AMI by using ECG and Pulse Oximetry sensors in a wearable armband and use machine learning analysis on the real-time collected data to provide personalized feedback to the user on their cardiovascular health and AMI risk condition. A printed circuit board (PCB) for the monitoring of cardiovascular parameters was designed and validated by EAGLE early-testing. Over 900,000 ECG, age, and sex samples obtained from the ECG-ViEW database have been used to train machine learning models, including naive bayes, logistic regression, CNN, and RNN, that predict the onset of AMI. High prediction accuracy of 90.5% (CNN) and 89.2% (RNN) have been achieved, demonstrating the promising application of early identification of AMI.
Author provided keywords: Machine learning, deep learing, heart attacks Cardiovascular diseases, myocardial infarction prediction, healthcare, diagnosticsAl-Nuaimy, Qutaiba, Aren Chen, Ghadeer Ghosheh, and Sanja Kastratovic. Non-Contact ECG Monitoring System2021-00652021AD-MC-0042021-0065
Scope and Contents
Cardiovascular diseases (CVDs) have been proven to be amongst the most deadly diseases worldwide. The majority of deaths associated with CVDs occurs amongst patients who have never been previously diagnosed with any CVDs. Many CVDs, such as arrhythmia, manifest their symptoms a long time prior to the onset of any adverse or catastrophic event(s), and such the early detection of cardiac abnormalities is incredibly important. However, traditional ECG monitoring systems face challenges with respect to their scalability and affordability as they require direct contact with the body and cumbersome equipment. In this Capstone Design Project, we aim to provide a solution to this problem by developing a small-size, non-contact, real-time feedback, and long-term monitoring lead-I ECG system. It is paired with an iOS application that receives the data through Bluetooth Low Energy and utilizes real-time machine learning analysis.

Scope and Contents
The objective of the capstone project is to design a system to quantify aspects of user haptic experience using brain signals from EEG. We aim to use EEG data collected from a previous study at the Applied Interactive Multimedia lab (AIMlab) to quantify haptic experience using EEG data and machine learning, in particular the haptic delay. Our nal machine learning model achieves an accuracy of 83.2 plus or minus 0.573 percent (reported within a 95 percent con dence level) in detection of a haptic delay in the user experience from a single trial EEG data stream using a light gradient boosting machine. Using EEG data to quantify haptic experience renders our model more accurate, and objective, which will have many applications in designing haptic electronics, attention rehabilitation, and neuroscience research.
Author provided keywords: Haptic EEG Machine, Learning, DataElgamal, Mariam, Yeojin Jung, Mohammed Adib Oumer, and Farida Shaban. Indoor Acoustic Localization of Pests via IoT Technologies & Machine Learning2021-00642021AD-MC-0042021-0064
Scope and Contents
Museums are fighting a constant battle to preserve their invaluable specimens and artwork from pests that can potentially damage them, including the Louvre Abu Dhabi. This project aims to develop a sound detection and analysis system to detect, locate, and determine the population dynamics of crawling and flying pests (e.g., crickets), thereby allowing pest control strategies to be more targeted and efficient. By collecting such information about pests, museum facilities teams can target their use of pesticide to only the affected areas of the museum and hence reduce the total exposure of the museum collections to pesticides throughout the year. Additionally, the collected information could be used to identify trends in the population dynamics and aid in designing long-term non-chemical pest preventative strategies (i.e., traps, ultrasonic pest repellents). Our system utilizes a network of Internet of-Things (IoT) devices that would collect and process necessary real-time information on the cloud using signal processing, machine learning models and big data analysis methods to aid efficient pest-control plans. Ideally, the system will aid museum administrators in decision-making by providing real-time analysis and visualizations through a user interface on handheld devices such as mobile phones, tablets, and laptops.

Design of a non-invasive cell density monitoring device for bacterial batch cultures2021-00602021AD-MC-0042021-0060
Scope and Contents
The proposed system is a device that enables automated non-invasive monitoring of cell density within a biological lab incubator during experiment preparation. The proposed device will have an accuracy within 5% of lab-grade spectrophotometers, a battery life of over 48 hours, and a component price below 150 USD. The target users are biological lab technicians currently required to manually measure, monitor, and estimate cell density via sporadic sampling over dozens of hours. The current technique is problematic because it consumes time, requires continuous inspection, involves human error, and occasionally contaminates or invalidates the experiment preparation. Due to time constraints and limitations by the COVID-19 pandemic, full development was not complete. However, the current progress serves as proof of concept that a device with such requirements is possible.

Scope and Contents
Robot-assisted surgery can address the limitations of minimally invasive surgical operations and to further enhance the confidence and precision of physicians conducting open surgery. Increasingly, the research in the industry has been evolving towards the development of completely automated surgical robotic systems. This project focuses on minimally invasive laparoscopic surgery and aims to design, implement and utilize an assistive surgical robotic system to conduct the necessary incision while enforcing the Fulcrum Point. This process entails designing, simulating and fabricating the laparoscopic tool while mechanically integrating it onto a commercially available robotic system. The performance of the system will be corroborated by a tool-tracking methodology to ensure the integrity of the simulated surgical operation.
Author provided keywords: Surgical Robotics, Fabrication and Control of Robotic Laparoscopic SystemGeneral EngineeringLin, Wei-Chung, and Sowani, Francis Thomas. Design of Automatic Test Pattern Generation System for VLSI Stuck-at-Faults2014-00331022014AD-MC-0042014-0033
Scope and Contents
Major: Engineering
Abstract: Applications vary from consumer electronics, such as phones and computers, to mission-critical ones such as those used for medical or avionics applications. Every chip is subjected to testing, as the manufacturing process is prone to defects. In the test process, a carefully selected set of input patterns are applied to chips, and the observed responses from the chip under test reveal whether the chip is good or bad. Today, the test process that aims at screening out the bad chips constitutes about 25-30% of the overall product cost.
The software system that produces the set of input patterns and their expected responses is called Automatic Test Pattern Generation (ATPG) system. It takes in a design netlist that describes circuit structure and a fault model that describes the targeted types of defects, and produces the test patterns. A traditionally used fault model is called the stuck-at fault model, which models defects that cause a net (wire) to be always stuck at 0 or 1, regardless of the actual value of the net.
This project aims at the design, development and evaluation of an ATPG system that targets only the stuck-at faults.Testing chipsAutomatic Test Pattern Generation (ATPG)DesignFilipovska, Monika. Transportation for Smart Cities2017-00132017Transportation for smart cities, significantly based on modern data Science and traffic analytics, is entirely dependent on the availability of accurate knowledge of real-time traffic conditions. Accurate data representing real-time traffic conditions is necessary for real-time traffic analytics, whose applications can range from network-wide signal control, real-time trip planning, to traffic incidents response. However, traffic analytics is often encumbered by the fact that real-time data is unavailable for large portions of the urban networks at any given instant. Thus data is discontinuous, interrupted and quite sparse to reflect the real-time traffic state and to be useful for any real-time applications. Therefore, urban traffic state estimation has become the core challenging problem for practitioners and researchers in the field. The goal of this capstone work is to identify and calculate spatio-temporal correlations in traffic flow that can be used for real-time traffic state estimation. The project focuses on developing a model for real-time traffic data reconstruction that allows for using the sparse data from instrumented road segments to accurately estimate the traffic conditions for segments that lack instrumentation.AD-MC-0042017-0013

Despite the importance of studying the response of coral and marine life to the changing climate, marine researchers are not equipped with the personnel or time to survey the reefs on a large scale. Existing methods for coral monitoring are limited, compromising either on accuracy and detail, as with remote sensing, or time and efficiency of data collection, as with manta tows and SCUBA transects. The reefRover project aims to provide a solution to this problem in the form of an autonomous ROV that will perform transects along the reef and obtain high-quality images of the coral in the UAE. The ROV will be developed in a manner that enables community divers to deploy the device while ensuring data quality, and the reefRover project will be kept open-source, allowing anyone across the world to develop and deploy the reefRover and expand the available data on coral reefs. The team is divided into three main efforts—Underwater Positioning System, Image Processing, and ROV Integration—and the vision is to have a fully operational, autonomous ROV for deployment in May 2018.AD-MC-0042018-0041

Rapid Sustainable Urbanisation in Peri-Urban UAE2019-00652019AD-MC-0042019-0065
Scope and Contents
The last few decades have witnessed a global rapid urbanisation trend which is expected to reach its zenith mid the 21st century when the global human population will start to plateau. The biggest challenge is complexity in planning ahead for the burgeoning population with a keen consideration of electricity and water resources management, availability of adequate transport and communication infrastructure, and ease of accessing these public services. It has been observed that the population bleeds out of urban centres into peri-urban regions which are located between urban settings and their immediate rural surroundings. These regions are relatively untouched in terms of urban planning, but well within the economic reach and influence of nearby cities therefore they present a great potential for the next generation of urbanisation. This project explores new perspectives that can be brought to the construction industry to aid a shift towards a much needed sustainable practice, with emphasis on the environmental aspect. The design presented here is informed by background research and experiential work in the Solar Decathlon house project, and case studies conducted in Abu Dhabi and Dubai to benchmark practices that can be improved on and adopted for future undertakings.Mechanical EngineeringKun, Janos Csaba, and Mohammed Omar. Design of an Inkjet Generator for Metal Oxide Nanostructures2014-0034972014AD-MC-0042014-0034
Scope and Contents
Major: Mechanical Engineering
Abstract, Janos Kun: Our project aimed to create a cost-effective and simple nanostructure-production method based on an off-the-shelf inkjet printer cartridge.
Scope and Contents
Major: Mechanical Engineering
Abstract, Mohammed Omar: This investigation deals with printing metal oxide nanostructures using inkjet technology as it is a much cheaper process than current processes of nanostructure synthesis. This is achieved by creating fine aerosol particles with an HP c6614 #20 inkjet cartridge and leveraging the so-called "coffee ring effect". Upon their deposition on a heated substrate, the aqueous droplets evaporate leaving behind porous nano-membranes. To be of any practical use, the inkjet aerosol generator had to create droplets on demand that have a diameter of less than 20μm, an initial velocity of 5m/s, a frequency of 1kHz and it should run for at least one hour continuously. Although, we fulfilled the first three specifications using the literature on our inkjet cartridge, the fourth was not. Our system however, finally synthesised ZnO porous nanomembranes which laid the foundation for future experimentation; our results were sufficient for our proof of concept. Future investigations would include studies on optimising the "throw distance" (defined as the distance from the inkjet nozzle to the substrate) to create the most useful nanostructures as well as creating a system that functions reliably for a practical time period.NanostructuresAerosolsInk-jet printingMechanical engineeringSaad, Ahmed Gamal. Design of a Microfluidic Dispensing Unit for C. Elegans Worms2014-00301052014AD-MC-0042014-0030
Scope and Contents
Major: Mechanical Engineering
Abstract: The aim of the project is to build an automated unit that dispenses one C. elegans worm in each cycle of operation from the tip of the device. The unit is built from a PDMS structures, a worm-detection system, and a pneumatic valves system. A set of experiments to test, evaluate and optimize each of the segments of the unit was fundamental for the construction of the unit. The unit should provide a replacement for the time-consuming, labor intensive, manual work that currently takes place to obtain one worm from their environment. Design of a Microfluidic Dispensing Machine for Caenorhabditis elegans worms2015-003134072015AD-MC-0042015-0031
Scope and Contents
Major: Mechanical Engineering
Abstract: The aim of this capstone project is to design and build a microfluidic-dispensing device to dispense a single C.elegans worm at a time into each micro-plate well. This device comprises microfluidic channels, pneumatic valves, a laser source, and a photodiode integrated in a Polydimethylsiloxane (PDMS) chip. When a C.elegans worm passes through the channel and blocks the laser light to the photodiode, a change in light intensity is observed and that change is used to detect the passage of the worm. A LabVIEW program is developed to detect this change in intensity and actuate the pneumatic valves that will allow trapping and disposing of the worm. The prototype accurately detects, traps and dispenses a single worm into a well plate.MicrofluidicsPneumaticsMicrofluidsC. elegansPolydimethylsiloxaneOptical detectorsMechanical engineeringDrug screeningBiomedical engineeringAbdouli, Nayef, and Coezette Sibanda. High-throughput Micro-Fluidic Chip for Optogenetic Studies of Neuromuscular Diseases Using C. Elegans.2016-002179882016Human neuromuscular diseases are as common as 1 in 3000 people. Examples of these diseases include Duchenne and Becker muscular dystrophies, amyotrophic lateral sclerosis, and these affect people and societies both physically and emotionally. Neuromuscular diseases lead to progressive loss in motor function and premature mortality. Vertebrate animal models have been for a long time used to study these diseases. These models however are expensive and slow. Newer models of using C elegans worms for studying neuromuscular diseases are under pursuit and growing rapidly. These models present the possibility to carry out the studies in a cost-efficient and high-throughput manner. There are challenges associated with the use of C-elegans worms however, due to the small sizes of the worms. These challenges include mainly automated handling and precise neural stimulation.AD-MC-0042016-0021

Water Filtration Using Plant Xylem.2016-001979902016Our capstone project aims to address the global void in cost effective water filtration. Every year, millions of people die from waterborne diseases caused by bacteria and viruses due to lack of access to clean water. This tragic fact creates a need for solutions specifically targeted towards the lower-income demographic in the developing world. Based on a research paper published in 2014, gymnosperm plant xylem was identified as a suitable filtering material. Plant xylem's inner structure is uniquely suited for water filtration due to nanoscale pores located between its water carrying channels called tracheids. These nano-pores are the vehicle of filtration capable of removing 99% of bacteria and particles larger than 100 nm. The goal of the project was to design a product that would provide individuals in developing countries with a method of taking advantage of xylem's filtering properties in an easy and cost-effective manner. The project design ultimately resulted in a two-piece plastic filter containment unit, whose cap is permanently attached to a jerry can, and whose xylem holder screws into the cap and contains eight holes to place xylem through. This paper describes the design process and an analysis of the final product.AD-MC-0042016-0019

Concentrated Solar Powered Stirling Engine for Reverse Osmosis Desalination and Pumped Storage Hydroelectricity.2017-00172017Said Abdallah, Tshering Gyaltshen: In recent years, there has been a rise in the demand of renewable energy because of the negative environmental impacts and their exhaustible nature. This has led to an increase in research in this field, to come up with new, innovative ways of satisfying this need. The most common form of renewable energy is solar energy, which is commonly utilized by converting the sun's rays of light into either electric or thermal energy. Although, countries like the United Arab Emirates have an abundance of non-renewable sources of energy such as oil, a lot of investment is being put into increasing the use of renewable energy sources in these regions. In the UAE, the government has set a goal to produce 25% of its energy renewably by 2030, a significant increase from the current levels of less than 1%. The aim of this project is to work towards the attaining of this goal and beyond, with a sustainable and cost-effective solution that makes use of the natural resources of the UAE. The proposed solution harvests solar energy with the help of Fresnel lens powered Stirling engines for both water desalination via reverse osmosis, and energy storage via a pumped storage hydroelectric system.Jean Edwards: As of 2009, the UAE had a total primary energy supply of 2,526.8 PJ, of which ~1.0 PJ was from renewable sources (about 0.04%). The UAE has set goals to increase the proportion of renewable energy from the current levels of less than 1% to 25% by 2030. The aim of this project is to work towards the attaining of this goal and beyond, with a sustainable and cost-effective solution that makes use of the natural resources of the UAE. The proposed solution harvests solar energy with the help of Fresnel lens powered Stirling engines for both water desalination via reverse osmosis, and energy storage via a pumped storage hydroelectric system. Water desalination was addressed because it currently accounts for about 10% of the UAE's total energy consumption. The pumped storage system makes use of seawater as the working fluid, with reservoirs constructed on the UAE's natural Eastern mountain ranges located close to the sea, thereby addressing power generation requirements, grid energy storage needs and peak-load demands.AD-MC-0042017-0017

Product Design for Manufacture, Reliability and Marketing of a Device to Predict Plant Strength. 2017-00212017Yield losses in maize (Zea mays L.) due to stalk lodging has significant negative economic impact. The lodging resistance in maize could be advanced more rapidly with the development of selective breeding tools that accurately predict stalk strength. Motivated by the strong correlation between flexural stiffness and stalk strength, a device that measures flexural rigidity was developed to predict stalk strength. To allow for a wider adaptation of such device, this Capstone aims to produce a second iteration of such device that is more accessible and robust. This is achieved through the integration of an intuitive graphical user interface, the redesign of mechanical structure to improve ergonomic comfort and robustness, and the refinement of electronics for more accurate data collection.AD-MC-0042017-0021

Solar-Driven Absorption Air Conditioner2018-00462018The purpose of this capstone project was to design, build and test a single-effect absorption refrigeration cycle that uses solar energy as the sole source of energy. Design goals were focused on low toxicity, sustainability, reliability and therefore, applicability to urban environments. Conventional vapor compression cycles use electricity and emit gases that cause air pollution and therefore, there is a strong imperative to create an alternative. The main drawbacks of the current absorption refrigeration systems, which use ammonia or lithium bromide working fluids, are: 1. Ammonia is highly toxic, flammable and explosive. 2. Lithium bromide is expensive and has the issue of crystallization at a range of temperatures, pressures and concentrations. Thus, in this capstone project, ethylene glycol was used as an absorption medium for the working fluid (water). Specifically, the design process included: 1. Optimization of the size of the absorber to get a coefficient of performance (COP) higher than 0.67. 2. Decreasing the heat loss from the desorber to increase the COP. 3. Preventing leakages when the cycle runs in a vacuum (pressure range from 1.5 kPa to 30 kPa) by using better-designed instruments. 4. Comprehensive data acquisition methods to get data from each component in the cycle.AD-MC-0042018-0046

Water Filtration system for developing region2018-00482018Potable or drinkable water is defined as having acceptable quality in terms of its physical, chemical and bacteriological parameters so that it can be safely used for human consumption. Among the various water pollutants, biological contaminants are the most fatal in developing regions. The only possible way to achieve potable water is to carry out disinfection processes. According to the research conducted at MIT, nano-pores in Gymnosperm plant xylem has been identified as an efficient filter of bacteria due to the "short tracheid that would force water to flow through pit membranes". The availability of this plant in the region makes it an affordable and reliable source to be incorporated in a water filter device. In addition, adding a compartment for sand and charcoal each makes the water filter more efficient at filtering out the physical, chemical and biological contaminants. In this capstone project, we aim to achieve an advanced multi-step xylem-based filter that can filter bacteria and heavy metals without blockage problems at an economical cost to people residing in developing regions who do not have access to potable water.AD-MC-0042018-0048

Building a Low Cost Turbidostat2019-00492019AD-MC-0042019-0049
Scope and Contents
Continuous culture devices can be used for various purposes such as establishing reproducible growth conditions or maintaining cell populations under a constant environment for long time periods. To more accurately characterize biological systems, researchers must turn to static environments, which yield lower noise in quantitative phenotyping. A primary tool for culturing cells in a static environment is continuous culture, where inoculated growth medium is continually diluted with fresh medium. Turbidostats are powerful characterization tools that provide static culture environments; however, they are often expensive, especially when purchased in custom configurations, and are difficult to design and construct in a lab. Eight culture chambers are controlled simultaneously with the proposed configuration, and all components are readily available from various sources. We demonstrate that our continuous culture device can be used under different modes, and can easily be programmed to behave either as a turbidostat or fluorostat. Addition of fresh medium to the culture vessel is to be controlled by a real-time feedback loop or simply calibrated to deliver a defined volume. The project aims to build a device which is both cheaper and less laborious in comparison to the already existing commercial versions.Castillo, Alberto, Pratik Maisuria, and Mahmoud Soliman. The purpose of the project is to rebuild the water clock in the closest resemblance possible to the original based on existing literature. Furthermore, the project aims to capture the essence of the clock as a landmark in human achievement. For this purpose the clock is to be reproduced with the same aesthetic artistry as the original, as well as the entirety of the operational mechanism. In the interest of practicality, the clock will first be built at scale, maintaining only the water regulation mechanisms at full size. A marvel of the ancient world, the engineered replica will stand a testament to the achievement and technicality of muslim engineers of the ancient world, namely Al-Jazari. In the long term, this capstone serves to mark the start of a project into tourism with a focus on the forgotten engineering marvels of the ancient muslim world.Iqbal, Mubasher, and Saad Sultan. Design of a continuous monitoring system for the Mineral Nutrient Uptake by Plants in Hydroponic System2019-00542019AD-MC-0042019-0054
Scope and Contents
Vertical farming is an agricultural method of growing plants where roots are ex- posed to the water solvent rich in mineral nutrients. It aids in food security by pro- viding control over all environmental factors, the preservation of endangered species of plants and the conservation of resources such as arable land and water. It is based on the finding that plants are best able to absorb particulate nutrients in a distance range of 1 to 50 micrometers (μm). Therefore, roots of the plants that are suspended within enclosed nutrient rich systems can better absorb and assimilate the minerals for more efficient farming with minimal water usage. Out of all available mineral nutrients, potassium ion (K+) plays particularly crucial role in plant growth and metabolism, and it is also the most abundant cation in plants. The project aims to develop a micro scale sensor that monitors the real time uptake of K+ via roots that are directly exposed to the nutrient solution. The data collected can be further used to optimize the amount of nutrients needed by plant thus minimizing nutrient waste and producing crops of higher nutritional value.Kasahara, Shunsuke. Design of a Bio-inspired Lizard Robot Mimicking Tail Autotomy Process2019-00532019AD-MC-0042019-0053
Scope and Contents
Caudal autotomy is widespread among lizards: around 13 out of 20 families show this reflex severance strategy of their tails as a self-defence mechanism either to escape the predator's grasp or in anticipation of any life-threatening situation. The detached tail continues to wiggle (may go up to 30 minutes) through anaerobic metabolism and attracts the attention of the predator, which ultimately gives time to the lizard escape the ambush site. The mechanism of autotomy still remains secret. To explain this sheer bizarre phenomenon, we have developed a mechanistic model. Bio-inspired by the microstructures found on the broken tail surfaces, a bio-interlocking model containing an array of hemispherical microstructures was proposed. To test the model, a lab test setup was built and experiments on the biomimetic tail part were performed for its characterization. Finally, to demonstrate the actuatable interlock mechanism, a lizard robot was designed and fabricated. This robot detects incoming danger (incoming objects) and releases its tail while running away, as a real lizard would do. The robot and its tail shedding mechanism using the actuated bio-interlock was successfully tested.Kedia, Raghav, Gjorgji Shemov, and Jotham Varghese. The project aims to design a 1:10 radio-controlled (RC) car powered by 1 Suoaki photovoltaic (PV) panel and 1 5000mAh Gens Ace Hardcase Li-Po battery, using SCX10 II™ 2000 Jeep® Cherokee as a model car. Mini projects have been completed by the student in the field of designing LiPo battery chargers and simulating car performance in the Gazebo Simulation software. A preliminary printed circuit board (PCB) has been designed and is currently being refined to be manufactured and tested. Several PV panel mounting structures are being prototyped and tested for structural competency and practicality. The car must navigate between sets of GPS waypoints with minimal human intervention. This requires the car to be driven to a certain level of autonomy by using obstacle detection and avoidance maneuvers whilst also relaying this information back and forth with the central computer using bidirectional communication over long distances.Kumar, Raghav. Fluidic Injection Thrust Reverser System for High Bypass Ratio Turbofan Engines2019-00592019AD-MC-0042019-0059
Scope and Contents
Conventional thrust reversers rely on mechanical blockers to block and reverse the flow of air. As they are designed to sustain heavy loads, they are bulky and hence account for 30% of the nacelle weight (excluding the engine core). This added engine weight results in a 0.5%-1% increase in the specific fuel consumption of the aircraft. The goal of this project is to design a thrust reverser system for high bypass ratio turbofan engines that uses fluidic injection to reverse the flow of air, eliminating the need of mechanical blockers completely. The project validates "Blockerless Engine Thrust Reversers (BETR)" proposed by NASA Langley and culminates with the construction of a working model demonstrating the applicability of optimized design. This report summarizes the entire process of building an experimental model of a "Fluidic Injection Thrust Reverser (FITR)" system. A detailed experimental investigation showed that ~71.5% of the fan flow (mass flow rate) with ~70% injection (in terms of fan flow). Operating at these parameters, the net negative thrust force readings reiterated our claim of achieving ~78% reversal of thrust through our implementation of FITR.Ali-Hassan, Adnan, Amr El-Ashmouny, and Gladys Mwedzi. Design of Cyclic Tensile Apparatus for Studying Cancer Cells2020-00492020AD-MC-0042020-0049
Scope and Contents
Abstract: Adnan Ali-Hassan and Amr El-Ashmouny: Cancer metastasis accounts for about 90% cancer deaths, hence understanding the mechanical attributes of cancer cells will allow for better development of inhibition techniques to curb the cancer growth. The capstone project aimed at developing a mechanical stretching device that works with applied air pressure to study the effect of different stresses on breast cancer cells. Several stretching devices have been designed and implemented to study functional responses of various cells by inducing elastic deformations (tensile, compressive, or shear) on cells. However, these devices, despite being very compatible with advanced microscopy techniques, offer many limitations. Therefore the project's main goal was to resolve the current devices drawbacks. The main steps included eliminating the insufficient clamping mechanism, the inconsistency in the periodicity of the strains applied to the cells, the non-uniformity of the strain distributions over the membrane surface, and the inapplicability of running multiple membranes at once.
Abstract: Gladys Mwedzi: Studying the effect of mechanical forces on the migratory and biological responses of cancer cells is of interest to several fields including drug delivery and metastasis. Several stretching devices have been designed and implemented to study functional responses of various cells by inducing elastic deformations on them. However, despite being helpful in our current understand of cellular mechanobiology, they entail various limitations. This senior undergraduate capstone project aims to develop a custommade stretching device that fits in an incubator as well as on a microscope stage, yet offers various stretching scenarios during the same experiment. Our device constitutes a PDMS chip with multiple wells of different shapes including circular, square, rectangular, and oval. A thin PDMS membrane covers the wells-chip and stretches upon pressurizing the wells. Our study considered optimizing the wells' sizes and shapes, and results show that the membrane stretches differently corresponding to each well geometry. Therefore, cancer cells seeded on the PDMS membrane can experience different stretching magnitudes, directions, and distributions, within the same setup and during the same experiment. Next steps include building and testing the biochip, followed by studying the response of cancer cells under these different multiaxial stretching scenarios.
Author provided keywords: Cancer, Cells, PDMS, Mold, Simulations, Cyclic, Maximum Tensile Strength Applied Pressure, Metastasis, Deflection, Strain, COMSOL Simulations BiochipAlabbasi, Majid, Shahad Badri, and Yuanbei Fan. Design of an Autonomous Wave Powered Desalination Unit2021-00612021AD-MC-0042021-0061
Scope and Contents
The objective of the capstone project is to design and model an autonomous wave powered reverse osmosis desalination unit. Local wave conditions include an average wave height of 0.5 m at depths of 21-30 m in the Gulf region. In the unit, a round buoy extracts kinetic energy from the heaving motions of the ocean waves and drives a submerged positive displacement pump to pressurize seawater through the reverse osmosis membrane in the desalination process. The desalinated permeate is transferred into a reservoir on shore, while the high concentrated brine is discharged to the ocean. Using the "Delbuoy" desalination unit as a benchmark, a more efficient system is developed by implementing bistable springs to create a nonlinear stiffness system. This system is able to reach resonance with incoming seawaves at different natural frequencies, therefore archives a higher permeate production of 0.252 m^3 /s. The design skips the intermediate step of the electromechanical conversion process, therefore utilizes no generators or motors, which offers advantages such as reduced cost, simplicity in the design and installation process, and increased power efficiency.
Author provided keywords: bistable desalination, autonomous wave powered, reverse osmosis, nonlinear stiffness buoyAlshurafa, Qamar. 3D Printed Water Purification Filter Based on Paper Lateral Flow2021-00572021AD-MC-0042021-0057
Scope and Contents
This project develops a novel 3D printed water purification filter that works based on water lateral flow within a single paper sheet. This new filter is an advancement of a previously invented Paper-Based Water Purification Filter. Although the employment of several materials between both projects are similar, this project involves new design that solves associated drawbacks with the previous filter. The goal is to be able to provide accessible purified water utilizing a simple device. This would be brought to areas where clean decontaminated water isn't readily available, as well as where there is a demand to remove undesirable chemicals and biological contaminants from water. The device will still similarly utilize a paper platform as the core for water purification, thus tackling the issue of paper recycling, among the addition of new materials such as charcoal. This filter design is completely new, utilizes only a single sheet of paper, and solves water leakage problems with a clean-cut route. In total, the new filter will be executed in a way that reduces technical past issues faced such as paper stacking, water leakage, and purification throughput as well as allowing for efficiency in purifying water.
Author provided keywords: 3D Purification Water Bacteria Paper Later Flow EfficiencyBaho, Ingie. Fabrication and Control of Robotic Laparoscopic System2021-00632021AD-MC-0042021-0063
Scope and Contents
Robot-assisted surgery can address limitations of minimally invasive surgical operations and to further enhance confidence and precision of physicians conducting open surgery. Increasingly, the research in the industry has been evolving towards the development of completely automated surgical robotic systems. This project focuses on the minimally invasive laparoscopic surgery and aims to design, implement and utilize an assistive to a surgeon robotic system to conduct the necessary incision while enforcing the Fulcrum Point. This process entails designing, simulating and fabricating the laparoscopic tool while mechanically integrating it onto a commercially available robotic system. The performance of the system will be corroborated by a tool-tracking methodology to ensure the integrity of the simulated surgical operation.
Author provided keywords: surgical, robotic, laparoscopyHaniffa, Zeenath Salma. The Effect of Chronic Social Stress on Core Temperature Rhythms and Related Changes in Gene Expression of RBM3 and HSF12021-00822021AD-MC-0042021-0082
Scope and Contents
Individuals affected by mood disorders display dysregulations in circadian rhythms. However, it isn't known if these irregularities arise as a result of mood disorders or if they play a causal role. Discernment of the nature of the association could shed light on potential markers and treatment strategies. Chronic stress can result in or aggravate such mood disorders. This project utilized a mouse model and the chronic social defeat stress paradigm to investigate the relationship between circadian temperature rhythmicity and mood disorders. Surgical implantation of a wireless device allowed for core temperature measurements of control, stress resilient, and stress susceptible mice to be recorded both prior to and during exposure to the stress paradigm. Results ascertained that resilient and susceptible mice exhibit dampened temperature amplitudes during chronic social stress. To examine associated molecular changes, RT-qPCR was used to determine the expression levels of thermosensitive genes: RNA-binding motif 3 (RBM3) and heat shock factor 1 (HSF1) which are linked to temperature decrease and increase respectively. No changes were observed in HSF1 levels. However, RBM3 was downregulated in resilient and susceptible mice during the inactive phase. This finding differs from its expected expression patterns.
Author provided keywords: Mice, Chronic Social Defeat Stress, Temperature Rhythm Amplitudes, RBM3, HSF1Jagdeo, Matthew. A Quantitative Approach to a Fluidic Injection Thrust Reverser Design for Turbofan Engines2021-00582021AD-MC-0042021-0058
Scope and Contents
Abstract 1: Engine Thrust Reversal systems on current commercially available turbofan engines rely primarily on mechanical systems to block and reverse the flow of air. These blockers are both extremely heavy (accounting for 30% of the nacelle weight) and contribute to fuel inefficiency. In a study conducted by the General Electric Aircraft Engines company, it was estimated that the specific fuel consumption can increase by ~0.5-1.0% due to the use of mechanical blockers. This is even more significant as thrust reversal systems are only utilized for a tiny fraction of a plane's operating time. According to the Boeing Company, running thrust reverser systems on a Boeing 767 can cost about USD $125,000 per airplane annually, vastly outweighing the financial savings from reduced brake wear. Depending on the airline and routes flown, this can account for almost 0.5% of the annual operating costs of a B-767. Previous capstone projects have proposed, designed, and verified the concept of using Fluidic Injection Thrust Reverser (FITR) systems on high bypass-ratio turbofan engines to reverse the flow of air and eliminate mechanical blockers completely.
Abstract 2: The goal of this project is to design an optimized FITR system and provide a quantitative analysis on its efficiency and feasibility. The project will have three main phases of development, namely, (1) Simulations (2) Modelling and (3) Testing. In the Simulation phase, extensive Computational Fluid Dynamics studies will be carried out on a full sized and scaled down model of a turbofan engine with the novel thrust reversal system. Then for the Modelling phase, a scaled experimental model will be prototyped via multiple iterations and small-scale testing will be done to ensure perfect modelling. Lastly, in the Testing phase, the optimal prototype will undergo rigorous testing and the results will be used in the conclusions of this report. The following report summarizes the concepts and iterations that were followed before reaching the final design as well as relevant literature review, project constraints and work management guidelines.

Implementation of a Peer-Mediated Health Education Model in the United Arab Emirates; Understanding Risky Behaviors Among Expatriate Teens2014-00541162014AD-MC-0042014-0054
Scope and Contents
Major: Biology
Abstract: In the United Arab Emirates (UAE), tobacco use amongst young people is on the rise, and the incidence of type II diabetes ranks the country at 15th in the world. Yet, few interventions directly address the risky behaviors that youth engage in, which lead to chronic, unhealthy habits. To test if an educational intervention would be effective in this cultural setting, we designed two peer-to-peer health workshops: one on tobacco use and another on nutrition/physical activity (N/PA). A pre-workshop survey was used to provide a baseline on the current attitudes, knowledge, perceptions and behaviors of our cohort with regard to tobacco use, physical activity and nutrition. We randomly assigned each classroom a workshop and used a post workshop survey to assess changes in the student's beliefs for each health topic. Our results provide a summary of the current risky behaviors of ninth grade expatriates in the UAE. Moreover, we concluded that the tobacco workshop positively affected knowledge, attitudes, and perceptions of tobacco use. The N/PA workshop affected the teenagers' level of satisfaction with their physical activity. This study provides evidence to support a national adoption of a peer-to-peer health education model as a tobacco use intervention.Schools/EducationHealthExerciseNutritionTobaccoDrivdahl Dougherty, Kelly Alice. Abstract: As the deciphering of algal metabolism becomes increasingly significant for algal optimization and its commercial applications, species' response and ultimately adaptation to environment becomes of particular practical interest. Because green algae can produce and accumulate lipids, the research model organism Chlamydomonas reinhardtii has been the subject of a large number of studies, including a genome-scale reconstruction of its metabolic network. The present study explores algal adaptation of three species, two from the USA and one from the UAE, to environment through temperature tolerance, metabolic capability, and genetics. High-throughput sequencing and metabolic phenotyping were used to define full metabolic profiles of these species and their phylogenetic assignments. Data indicates that while the isolates are closely related genetically across locations, and of the same species within the two locations, each strain has a unique metabolic profile and temperature range. This hints at epigenetic influence within locations, as well as intra-species phenotypic variations. Strains in the UAE displayed higher temperature tolerances. Strains from New York City showed lower, and different growth temperature preferences. Metabolic differences were observed across all strains, including between both strains from New York.Green algaeChlamydomonas reinhardtiiHigh throughput phenotypingHaining, Brianna Leigh. Abstract: Through the process of domestication, humankind has driven evolutionary change in a wide variety of plants. The date palm, Phoenix dactylifera, has been cultivated in the Middle East and North Africa for approximately 5000 years. In this study we employ a phylogeographic approach using DNA sequence variation from one chloroplast region, psbA-trnH, to elucidate the evolutionary history of the cultivated date palm from across its native range. The evidence suggests that there were at least two domestication events in the date palm, one in North Africa and one in the Arabian Peninsula region. A third event may have occurred in Iraq.OutdoorsGenotypingPhylogenyDNA barcodingBiogeographyPalm TreesMiranda, Clive Jude. Abstract: Little is known about the frequency and types of supplements used in the United Arab Emirates. With a recent focus on improving healthcare in the nation, much importance is given to the emergence of gymnasiums that offer promises ranging from weight loss to better athletic performance. The anticipated expectations of accelerated results is brought about through the common, yet often uncontrolled, usage of performance-enhancing drugs and body supplements. This study aims to analyze the trends pertaining to supplement usage and perspectives in the emirate of Abu Dhabi. 200 weight-training participants were surveyed across 5 large gyms in the emirate. Results obtained saw high supplement usage, ranging from common protein supplements and creatine to suspected anabolic androgenic steroids. Major reasons for taking supplements, as reported by participants, were to "gain muscle mass", "improve athletic performance" and "reduce onset of muscle fatigue". Throughout this study, there appears to be an impetus to develop the "ideal" body revolving around the concept of a 'Western aesthetic physique'.GymsSurveysPublic healthHealth surveysDoping in sportsDrugsProteins in human nutritionNehme, Samer Intissar. Abstract: Iron Oxide (γ-Fe2O3) nanoparticles (NPs) had been coated with water soluble molecular containers called cucurbit[7]uril (CB[7]).1 The cancer drug Paclitaxel3 (PTX) was successfully encapsulated in these macrocycles. Major: Biology
Abstract: Globally, 8.4% or 382 million people of the adult population suffer from diabetes, and the number is expected to increase in the following years [15]. Diabetes prevalence among the UAE nationals were reported to be 24%, and 67% adults were obese or overweight, while 57% had central obesity [20,22]. The high prevalence of diabetes in the UAE is attributable to changes in lifestyle, yet the specific biochemical mechanisms that lead to increased diabetes complications in this population is not known. In hyperglycemia, the formation of advanced glycation endproducts (AGEs) through non-enzymatic glycation and oxidation of proteins is greatly accelerated [27]. The AGE/RAGE pathway has an important implication in the vascular damage that is observed in diabetes. This Capstone project is aimed to understand the epidemiology and the burden of diabetes worldwide and in the UAE, and to study the biochemical pathways that modulate diabetes complications. The first goal was achieved through literature research and clinical observation. The second goal was attained through experiments investigating the levels of several gene expressions in hyperglycemia and oxidative stress induced conditions in vitro. This study found that the expression of those genes changed during those conditions.AGE/RAGE pathwayDiabetesDiseases |x ComplicationsCardiovascular diseasesStanley, Zachary David. Abstract: Tobacco use amongst young people is on the rise in the United Arab Emirates (UAE). The UAE is also ranked 15th in the world for incidence of type II diabetes. To test if an educational intervention would be effective in this cultural setting, we designed two peer-to-peer health workshops: one on tobacco and another on nutrition/physical activity (N/PA). We randomly assigned each classroom either a N/PA or tobacco workshop and used a post workshop survey to assess the effect of the workshops on the student's beliefs for each health topic. The N/PA workshop acted as a control group for tobacco related questions and vice versa. Our results provide a summary on the current risky behaviors of ninth grade expatriates in the UAE. Moreover, we concluded that the tobacco workshop positively affected knowledge, attitudes, and perceptions of tobacco use, with noticeable spillover effects on perceptions of nutrition and physical activity as well. The N/PA workshop was only able to affect teenagers' level of satisfaction with their physical activity.DiabetesTobaccoHealthSchools/EducationNutritionZarate-Rodriguez, Jorge. Abstract: An altered intestinal microbiome and high-fat diet (HFD) can each contribute to obesity, this study tried to elucidate their combined effects on host physiology. Mice received sub-therapeutic antibiotic treatment (STAT), whereas control mice did not. Both groups were fed normal chow (NC), and at 17 weeks half the mice were switched to HFD. STAT elevated total and fat mass in both NC and HFD mice compared to controls; a more substantial weight gain was observed when STAT and HFD were combined. To examine the effects on the microbiome, DNA was extracted from fecal samples and the V4 region of the 16S rRNA gene was sequenced. Principal coordinate analysis revealed that both STAT and HFD changed microbial community structure. To determine whether an altered microbiota could cause an obesity phenotype independently of exposure to antibiotics, the microbiota of 18-week old control and STAT mice was transferred to germ-free mice via oral gavage. STAT-recipient mice showed significant increases in total and adipose mass compared to control. Histological analysis showed no difference in mean surface area or frequency distribution of adipocyte surface area between control and treatment groups.PhysiologyObesityMicrobiomeAntibioticsBacteriaPenicillinFatAsfoor, Janeen Waddah. Major: Biology
Abstract: Amyloid diseases, which include neurodegenerative diseases such as Alzheimer's and prion diseases, are characterized by the misfolding, aggregation and toxicity of cellular proteins. Segments of prion proteins have been show to function as cell-penetrating peptides (CPPs), which can cross the cell membrane with high efficiency even when coupled to large cargoes. In this study, a new peptide composed of a highly charged segment (KKLVFF) from the Aβ peptide, associated with Alzheimer's diseases, and a targeting sequence, was studied to determine whether it can function as a CPP and inhibit the aggregation and toxicity of Aβ. My studies show that the peptide effectively inhibited the aggregation of Aβ, was not toxic to cells, and rapidly entered cells and localized to the mitochondria, which has been suggested as a target in a number of amyloid diseases, including Alzheimer's disease. Significantly, these findings give us insight into developing a 'universal inhibitor' of amyloid protein aggregation and cytotoxicity.Cell-penetrating peptidesAggregation, CellCytotoxicityAmyloidAlzheimer's diseasePeptidesPrion proteinsEdmonds, Victoria Susan. Audio-Visual Integration in Speech Perception2015-004334202015AD-MC-0042015-0043
Scope and Contents
Major: Biology
Abstract: This study investigates whether speech perception is primarily subserved by modality-specific or amodal representations by expanding the work reported by Kim et al. (2004). Visual speech was used to prime auditory and written targets across four conditions: repetition, non-repetition, same-onset, and same-rhyme. Lexical decision task (word vs. pseudoword) reaction times were used to assess the degree of priming. Selective repetition priming for both auditory and written LDT's was predicted. Results demonstrated facilitatory priming of repetition, same-onset, and same-rhyme conditions compared to control for both words and pseudowords in the auditory LDT. In the written LDT, repetition and same-onset priming was found to facilitate processing of words while repetition priming inhibited priming of pseudowords. Together, these results suggest that silent visual articulations do influence language perception, which is consistent with an amodal model of language perception dependent on an underlying motor bases. It remains unclear whether visual speech simply activates phonological units without lexical-specificity, as suggested by results of the auditory LDT, or whether it activates words in the mental lexicon, as suggested by results of the written LDT.PerceptionSpeechesCross-modal primingPriming (Psychology)Visual speech perceptionSpeech perceptionWickramasinghe, Nadheera Madhavi. Zelda's Regulatory Role in the Neuroepithelial-to-Neuroblast Transition in the Developing Drosophila Larval Brain2015-003834162015AD-MC-0042015-0038
Scope and Contents
Major: Biology
Abstract: Zelda (Zld) is a transcription factor that is thought to coordinate the neuroepithelial (NE) stem cell network in the Drosophila larval brain. NE cells undergo differentiation to become neuroblasts (NB), which divide asymmetrically to maintain the correct balance of stem cells vs. differentiated cells. The NE-to-NB transition is controlled through the interaction of the EGFR and Notch signaling pathways. zld is expressed in NE cells of larval brains, and NE cells lacking Zld show early transformation into NBs. As such, we hypothesize that Zld is a possible regulator of the NE fate and thus integral to these pathways. The expression patterns of the Bearded (Brd), Ocho and escargot (esg) genes were assayed in wildtype and zld mutants as they are known to be expressed in NE cells. Zld was found to regulate the expression of Brd and esg, but not Ocho, suggesting that Zld only regulates certain genes involved in NE-to-NB transition. Many of the regulatory mechanisms involved in controlling NE cell fate are conserved between Drosophila and humans. Uncovering the molecular mechanisms through which Zld controls the NE-to-NB transition can lead to a better understanding of human neurodevelopmental diseases and brain tumors, as well as identifying targets for treatment.Neural stem cellsNervous systemDrosophilaBatbold, Sarah. Investigating variation in Trichomonas vaginalis cytotoxicity and growth rate.2016-004581222016Trichomonas vaginalis is a flagellated parasitic protist and the causative agent of trichomoniasis, the world's most prevalent non-viral STI. Significant variation has been observed in the nature and severity of clinical manifestations of T. vaginalis infection, with only about 50% of infected women and an even lower proportion of infected men exhibiting any observable symptoms of trichomoniasis. The genetic bases for this – either in the parasite or the host – remains unknown. This study was undertaken to investigate variation in T. vaginalis cytotoxicity and growth rate across 15 different global isolates of the parasite. We found significant variation in cytotoxicity across different isolates of T. vaginalis. In particular, type 1 isolates exhibited significantly higher (p less than 0.05) cytotoxicity than type 2 isolates. Growth rates also differed between isolates, however no correlation was found between cytotoxicity and growth rate.AD-MC-0042016-0045

Variation and Parameters Associated with Plasmodium falciparum Malaria Parasitemia in a Pediatric Cohort in Burkina Faso.2016-004280932016Studies have shown that malaria severity positively correlates with parasitemia, which depends on host immune status, parasite virulence, and environmental factors. In this project, variation and parameters associated with Plasmodium falciparum malaria parasitemia in a cohort of 150 children in Burkina Faso were investigated. Quantitative real-time PCR (qRTPCR) analysis of saliva samples revealed that detection of parasitemia in saliva is possible, but further optimization is required for consistent detection of samples with low parasite counts. The non-invasive nature of saliva collection and low limit of detection of qRT-PCR can potentially increase earlier detection and treatment of malaria infection. Analysis of blood cell counts has shown that platelets, neutrophils/lymphocytes ratio and eosinophils were significantly associated with parasitemia in infected children highlighting the role these cells play in the immune defense against malaria infection. Gene expression profiling of 48 genes, which are involved in genetic predisposition and resistance to Malaria infection, revealed 17 genes whose expression is associated with parasitemia levels. These results highlight some of the factors controlling parasite load during malaria infection and will help understand how the disease progresses and what factors modulate children's resistance/susceptibility to symptomatic malaria infection.AD-MC-0042016-0042

Cell-Penetrating Peptide Inhibitors of Amyloid Formation And Cytotoxicity.2016-003580972016The misfolding and aggregation of protein into amyloid fibrils has been associated with major human diseases, including Alzheimer's disease, prion diseases and type II diabetes. Here, we study the effect of two novel peptide constructs, NCAM-prion and NCAM-Aβ, which are composed of the Neural Cell Adhesion Molecule 1 (NCAM 1) signal sequence combined with an 'NLS' like motif from an amyloid protein, to determine whether they can effectively inhibit amyloidogenesis. Using ThT assay and TEM, we demonstrate that these peptide constructs can inhibit amyloid formation of IAPP and Aβ, proteins associated with type II diabetes and Alzheimer's disease, respectively. In addition, our cell toxicity assays indicate that NCAM-prion and NCAM-Aβ are effective inhibitors of IAPP-induced cytotoxicity. Through confocal microscopy, we also show that the inhibitors are cell-penetrating peptides (CPPs) that localize to the mitochondria, which has been suggested as a target in a number of amyloid diseases, including type II diabetes and Alzheimer's disease. The ability of these peptide constructs to enter cells efficiently, and inhibit both aggregation and cytotoxicity of IAPP and Aβ underlines their potential therapeutic value. These promising findings also give us insight into developing a 'universal inhibitor' of amyloid protein aggregation and cytotoxicity.AD-MC-0042016-0035
Scope and Contents

The ability of these peptide constructs to enter cells efficiently, and inhibit both aggregation and cytotoxicity of IAPP and Aβ underlines their potential therapeutic value. These promising findings also give us insight into developing a 'universal inhibitor' of amyloid protein aggregation and cytotoxicity.Ridgeway, Samuel. 16S rRNA Metagenomic Profiling of the Faecal Microbiota in Falcons.2016-004481052016Falcons (genus: Falco) are birds of prey. Saker, Gyr, Peregrines, and hybrids of these species are the most popular birds used for falconry in the Arabian Gulf. There has been limited research on the gut microbiome of falcons though it may help in understanding their nutrition and susceptibility to bacterial infections. Here we describe the first study of the bacterial communities in faecal matter of Peregrine, Gyr, Saker pure and hybrid falcons using 16S rRNA amplicon sequencing. The analysis of 3,694 operational taxonomic units showed the most abundant bacteria in falcons' faecal microbiota are Clostridia (52.4% std13.8) and Bacilli (14.4% std5.9). Dominance of Clostridia across the falcons investigated indicates a major difference in microbial community composition between falcons and other avian species. Qualitative comparison of microbial community composition shows that the presence and dominance of few major microbial classes is largely conserved across the sampled falcon groups and individual falcon variation is driven mostly by relative abundance of specific taxonomic units. The results contribute to the continually growing database of avian microbiomes that can be used for comparative studies and lays the foundation for further systematic evaluations of microbial community composition in falcons.AD-MC-0042016-0044

The effect of seasonal extremes on photosynthetic health of the grey mangrove (Avicennia marina) in a high latitude arid environment.2016-002881462016Mangroves are an essential part of habitats all over the world. They support numerous bird and fish species and play an important role in the preservation of coastlines. Most mangroves around the world grow in coastal wetlands found in tropical and subtropical regions. One such species, Avicennia marina, also called the grey mangrove, grows and thrives under extreme conditions of heat and light stress in the Arabian Gulf. We sought to address how photosynthetic efficiency changes in response to seasonal stress. We analyzed photosynthetic efficiency in A. marina leaves using chlorophyll fluorescence on natural and afforested mangroves, and HPLC on targeted metabolites in select natural samples. Both our Fv/Fm values and HPLC analyses suggest a significantly reduced photosynthetic efficiency in summer natural samples but no significant differences between seasons for afforested mangroves. In order to further clarify the metabolic changes that accompany stress we characterized the metabolome of A. marina leaves in summer and winter samples. We noted the elevation of certain compounds such as polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons and anti fungal secondary metabolites in summer samples. The greater abundance of pheophytin-a in winter sample suggest a higher photosynthetic efficiency of A. marina in the winter season.AD-MC-0042016-0028

Scheduling the End of Neural Progenitor Divisions in the Inner Prolferation Center of the Drosophila melanogaster Optic Lobes.2016-004781092016Establishing the correct number of neurons is of vital importance to achieve the appropriate form and function of the brain by the end of development. One way of controlling the number of neurons produced is by regulating the proliferation of their progenitors. In the Drosophila central nervous system (CNS) a temporal series of transcription factors in the neuronal progenitors, called Neuroblasts (NBs), specifies neuronal identity in a birth order dependent manner and schedules the termination of NB proliferation by either Prospero-dependent-cell cycle exit or hid/ reaper/grim/sickle-mediated apoptosis. In the CNS, the timing of division termination through either process relies on the combined activity of members of the temporal series and their indirect feed forward targets, Dichaete and Grainyhead. Here we provide evidence that in the developing optic lobes of Drosophila, the NBs in the ventral tip of the Inner Proliferation Center do not progress though a temporal transcription factor series, yet still manage to schedule apoptosis.AD-MC-0042016-0047

Influence of environmental extremes on reef fish trophic ecology: A metagenomics approach.2016-007881032016The Arabian Gulf constitutes a harsh environment for marine life. Some of its key features 52 are sea-surface temperatures that range from 12 °C in winter to over 36 °C in summer and 53 hyper-salinity (>40 PSU) year round. One expected consequence of these environmental 54 extremes is a variation in the diet of the Gulf's reef fish compared with conspecific reef fish 55 from more benign environments, as diet is expected to vary as an adaptive response to the 56 seasonal changes in the environment and associated food items. Despite its unique 57 environmental conditions limited research is available on reef fish feeding ecology in the 58 Arabian Gulf. Using a metagenomics approach, we surveyed seasonal variation in the diet of 59 three abundant fish species associated with reefs in the extreme southern Gulf (Abu Dhabi, 60 UAE): Pomacentrus aquilus, Pomacentrus trichrourus, and Pomacanthus maculosus. The 61 results of this study provide the first quantitative assessment of the dietary habits of reef fish 62 in the Arabian Gulf. Our analyses show that that there are strong compositional shifts in diets 63 across seasons in all three species. The overall dominant diet content organisms, at the 64 phylum level, were Porifera, Cnidaria, and Arthropoda. A variety of items that presented in 65 the content have not been previously associated with the dietary habits of these fish in other 66 regions, suggesting that these species have developed a distinct feeding ecology that is unique 67 to this region, likely as a result of the effects of the extreme environmental conditions in 68 structuring food resource availability.AD-MC-0042016-0078

Development of tumor-specific drug delivery platforms through coupling of liposomes to pH-sensitive membrane insertion peptides.2016-002981482016This project exploits extracellular acidity, a salient feature of the microenvironment of solid tumors, to develop a drug delivery system with high specificity for cancer cells in order to prevent harmful targeting of healthy tissue and enhance the potency of the drugs by accumulating them at the tumors. To achieve this we coupled drug-encapsulating liposomes to short peptide sequences, the pH-low insertion peptide (pHLIP) and the novel acidity-triggered rational membrane peptide (ATRAM) that interact weakly with cell membranes at physiological pH and insert into the lipid bilayer at acidic pH. We used cell viability assays, confocal microscopy, and flow cytometry to characterize the cellular uptake and drug delivery capacity of ATRAM under physiological and acidic pH. We demonstrated that ATRAM promotes cellular uptake of PEGylated liposomes, particularly at low pH that mimics the tumor environment. We also found that, similar to pHLIP, the C-terminus of ATRAM is the membrane-binding domain, while N-terminus can be utilized as a cargo-binding site. Our results show that encapsulating therapeutics in liposomes and coupling them to ATRAM is a promising tool for targeted delivery of anticancer therapeutics.AD-MC-0042016-0029
