Characterisation of Symbiodinium communities in Singapore's marginal coral reef environment2017-00352017Singapore marine waters are characterized by high turbidity due to widespread coastal development. Corals receive over 90% of metabolic energy from photosynthetic symbiotic algae (zooxanthallae) that live within the coral. Such light-limited environments as Singapore thus represent marginal conditions that should limit reef development. However, over 60 coral reefs have been reported across Singapore, containing at least 255 species of hard corals. Corals' sensitivity to environmental conditions varies with different coral-associated symbionts. Given the relatively stressful environment it is expected that Singapore's corals likely harbor stress-tolerant zoothanthallae, but symbiont communities there are largely unexplored. This study used NGS to explore the symbiont composition in five dominant coral species collected from six major coral reef sites across Singapore. Out of 19 distinct OTUs identified in this study, just two (C_01 and D_01) dominated the symbiont community (average percent coverage >90% across all sites and host coral species). BLAST analysis identified C_01 and D_01 as Symbiodinium sub-clades C30/C27 and D1, respectively. The results of this study provide important insights into how coral communities respond to marginal environmental conditions in an area characterized by high turbidity.AD-MC-0042017-0035
Scope and Contents
Singapore marine waters are characterized by high turbidity due to widespread coastal development. Corals receive over 90% of metabolic energy from photosynthetic symbiotic algae (zooxanthallae) that live within the coral. Such light-limited environments as Singapore thus represent marginal conditions that should limit reef development. However, over 60 coral reefs have been reported across Singapore, containing at least 255 species of hard corals. Corals' sensitivity to environmental conditions varies with different coral-associated symbionts. Given the relatively stressful environment it is expected that Singapore's corals likely harbor stress-tolerant zoothanthallae, but symbiont communities there are largely unexplored. This study used NGS to explore the symbiont composition in five dominant coral species collected from six major coral reef sites across Singapore. Out of 19 distinct OTUs identified in this study, just two (C_01 and D_01) dominated the symbiont community (average percent coverage >90% across all sites and host coral species). BLAST analysis identified C_01 and D_01 as Symbiodinium sub-clades C30/C27 and D1, respectively. The results of this study provide important insights into how coral communities respond to marginal environmental conditions in an area characterized by high turbidity.Tran, Thinh. Determining the identities and functions of missing temporal transcription factors in the Drosophila optic lobes2017-00372017The sequential expression of transcription factors (TFs) in neural progenitors activates or represses different genes, and thus generates different types of neurons from a homogenous pool of stem cells. In the fruit fly, neuroblasts that give rise to the optic lobes sequentially express five TFs to specify different neural fates. However, two TFs in the cascade fail to regulate each other's expression, in contrast to the other three TFs, which suggests that there exists at least one missing TF that acts between them. This study aims to identify the missing TF(s) through a genetic screen. After testing the potential of ~190 TFs for being part of the temporal cascade, I identified three primary candidates, Nuclear factor Y (NF-Y), homeobrain and max. The knowledge of the missing TF will allow us to further examine how temporal patterning progresses and contributes to the generation of neuronal diversity in the optic lobe.AD-MC-0042017-0037
Scope and Contents
The sequential expression of transcription factors (TFs) in neural progenitors activates or represses different genes, and thus generates different types of neurons from a homogenous pool of stem cells. In the fruit fly, neuroblasts that give rise to the optic lobes sequentially express five TFs to specify different neural fates. However, two TFs in the cascade fail to regulate each other's expression, in contrast to the other three TFs, which suggests that there exists at least one missing TF that acts between them. This study aims to identify the missing TF(s) through a genetic screen. After testing the potential of ~190 TFs for being part of the temporal cascade, I identified three primary candidates, Nuclear factor Y (NF-Y), homeobrain and max. The knowledge of the missing TF will allow us to further examine how temporal patterning progresses and contributes to the generation of neuronal diversity in the optic lobe.Torres, Gabriel Figueroa. Impact of infection and treatment on epigenetic profiles of malarial children in Burkina Faso2017-00282017Malaria is a major public health problem with 3.3 billion individuals at risk in tropical and subtropical regions of the world and an estimated 438,000 deaths in 2015. Major advances have been made in understanding the epidemiology and pathobiology of the disease. However, little is know about the genetic and epigenetic mechanisms modulating variation in host immune response against the parasite. In this project, we investigate variation in genome-wide epigenetic profiles of circulating immune cells of children from Burkina Faso before and during infection, and after treatment using more than 850,000 epigenetic markers from the Infinium MethylationEPIC BeadChip. Our results revealed major and statistically significant changes in the epigenetic profiles of children in response both to infection and treatment and the genomic regions underlying these changes - including five genes within the human Major Histocompatibility Complex (MHC). These results highlight the role epigenetic factors play in modulating response to malaria infection.AD-MC-0042017-0028
Scope and Contents
Malaria is a major public health problem with 3.3 billion individuals at risk in tropical and subtropical regions of the world and an estimated 438,000 deaths in 2015. Major advances have been made in understanding the epidemiology and pathobiology of the disease. However, little is know about the genetic and epigenetic mechanisms modulating variation in host immune response against the parasite. In this project, we investigate variation in genome-wide epigenetic profiles of circulating immune cells of children from Burkina Faso before and during infection, and after treatment using more than 850,000 epigenetic markers from the Infinium MethylationEPIC BeadChip. Our results revealed major and statistically significant changes in the epigenetic profiles of children in response both to infection and treatment and the genomic regions underlying these changes - including five genes within the human Major Histocompatibility Complex (MHC). These results highlight the role epigenetic factors play in modulating response to malaria infection.Al Mheiri, Ghareesa. Probing the Structure of a Catalytically Active Unique Minimal Hammerhead Ribozyme and Determining its Biological Relevance2018-00872018AD-MC-0042018-0087
Scope and Contents
Hammerhead Ribozymes (HHRs) are single-folded RNA motifs that undergo the reversible autocatalytic self-cleavage. The RNA motif of interest, N15, was found to carry out catalysis despite its stem-loop II structure being shorter. Two structural conformations were found to stabilize the core of the minimal N15min7, LCI (loop II-core interaction) and LSI (loop II-loop I interactions), which then facilitate catalytic activity of the RNA molecule. To further examine the HHR, N15min7 was assayed at 1 mM of MgCl2 to determine if these interactions are maintained at lower concentrations of divalent metal ions. When assaying the wild-type (WT) N15min7, LSI and LCI structures with deoxy-base substitution at lower concentrations of MgCl2, no significant difference in catalytic activity was observed among these three structures, indicating that an alternative interaction is taking place. Our results indicate that despite an overly simplistic structure, the N15min7 requires multiple interactions to catalyze self-cleavage at varying concentrations of divalent metal ions. Furthermore, the biological relevance of the N15min7 motif was determined by extensive computational searches for N15min7-like structures in a collection of ~8,000 genomes. The search identified ~100 instances of N15min7 sequences that can potentially form catalytically active structures.Baby, Dhanya. Generation of a Wolbachia Secretome Resource for High-Throughput Analysis of Lymphatic Filariasis2018-00712018AD-MC-0042018-0071
Scope and Contents
Lymphatic filariasis is caused by the parasitic nematode, Brugia malayi. These roundworms persist in the human host for years, and the suspected mechanism is immunomodulation of the human immune system. Most of the filarial nematodes including B. malayi harbour an endosymbiotic bacterium, Wolbachia in their lateral chords. The goal of this project was to generate a comprehensive resource to enable functional proteomics studies of the interactions between Wolbachia and human. We produced an Open Reading Frame (ORF) resource for high-throughput experimentation by synthesizing a subset of ORFs of secreted Wolbachial proteins. We successfully cloned over 80% of our synthesized ORFs into two destination vectors optimized for high-throughput experimentation, namely Yeast 2-Hybrid screening and protein expression. Gene expression analysis indicated genes up-regulated during infectious stages were associated with protein folding and chaperone functions, suggesting a likelihood of increased protein production during infectious stages. We also conducted in silico protein analysis to understand the function of protein products in our subset. Our genome-scale Yeast 2-Hybrid Screen with our cloned ORFs against the human ORFeome yielded 3 of the Wolbachial proteins, involved in DNA repair, potentially interacting with human gene products.Bhagani, Humna. Exploring the role of the heterogeneous nuclear ribonucleoprotein CBF-A in neuronal development 2018-00702018AD-MC-0042018-0070
Scope and Contents
Posttranscriptional regulation of gene expression is an essential mechanism that controls development and differentiation in cells. Here, we focused on the role of the heterogeneous ribonucleoprotein CBF-A, known to regulate mRNA transport by binding the RNA trafficking sequence located on the 3' UTR of mRNA transcripts. We applied genome wide approaches to MEFs from a CBF-A KO mouse to examine whether CBF-A mediates RNA trafficking at an early stage during RNA biogenesis in developing neurons. RNA-seq analysis of CBF-A KO and heterozygous (HT) MEFs showed that there are many neuronal genes altered in the absence of CBF-A. We then chemically reprogrammed CBF-A KO and HT MEFs into neuron-like cells. Immunostaining confirmed differential expression of neuronal markers. To begin characterizing the induced neurons, we tested 150 neuronal and fibroblast- specific primers on WT MEFs and reprogrammed neurons to create a primer profile for future analyses. Results from this study confirm a primary role of CBF-A in RNA biogenesis and begins to highlight its importance in achievement of cell fate during neuronal development.Choi, JooHee. Characterizing the Transposable Element Landscape of Date Palm (Phoenix dactylifera)2018-00522018AD-MC-0042018-0052
Scope and Contents
The date palm (Phoenix dactylifera) is a culturally and economically important crop across the Middle East, South Asia, and Northern Africa- yet our understanding of its genome remains relatively limited. This study aims to detect and characterize the transposable element (TE) landscape in this significant species through a novel combination of both library-based (Repeatmodeler) and k-mer based (REPdenovo) computational methods. The resulting consensus reads were masked via Repeatmasker and mapped to a gene map (NCBI: GCF_000413155.1_DPV01). Of the 500Mb genome assmbly, 38% was annotated as repetitive elements, of which LTR Copia and Gypsy were predominant. Comparison of element length and divergence indicate that LTR Copia elements are likely young and recently active. When mapped against regions upstream and downstream to genes, there was a relative abundance of Gypsy upstream compared to Copia, that may suggest an innate insertion bias at play. Of the elements uniquely assembled by REPdenovo, a majority were identified as plastid-derived sequences. Estimates suggest approximately 0.2% of the date palm genome consists of such elements, highlighting a category of plant DNA often overlooked. Through this study, we provide a TE-level understanding of the date palm genome structure that may act as a "roadmap" in future palm studies.Degutis, Karolis. Investigation of Top-down and Bottom-up Signals in Visual Working Memory in V12018-00762018AD-MC-0042018-0076
Scope and Contents
Working memory (WM) allows for the maintenance of information over short periods of time when the initial source of the information is no longer present. In this study, we investigated whether the visual WM signal in the primary visual cortex (V1) is top-down or bottom-up using 3T functional magnetic resonance imaging (fMRI). A top-down signal would indicate storage of visual WM outside of V1, while a bottom-up signal would indicate V1 maintenance. The direction of the signal was operationalized with an Attention and Perception task; each one activating distinct neural populations within V1. These patterns of activity were then compared using multivoxel pattern analysis (MVPA) to the pattern elicited from a visual WM task. The study replicated previous results by finding orientation-selective information present in V1 without a high-amplitude sustained BOLD response. We also found significant similarity between the patterns of the visual WM and Attention tasks. These results suggest a top-down signal in V1 during the maintenance of visual WM, consistent with the idea that visual WM is not maintained within V1.Fadil, Chaimaa. Single-Cell Transcriptome Profiling of the Drosophila Optic Lobe Suggests a Regulation of Terminal Characters by Cell Type-Specific Transcription Factor Cohorts2018-00942018AD-MC-0042018-0094
Scope and Contents
Understanding how a system comes to be and what its different components are is critical to deciphering its mode of action. In multicellular organisms, it is now established that transcription factors expressed during development play a key role in specifying cell fate. However, to better encompass cellular diversity, we are yet to understand how molecular specification translates into character acquisition. This study takes a holistic and unbiased approach to molecularly characterize cellular diversity in the adult Drosophila optic lobe based on Drop-seq single-cell RNA-seq of 57,000 cells. With unsupervised analysis and differential expression testing, I identified 52 clusters of transcriptionally distinct single-cell populations. I annotated several clusters by correspondence to known cell types on the basis of canonical markers or by characterizing cells' localization and projection patterns using Gal4 lines. Regulatory interactions between the transcription factors apterous and traffic-jam and the respective markers of cholinergic and glutamatergic neurons, ChAT and VGlut, were confirmed by gene knock-down through RNAi. Interestingly, these results, in addition to a weighted gene co-expression network analysis (WGCNA), showed that cell types with similar phenotypes do not necessarily share the same transcription factor signature, thus suggesting that phenotypic convergence is a likely cellular evolutionary model in Drosophila.Govind, Jigar. Long-Term Balancing Selection at MHC class I loci in the Ethiopian frog Leptopelis gramineus2018-00772018AD-MC-0042018-0077
Scope and Contents
In the defense against diseases, organisms must maintain a repertoire of molecules that can respond to the variety of pathogens in their habitat. The variety of pathogenic threats present in one's surroundings depends on several environmental variables, including climate. Here I isolated and analyzed class I MHC sequences from the Ethiopian frog Leptopelis gramineus, sampled across a heterogeneous habitat range, to investigate the relationship between demography, population structure and climate in the context of immunogenetic variation. I hypothesized that the signature of balancing selection is stronger in warmer climates. I used neutral markers to reconstruct the demographic history of each clade belonging to L. gramineus, measured genetic diversity, differentiation, and gene flow, and simulated these measures against neutral scenarios. While intra-specific subpopulation Tajima's D and Fu and Li's analyses revealed strong evidence for balancing selection, inter-specific analysis revealed a lack of clear genetic structure at MHC class I loci with respect to differences in clade, elevation difference, and geographical distance. Instead, the data demonstrate clear effects of long-term balancing selection that may predate the spatial dispersal of L. gramineus across Ethiopia.Jankauskas, Robertas. During differentiation nuclear beta-actin regulates neuronal gene programs2018-00642018AD-MC-0042018-0064
Scope and Contents
During the process of cellular differentiation global changes in chromatin lead to genome organization and the suppression and activation of gene programs. Emerging evidence indicates that nuclear β-actin is a major regulator of genome organization. β-actin performs this important function by regulating genomic deposition of the BAF chromatin remodeling complex. This leads to tethering of heterochromatin to the NL while controlling the level of euchromatin. To further study the role of nuclear actin in these processes and its potential impact on development and differentiation, here we implemented a direct reprogramming protocol on embryonic fibroblasts from a β-actin knockout mouse to directly reprogram them into induced neurons. We report differences in neuronal morphology between WT, HET, and KO cell lines arising from differential gene expression levels. Many of the compromised genes were found to be downregulated in a β-acting dosage dependent manner. GO term analysis found that these changes compromised programs related to neuronal development. Reintroducing an NLS containing β-actin in the KO cells positively affected neuron specific marker expression. Because the model organism is embryonic lethal at developmental stage 10.5 we conclude that nuclear β-actin helps regulate neuronal gene expression during development.Kirwan, Liam Ingmar. Identification of Natural Products from Sponge/Tunicate-Associated Bacterial Species in the Abu Dhabi Region2018-00722018AD-MC-0042018-0072
Scope and Contents
Marine invertebrate-associated bacteria are a promising source of natural products, especially in harsh conditions (such as Abu Dhabi) where metabolitefacilitated adaptation is necessary. This paper outlines a method of advanced bacterial isolation and high-content screening of crude bacterial cell extracts and SPE fractions, with the aim of identifying biologically active natural products through a process of cytological profiling and image analysis. Mammalian cell and C. elegans screens revealed the presence of a significantly toxic compound produced by a Vibrio sp. proteobacterium along with several other compounds that exhibit some form of phenotypic effect. Liquid chromatography-mass spectrometry was performed to provide insight into the potential chemical formulae of biologically active compounds. Phenotypic profiles and mass spectra were created for all active fractions, providing a solid foundation for future characterization of chemical structure and mode-of-action.Manzoor, Ridda. Regulation of Transposon Expression by DNA methylation in Zebrafish uhrf1 mutants2018-00922018AD-MC-0042018-0092
Scope and Contents
DNA methylation is a major epigenetic modification and its loss is associated with autoimmune disease, re-expression of oncogenes and the activation of transposable elements (TEs). This project aimed to investigate the relationship between TE expression and DNA methylation, as well as characteristics of TEs that could be contributing to expression. Previous RNA-seq analysis identified the top 10 upregulated TEs in uhrf1 mutants as compared to wild type (WT) larvae. Here, I analyzed the genomic features of these TEs and their pattern of expression by in situ hybridization (ISH). Bioinformatics analysis showed a significant correlation (r=0.6328 for WT and r=0.5871 for uhrf1 mutants) between read counts and number of full length reads. ISH showed significant expression of TEs in both the WT and uhrf1 mutant larvae, particularly in the brain, eyes and jaws. In the mutants, we observed a difference in signal in some TEs, but not major differences in the pattern of expression between WT and uhrf1 mutants. Phylogenetic analysis of the reverse transcriptase domains of the LTR Gypsy elements showed that Gypsy117-I_DR expressed the greatest fold change.Mo, Ziyi. Phylogenetics of date palm (Phoenix dactylifera) and closely related wild species elucidates the nature of introgressive hybridization between North African date palm and Phoenix theophrasti2018-00862018AD-MC-0042018-0086
Scope and Contents
The domestication history of date palm (Phoenix dactylifera), an important staple crop in the Middle East and North Africa, is not well understood. The popular model of domestication argues that date palm originated from the Middle East and later spread westward to North Africa via trade routes. However, higher observed nucleotide diversity within the North African date palm population suggests that the North African population is not the product of recent colonization, thereby contradicting the model. This study of 71 date palm cultivars from across Middle East and North Africa and 6 of its closely related wild species reconciles the higher observed nucleotide diversity in North African population and the popular domestication model by demonstrating that the North African date palm population is a result of introgressive hybridization between date palm and P. theophrasti. Linkage disequilibrium analysis and phylogeny of phased haplotypes in highly introgressed genomic region provide evidence for intro- gression, whereas chloroplast and mitochondrial phylogeny reveals that hybridization occurred through pollination of date palm offshoots by P. theophrasti.Nehme, Mona. Adaptation of mitochondrial Oxidative Phosphorylation Genes to High Altitude in Leptopelis gramineus2018-00492018AD-MC-0042018-0049
Scope and Contents
Harsh environmental conditions are common characteristics of high altitudes, such as those in the Ethiopian highlands. This can be detrimental to the survival of maladapted organisms, yet these areas continue to be biodiversity hotspots. This alludes to adaptive selection that equips high altitude organisms, such as Ethiopian endemic frog Leptopelis gramineus , with the capacity to survive in hazardous conditions. The mitochondrial genome has been previously shown to be crucial in adaptation due to it comprising of rapidly evolving non-recombining sequences. In this paper, I studied the role played by mtOXPHOS genes in adaptation to high altitude in L. gramineus using aBSREL, FEL, and MEME analytical methods . Diversifying selection was found in codons 42 in ATP8 and 311 and 317 in ND1. However, this selection could not be attributed to adaptation to high altitude considering the individuals who expressed the necessary mutations were collected from varying altitudes. The result could also potentially be related to incomplete lineage sorting resulting from high mutation rates in the addressed codon positions. Therefore, further analysis is needed in order to determine the role of ATP8 and ND1 on L. gramineus high altitude adaptation.Šabanović, Merima. What it takes to be at the top: The complex interrelationship between chronic social stress and social dominance2018-01032018AD-MC-0042018-0103
Scope and Contents
Most animal societies are organized in dominance hierarchies that affect an individual's reproductive success and access to resources. Exposure to stress is one of many complex factors contributing to hierarchy formation, but a hierarchical status itself can be stress-inducing. I aimed to elucidate the complex relationship between stress and dominance by delineating how social rank predicts vulnerability to social stress and whether chronic stress modulates hierarchy establishment. Using the C57 mouse model, hierarchical rank is studied using an automated social confrontation tube test that is consistent with at least three other dominance measures. Chronic social stress is mimicked by the chronic social defeat (CSD) paradigm that induces a depressive-like phenotype in stress-susceptible mice. I show that exposure to chronic stress predicts higher success in subsequent hierarchy formation. The mice that underwent CSD exhibited markedly higher winning ratios than their stress-naïve conspecifics. Results also suggest that the differences in social competitiveness are not related to the overall differences in stress-susceptibility, but hierarchical status may predispose the subordinate ranks to decreased baseline social preference. In contrast, dominant males are liable to higher anxious-like behavior following CSD-stress. Furthermore, I also demonstrate how individual housing conditions markedly increases a range of anxiety-like behaviors. I additionally report preliminary data on a neural circuit potentially underlying dominance- and stress-specific signal integration.Saleh, Hadi Omar. CPP-Cargo Complex Translocation in Model Membrane Systems: Experiments and Simulations2018-00572018AD-MC-0042018-0057
Scope and Contents
Cancer is a disease of multicellular organisms characterized by uncontrolled cell division. The vast majority of all human cancers are directly linked to carcinogen exposure, which leads to a series of genetic changes that progressively alter the growth properties of cells. Chemotherapy relies on the use of chemical agents to disrupt cell division as a means of curtailing the proliferation of tumor cells, but in doing so they inflict great collateral damage on healthy tissues. One of the most powerful capabilities of cell penetrating peptides (CPPs) is their capacity to deliver a wide variety of compounds and macromolecules into the cytosol in an active form. Previous studies have shown CPPs to be a promising platform for the delivery of conventional chemotherapeutics into cells; tumor-targeting has been achieved in-vivo. In this study we use molecular dynamics simulations to study the uptake mechanisms of novel CPPs derived from Hexokinase II and compare their performance to Polyarginine peptide in human breast cancer cell line MCF-7.Semesta, Khairunnisa. Nuclear myosin I is required for chromatin maintenance and transcriptional regulation2018-00802018AD-MC-0042018-0080
Scope and Contents
Nuclear myosin I (NMI) is implicated in several nuclear processes, such as chromatin remodeling by the B-WICH complex, establishment of histone marks, and transcription facilitated by RNA Polymerase I and II. However, the the current knowledge of its global role in transcription remains limited. Using high-content screening of embryonic fibroblasts from NMIknockout (KO) mouse, we report significant changes in histone modifications, such as acetylated histone(H)3-lysine-(K)9 and acetylated histone(H)3-lysine-(K)27, marker of active transcription and active enhancer regions respectively. Confocal microscopy and Western blot analysis confirmed the reorganization of chromatin structure and histone modifications in the absence of NMI. Transcriptomic analysis revealed that these genome-wide changes in the level of histone modifications are accompanied by a significant differential expression of genes associated with cellular response to DNA damage and DNA repair. We propose that NMI plays an important role in establishing histone modifications through its interaction with chromatin remodeling complexes, leading to proper activation of DNA damage response gene programs.Wunsche, Leonore. Endoplasmic Reticulum Morphology as an Indicator for Stress Severity2018-00662018AD-MC-0042018-0066
Scope and Contents
The Unfolded Protein Response (UPR) serves to counteract the accumulation of proteins in the Endoplasmic Reticulum (ER) during stress. The initial phases of the UPR are adaptive, but chronic activation leads to cell dysfunction and pathology, such as steatosis. We reasoned that alterations in ER morphology would occur during an adaptive phase, where ER phenotypes could indicate early stress responses. We tested this utilizing intravital confocal imaging of 5 dpf transgenic zebrafish expressing a hepatocyte specific ER marker. We defined seven ER phenotypes in during various stress conditions (tunicamycin, ethanol, trappc11 and nAtf6) and scored for their prevalence. Tunicamycin, a well-established ER-stressor, caused motile punctae which retained the fluorescent ER label. These emerged at 12 hours and were present in 74% of larvae after 24 hours of tunicamycin exposure. Furthermore, the ER punctae colocalised with LysoTracker, a fluorescent dye staining acidic structures. Gene expression analysis showed UPR target gene upregulation in livers from larvae with extensive ER punctae prevalence, compared to those looking like controls. Thus, our ER marker represents a proxy for identifying ER stress states, where morphology changes can indicate the fish most prone to disease.Jansen, Gloria. Effect of Chronic Social Stress on Homeostatic Sleep Response2018-00652018AD-MC-0042018-0065
Scope and Contents
A remarkably conserved behavior, sleep is thought to restore neural circuits and their synaptic outputs. Clinical findings that sleep deprivation can reverse symptoms of depression support putative interactions between mood and sleep/wake regulation. The molecular pathways that govern these interactions remain ambiguous. Here, we exposed C57BL6/J mice to chronic social defeat stress (CSD), using social interaction and sucrose preference tests to determine susceptibility or resilience to stress. Combining electroencephalogram (EEG) analysis with transcriptomics of the ventral tegmental area (VTA) and laterodorsal tegmental nucleus (LDT) in the midbrain, we investigated homeostatic sleep response after 4-hour total sleep deprivation (TSD) in stress-susceptible and -resilient mice. Susceptible mice spent an average 9% more time in REM rebound sleep, while resilient mice exhibited elevated non-REM (NREM) sleep following TSD. Prolonging time awake by TSD had differential effects on expression of synaptic plasticity genes Arc and BDNF, potassium channels and neuroinflammatory genes in susceptible and resilient groups. Thus, we show that differential response to CSD stress influences global sleep architecture as well as localized molecular dynamics.Sveiczer, Zsofia. Evaluating 'activity-silent' and 'persistent neural activity' models of visual working memory2018-00692018AD-MC-0042018-0069
Scope and Contents
Currently there are two competing hypotheses about how neurons keep information active in WM. One commonly accepted theory claims that information is maintained in WM through 'persistent neural activity'. This refers to the idea that neurons keep information active through constant firing despite the fact that the information is no longer present. Recent evidence indicates that memories are also potentially stored through 'activity-silent' states, where the functional architecture of the neural network is altered in a way that memories instead of being active representations are being stored as a silent pattern of synaptic weights. While this 'activity-silent' model could provide a compelling explanation for some neural data, it doesn't constitute conclusive evidence yet. The overall aim of this research is to propose a novel way to evaluate the two potential models of visual WM, thus providing further evidence for potential mechanisms that could possibly present in WM. We tested this hypothesis behaviorally using a continuous report WM task, and neurally using functional MRI (fMRI) and multivoxel pattern analysis (MVPA) to uncover patterns of brain activity that contained information about WM items.Al-Ajlouni, Yazan. Investigating the Association between Midwakh smoking behaviors and risk factors of Cardiovascular Disease and Hypertension among UAE nationals: Findings from the UAE Healthy Future Study.2019-00922019AD-MC-0042019-0092
Scope and Contents
Midwakh is an emerging type of smoking, specifically popular among the youth in the Arab gulf region. Research on Midwakh smoking is limited to descriptive statistics regarding its spread in addition to simple analysis regarding its content. This study considers the association of Midwakh smoking, as compared to Cigarettes smoking, and the risk of Hypertension and CVD among a sample of adults in the UAE. 471Participants were recruited as part of the UAE Healthy Future Study. Modified Poisson models with robust error variance were computed to estimate risk ratios (RRs) and 95% confidence intervals (CI) for the associations between smoking behavior (e.g., Midwakh only, Dual-use with cigarettes or Shisha, or poly-use of Midwakh, Cigarettes, and Shisha) and measures of Hypertension (e.g., Systolic Blood Pressure, Diastolic Blood Pressure, and Heart Rate) and CVD measures (Cholesterol, Triglyceride, HDL, LDL, Apolipoprotein A, and Apolipoprotein B). Compared to smoking cigarettes, Midwakh smoking was significantly associated with increased risk of Apolipoprotein A and Low Density Lipoprotein (LDL). Future research should investigate whether this relationship is causal and study other health outcomes risks for smoking Midwakh among this high-risk population.Ali, Ghaniba. Population genetics of four commercially important fisheries species in the southern Arabian Gulf2019-01092019AD-MC-0042019-0109
Scope and Contents
Overharvesting has resulted in dramatic declines of stocks of commercial fish species in the UAE in recent years. Although a variety of management efforts have been put in place, there is currently limited information on the population dynamics of fish species in the UAE. This information is crucial to guide the development of Mrine Protected Areas. This study explored the population structure of four commercially important fish species in the UAE: Diagramma pictum (painted sweetlips), Carangoides bajad (orange-spotted trevally), Epinephelus coioides (orange-spotted grouper), and Lethrinus borbonicus (snubnose emperor). Using RADsequencing we report evidence of a significant population structure within D. pictum that divides the species into two populations across the southern Arabian Gulf. The other three species, C. bajad, E. coioides, and L. borbonicus, did not reveal a population structure, suggesting that this population homogeneity could potentially be a result of adult spawning aggregates or larval dispersal. The results have important implications for informing the design of future Marine Protected Areas in the southern Arabian Gulf.Aqel, Hala. Jet Lag as a Global Stressor: Effect of Shifting Light on Depressive-Like Behavior and Stress Susceptibility2019-00962019AD-MC-0042019-0096
Scope and Contents
Major depressive disorder (MDD) is a disease increasing in occurrence globally. One of the most significant factors contributing to the prevalence of depression is disruption of natural human circadian rhythmicity due to extended exposure to light in our technologically-driven societies. A well-studied stress paradigm of chronic social stress is mimicked by the chronic social defeat (CSD) paradigm that induces a distinct, robust depressive-like phenotype in stress-susceptible mice. Due to evidence indicating that shifting light cycles and mood are interconnected, I aim to investigate whether a chronic jet lag paradigm modelled in mice produces depression-like behavior comparable to the chronic social defeat paradigm. Although results are not statistically significant, qualitative analyses indicate that a chronic jet lag model is a comparable stressor, if not a stronger stressor, than chronic social stress.Chang, Yoonhoo. Investigating IgM response to P.falciparum infection2019-00912019AD-MC-0042019-0091
Scope and Contents
During the blood stage of malaria infection, invasion and multiplication of the Plasmodium parasites cause symptoms ranging from fever and chills to vital organ dysfunction. One of the most important factors source of variation in the severity of such symptoms is the host immune system. Host immune system consists of multiple layers of defense, but the ultimate step of an efficient response to clear the parasites is the production of immunoglobulins. Here we focus on immunoglobulins M (IgM) with the aim to clarify the nature of IgM changes taking place during the course of Plasmodium falciparum infection and if these changes are controlled by host genotype. The study population is a pediatric cohort in Burkina Faso, consisting of children sampled before infection, during asymptomatic infection, during symptomatic infection and three weeks after treatment. IgM levels were quantified using ELISA and compared between the four groups and tested for association with parasitemia in the symptomatic infection group. Furthermore, we report genetic variants in candidate genes associated with IgM levels. Combined, these results document changes of IgM levels in vivo in a pediatric cohort in Africa and show how host genotype can modulate IgM response to Plasmodium falciparum. Farrukh, Sannia. DNA damage dependent regulation of p53 pathway by Nuclear Myosin I2019-00812019AD-MC-0042019-0081
Scope and Contents
Nuclear myosin 1 (NM1) is an emerging key regulator of transcription and chromatin organization. It has been implicated in several nuclear processes involving chromatin remodeling and histone modifications. Recent studies have highlighted the role of myosins in DNA repair, however how NM1 regulates that pathway is still unknown. Using NM1 knockout mouse fibroblasts, we show that NM1 gene deletion leads to differential expression of genes involved in DNA damage response and cell cycle. We found that genes that are downstream p53 signaling are down regulated and that cells lacking NM1 display constitutive DNA damage foci. Based on these observations, we silenced NM1 by siRNA to study its function in response to DNA damage. Chromatin immunoprecipitation (ChIP) and qPCR analyses on cells subjected to NM1 knockdown revealed that NM1 binding to the p21 gene is enhanced upon DNA damage. Actin has many functions in the nucleus. Our lab recently showed that the loss of β-actin in mouse embryonic fibroblasts (MEF) leads to differential expression of gene programs related to development and differentiation, including neurogenesis. In this study, we directly reprogrammed MEFs to osteoblast-like cells. Firstly, we showed that mineralization of the extracellular matrix correlates with β-actin level: β-actin-/- KO cells show mineralization after 4 days, whereas β-actin+/-HET and β-actin+/+ WT cells require 8 and 14 days, respectively. Using Scanning Electron Microscopy, we also observed hydroxyapatite-like polycrystalline structures secreted exclusively by KO cells on day 4. We also performed RNA-seq analysis on all the CiOsteo cells, and found genes related to osteogenesis that are dysregulated between WT and KO CiOsteo cells. Lastly, we identified increased heterochromatization at the loci of key regulatory genes, such as Msx1 and Mmp13 that are downregulated in KO CiOsteo. Speciation and transposable element amplification in the Ethiopian frog species Ptychadena neumanni2019-01122019AD-MC-0042019-0112
Scope and Contents
Transposable elements (TEs) exhibit high variation in diversity and copy number in vertebrates, which has important evolutionary implications as they constitute a source of evolutionary novelties. The dynamics of TEs are strongly affected by factors such as host demography. In small populations, genetic drift opposes the effect of negative selection and can result in the fixation of TE insertions that would be eliminated in large populations. The carrier subpopulation hypothesis predicts that population subdivision caused by vicariance or dispersal may trigger fixation of TE families by genetic drift. We used the Ethiopian Ptychadena neumanni species complex to test this hypothesis and to investigate any relation between speciation and TE amplification. Using a high-quality genome sequence for P. cf. neumanni 2, we identified 2342 repeat families de novo using RepeatModeler and characterized the repeat landscape of the frog using RepeatMasker. Resequencing data from six closely related frog species were used to identify mobile element insertions that differ among species. Our analysis revealed that the amplification of TEs is consistent with the evolutionary history of the host inferred by SNPs. We also observed substantial differences in the rate of amplification of TEs between species.Kapetancic, Erna. Scope and Contents
Chronic Myeloid Leukemia (CML) is a cancer characterized by increased growth of granulocytic precursors. Currently, there are two therapeutic strategies to CML: imatinib mesylate, and a combination of arsenic trioxide and IFN-α. Imatinib is effective in controlling the chronic phase of the disease, but it is not curative since most of patients who discontinue the therapy relapse. The combination of arsenic trioxide and IFN-α is a novel treatment, which has been shown to reduce the clonogenic activity of CML cells ex vivo, and prolong the survival of primary CML mice. However, the major downside of this combinatorial treatment is its lack of specificity. The present study aims to overcome this lack of specificity by creating BSA-PLGA nanoparticles which encapsulate arsenic trioxide and IFN-α. To specifically target CML cells, Y-R-A-P-W-P-P sequence (CML cell-associated peptide) was conjugated to BSA surface.In vitro, these nanoparticles showed to be more effective in inducing apoptosis in CML cell lines than the current therapeutic strategies to CML. In vivo, the nanoparticles depleted all GFP-positive CML cells from CML mice blood.Lakhiani, Priyanka. The accumulation of misfolded proteins in the endoplasmic reticulum (ER) triggers the unfolded protein response (UPR); activating transcription factor 6 (Atf6) mediates one of three branches of this signaling pathway. UPR induction, however, can manifest heterogeneously across distinct conditions, generating variable molecular signatures and pathogenic phenotypes. This study aimed to elucidate the role of Atf6 in mediating UPR induction in zebrafish livers by characterizing Atf6-regulated transcriptomic signatures under distinct stressors. Putative Atf6 target genes were curated via a predicted consensus sequence and scraping transcription factor databases. UPR genes were similarly identified by compiling genes annotated for relevant Reactome and Gene Ontology terms. Curated gene lists were analyzed using RNAseq data from an atf6-overexpressing transgenic model of UPR induction; Atf6 was sufficient to cause differential expression of 23.6% of Atf6 target genes and 34.5% of UPR genes. RNAseq data from livers exposed to ethanol and arsenic was integrated to identify downstream genes inducible under environments of ER stress. Thus, by analyzing transcriptomic patterns and their biological relevance, we found that Atf6 mediates distinct forms of UPR activation through complex regulatory programs dependent on cellular environment.McHardie, Tayla. The algae Chloroidium sp. UTEX 3007 is a potential sustainable alternative for palm oil production.A large proportion of the lipids produced by Chloroidium sp. UTEX 3007 are palmitic acid, the fatty acid which is the main constituent of palm oil. Chloroidium sp. UTEX 3007 has been found to only produce palmitic acid during stationary phase, which is a limiting factor for large-scale production. This study optimises palmitic acid production during growth phase in Chloroidium sp. UTEX 3007 via a workflow of UV mutagenesis and sorting for high-lipid producing mutants with FACS. Two rounds of mutagenesis and FACS selection were conducted, resulting in a population of high-lipid producing cells. Alongside FACS data, fluorescence microscopy results indicate increased lipid content in the mutant cells. FT-ICR/MS, GC-MS and Confocal Raman Microscopy were used to characterise the lipid composition of the mutant strains. Palmitic acid was found to be consistently produced in the mutant, and the saturation status of the mutant was unchanged relative to the wildtype.Mountcastle, Hayden. Scope and Contents
Tropical coral reef fish are under extreme thermal stress in the Persian/Arabian Gulf (PAG), with annual thermal fluctuations from winter lows of 12°C to summer highs of 36°C. Coral reef fish are exclusively ectotherms, so their physiological performance is directly tied to environmental temperatures and behavioral modulation is critical for ectotherms to regulate internal body temperatures. This study examined the effects of temperature and time of day on fish behavior in model fish from PAG, Lutjanus ehrenbergii (Blackspot snapper) and Scolopsis ghanam (Arabian monocle bream), at 18°C, 27°C, and 35.5°C between morning (07:15), noon (12:55), and evening (18:35). Specifically, five ecologically important behaviors: relative swimming speed, activity, exploration, sheltering, and sociability. Results showed that there were significant interactions between time of day and temperature on relative swimming speed, activity, and exploration, where each measure would increase as temperature increased and had peak values in the evening. Conversely, there were only interactions with temperature for S. ghanam, where sheltering was lowest at the thermal optimal 27°C. These behavioral modulations may be used to acclimate to extreme thermal stress within the region.Nayfeh, Layanne. The Salehi-Ashtiani lab has been optimizing the lipid content of microalgae, specifically the Chlamydomonas reinhardtii, to efficiently produce compounds that can serve as substitutes for fossil fuels. Previously, the lab has shown that through cycles of mutagenesis and selection, strains that accumulate high levels of lipid can be obtained. The broad objective of this project is to explore the hypothesis that there are specific epigenetic modifications involved in regulation of transcripts and can lead to increased lipid accumulation in the unicellular microalga under certain environmental conditions. To investigate, we carried out bisulfite sequencing and analyzed the results for a subset of 112 transcripts encoding 10 genes, which are involved in C. reinhardtii's lipid production pathways. Although there isn't substantial differences in methylation levels collectively between the parental C. reinhardtii (CC-503) strain and the CC-H5 mutant, there were two genes that showed significant differences in methylation levels. One drawback of chemotherapy is nonspecific targeting of normal cells by therapeutic molecules. This project focuses on developing and testing two drug delivery systems that exploit the low extracellular pH of the tumor environment to specifically target cancer cells, thus reducing harmful localization of therapeutics to healthy tissue, and increasing the potency of therapeutics. To achieve this pH sensitivity, drug-loaded carriers were coupled with a novel acidity triggered rational membrane (ATRAM) peptide which at physiological pH, lies parallel to the cell surface but at acidic pH, undergoes conformational change that drives insertion into the lipid bilayer. The first system is a Doxorubicin (Dox)-encapsulated, ATRAM N-coupled POPC-DSPE-PEG liposome system. The second system is a Dox encapsulated nanoparticle system consisting a poly (lactic-co-glycolic acid) (PLGA) core, a bovine serum albumin (BSA) shell crosslinked in situ with glutaraldehyde, and coupled ATRAM peptide. Cell viability assays show that ATRAM facilitates pH-dependent uptake of liposomes and NPs, and delivery of their cargo which leads to specific toxicity of Dox to cells at low pH conditionsYanez, Alvaro. Stress, sleep and sleep deprivation: How social defeat stress and sleep architecture affect each other 2019-01142019AD-MC-0042019-0114
Scope and Contents
Accumulating evidence suggests that depression is tightly associated with sleep. This interaction has been unsuccessfully modeled in mice due to a failure to adhere to common behavioral models of stress. Given the need to reliably investigate this relationship, the social defeat model of depression was used to determine how stress affects sleep architecture and sleep regulation, and how sleep can prevent or induce stress susceptibility. Combining EEG with transcriptomics of the medial prefrontal cortex, we found that mice susceptible to chronic social defeat (CSD) stress displayed fragmented NREM sleep with intrusions of wakefulness, which may be explained by differential expression of serotonergic receptors Htr1a/2a and afternoon blunting of Slc29a3 adenosine transport. Exposure to CSD increased the proportion of REM sleep at the beginning of the light cycle through more frequent but shorter bouts, which were associated with blunted morning expression of serotonergic signaling enzyme Prkcd and myelin function gene Mobp. Furthermore, manipulating sleep through TSD or REM deprivation (REMD) suggested that recovery sleep after REMD, but not TSD, may promote resilience to stress. Findings from this Capstone project therefore support the notion that susceptibility to stress and adaptive sleep responses mutually affect each other.Ahmad, Anique. Phenotypic divergence and marked population structure in the Arabian gray mangroves (Avicennia marina)2020-00902020AD-MC-0042020-0090
Scope and Contents
Population differentiation involves both selective and neutral factors and here we study patterns of neutral genetic divergence and phenotypic differentiation in the Arabian gray mangrove using genome-wide markers and a suite of leaf-associated morphological traits between the Arabian Sea, where oceanic conditions exist, and the geographically isolated stands from the Arabian Gulf, one of the hottest and most saline seas in the world. Multivariate analyses based neutral SNPs revealed marked population structure between and among the Arabian Gulf and the Arabian Sea, suggesting strong genetic drift and limited gene flow. Our analyses also showed that leaf stomatal density was 27% lower in populations inside the Arabian Gulf compared to those outside, an adaptive response to cope with the higher temperature and salinity of the Persian/Arabian Gulf. These results suggest that the combined effects of natural selection and drift in isolation are driving population divergence in the Arabian gray mangroves.

Malaria is a blood born disease that affects 300 million people annually and is caused by parasitic protozoans of the genus Plasmodium. Upon infection, transcriptional activation of host immune cells is required to mount an efficient immune response. Both genetic and epigenetic mechanisms are involved in the regulation of transcription, but little is known about these effects in malaria. Here we focus on documenting the temporal changes in chromatin accessibility of circulating immune cells at three stages: before infection, during asymptomatic parasitemia, and during symptomatic parasitemia. First, an Assay for Transposase-Accessible Chromatin ATAC-seq protocol was developed and optimized to frozen Peripheral Blood Mononuclear Cells PBMCs collected from malarial African children. Sequencing of bulk and single-cell ATAC-seq libraries generated high quality sequencing data that was analyzed using multiple pipelines. These analyses generated the first ATAC-seq data in malaria and provided genome-wide insight about temporal changes in chromatin accessibility and cell-types implicated during infection. scATAC-seq data revealed accessibility patterns that are masked in bulk analysis. These PBMCs accessibility maps are the foundation for future epigenetic studies aiming to better understand host in vivo immune response to malaria.

DNA methylation is an epigenetic modification that suppresses transposons and stabilizes the genome, and nearly all cancers are characterized by global DNA hypomethylation and, in some cases, hypermethylation at promoters of tumor suppressor genes. Given that one of the first responses to widespread oncogenic signals is the activation of tumor-suppressive processes, including cellular senescence, we asked whether global DNA hypomethylation activates oncogene and leads to senescence. We used 5 days post fertilization (dpf) zebrafish mutants that lack a key DNA methylation component, DNA methyltransferase 1 (dnmt1), to answer this question. Through our experiments and RNAseq analysis, we found that there's global DNA hypomethylation, senescence, up-regulation of immune response pathway genes, but no significant altered expression of oncogenes in dnmt1 mutant livers. We concluded that dnmt1 loss induces senescence in zebrafish hepatocytes, but this is not oncogene-induced. Alternatively, it could be activation of transposons that causes senescence in this case.

Major Depressive Disorder (MDD) is a mood disorder that is defined by the World Health Organization as the feeling of sadness, guilt and of low self-worth, loss of pleasure, appetite and concentration and sleep disturbances. Though it has been established that depressed patients exhibit aberrant circadian rhythms, little is known about the mechanism behind this phenomenon. In fact, it is still unclear whether circadian dysregulation is a cause or consequence of mood disorders. Understanding this relationship will help in the development of novel therapeutics for the treatment of mood disorders. This study, therefore, investigated the effect of stress on the oscillation of an SCN output molecule, Prokineticin-2 (PK2). We studied the differential expression of PK2, the clock gene Period1 and the PK2's receptor, PKR2, in stress-susceptible and resilient mice at different times of the light-dark cycle in both the SCN and LHb at the mRNA level using quantitative PCR. Our study shows that stress-susceptible mice have upregulation of PK2 in the LHb, while stress-resilient mice exhibit a phase advance in Per1 rhythmicity in the LHb.

Global warming has caused a rise in sea surface temperatures (SST). The rise of SSTs reduces oxygen to be dissolved in water, while simultaneously increasing the metabolic oxygen demand in fishes. The purpose of this study was to investigate whether gill remodeling occurred in tropical fish, specifically in Scolopsis ghanam, in relation to temperature change. Gill remodeling could increase oxygen uptake and transport by increasing the surface area available for absorption. S. ghanam was assessed at three different temperatures representing the natural range of temperatures for the Arabian Gulf, 18 ˚C (winter), 27 ˚C (shoulder season), and 35.5 ˚C (summer). Using histology images, five gill parameters were measured (filament length, number of lamellae, perimeter of lamellae, lamellae base thickness, and intralamellar cellular mass). With the exception of lamellae perimeter, all measured traits showed significant variation with temperature. This is the first study to demonstrate gill remodeling in tropical reef fish in response to temperature change, with important implications for how fish throughout the tropics may respond to future climate change.

Major Depressive Disorder is a global burden with symptoms such as low moods and irregular sleep. Sleep presents itself as a symptom and cause in mood disorders. In this project, Chronic Social Defeat was used to induce stress-susceptible or stress-resilient subjects through physical stress. Behavioral tests determine phenotypes, then mice were subjected to sleep deprivation either during the day or night. Although mice are nocturnal, their polyphasic sleep patterns can be disturbed through night-sleep deprivation. Following sleep deprivation, homeostatic sleep response was observed. Through electroencephalography/electromyography recordings, vigilance states and sleep propensity were recorded. Mice were either deprived during the day or the night, then their homeostatic sleep recorded for 24 hours. The sleep propensity marker in stress-susceptible mice was blunted when compared to stress-naïve/resilient mice after daytime-sleep deprivation. Night-deprived mice showed similar sleep-propensity response during the day as day-deprived mice. Our data concludes that sleep deprivation during the night alters proportions of REM sleep in stress-susceptible mice most notably, with REM sleep decreasing during the night and increasing during the day compared to the other phenotypes.

Mutations in p53 occur in more than 50% of human cancer types, with a vast majority of these mutations taking place in the DNA-binding domain of p53. Recent research has shown that many of these mutations cause aggregation of p53 with its wild type form and other proteins in the pathway, resulting in loss of ability to arrest the cell cycle and induce apoptosis. alpha-helix mimetics have been shown to inhibit amyloid aggregation of Ab and IAPP, which are associated with Alzheimer's disease and type II diabetes, respectively. Here, we show that ADH-6 acts as a potent, specific mutant p53 inhibitor that can abrogate p53 aggregates and rescue its function in pancreatic carcinoma. Rescued p53 recovers its cellular functions, particularly cell cycle arrest and apoptosis. Patients diagnosed with major depressive disorder show significant aberrations in circadian temperature rhythms. To elucidate the putative connections between temperature rhythmicity and depression, core body temperature was recorded using wireless telemetry in stress-naïve, resilient and susceptible mice exposed to chronic social defeat stress (CSDS), a rodent model of depression-like behaviour. RT-qPCR was used to measure the expression of cold-inducible RNA-binding protein (CIRP), a temperature-sensitive gene which acts as a circadian regulator. Levels of Clock and Per1 in the suprachiasmatic nucleus (SCN), lateral habenula (LHb) and dorsal raphe nucleus (DRN) were also assessed as they are downstream targets of CIRP. Amplitude of temperature rhythms was blunted more severely in susceptible mice. As a result, CIRP was only up-regulated in susceptible mice, leading to loss of CIRP rhythmicity in the SCN and LHb. These initial findings suggest that rhythms in temperature and CIRP expression could be used as markers of mood disorders.

Stress in the form of alcohol abuse, high fat diet and environmental toxicant exposure leads to activation of signaling pathways. The response to unfolded protein accumulation in the endoplasmic reticulum (ER) is critical to cellular homeostasis and mediated by the unfolded protein response (UPR). Chronic UPR induction is maladaptive and known to cause diseases. Steatosis is the accumulation of lipid droplets in hepatocytes, and while not pathological, steatosis is a requisite for the more severe steatohepatitis. I leveraged models of steatosis in zebrafish to further understand if the microbiome could influence the UPR. There was no significant impact of the germ-free rearing on ER structure or steatosis severity in stressed hepatocytes. To assess lipid accumulation and its influence on the UPR, I used a transgenic zebrafish line overexpressing the lipid droplet protein Perilipin-2 in hepatocytes (Tg(fabp10a:EGFP-hPLIN2)). Lipid droplet accumulation was significantly higher in Perilipin-2 zebrafish compared to wild-type controls. Overexpression of Perilipin-2 also reduced the incidence of aberrant ER morphology. This supports the conclusion that stabilization of lipid droplets by Perilipin-2 protects against ER deformity in the liver.

Malaria is one of the world's leading causes of infection-related deaths, disproportionately affecting children aged under five in the African Region. Efforts to develop novel therapeutic drugs and an effective vaccine are hampered by considerable inter-patient variation, which is still poorly understood due to an overall lack of understanding of the host immune response to infection. Here, we developed experimental procedures adapted for PBMC samples collected in the field in Africa and performed single-cell RNA-seq (scRNA-seq) on matched samples from four children before and after symptomatic P. falciparum infection to determine how malaria shapes the landscape of circulating immune cells during blood-stage malaria. Twelve immune cell types were identified based on classical gene markers. Matched individual-level analysis revealed significant inter-individual variation. Together, these results strongly suggest that inter-individual variation in the symptomology of malaria originates from variable alterations in both innate and adaptive cells in response to infection. Furthermore, the datasets generated will serve as foundational scRNA-seq PBMC maps of malarial children for future studies of host immune response in malaria.

DNA damage and the inability of cells to faithfully repair it can lead to inhibition of cell cycle progression, apoptosis and many disorders such as cancer, neurodegenerative diseases and developmental defects. Cells have therefore developed a complex defense mechanism, known as the DNA Damage Response/Repair (DDR) pathway, in order to detect and repair these damages. While various proteins have been identified as key players in the DDR pathway, a complete understanding of the pathway is still elusive, suggesting the involvement of as yet unidentified additional proteins. Here, we report for the very first time that Microtubule Associated Protein 4 (MAP4), which was thought to be cytoplasmic and only involved in regulation of intracellular transport by promoting microtubule polymerization and stability, is a nuclear protein that interacts with key players of the DDR pathway upon induction of double-strand DNA breaks. Further, we show that over-expression of its microtubule binding domain leads to a faster recovery from DNA damage. Our findings place MAP4 at the hub of the DNA repair pathway, which may hold key to further understanding of the DDR mechanisms. Understanding the DNA repair pathway may provide novel therapeutic approaches to alleviating the risk of disorders caused by DNA damage.

Previous research reveals the role of nuclear myosin 1 (NM1), a cytoskeletal protein found in the nucleus, which is also a component of the B-WICH transcriptional assembly and an agent that responds to DNA damage. Experiments with brain tissues from neurodegenerative disease patients found increased oxidative DNA damage in nuclear and mitochondrial DNA in these tissues, alluding to a potential role of NM1 in the disease etiology. We aimed to identify the connection between NM1 and common neurodegenerative diseases by generating NM1 KO cell lines from primary MEFs. We found an over-representation of genes related to neurodegenerative disease and oxidative phosphorylation in GO analyses. While most nuclear-encoded genes were down-regulated in the KO cells, a few were up-regulated along with some genes encoded in mitochondria. CRISPR-generated NM1 KO cells exhibited a smaller amount of OXPHOS subunits compared to the WT, but also showed an increase in both ATP and hydrogen peroxide levels. GO analysis on those CRISPR NM1 KO cells reveals an over-representation of genes related to axon guidance and neurogenesis, indicating that NM1 might be implicated in other neuronal development processes.

Arterial stiffness has shown large prognostic value as a biomarker for all-cause mortality and the onset of severe cardiovascular events, independent of other CVD risk factors. Forty percent of deaths in the United Arab Emirates is attributable to cardiovascular disease, highlighting the need for greater investigation into potential biomarkers that may point to mechanisms underlying CVD risk in this population. Due to the limited number of studies on arterial stiffness in the region, this study investigates the epidemiology of arterial stiffness in the UAE population, using augmentation index (AIx) as a surrogate measure. Baseline descriptive statistics were calculated for 3,856 Emiratis aged ≥18 years. The analysis identified sex, blood pressure measurements and cholesterol as large drivers of variation in the data and found that females and older aged individuals had significantly higher average AIx values than males. AIx positively correlated with blood pressure measurements, smoking, anthropometric measures and CRP in both males and females, yet variations in relationships and correlations did exist across sex. These sex-differences as well as the accelerated vascular aging identified in aging females compared to males suggests that different mechanisms may be underlying arterial stiffness between males and females.

Sickle Cell Disease (SCD) is a heritable hemoglobinopathy caused by a point mutation in the β-globin protein of the tetrameric hemoglobin protein resulting in the sickle-shaped RBC. Presently, metabolomic differences between SCD patients and healthy individuals have been partly studied. This study generated constraint-based models of RBC based on a baseline iDEA-RBC-1494 model to characterize the metabolic phenotype in SCD and healthy controls. The iDEA-RBC-1494 model is a 5-fold expansion in the number of genes of a previously published iAB-RBC-283 model using Recon 3D and the latest RBC proteomic dataset. In silico perturbations to non-trivial metabolic reactions in our SCD model resulted in the prediction of potential drugs that could rescue the SCD phenotype. Bioenergetic analysis resulted in the identification of target reactions, which we used to query the Drug Gene Interaction Database for potential drugs. We identify candidate drugs that revert the SCD bioenergetic phenotype and which can be evaluated further for the clinical treatment of SCD. The significantly expanded network model for RBC offers an enabling, quantitative resource for studying blood metabolism and blood-related disorders.

Malaria continues to be a major global public health problem, with young children in sub-Saharan Africa bearing a disproportionate burden of malaria-related deaths. Despite multitudinous endeavors to eliminate the disease, a limited understanding of mechanisms underlying variation in host immune response to malaria hinders the potential of developing effective anti-malarial drugs and vaccines. Previous studies have shed light on the impact of post-transcriptional regulation and host genetic control of miRNA expression during malaria infection. Here, we generated miRNA profiles of children from two sympatric ethnic groups with varying levels of susceptibility to malaria in Burkina Faso (Mossi and Fulani) during natural P. falciparum infection and assessed interethnic differences in their miRNA transcriptomes at multiple levels. The results of my study highlight variation in post-transcriptional regulation and ethnic-specific effects of host genotype on miRNA expression as potential mechanisms driving interethnic differences in host susceptibility and immune response to malaria.

Differentiation occurs through activating and repressing various gene programs towards a given cell identity, done in part by regulating chromatin states using chromatin modifiers, some of which use long noncoding RNAs (lncRNAs). β‐actin is also important in differentiation, regulating chromatin and overall gene expression, like as part of certain chromatin remodelers. This study used RNA-seq, ChIRP-seq on the lncRNA Meg3, and ChIP-seq for the Meg3-interacting chromatin remodeler Prc2, on wild-type and β‐actin depleted mouse embryonic fibroblasts. With β‐actin loss: several lncRNAs were differentially expressed, including Meg3; Meg3 occupancy changed across specific chromosomal locations, impacting expression of several genes related to differentiation; and no differentially expressed genes shared Meg3 and Ezh2 occupancies. Overall, both expression and genomic deposition of Meg3 are β‐actin-dependent. Also, Meg3 genomic association is likely mediated in an β-actin-dependent manner through mechanisms independent from the Prc2 complex. These alterations likely impact expression of genes involved in cell fate.

Previous studies have shown that cytoskeletal proteins regulate and maintain chromatin organization and gene regulation. Nuclear Myosin 1 (NM1) as a part of the BWICH multiprotein transcriptional complex is involved in the regulation of gene transcription and DNA integrity. Regulation and coordination of the chromatin are crucial for the activation of specific gene programs during differentiation. Given that NM1 is involved in transcriptional complexes, NM1 could also be potentially involved in regulating differentiation. This study aims to investigate the transcriptional role of NM1 in neuronal differentiation. Using a small chemicals cocktail we transdifferentiated Mouse Embryonic Fibroblasts (MEFs) to neurons and found that neuronal specific genes in MEFs were mostly downregulated in the absence of NM1. Further, we investigated the impact of NM1 in neurons by observing the change in morphology during the neuronal induction period. Through RTqPCR and immunofluorescence, we assessed the differences in neuronal expression levels in presence and absence of NM1. Our results showed that in absence of NM1, neurons tend to have a higher survival rate and different morphology. The loss of NM1 resulted in irregular axon connections, an increase in dendrites, and a potential delayal in differentiation or potential formation of oligodendrocytes.

Scope and Contents
Understanding the evolutionary landscape of the major histocompatibility complex (MHC) lays at the core of immunology and has strong implications for conservation. The latter claim is particularly true in the case of amphibians, an understudied vertebrate class that remains severely impacted by emerging infectious diseases. Here, I investigated the evolutionary dynamics of the classical MHC genes in the grass frogs of genus Ptychadena that are endemic to one of the world's biodiversity hotspots – the Ethiopian Highlands. Using intra- and inter-specific whole-genome resequencing datasets, I conducted phylogenetic inference, selection tests, and population genetics analysis to characterize the evolutionary forces that shaped the evolution of the classical MHC genes. The results revealed characteristic signatures of balancing selection, such as excess of nonsynonymous polymorphisms and above-average nucleotide diversity, amongst the MHC class I loci, whereas the patterns of diversity at class II loci were not consistent with balancing selection. The signals at the class I loci point towards recent balancing selection, which did not result in trans-specific polymorphisms. Based on the conducted analysis, I discuss several challenges related to using low-coverage resequencing data for studies of the MHC, which may aid in the execution of similar studies in the future.
Author provided keywords: Major Histocompatibility Complex, MHC genes, Balancing Selection, Ptychadena, Anurans, AmphibiansHau, Sion Delores. Investigating the Transcriptional Landscape of Dendritic Cells in 3D Culture2021-00812021AD-MC-0042021-0081
Scope and Contents
Monocyte derived dendritic cells (DCs) play an essential role in bridging the innate and adaptive immune responses through their efficient antigen presenting abilities. They have recently been shown to exhibit enhanced immune potency when differentiated and activated on 3D collagen matrices compared to traditional 2D cell culture environments. However, the transcriptional immune response of DCs differentiated and matured on various scaffolding remained unexplored. This study investigated the transcriptomic differences of DCs differentiated and activated on 3D collagen matrices with a DESeq2 analysis pipeline in an aim to provide insight into the transcriptional regulation and mechanisms behind the previously observed increase in immune potency. The findings revealed that the 3 mg/ml collagen concentration provided a supportive microenvironment for the differentiation and activation of DCs with antigen-specific cellular response transcriptional pathways activated. The same specific immune response pathways failed to be activated in DCs cultured in traditional 2D cell culture plates. Most unexpectedly, the 1 mg/ml collagen matrix was found to prematurely activate mDC-like transcriptional level immune responses in the absence of maturation factors, possibly suggesting a mechanosensitivty of DCs to soft substratum mimicking wound tissue.
