Prion protein-derived cell-penetrating peptide inhibits type II diabetes-associated islet amyloid polypeptide aggregation and cytotoxicity2021-00752021AD-MC-0042021-0075
Scope and Contents
Amyloid diseases are conditions including Alzheimer's and Parkinson's disease whose pathologies are caused by the mis-folding and aggregation of one of many amyloid proteins. This in turn results in toxic gain of function (GoF) and cell death. One such amyloid protein is islet amyloid polypeptide (IAPP), whose aggregation and toxic GoF is implicated in the loss of beta cells associated with type II diabetes. As in other amyloid diseases, there is currently a dearth of therapeutics aimed at addressing IAPP aggregation and cytotoxicity. In this study, we test the efficacy of a cell-penetrating peptide (CPP) composed of the nuclear localization sequence (NLS) of the prion protein (PrP) conjugated to the signal sequence of neural cell adhesion molecule 1 (NCAM) against IAPP aggregation and toxic GoF. This construct has already been shown to be effective against the amyloid (A) peptide, which is implicated in Alzheimer's disease. We report that the construct is effective against IAPP aggregation and toxic gain of function and suggest that this makes it a promising potential amyloid inhibitor.
Author provided keywords: amyloid, type II diabetes, islet amyloid polypeptide (IAPP)Keil, Netanya Danielle. Dual RNASequencing of the human host and Plasmodium falciparum parasite2021-00782021AD-MC-0042021-0078
Scope and Contents
Almost half of the world population is at risk of malaria infection, and Plasmodium falciparum, the deadliest malarial parasite, stands as one of the most serious threats to global public health accounting for the large majority of all estimated malaria cases and mortalities. P. falciparum malaria afflicts children unpredictably with high levels of symptomatic variability during the blood development stage of the parasite life cycle. Investigating the natural dynamic variation in transcriptional response of both the human host and Plasmodium parasite has the potential to elucidate the mechanisms that drive inter-individual variability in host immune response at the transcriptional level. This study presents an optimized experimental and bioinformatic approach for dual RNA sequencing of the human host and P. falciparum parasites using blood samples collected from a symptomatic malarial African pediatric cohort. The procedure generates a quantitative readout of host-parasite transcriptomes. The host-parasite transcriptional data was used to identify cross-correlated host-parasite transcripts and transcripts associated with parasitemia. This study lays the foundation for population-scale integrative joint transcriptomic analysis of in vivo host-parasite interactions and provides data and tools to apply in the context of other infectious diseases to elucidate the complex architecture of host-pathogen interactions at the transcriptional level.
Author provided keywords: Dual RNASequencing, malaria, plasmodium, co-transcriptomeMic, Eliza. Neural Encoding of Thermal Stimulation2021-00722021AD-MC-0042021-0072
Scope and Contents
Thermal stimulation and perception has been explored in several studies through self-reports (Filingeri et al., 2014; El Ali et al., 2020; Watanabe et al. 2014) and positron emission tomography (PET) (Craig et al. 2000). Neural techniques such as electroencephalography (EEG) have the potential to provide brain correlates associated with thermal stimulation. The literature, however, does not provide any information on the event related potential (ERP) formation when performing a thermal recognition task. In the current study, four different temperature stimuli were delivered to 15 healthy participants and their brain activity was measured using EEG. We found the P200 ERP component in the middle frontal cortex and the central parietal cortex and the P100 ERP component in the occipital cortex. Interestingly, in the middle frontal and the central parietal cortices, the highest temperature (41°C) had the lowest activation compared to the lowest temperature (23°C), while, in the occipital cortex, the activation for the two conditions was inverted. Future research is needed to explain the differences in activation patterns found between the occipital region and middle frontal and central parietal cortices when participants receive higher and lower temperature stimuli.
Author provided keywords: thermal stimulation EEG ERP neurohapticsSafadi, Layla Al. Novel cancer combinatory therapy using drug-loaded, active-targeting, nanoparticles functionalized with immune checkpoint inhibitors2021-00742021AD-MC-0042021-0074
Scope and Contents
Despite the global efforts to cure cancer, it remains a leading cause of death worldwide. Chemotherapy has many limitations: multidrug resistance, poor solubility, and lack of targeting specificity. Nanoparticles as a delivery vehicle for chemotherapeutics have been shown to have increased in-blood circulation, biocompatibility, and targeting specificity. Moreover, a promising line of research known as immune checkpoint therapy inhibits the PD-1/PD-L1 interaction between cancer cells and immune cells. This approach has shown promising and more long-lasting results as it potentiates the immune system. Therefore, this project combined these two lines of research and developed a doxorubicin-loaded, lipid-coated, PD-L1 inhibitor and active targeting peptide-conjugated mesoporous silica nanoplatform that aimed to treat cancers that over express PD-L1. Cell viability MTS assays showed that the loaded nanoparticles were more toxic to MIA PaCa-2 cells than doxorubicin alone. This demonstrates the potential that the proposed system has for treatment of tumors expressing PD-L1.
Author provided keywords: Immune checkpoint therapy, chemotherapy, nanoparticles, active targetingSapkota, Oscar. Nuclear Myosin 1 (NM1) regulates mitochondrial gene expression and dynamics2021-00792021AD-MC-0042021-0079
Scope and Contents
Nuclear Myosin 1 (NM1) regulates gene expression through a chromatin-based mechanism. Previous research has established its role in transcriptional activation and chromatin remodeling. Gene Ontology (GO) analysis of published RNAseq data from CRISPR-generated NM1 KO MEFs reveals multiple mitochondrial processes to be enriched in the absence of NM1. This led us to investigate differences in mitochondrial dynamics and bioenergetics in WT and NM1 KO MEFs. We report NM1 KO cells to have lowered expression of OXPHOS genes and dysregulated mitochondrial metabolites. Absence of functional NM1 in cells is also associated with decreased mitochondrial mass, perinuclear mitochondrial distribution, and underdeveloped mitochondrial morphology. Overall, our results suggest NM1 KO MEFs to resemble a mitochondrial phenotype similar to that of rapidly proliferating cells such as Stem Cells. Based on our results, we propose a model where NM1 controls mitochondrial gene expression through a chromatin-based mechanism and regulates key cellular differentiation pathways.
Author provided keywords: Cell Biology, Mitochondrial gene regulation, Nuclear Myosin 1, cellular differentiationSchrader, Andres Lopez. Zooxanthellae Symbionts of Acropora corals in Saadiyat Island Coral Reef Across Seasonal Changes2021-00692021AD-MC-0042021-0069
Scope and Contents
Coral reefs are globally in danger of extinction because of warming waters. Coral mass extinction is particularly concerning in the Arabian Gulf because sea surface temperatures (SST) are amongst the hottest in the world. Symbiosis between corals and dinoflagellates sometimes confers heat resistance to corals by preventing symbiont death. Identification and classification of coral-associated dinoflagellates uses degenerate amplification of genetic markers. In this study, I uniquely identified the thermoresistant Symbiodinium thermophilum strain in Abu Dhabi coral colonies of Acropora downingi collected at three different SSTs (27°C, 32°C and 34°C) using metagenomic analysis and subsequent mining of five genetic markers: ITS2, psbA, cp23S, LSU and cob. Symbiodinium thermophilum was significantly more abundant in 34°C samples compared to 27°C SST. These results confirm high fidelity of A. downingi-Symbiodinium interactions in the Arabian Gulf across temperature fluctuations. This study also reveals that improvements are needed to identify coral-associated photo symbionts using metagenomics.

Abstract: Ultrasonic levitation can provide a unique tool to study processes of light emission such as triboluminescence, as the material can emit light under contactless acoustic impact. The design of an experimental setup to study the effects of acoustic energy on ultrasonically levitated triboluminescent materials suspended in liquid droplets is reported here. The setup was utilized to record an absorption spectrum from a levitated droplet of aqueous solution of organic dye. Two metal coordination materials with structure-independent (blue light due to nitrogen discharge) and structure-specific emission (secondary emission due to ligand-metal charge transfer) were synthesized and suspended in a liquid. Droplets of this suspension were levitated and examined for visible emission. However, no visible emissions were observed, even in a darkened room. Although this shows that ultrasonic levitation cannot be used as a tool for examining triboluminescent materials, it has interesting implications for theories of sonoluminescence.TriboluminescenceUltrasonic levitationAcoustic pressureLarkin, Alexander William. Abstract: The expenses related to the "cold chain" required for transportation of thermally labile medicines to remote locations remains as one of the greatest challenges for developing countries with hot climate. In this work, three different proteins, green fluorescent protein (GFP), H1N1 influenza neurminidase, and H1N1 hemagglutinin, were included as guests and stabilized in crystals of -lactose monohydrate, maltose, and sucrose as crystalline matrices. The proteins were then analyzed with fluorescence microscopy and gel electrophoresis, before and after an hour of incubation at 60 °C, to determine whether denaturation had been retarded by the inclusion of the proteins in their host matrix. Sucrose failed to crystallize properly on the scale necessary for the experiment and so could not be analyzed on its success as a host. Similarly, maltose failed to crystallize with hemagglutinin. Lactose and maltose appeared to readily crystallize and effectively protect GFP against denaturation, and gel electrophoresis (SDS-PAGE) results showed lactose including hemagglutinin and protecting it from denaturation. Results regarding neuraminidase inclusion in both dissacharides are inconclusive due to concentrations of that protein which were too low in all samples to produce bands in SDS-PAGE.MaltoseLactoseHemagglutininNeuraminidaseStabilizing agentsMatricesCrystalsGreen fluorescent proteinDisaccharidesLiang, Haoran. Smart Hybrid Polymer that Responds to Humidity, Light and Heat2014-00461122014AD-MC-0042014-0046
Scope and Contents
Major: Chemistry
Abstract: A conceptually new smart hybrid polymer material that responds to humidity, UV light and heat was fabricated and its pho-to-, thermo- and hydro-responsive properties were studied. The prototypic material was prepared by introducing azobenzene units into a polymer chain by condensation polymerization. The product thus obtained was combined with a hydrophilic polymer as a flexible matrix that provides elastic environment for facile isomerization of azobenzene moieties. In the result-ing hybrid films, cis-trans isomerization of the main polymer chain leads to contraction or expansion, thereby inducing re-versible macroscopic deformation of the film. The hydrophilic component is capable of exchange of water with the sur-roundings, causing periodic contractions and expansions that appear as rapid locomotion of the film over a moist surface. Moreover, the hybrid film also exhibits rapid mechanical response by bending of nearly 180o when exposed to UV light or when heated anisotropically. The new smart material could be utilized in a variety of actuating devices, including soft robot-ics, medical prosthetics, and in printing.Smart polymersPolymersCondensation polymerizationSmart materialsEl Khoury, Roberto Ibrahim. Abstract: Recently, a stream of research into synthetic receptors has focused on recognizing oxoanions, particularly because of their environmental impacts. For example, phosphate, an oxoanion, builds up through the excessive use of fertilizers resulting in eutrophication of water bodies, while sulfate is used in the separation of nuclear wastes. Our group succeeded in simultaneously assembling three remarkable zinc-based complexes in water: the 2-catenane ([2]C), trefoil knot (TK), and Solomon link (SL). TK is interesting because of its cavity that can recognize a wide range of anions. We have now synthesized an analogous TK based on urea groups that preferentially recognize oxoanion pollutants such as phosphate and sulfate. Urea groups equip the cavity of TK with improved hydrogen bond donor capabilities, allowing it to interact better with oxoanions.Metal templationImine-bond formationAnionsIbrahim, Nadine. Computational Study of How β-loop Dynamics Regulates HCV Polymerase Activity in the Presence and Absence of a Thumb-site-II Inhibitor. 2017-00322017The Hepatitis C virus (HCV) infects around 150 million people globally, and chronic infection causes cirrhosis and cancer. The replication of the viral genome is carried out by NS5B, an RNA-dependent RNA polymerase. NS5B has become a major drug target over the past years, yet its inhibition mechanism remains a mystery. We used MD simulations to study the dynamics of NS5B, focusing on the β-loop. Microseconds simulation of NS5B with varying RNA lengths resolved the microstates accessible to β-loop both in initiation and elongation. We carried out further simulations to study the mechanism of inhibition of a thumb-site-II molecule, Filibuvir. Filibuvir serves to allosterically rigidify the β-loop, inhibiting the transition to elongation. Consistent with HDX experiments, our results showed that upon binding of Filibuvir, the enzyme enters an inactive state that rigidifies the β-loop by burying it within the active site. Through identifying residues that play a role in β-loop dynamics, we were able to propose mutagenesis experiments that controlled the enzyme's action. Our study shows how integration of experiments and simulations provide deeper insight into the mechanism of replication of viral polymerases.AD-MC-0042017-0032

Computing the kinetics and thermodynamics of biological processes from all-atom MD simulations2018-00552018AD-MC-0042018-0055
Scope and Contents
Molecular Dynamics (MD) simulations are invaluable in obtaining an atomic-level description of biomolecular processes. Despite the many recent advances, the dynamics of complex systems operating on long timescales still evades researchers due to the high computational demand. We developed a suite of programs to study biological processes across a range of timescales using short trajectories, providing a coarse-grained representation of relevant conformational states. This method was applied to two systems: (1) the rapid ion incorporation conformation in HIV Reverse Transcriptase; and, (2) the complex conformational transition of the Hammerhead-like ribozyme. Using only a one-dimensional reaction coordinate, ion incorporation was found to be a spontaneous and favorable process, with a free energy change of -3.37 kcal/mol. The structural switch mechanism of the Hammerhead-like ribozyme was also discovered in atomic detail, using both a low- and multi-dimensional configuration space definition. This higher-dimensional partitioning was shown to reliably describe the complexity of the system, but was found to be subject to poorer statistical convergence. Further development of this method may unlock new insights into the structure and dynamics of complex biological processes.Dho, Yaereen. We developed a green and innovative synthetic route for gold nanoparticles, surface coated with therapeutic agent triphenylphosphine (TPP) and stabilized with Pluronic F-108 polymer (F-108@TPP-AuNPs) for an effective cytotoxic system to cancer cells. Gold nanoparticles (AuNPs) can selectively target cancer cells, image tumors, and induce hyperthermia. Gold(I)phosphine complexes such as TPP gold(I) chloride are cytotoxic, suggesting that TPP-AuNPs can be used in chemotherapy. Pluronic F-108 enhances the circulation time of the TPP drug and stabilizes the AuNPs, avoiding their aggregation. F-108@TPP-AuNPs were synthesized under microwave irradiation by heating an aqueous solution of TPP gold(I) chloride in presence of 1% Pluronic F-108 in basic conditions at 105°C for 20 minutes. UV-Vis, PXRD, TEM, DLS, EDX, and XPS confirmed the formation of spherical AuNPs surrounded with TPP molecules and stabilized with a polymeric shell of F-108. The biological assessment of the F-108@TPP-AuNPs on HeLa cancer cells showed superiority of the NPs over free TPP gold(I) chloride by two folds.Fanning, Jhamal. Bacterial Phytohormones Regulate the Growth of a Blooming Cosmopolitan Diatom2018-00512018AD-MC-0042018-0051
Scope and Contents
Interactions between diatoms and bacteria are an essential part of aquatic environments that influence many oceanic biogeochemical cycles. One synergistic pathway is through biosynthesis of indole-3-acetic acid (IAA)—a phytohormone—by diatom-associated bacteria from diatom-secreted tryptophan that triggers nutrient exchanges between both taxa. The role of other phytohormones in diatom-bacteria interactions remains largely unknown. Here, several strains of bacteria associated with the cosmopolitan bloom-forming diatom Asterionellopsis glacialis were isolated and cultivated to establish the roles phytohormones play in diatom physiology. IAA alone did not enhance the growth of A. glacialis, but did so in combination with two other phytohormones, gibberellic acid and kinetin. Analyzing the metabolomes of F5, F10, and F28 using UHPLC-Q-ToF-MS showed that out of 74 known phytohormones, auxins, jasmonates, and a cytokinin were produced by all associated bacteria, with higher auxin production in F5 and higher jasmonate production in F10 and F28. These results suggest that a unique combination of hormones may enhance the diatom growth and that, in a complex microbiome, multiple phytohormone production by one or more bacteria, could cooperatively regulate or initiate diatom growth.Gambrill, Yumi. Scope and Contents
Understanding physiological processes is vital for scientific advancement in many areas, from disease control to technological developments. While much progress has been made, particularly with the help of bioimaging techniques, a full knowledge of human physiology remains distant. To narrow the gap in knowledge, there is a need to develop more biological probes for studying the dynamic nature of physiological processes. Using light-dependent probes is effective as they provide tight control of the timing and location of events. In this category, photolabile protecting groups (PPGs) are of particular interest because of their simplicity of use. PPGs activated through the simultaneous absorption of two photons are especially useful for investigations in whole animals. However, the lack of PPGs activated by absorption of two photons is an impediment to their use. This project aims to optimise the 8-cyano-7-hydroxyquinolinyl PPG for higher sensitivity to two-photon absorption.Jahovic, Ilma. Scope and Contents
Because of its non-biodegradable nature and persistence in the environment, perfluorooctanoic acid (PFOA) accumulates in water resources and poses serious environmental issues in many parts of the world. Adsorption is the most frequently used water decontamination method but the common drawbacks of adsorbents used (e.g. activated carbon) include low adsorption capacity, limited regeneration ability, and slow pollutant uptake. Here, we present the development of two fluorine-rich calix[4]arene-based porous polymers, FCX4-P and FCX4-BP, and demonstrate their potential utility for the removal of PFOA from water. FCX4-P removes ~99% of PFOA at environmentally relevant concentrations with higher affinity than the commercial activated carbon and with comparable kinetics. Given the structural and chemical versatility of porous polymers containing the calixarene macrocycle in their backbone, our findings herald the advent of a new generation of materials that can be successfully used for water purification.Moussa, Yasmine. Chemical Screen Exploring the Role of mel-28 Nucleoporin Gene in C. elegans and its Potential Connection to Cancer Therapy 2018-00532018AD-MC-0042018-0053
Scope and Contents
Nucleoporins (NUPs), components of nuclear pore complexes (NPCs) that regulate transport of proteins and RNA across the nuclear envelope, are indispensable for cell function and are at the center of several human diseases. The MEL-28 protein in C. elegans (ELYS in vertebrates) is a NUP with numerous essential cell cycle functions that are conserved in humans, including a role in DNA replication licensing. Zebrafish Elys mutants are highly sensitized to treatment with DNA replication inhibitors such as Cisplatin, suggesting that MEL-28 could be used as a cancer therapy target. To test this hypothesis, we characterized a C. elegans mel-28 thermosensitive mutant strain and screened the Spectrum Collection small molecule library to identify chemicals that cause enhancement in a mel-28 sensitized background. We identified seven compounds that specifically enhance mel-28, some of which are known to affect microtubules. We then tested whether the selected compounds act in a synergistic way with Cisplatin in the mel-28(ts) and wildtype genetic backgrounds and observed synergism with three compounds specifically in the mel-28(ts) strain. Interestingly, one of them, Mitotane, is already used in combinatorial drug therapy with Cisplatin in patients with adrenal carcinoma, thus providing proof of concept for our experimental approach. Our results confirm MEL-28/ELYS as a candidate chemotherapy drug target, establish C. elegans mel-28 as a model for identifying new cancer drugs, and demonstrate that known chemicals could potentially be repurposed for combinatorial chemotherapy. Finally, we identified compounds not previously described to affect wild-type worms that could provide leads for new broad-spectrum anthelmintics.Boutros, Sandra Emad. Because of the premature depletion of lithium resources due to the extensive battery production, extracting it from various and uncommon resources is a vital need to maintain a growing industry of electric devices and vehicles. Here, we synthesized two crown ether calix[4]arene-based porous organic polymers, C-CX4P and CP-CX4P, and investigated their potential utility for the adsorption of lithium from water. C-CX4P shows a remarkable lithium uptake capacity of 941.69 mg g −1. In addition, both polymers exhibit specificity to lithium in the presence of competitive sodium ion in excess, such that a 0% removal of sodium is obtained for CP-CX4P. These preliminary results demonstrate the potential use of carefully designed porous organic polymers as a new generation of materials which can be used for lithium adsorption from various sources.Faisal, Tabinah. Scope and Contents
Asphaltene precipitation, which leads to asphaltene deposition, has proven to be highly catastrophic for the oil industry. Scale inhibitors, chemical inhibitors which can prevent the formation of asphaltene deposits in oil wells and pipelines, are of particular interest. The scale inhibitors currently in use have low efficacy and several shortcomings, which increases the need to extend research into novel chemicals. In this study, we test various aromatic inhibitors with different functional moieties. Fluorescence studies and Hill analysis demonstrated that inhibitors X3 and Y3, which were surfactant-like with strongly acidic and electron-withdrawing moieties, showed the lowest dissociation constants (Kd) over time and across different sources of asphaltenes. These inhibitors showed the highest affinity to different types of asphaltene molecules and are, therefore, most likely to form complexes with asphaltenes, preventing them from further aggregating. Additionally, quartz crystal microbalance with dissipation (QCM-D) analysis revealed that inhibitor X3 was able to remove 70% of the adsorbed mass of asphaltenes from carbon steel, which mimics actual surfaces in oil wells and pipelines. The results indicate that aromatic inhibitors with acidic and electron-withdrawing moieties are good scale inhibitor candidates; they can be effective in interacting with asphaltenes and potentially preventing them from aggregating further.Knyazeva, Anastassiya. Degradation and loss of integrity are among the biggest shortcomings of materials that are exposed to mechanical impact. One of the possible solutions to confront this problem was the discovery of materials that are able to autonomously repair the damages, and recover their integrity. The developments in this area were, however, restricted to ceramics, as well as the soft-materials, such as polymers and hydrogels, and only a limited research was done in a solid state crystalline chemistry. In this project we aimed to examine the relationship between mechanical properties and the self-healing on the examples of selected boronic esters and disul-fides, the Young's modulus and stiffness were measured for selected crystals and the self-healing experiment was attempted. Var-ious issues such as hydrolysis, fracturing during manipulation and the solvent encapsulation within the crystal limited the assess-ment of self-healing for several crystals. From the Young modulus of the crystals that exhibited self-healing, we could observe that self-healing percentage is higher in softer crystals.Egbunu, Gabriel. Thermodynamic Characterization of HK32021-00832021AD-MC-0042021-0083
Scope and Contents
Tumor cells utilize a high glycolytic flux known as the "Warburg effect" to sustain their high proliferation rates. The activation and further metabolism of glucose are initiated by hexokinase, a focal point of metabolic regulation. Hexokinase 2 (HK2) is significantly overexpressed in many cancer types and hence, it is a vital point in the development of inhibitors. The human hexokinase 3 (HK3) is not significantly overexpressed in tumors. However, biochemical differences in HK2 and HK3 could be exploited in improving the potency and specificity of current HK2 inhibitors. Here, we report the thermodynamic characterization of HK3. Experimental results reveal that both the melting temperature and calorimetric enthalpy change of wild-type HK3 are higher than for HK2. The identification of structural and biochemical differences between HK2 and HK3 could potentially be used in the development of new and more effective cancer therapies.

Major: Computer Science
Abstract: The public is largely unaware that third-party trackers actively collect their data. In turn, the application of data mining and machine learning to utilize this data is largely a mystery to users without a background in information technology. This paper proposes the use of a built-in browser application that actively collects user data and renders it to create a privacy feedback profile to the user. The feedback page focuses on informing users that third parties can monitor their data, along with making inferences on the user so they're aware of how telling their data can be. In a weeklong study, users of the application showed increased levels of concern and awareness for their digital privacy. These results encourage the use of such applications as viable ways of educating individuals and encouraging safer online browsing habits.Information technologyInternetData miningPrivacyGrishin, Oleg. Abstract: Many public spaces, including university campuses, have an abundance of public screens displaying information relevant to a particular site, such as upcoming events, student work showcases, general announcements, infographics and other relevant media. Displayer focuses on proposing and implementing an easy-to-use system that provides a front-end interface to create and schedule tasks that include but are not limited to displaying pictures, videos and slideshows. While many of such public screens focus on simply displaying information, the proposed system also allows for creating more interactive tasks, e.g. a video-portal between two displays. The project discusses a working implementation of such a system, while also outlining possible future extensions, e.g. connecting systems like the Microsoft Kinect to allow the creation of more complex tasks, such as signing up for events by showing a student ID. While the working implementation performs a variety of those simple tasks, the system's back-end is built around the idea of allowing future (possibly user-written) extensions.Computer systemsInformation display systemsCalendarsComputersShin, Jiwon. In Game Assistance Methods2017-00242017One of the most important factors when it comes to making a multiplayer competitive game is ensuring that players are evenly matched. When skill differences are extreme, weaker players become frustrated and there is not enough of a challenge for the stronger player to stay engaged. Earlier papers on the topic establish that assisting weaker players works extremely well in reducing the score differences. In this paper we explored different types of assistance methods and specifically their effects on player enjoyment and perceived competence. Overall we see that assistance methods very significantly reduce the score disparity and affect several aspects of their gameplay experience.AD-MC-0042017-0024

Earlier papers on the topic establish that assisting weaker players works extremely well in reducing the score differences. Overall we see that assistance methods very significantly reduce the score disparity and affect several aspects of their gameplay experience.Onyibe, Chukwuyem. Sentiment Analysis in Tweets2017-00252017This capstone project is about the detection of sentiment and stance in individual tweets. The task encompasses two subfields in Natural Language Processing: Sentiment Analysis and Stance Detection, both of which are related. The main objective is to use the Conditional Random Fields, the statistical modelling method, to build a system(s) that automatically determines from a tweet, with high efficiency, an author's general sentiment or sentiment towards a given target. Every iteration of the system is tested against a gold standard to gauge its efficiency. The reason for the use of CRFs is test how it fairs in non-sequential data classification tasks. The approach is feature-based, improved by optimized CRF parameters. A set of lexical feature combinations are tested and the top scoring feature combinations is tested again with sets of CRF parameter value combinations. The top scoring values, combined with the top scoring lexical features make up the system for dataset in question. The results show that CRFs perform well at non-sequential classification. Moreover, if sequential context are added to these tweets (i.e. tweets in a conversation thread), the efficiency of CRFs increases.AD-MC-0042017-0025

Spatial Distortion Approach to Traffic Congestion Visualization2017-00392017The field of traffic congestion visualization relies heavily on colorcoded topographical maps; little work has been done, however, to examine the merits and possible weaknesses of this approach, and to evaluate its performance in comparison to alternative visualizations. This paper presents a new approach to visualization of traffic congestion that uses spatial distortion instead of color to present traffic information in a fundamentally different manner. A user study was employed to empirically evaluate the ability of each of the two visualization approaches to influence the users' routing decisions in a given traffic network.AD-MC-0042017-0039

This paper presents a new approach to visualization of traffic congestion that uses spatial distortion instead of color to present traffic information in a fundamentally different manner. A user study was employed to empirically evaluate the ability of each of the two visualization approaches to influence the users' routing decisions in a given traffic network.Terai, Koh. Autofocus System for Cinematic Applications.2017-00312017Unlike video camcorders, phone cameras, point-and-shoot, and DSLRs, cameras and lenses used for cinema do not come with any autofocus capabilities. Instead, a dedicated person on a film set (the focus-puller) is in charge of manually measuring the distance from the camera to the subject and focusing the lens. Although this allows for complete artistic control over the focus, there are situations in which perfect focus is hard to achieve by focus-pullers (e.g. actors missing their positions, actors moving around within their positions) or a situation in which having a dedicated focus-puller is difficult (e.g. budgetary constrains, tight spaces). This project will attempt to design and create an autofocus system that will aid the focus-pullers to get the right focus through the use of software and hardware development. This intuitive system should be able to out perform inexperienced focus-pullers as well as making focus pulling easier for certain environments such as low contrast and dark locations. Our current prototype of the system is slow but relatively accurate and functional as an initial proof of concept.AD-MC-0042017-0031
Scope and Contents
Unlike video camcorders, phone cameras, point-and-shoot, and DSLRs, cameras and lenses used for cinema do not come with any autofocus capabilities. Instead, a dedicated person on a film set (the focus-puller) is in charge of manually measuring the distance from the camera to the subject and focusing the lens. Although this allows for complete artistic control over the focus, there are situations in which perfect focus is hard to achieve by focus-pullers (e.g. actors missing their positions, actors moving around within their positions) or a situation in which having a dedicated focus-puller is difficult (e.g. budgetary constrains, tight spaces). This project will attempt to design and create an autofocus system that will aid the focus-pullers to get the right focus through the use of software and hardware development. This intuitive system should be able to out perform inexperienced focus-pullers as well as making focus pulling easier for certain environments such as low contrast and dark locations. Structure Identification in PDF Documents2018-00952018AD-MC-0042018-0095
Scope and Contents
Up until the present day, there has not been a reliable, consistent, and easily available tool with which to identify and extract structural elements within documents. This is due to the fact thatPDFs do not conform to any conventions in terms of document structure and that PDF generators tend to use different rules for assembling the documents. A solution that can allow users to retrieve structured information from a document in a form that is easily manipulated can have a noticeable positive impact for professionals across a broad spectrum of industries.The framework put forward in this paper,Texture, uses diverse heuristic techniques in order to extract structural elements (lists, titles, headers and footers, paragraphs, figures and tables) fromPDFs. They are assigned different weights that lead to robust and accurate extractors.Texture also introduces a domain specific language that allows users to query documents using natural language.We demonstrate that Texture has potential to perform as well as the manual labeling process while being much easier to use than any labor crowdsourcing platform. Texture is also cheaper, quicker, and more scalable than hiring crowd workers to handle the same extraction tasks.Ahmad, Muaz; Dana Abu Ali, Hayat Al Hassan, Ming Hu, Paula Dozsa. Time-offset Interaction Application2018-01012018AD-MC-0042018-0101
Scope and Contents
This paper presents a bilingual (Arabic-English) interactive human avatar dialogue system. The system is named TOIA (time-off set interaction application), as it simulates face-to-face conversations between humans and digital human avatars recorded in the past. TOIA is similar to a conversational agent, or chatbot, but differs in that it is based on an actual human being and can be used to preserve and tell stories. The system is designed to allow anybody, simply using a laptop, to create an avatar of themselves, thus facilitating cross-cultural and cross-generational sharing of narratives to wider audiences. It also supports cross-lingual dialogues in Arabic and English.Hayat, Hashim. Esfera: A Scalable peer-to-peer video broadcasting architecture overlaying WebRTC2018-00682018AD-MC-0042018-0068
Scope and Contents
Due to the increasing accessibility of the Internet, and live video streaming platforms like YouTube and Facebook, the demand for live video broadcasting is growing rapidly. Public figures, news channels, and sports event with followers numbered in millions receive up to a million views in their livestreams and the number is growing. The current broadcasting infrastructures rely on large and expensive networks of media servers and edge caches that are distributed around the globe to maintain network efficiency, quality, and reliability. In this paper, we present Esfera, a light-weight, scalable, peer-to-peer live video broadcasting infrastructure that utilizes the potentials of WebRTC, a set of APIs that allows ultra-low latency browser-to-browser communication without external plugins. Commercial platforms such as Facebook Messenger, and Google Hangouts have successfully tested and deployed their VoIP services on WebRTC, and broadcasting is the next milestone in the success of WebRTC. In this paper, we provide a detailed analysis of the design and implementation of Esfera and present an evaluation of its performance. Finally, we discuss the limitations and future challenges that are posed by peer-to-peer live broadcasting using WebRTC.Hopkins, Brooke. Insulin Pump Vulnerabilities and Design for Secure Device Communication2018-00732018AD-MC-0042018-0073
Scope and Contents
Advanced health technology promises to bring considerable advances to patient care. However, there are great security risks which can have disastrous health consequences. Several studies show that implantable medical devices (IMDs) have vulnerabilities enabling man in the middle attacks that could disclose patient data or even inflict patient harm. Insulin delivery systems, which are commonly used IMDs, are vulnerable for this reason. All communication between the continuous glucose monitor (CGM) and the insulin pump is unencrypted, and protective PINs are passed in plain text. While there is existing research that documents this vulnerability and proposes solutions, these provide only suggestions for device modification that could be implemented by the manufacturer in future models. In this paper, we propose a design for a fully backwards compatible external device that ensures authenticity and integrity of communication between the CGM and the insulin pump. The design employs friendly jamming techniques to provide access control by jamming unauthenticated communication.Jensen, Frederik. On Problems Related to Epsilon-Nets 2018-00812018AD-MC-0042018-0081
Scope and Contents
This capstone presents results on problems related to epsilon-nets in the plane; a method to approximate a set of data points with a small number of points. We contribute to the literature by improving the bounds for several simple cases. Speci cally, we obtain a tight lower bound of 2/3 on two-point strong epsilon-nets with respect to both halfspaces and disks closing two open problems in the literature. We also obtain tight bounds for all k-sided objects in the dual setting for nets of size 1, and a tight bound of 2/3 for nets of size 2 with respect to halfspaces. We show the two following elegant results: Given a set of points and a set of disks in the plane, if every three disks intersect in a common input point, then two of those points hit all disks; and, given a set of points and a set of halfspaces in the plane, if every three points belongs to a halfspace then two halfspaces cover all points.Joshi, Aadi. Epsilon-nets and related problems2018-00672018AD-MC-0042018-0067
Scope and Contents
Given a family of geometric objects S and a set of points P, we would like to prove that all object s in S that contain more than a certain fraction, epsilon, of points in P, can be hit by a small number of points in a set called the epsilon-net. By this we mean that if an object s in S contains more than a fraction epsilon of the points in P, then the object must also contain one or more of the points in the epsilon-net. In this capstone paper, we explore a variety of problems related to epsilon-nets. We improve the bounds on epsilon for disks and half-spaces when the epsilon-net contains 2 points. We also improve the bounds for disks and half-spaces for dual epsilon-nets. There are two additional proofs we provide related to hitting sets. We prove that if every three points is contained in a half-plane, then two half-planes must cover all points. We also prove that if every three disks intersect at a point, then two points hit all disks.Chen, Wei Peter; Shehroze Khan, Jihyun Kim, Tarik Zulfikarpasic. Qutr: A Cross-lingual Messenger with Keyword Searchable Phrases for the Travel Domain2018-00892018AD-MC-0042018-0089
Scope and Contents
We present Qutr (Query Translator), a smart cross-lingual communication application for the travel domain. It is a real-time messaging app that automatically translates conversations while supporting keyword-to-sentence matching. Qutr relies on querying a database that holds pre- translated phrases in different languages with the use of keywords. The application addresses common cross-lingual communication issues such as translation accuracy, speed, personalization and privacy.Csapo, Gabor. Classifying face representations with noise tolerant deep learning2018-00542018AD-MC-0042018-0054
Scope and Contents
Many massive sociological studies could be enabled by efficient machine learning on large scale online dataset. The main problem in the domain is that classification requires uniform data with accurate labels, but online collected image datasets can not provide pose, illumination or resolution invariance and the assigned labels have a high error rate. We surveyed the current state-of-the-art methods in generating face representations from online datasets, and tested them with noise resistant machine learning architectures. We applied the findings on a dataset of 30 million images to aid research at Princeton University on racial discrimination in career progression in corporate structures. Our final architecture: From the input images we generate low level face representations using the Openface neural network to overcome the invariance in our dataset. These representations are then fed into a base neural network which has a denoising layer attached to it that attempts to correct the error in the labels. Our approach reached 0.79 f1-score on the FERET dataset. The novelty of the project is two-fold: it adds to our understanding of machine learning under noisy conditions, and proposes a computationally efficient approach to classify millions of faces. Mirza, Muhammad Shujaat. Reimagining Privacy in Online Social Networks 2018-00932018AD-MC-0042018-0093
Scope and Contents
There has been growing interest in the field of longitudinal exposure of the user's publicly available data on social media platforms. While the privacy of current postings has been the subject of multiple research groups, the re-evaluation of the privacy settings for these posts down the line is a new area of interest for people. In regard to recent episodes such as the Facebook Cambridge Analytica scandal, discussions have revolved around the value we associate with the old postings. Whereas different platforms try to offer options to have some control over the accessibility of our information, their effectiveness relies on the extent to which users understand those options. Through this study, we aim to explore the relation between user's perception of their profile privacy settings and their actual settings. Our study, based on the participant pool of 91, reports that there is a significant mismatch between the actual exposure to the posts versus the user's perception of the privacy settings. We also investigate the impact old postings can have on friend circle expansion. The findings show how the aged information, relevant or irrelevant, finds a way to influence the user's behavior in the current context.Moore, Megan. Detection and Analysis of Devices Used to Censor Networks2018-00602018AD-MC-0042018-0060
Scope and Contents
This capstone sought to better understand the state of censorship in the world today. By fingerprinting a BlueCoat ProxySG, scanning the internet for identifiers and analyzing current censorship data and statistics, the research found a presence of censorship devices in more than 65 countries. These devices are being used in a range of industries and institutions including telecommunications companies and governments. They are being used to censor different types of content, including political discussion, western news sources and social commentary. Additionally devices were found in nations under US sanctions that limit them from procuring such devices and raise questions about how such devices are being acquired.Mountcastle, Zane D. User Authentication for In-Flight Captive Portal Wireless Networks2018-01022018AD-MC-0042018-0102
Scope and Contents
The drastic increase in IEEE 802.11 compatible mobile devices in recent years has been complemented by a widespread adoption of public WLAN (PWLAN) infrastructure. Open PWLANs are now a standard part of the global Internet infrastructure and are becoming a standard in-flight amenity on many commercial airplanes. Public networks, including in-flight Wi-Fi hotspots, are typically implemented as open wireless hotspots with user authentication and connection control implemented via redirection of HTTP(S) traffic from unrecognized devices to a captive portal. In this paper, we describe an exploit in which captive portal networks are exposed to authentication bypassing by unauthorized, selfish clients. We then describe a spoofing detection and mitigation suite designed to protect PWLANs against this class of spoofing attacks. In the context of in-flight wireless networks, captive portal circumvention by unauthorized users is especially critical given the high latency, low bandwidth physical layer that this type of network relies upon. The ultimate goal of this paper is to outline the construction of a comprehensive spoofing attack defense mechanism.Sharma, Prashant. Scope and Contents
Climate scientists use methods of decomposition of Outgoing Longwave Radiation (OLR) signal obtained through satellite imagery in terms of orthogonal basis functions which are determined from the data and find both time series and spatial patterns to construct Monsoon Intraseasonal Oscillation (MISO) phases. In this project, I attempted to train Outgoing Longwave Radiation (OLR) data without providing temporal information using standard Artificial Neural Networks, Convolution Neural Networks and Support Vector Machines. My attempts to train neural networks were unsuccessful. Having been able to predict MISO phases using Support Vector Machine by providing less information suggests that daily mean OLR data might have more MISO signal than previously thought and it suggests the possibility that we would be able to construct a long term time series of MISO phases using rain gauge data.Si, Peter. Permanent Marker2018-00852018AD-MC-0042018-0085
Scope and Contents
Permanent Marker is a decentralized news application that employs the blockchain data structure as a building block for its security. Specifically, it employs the immutability and availability of the Bitcoin blockchain network as a way to create a platform that can share and access information in a way that cannot be altered or hindered by a single entity. Permanent Marker allows users to interact with the Bitcoin network directly, allowing individuals to upload their articles of varying lengths as well as read such articles through the blockchain. Permanent Marker has the functionality to create and share articles of upto 4.8 Mbs. It is expected that Permanent Marker will provide an effective platform against censorship, allowing users to freely share and access information without the concern that their articles will be modified or destroyed.Vasishth, Abhimanyu. Synner: The Design and Implementation of a Usable Data Generation Tool2018-00962018AD-MC-0042018-0096
Scope and Contents
Testing data analytics tools is crucial in order to avoid incurring the high cost of post-release bug fixing. Test data is also useful for demonstrating product features or for creating educational material. Since real data may be confidential or difficult to obtain and wrangle, engineers and researchers rely on synthetic data generators. Existing data generators may be platform or programming language specific, difficult to use, and may often generate unrealistic-looking data because they do not allow users to adequately customize inputs and generated data. We present Synner, a data generation tool which focuses primarily on usability. Synner allows users to sketch custom input data distributions and specify relationships or dependencies between fields. In the spreadsheet interface, users can select from a various data types, domains and functions and see a preview of records. Since ultimately data is generated probabilistically, it is imperative to communicate this uncertainty in probabilistic data generation to users. We perform a user study to determine visualization techniques to suitably communicate probabilistic uncertainty. We allow users to enter examples of data and generate data that matches these examples by inferring the type, distribution and proportion of the examples provided by the user.Ahmed, David. Combining Keystroke and Mouse Dynamics for Stronger and More Usable Authentication2019-00752019AD-MC-0042019-0075
Scope and Contents
Traditional approaches to strengthening authentication systems come in the form such as Multi-Factor authentication (MFA) schemes, One-Time-Passwords (OTP), new password policies, etc. Even though these measures tend to improve authentication methods in theory, they come at a huge cost in terms of usability and practical security. This project investigates and proposes a combined implementation of keystroke and mouse dynamics for increasing the usability of current authentication schemes by making authentication systems more intelligent and user-centric. Consequently, instead of blindly posing challenges to authenticators, our approach allows for the authentication system to make real-time decisions as to if there is a necessity for new challenges in the form of MFA or other forms of traditional approaches. Al Dhaheri, Ali Saif Gharib Salem. Bulbul: An Online Application for Testing Arabic Dialect Knowledge2019-00732019AD-MC-0042019-0073
Scope and Contents
My project aims to educate native Arabic speakers as well as advanced non-native Arabic speakers on some of the basics of the numerous Arabic dialects through the use of a web application. The application will incorporate three main functionalities which are as follow: 1) Multiple Choice Questions and True/False Questions 2) Personal Accounts 3) Point system. Users will be able to go through the questionswhere they will be tested on their ability to identify certain Arabic dialectal words and phrases. The multiple choice and true/false questions are automatically generated uniquely by the application. By registering and logging in, users may save their progress of the questions. Questions will have points based on users' attempts at answering them. Lastly, I hope to bring natives and non-natives together in better understanding the fluidity of the Arabic language as well as its dialectal ambiguity through the help of this web application. Al Hosani, Khaled Tareq. Empirical Comparison of Heuristics for the Discrete Disk Cover Problem2019-00842019AD-MC-0042019-0084
Scope and Contents
We empirically examine the performance of two heuristics that return an approximate solution to the discrete disk cover problem. Given a set of disks D of varying radii and a set of points P, we attempt to choose the subset of minimal cardinality D′ ∈ D that covers all the points of P. We made two heuristics to test which we called the probability and random solvers. A third heuristic, called simple solver, is used to as a metric to examine how much the first two heuristics beat the fastest feasible solution. Finally, we also compare the results to that provided by the GNU Linear Programming Kit in order to see how close the heuristics came to what we consider the best possible solution. We find that the heuristics return solutions within one disk until the ILP reaches a threshold where calculation time is no longer feasible.Bachosz, Tomasz. Paper and digital data collection in New York: challenges and possible solutions2019-01082019AD-MC-0042019-0108
Scope and Contents
The digital revolution is happening today in every field, including the business, non-profit, and politics world. The same relates to the offline data collection. This research is to find the best solution to conduct offline data collection in the metropolitan area of New York City, as well as develop a mock product for it. This is based on the research that was conducted over the Summer 2018 through methods similar to those used in customer discover, as well as the later findings in the appropriate literature. The participants that helped develop this final report were huge non-profit organizations, political organizers, and businesses. Based on the results a list of biggest disadvantages of current paper data collection was created. Many of them proved to be similar to researches carried out in the same filed in different places and organizations, which might indicate that they are universal. However, there were also specific cases that were characteristic of highly congested metropolitan areas. Based on the input and the results, a mock-up software was created to address the issues faced by these organizations.Bhatia, Shantanu, and Yana Chala. Inferring Evidence-Based Processes from Outcomes and History2019-00892019AD-MC-0042019-0089
Scope and Contents
In this paper, we propose a system for analyzing Intensive Care Unit (ICU) visits and thereby supporting the diagnosis and treatment of patients in ICU settings. The goal of the system is to infer recommendations for actions that medical staff should perform on a given patient. To achieve this, we find patients in similar conditions, and devise a number of strategies for recommending actions that should improve a patient's medical state. These recommendations are derived from the set of similar patients and a patient's most recent test results. Currently, our system is trained on data collected from ICU patients admitted for pneumonia. In the future, it can be extended to accommodate a variety of diseases. We compared our system against a random sampling of actions. Our highest-performing strategy yields a mean F-score of 0.417 after three days, outperforming the mean F-score of the random sampler by 0.150 (p-value 0.026).Chung, Christine. Gender Awareness and Modification in English-Arabic Machine Translation2019-00862019AD-MC-0042019-0086
Scope and Contents
The rapid development of Natural Language Processing (NLP) has increased awareness of some of the biases these systems have with regards to gender identities. Nearly half the world's languages are gender-dependent, yet current machine translation systems do not indicate the gender of the characters that appear in the translated phrases. This is largely due to the fact that they are built on gender ambiguous human-generated data which reflect social biases, as well as the fact that these systems are designed to give one output. Providing the system with access to user preferences is the ideal seamless solution; but giving the user clear alternatives to select from is a good alternative. We propose an approach to designing a gender-aware machine translation system through gender identification and gender translation that can be used together with any NLP application that generates text interfacing with users. We focus on English-Arabic sentence pairs in the first-person where the gender identity needs to be specified. We develop a first-of-its-kind gender-labeled corpus for training and evaluating first-person gender identification and gender translation.Diugan, Raluca-Georgia, Guyu Fan, and Xin Tong. Timbre: A Decentralized Forum with Blockchain-based Distributed Data Store2019-01252019AD-MC-0042019-0125
Scope and Contents
Much of the public discourse today takes place online on social media platforms. However, these platforms are typically subject to censorship because centralized storage of user content allows for monopoly of moderation power. For example, posts on Facebook and tweets on Twitter may be removed at will by the service providers, and threads on Reddit may be locked or deleted by subreddit moderators. In response to this issue, we design and implement Timbre, a Blockchain-based distributed data storage system for decentralized online forums. In Timbre, forum content is distributed to different nodes, and a blockchain that records the complete history of user data storage and transactions for data retrieval is propagated across the peer-to-peer (P2P) network. Ultimately, we aim to provide an open and censorship-resistant system for public online discourse.Elsharkawi, Rayan. Understanding Money in the Digital Age: A Crypto-economic Investigation of Bitcoin Transaction Tips2019-01262019AD-MC-0042019-0126
Scope and Contents
This paper aims to contribute to the limited literature on Bitcoin tips to better understand what technological constraints and monetary properties drive them; this would potentially ameliorate regulatory decisions and design considerations for government sponsored cryptocurrencies. A two-stage linear regression is used to model the effect of the following drivers on Bitcoin transaction tips: mining difficulty, Bitcoin velocity, Bitcoin illiquidity using Amihud's illiquidity measure, block reward, exponentially weighted moving average volatility, and the estimated block size from the first-stage regression using WTI crude oil and natural gas futures prices as instruments. The instruments serve as a proxy for electricity costs to partial out the supply-side costs of mining. Statistically significant (at 95% confidence levels and higher) results show that transaction volume, velocity, and volatility have positive effects on Bitcoin transaction tips while mining difficulty and block reward have negative effects.Held, Will. The Effectiveness of Simple Hybrid Systems for Hypernym Discovery2019-01202019AD-MC-0042019-0120
Scope and Contents
Hypernymy modeling has largely been separated according to two paradigms, pattern-based and distributional methods. However, recent works utilizing a mix of these strategies have yielded state-of-the-art results. This paper evaluates the contribution of both paradigms to hybrid success by evaluating the benefits of hybrid treatment of baseline models from each paradigm. Even with a simple methodology for each individual system, utilizing a hybrid approach establishes new state-of-the-art results on two domain-specific hypernym discovery tasks and outperforms all non-hybrid approaches in a general hypernym discovery task.Nwadike, Munachiso. Recent work in semantic segmentation has shown the effectiveness of context encoding in allowing neural networks to model spatial context for better performance. We set out to apply this development to the field of remote sensing. Our focus is to develop a new approach for semantic segmentation of Very High Resolution (VHR) images. This class of aerial images is often difficult to attain high quality semantic labels for, given the distinct challenges that come with images that have been remotely sensed via satellite or other aerial mechanisms. We make use of a lightweight architecture of convolutional neural networks, combined with context encoding to attain strong performance on the Vaihingen 2D semantic labeling competition. Our approach attains a competitive overall accuracy, as well as a strong classwise performance.Olesen, Emil Goldsmith. GoodLiving (https://goodliving-beta.herokuapp.com/) is a system that supports new features for property search. GoodLiving specifically provides users the ability to find properties near places that they would like to visit (e.g. specific tourist destinations) or utilize (e.g. specific ethnic restaurants) and far from places they want to avoid (e.g. train stations). We built GoodLiving focusing both on creating an easy to use, simple and intuitive user experience, and on offering as many searchable attributes as possible. We then conducted a preliminary pilot user test, which despite being affected by imperfections in the prototype, showed great promise for GoodLiving and our proposed features (see complete data and scripts here), leading us to strongly recommend further work being done on developing GoodLiving and generally good location-based search parameters for property search. GoodLiving is open source (https://github.com/emilgoldsmith/GoodLiving) to allow further development.Rodriguez, Arantza. Emerge: a content creation and distribution application2019-00832019AD-MC-0042019-0083
Scope and Contents
The increased development and use of smartphone technology are contributing greatly to social empowerment and economic growth in emerging countries. However, despite this, smartphone users are still facing major challenges. Access to the internet in these regions suffers from slow load times, poor performances, and limited opportunities dedicated to local content creation and diffusion. Therefore, there is no chance for relevant information to be easily distributed. For my computer Science capstone project, I have developed an Android mobile application, known as EMERGE, to enable the diffusion of locally produced content in emerging countries. It has a series of templates that members can use to efficiently publish content in the form of articles. These articles are organized into several categories that help members easily find information that is most relevant to their interests. The application has been tested in three communities in Central Mexico: Juriquilla, La Barreta, and Colon. Through behavior analysis and a feedback survey, data has been gathered, processed, and presented in this paper. We believe that the results have been generally positive with people praising the features of EMERGE. Nonetheless, there have been several suggestions to improve the application, which will be implemented in the near future.Seo, Simon.
