A half-space in R3 is either of the two parts separated by a plane. Because of some helpful properties that exist in half-spaces, it is often useful to map geometries in a plane to half-spaces in R3. We attempt to prove or disprove the existence of a mapping from a family of squares in a plane to a family of half-spaces in R3 such that all points inside each square are mapped to points inside the corresponding half-space and all points outside each square are mapped to points outside the corresponding half-space. If such a mapping can be shown to exist, we attempt to provide a mathematical description of it or nd an algorithm that performs the mapping.Tenev, Theodore. Connected Home Devices: IoT Standardization Efforts to Advance Interoperability and Business Intelligence2019-00772019AD-MC-0042019-0077
Scope and Contents
QLM is a whole-of-life lifecycle management technique which leverages the ability of devices to connect to the Internet of Things to extend traditional PLM to include detailed information about device state and usage in each stage of the product life. This report identifies and compares the emerging technical standards of data collection and communication between connected home devices in the ever-growing Internet of Things to support broad adoption of standardization efforts by the manufacturers of such devices. The report highlights the importance of technical specifications and open standards in the IoT industry, reviews and analyzes existing formal standards and frameworks by The Open Group, bIoTope, NIST, and W3C. The report gives recommendations for the creation of cross-industry, cross-platform and cross-organizational services by fostering interoperability and openness between manufacturers and within product categories, as well as highlights areas for further improvement and optimization of the existing efforts. Ultimately this research will contribute to the ideation and development of a set of capabilities for extracting business knowledge from the information streams provided by the devices in the Internet of Things, adapting the PLM approach for the IoT context.Trejo, Alejandra. Digital Forgetting with Audience Awareness2019-00802019AD-MC-0042019-0080
Scope and Contents
The content uploaded to social networks is only relevant for a limited amount of time. As a response to this, online Social Networks (OSNs) like Instagram and Snapchat have introduced features that allows users content to be deleted after a predetermined amount of time. However, this system is inflexible as it only provides with one option for the amount of time a users content will be available online (24 hours). Other time-based revocation protocols have been proposed such as Neuralyzer which introduces the concept of flexible expiration times in which data is deleted based on different heuristics with one of them being drop of interest. None of these models account for the fact that users have different audiences in mind when they post content online which can range from close friends and family to the general public depending on the occasion. The aim of this capstone project is to create a time-based revocation model based on the drop of interest heuristic presented by Neuralyzer but that is also aware of the intended audience of the users content.Watanabe, Shunya. Supervised Segmentation of Electronic Dance Music 2019-01152019AD-MC-0042019-0115
Scope and Contents
In this research, I provide a case study for the segmentation of Electronic Dance Music. First, the chroma feature is employed to obtain the harmonic content of a song. The information gained from the chroma feature is then used to construct the self-similarity matrix. Using the self-similarity matrix, the novelty curve is calculated. The data consist of fifty arbitrary chosen songs in the genres of Electronic Danice Music, including Big Room and Future House. For the sake of simplicity, all the songs have the beats per minute (bpm) of 128. The performance of the algorithm is determined by calculating its F1 score, and the implications of the research are discussed in the paper. Utilizing the algorithm, I created an interface for the DJs to efficiently make a playlist for their performance. The interface provides recommendations for the next song to play and when to mix. The recommendations are based on its bpm, energy level, and segment types. I believe that this will change the workflow of making the playlists for the DJs.Cherevkov, Vlad. Analyzing JavaScript in Modern Webpages Using Machine Learning2020-00602020AD-MC-0042020-0060
Scope and Contents
Javascript is the most popular web-based programming language and is also unfortunately a major reason why the performance of modern web pages has been deteriorating. My main objective is to create the most accurate and robust machine learning classifier for third party JS scripts that will be deployable on a client system that does not have many available computational as well as disk resources. I focus on tree-based algorithms and, in particular, on performance differences between top bagging and boosting ensemble classifiers. The abundance of JS scripts used for tracking, advertising, beautification, and unnecessarily heavy content in the form of images or videos, put a heavy burden on users that lack either computational or internet data resources. By accurately identifying such scripts, the classifier was then successfully deployed in a two web-simplification focused pieces of software.
Author provided keywords: Machine Learning, Classification, Feature Elimination, Random Forest, XG BoostCoke, Russell, and Robert Gordon. Identity vs. Action: Exploring Bias Against Bots Using the Public Goods Game2020-00812020AD-MC-0042020-0081
Scope and Contents
It has been shown that when playing against a bot opponent in the Prisoner's Dilemma, a human is less likely to cooperate than if they were playing against a fellow human \cite{transparency2018ishowo-oloko}. This behaviour is detrimental to the progress of Artificial Intelligence because if humans are unwilling to cooperate with autonomous agents due to bias, then the usefulness of such agents is severely diminished. In an original controlled experiment, we will utilize a four-player iterated version of the public goods game to determine the extent to which humans are willing to cooperate with another participant who is labelled as a bot and whether that cooperation (or lack thereof) is based on the label or the behaviour of the ``bot'' participants. The results of this research has important implications for the fields of Artificial Intelligence and Human-Robot Interaction. Understanding humans' attitude towards interacting with autonomous agents at a fundamental level would shape how such agents are designed and implemented in the future.
Author provided keywords: AI, Artificial Intelligence, bias, public goods, game, iterated, social dilemma BotsElHassan, Yousra. Evaluation and Validation of an SQL Teaching Tool2020-00792020AD-MC-0042020-0079
Scope and Contents
The ability to write and understand data query languages is an essential skill for anyone that requires the use of databases, be it in an academic or commercial context. However, learning SQL has been identified as posing a number of difficulties to beginners. This project aims to design, prototype, test, and validate an SQL teaching tool and interface. Specifically, we aim to articulate a set of features extrapolated from the needs and challenges of the broader space that achieve an improved pedagogical efficacy. After an evaluation of the existing landscape, we present an interface that provides a visualization of query processing and allows users to view intermediate results at each step.
Author provided keywords: human-computer interaction, SQL education, user-study, validation research, evaluation researchElKattan, Alia. Building Ideology Language Models Using Twitter Network Data2020-00662020AD-MC-0042020-0066
Scope and Contents
Past research on political ideology of text has typically used supervised machine learning, where the training data must first be labelled by human coders or according to its source. This data collection process may incorporate its own subjectivity and bias and is not easily scalable or generalisable. In this paper I build an unsupervised language model which uses social media data to learn to identify the ideology of text. I find that it is possible to rely on Twitter networks to build language models, and identify challenges with interpreting such models and utilizing them for diverse applications.
Author provided keywords: nlp, language models, social media data, computational social scienceFriedman, Jaisal Paul. Comparing Random Forest and Linear Regression Models in Predicting Housing Sales Prices2020-00702020AD-MC-0042020-0070
Scope and Contents
This paper investigates the research question: can a random forest outperform a linear regression model for cross-sectional and time-series data partitioning in a 10-year random sample of San Francisco housing sales? The data-set is engineered, selected, and encoded producing optimized data-sets for each model. The key metrics: r-squared, RMSE, MAE, and mean error are then estimated for both time-series and cross-sectional data using 5-fold cross-validation. The metrics indicate that random forests outperform linear regression for both data approaches and that cross-sectional outperforms time-series data partitioning approaches. The learning curves, feature importance, and normalized regression coefficients from both models prove that random forest models better estimate complexities in the housing sales function and identify important features. The paper aims to convince the reader that random forest models are more flexible, can capture more complex relationships between variables, and thus perform better in predicting future sale prices and cross-sectional home values.
Author provided keywords: Econometrics, Machine Learning, Linear Asset PricingHu, Jacinta. Reducing Client-Side JavaScript Evaluation with JSAnalyze2020-00952020AD-MC-0042020-0095
Scope and Contents
JavaScript evaluation is one of the most costly and time-consuming parts of loading a web page. This project introduces a tool called JSAnalyze which automatically analyzes a web page to determine what JavaScript can be removed without impacting the user experience. JSAnalyze allows users to better understand the scripts present in their webpages and verify or alter the script removal choices made by the tool before saving the simplified page to an external proxy for future retrieval. Analyzing 100 popular web pages using JSAnalyze showed a reduction in overall Page LoadTime of more than 30% on mobile devices while retaining more than 90% of the original page content, as evaluated by a user study of 22 users.
Author provided keywords: JavaScript, optimization, web page, user experience, human-computer interactionJiang, Ross. An Online Arabic Readability Leveled Thesaurus2020-00592020AD-MC-0042020-0059
Scope and Contents
In this project, we developed the first ever readability leveled Arabic thesaurus interface. The effort built on and connected two existing resources: (a) AWN (the Arabic WordNet) [2] which provided synonymy information and alternative phras- ings, and (b) the Standard Arabic Morphological Analyzer [4] which allows us to abstract from inflected forms of Arabic words to their possible dictionary entry forms. Moreover, we supported the building of a third necessary component: a readability-labeled lexicon for the dictionary entries. Finally, we designed and implemented a public online interface to navigate our database. A user can also choose to search our database by Arabic words, Arabic lemmas in our standard representation, Arabic roots or English glosses. The interface provides information on part of speech, root, English gloss, a readability rating on a five-level readability scale and a list of synonyms. This database and interface are made as part of the NYUAD funded project SAMER (Simplification of Arabic Masterpieces for Extensive Reading) where it is intended to aid scholars who are tasked with simplifying Arabic literature to reach a wider audience with varying Arabic abilities. However, we believe that this interface will benefit anyone with an Arabic writing task.
Author provided keywords: Readability, Lexicon, Arabic, NLP, InterfaceJung, MinKyu. SynnerDB: A Scalable Database System for Synthetic Data Generation2020-01012020AD-MC-0042020-0101
Scope and Contents
Synner is a synthetic data generator, developed to meet the rising demand in high quality data, which are scarcely available in public. Under current Synner's capacity, sophisticated datasets can be produced realistically in a simple manner. However, Synner stores data by row, which may bring question in its scalability performances, especially when users want to produce big data. Big data is particularly scarce making it difficult for students to test the machine learning techniques they learned outside of a classroom, let alone initiate their own projects. Additionally, startups can also face difficulty to test their products due to the lack of large datasets that are specific to their business. While Synner's current engine allows these two groups to produce realistic data that meet their circumstances, due to Synner's row-oriented storage, producing terabytes of data can raise data generation speed issues. In this paper, we further improve Synner's function by adding more tools and specifications for users to generate sophisticated dataset, and also improve Synner's scalability by integrating a column-oriented DBMS, MonetDB.
Author provided keywords: database systems, data generation, c-storeKhan, Haseeb. Wireguard: An Efficient Solution for Securing IoT Device Connectivity?2020-01122020AD-MC-0042020-0112
Scope and Contents
With the increasing number of automated and manual cyber-attacks in recent years due to the growing number of devices connected to the Internet, the introduction and then the rapid adoption of the Internet of Things (IoT) like smart home devices have further increased pertinent risks. Virtual Private Networks (VPNs) are usually used to protect from classical MITM and other attacks. However, for weak and low resource IoTs like a smart thermometer connected to the Internet, using a VPN is often rendered impractical by the overhead it adds. In this project, we consider different ideas put forward to solve this problem, discuss their drawbacks, and show that a new VPN called Wireguard drastically reduces the attack surface for hackers in comparison to other popular solutions, and also provides a compelling reason to be used as the solution. It will provide them with reliable security that usually only more powerful machines benefit from. In this paper, we have tested Wireguard in the context of weak devices that mimic IoT devices and derive promising results in terms of performance.
Author provided keywords: Wireguard, VPN, VPN performance, IoT Security, OverheadLeyva, Gabriel. Simplifying the Web: Optimized Network Architecture and User Interface for improved Internet access in Developing Regions2020-00992020AD-MC-0042020-0099
Scope and Contents
The Internet has grown exponentially since its inception. To support this growth the developed world has deployed high-speed networks that compensate for the Internet's complexity. This leaves developing regions with a sub-par and cost-prohibitive Internet experience, as most users access the Internet through mobile data. We provide an optimized Network Architecture and User Interface for developing regions. Our research focuses on deploying Man-In-The-Middle (MITM) Proxies on Edge Caches that are close to the users and store cached pages, which are optimized through our JavaScript simplification software. We also provide a light-weight User Interface that allows users to search our database of cached pages through relevant keywords, thanks to our word-ranking algorithm. Our Results showed our solution provided significant improvements in (PLT), Page Size, and Number of Requests.
Author provided keywords: PLT, Page Size, Requests, JavaScript, Developing Regions, UX, Network ArchitectureLiu, Michael. Quantifying Editors' Role in Academic Publication2020-00932020AD-MC-0042020-0093
Scope and Contents
As the most important metric for scientific impact, citation is as valuable for journals as it is for scientists. To be published in a more prestigious journal means that a paper is likely to receive more citations, and to publish potentially impactful papers will in return boost the reputation of a journal. The fate of a paper is determined in the peer review process, where editors play a critical role. However, due to the lack of comprehensive data regarding journal editors, there has been little quantitative research dedicated to them. This research studies editors from about 2000 Elsevier journals, and uncovers patterns of interaction between scientists, journals, and editors. We generated a first-of-its-kind temporal dataset of editorial board members, and showed that being an editor positively affects a scientist's impact but negatively affects one's productivity.Mai, Anh. Policy optimization to control epidemics2020-00922020AD-MC-0042020-0092
Scope and Contents
We present an epidemic management framework that combines an epidemic model with reinforcement learning. This framework focuses on the interaction between the epidemic and a decider who uses tools (vaccines, isolation etc) to counter the epidemic. We demonstrate the reproducibility and capability of this framework in designing flexible public health interventions as well as how to train the decider to control the epidemic. Finally, we apply the framework to show qualitative results that support: Aggressive travel restriction and social distancing strategies help to delay and lower the peak in an epidemic, Early action matters a lot more than late action, Contact tracing plays an important role in controlling the epidemic.
Author provided keywords: public health policy, compartmental model, reinforcementlearning, epidemic frameworkMiller, Jahnae. An Empirical Comparison of Code Similarity Algorithms 2020-00582020AD-MC-0042020-0058
Scope and Contents
As the usage of JavaScript libraries becomes more prevalent, so does the adoption of bad and careless practices, such as including multiple versions of the same library within the same document. These bad practices negatively impact the page load times (PLTs) of the web pages. Thus, an in- tuitive way of reducing page load times is removing these duplicate scripts. There are four main categories of duplicate detection techniques: metric-based techniques, token sequence-based techniques, tree-based techniques and PDG-based techniques. However, PDG-based and metric-based techniques have al- ready been proven to be costly and not very accurate, respectively. Thus, suitable candidate algorithms must be found within the realm of tree-based and token-sequence based techniques. In this paper, three algorithms are explored: two token- sequence based algorithms and one tree-based algorithm. These algorithms are compared and evaluated to find the best algorithm for use in a light-weight tool meant to help reduce page load times by cutting out unnecessary JavaScript.
Author provided keywords: clone detection, web optimization, javascript, similarity comparison, redundant codeRistova, Teona. The effect of air-pollution and Republican vote share on police performance and racial bias2020-01042020AD-MC-0042020-0104
Scope and Contents
Extensive research has been conducted on the topic of racial bias in policing, ranging from traditional surveys to large-scale data analysis. This existing research largely focuses on evaluating police behavior towards minority groups while controlling for socioeconomic factors such as neighborhood characteristics, vehicle type, poverty rate, and income level. Our research takes a less traditional approach in evaluating human behavior and racial bias by evaluating how police performance is affected by environmental factors such as air pollution and temperature. We show that higher temperatures and lower air quality are associated with higher efficiency rates among police officers. Our findings further suggest that these environmental conditions may also be associated with increased bias rates towards Blacks. We then explore the link between the proportion of votes for a Republican president against police performance and bias. We find that increased proportions of voters in support of a Republican candidate are associated with superior police performance. Nevertheless, we find no evidence suggesting that increased vote share in favor of a Republican president is associated with discriminatory behavior by the police.
Author provided keywords: pollution, bias, temperature, elections, police, performanceSandoval, Jose. AutoTag: Metadata Automation for Film Post-Production2020-00642020AD-MC-0042020-0064
Scope and Contents
Film post-production can be time- and money-inefficient. A lot of the work involves a person or group of people, called metadata taggers, going through each individual piece of media and marking it up with the relevant tags, such as the scene number, transcripts, and the type of shot for video footage. Such a task is particularly time-consuming for films with high shooting ratios (i.e., footage shot/footage shown). The average high production movie has a shooting ratio between 100:1 and 1000:1. A metadata tagger's task is to watch all of these media and tag it. Assuming the most popular runtime of a movie, 101 minutes, and a conservative shooting ratio of 100, the time it would take for a single person to achieve this task is 168 hours, without even taking into account the audio recording associated with each piece of video. This is at least 21 days of a person working full-time, both delaying the post-production process significantly and placing a significant burden on independent filmmakers who often have a small budget. AutoTag automates much of the tagging process, saving both time and money. We describe the algorithms and implementation of AutoTag and report on some case studies.
Author provided keywords: Post-production, film editing, speech recognition, image clas- sification, Google speech-to-textShazal, Ali, and Aiza Usman. Arabizi-to-Arabic Transliteration using Sequence-to-Sequence Models2020-00612020AD-MC-0042020-0061
Scope and Contents
While online Arabic is primarily written using the Arabic script, a common Roman-script variant called Arabizi is often seen on social media. Although this representation captures the phonology of the language, it is not a 1-to-1 mapping with the Arabic script version. Due to the different sound-to-letter rules of English and Arabic, there are complex mappings be-tween the two writing systems. This issue is exacerbated by the fact that Arabizi on social media is Dialectal Arabic which does not have a standard orthography. Moreover, many people writing Arabizi are bilinguals, so they code switch between Arabic and a foreign language such as English in the same sentence. To map Arabizi text to Arabic script in the context of complete sentences or utterances, previous published works have utilized finite state machines, n-gram language models and morphological analyzers. In this project, we present a sequence-to-sequence deep learn-ing model for the task. We employ a large dataset of Egyptian Arabizi words that have been transliterated to the Arabic script. Our best model beats the best previously reported results in this task.
Author provided keywords: transliteration, arabizi, arabic, NLP, seq2seq, deep learningShibly, Maahir UR Rahman Mohamed, and Mingyang Wang. Timbre: A Censorship-resilient Online Platform2020-01112020AD-MC-0042020-0111
Scope and Contents
A large and growing part of our public discourse is taking place over online platforms. These platforms create a bottleneck to freedom of speech as a consequence of censorship policies imposed by corporations, governments, and private entities. While the ability to moderate content is pertinent, today's centralized platforms allow content to be removed by platform owners and moderators without real recourse or accountability.Timbre is a distributed decentralized discussion forum that aims to preserve freedom of speech while allowing 'moderation', all the while preventing itself from being re-centralized by adversaries.Timbre strikes a balance between freedom of speech and moderation by allowing all content to be posted and by decentralizing censorship power. A Timbre forum is indexed by a blockchain while the content itself is stored separately by distributed data stores. Moderation is implemented as published streams that users can selectively apply as filters onto raw forum content. Timbre prevents blockchain re-centralization and 'buy-outs' through the use of a proof-of-stake consensus algorithm in conjunction with periodic epochs that essentially enable us to reset any form of power centralization that may occur over the course of the epoch.
Author provided keywords: Blockchain, Decentralized, Forum, DPoS, Timbre Shrestha, Samridha. Ensemble AutoDecoder CompNets for 3D Point Cloud Pair Encoding and Classification2020-00762020AD-MC-0042020-0076
Scope and Contents
Since the inception of LeNet5, Yan LeCun's first Convolutional Neural Network for handwritten digit-recognition in 1998, Neural Networks have come a long way in classifying 2D images and extracting their features. However, since we live in a 3D world, it is natural to ask if we can classify 3D shapes and extract their shape descriptors. This turns out to be rather difficult given the exponential increase in complexity with the added third dimension. To perform this classification efficiently, we propose an ensembled encoderless-decoder and classifier neural network to learn the latent encoding vectors for 3D point-cloud pair transformations. This ensemble extracts the feature descriptors of the transformations without a parametric encoder or a lossy 2D projection. We also empirically demonstrate the effectiveness of our ensemble model through a benchmark comparison on a 3D point cloud classification task for the PointNet and ModelNet dataset. Finally, we discuss the applicability of our 3D shape descriptor learners and classifiers as preprocessing techniques for eventual 3D object classification, segmentation, and database retrieval tasks.
Author provided keywords: AutoDecoder, 3D Point Cloud Classification, Ensemble Neural Networks, latent point-driftWatson, Daniel. Bounding Neural Mutual Information Estimates via Additive Noise2020-00652020AD-MC-0042020-0065
Scope and Contents
We study the problem of estimating mutual information (MI) between a data distribution and the pushforward distribution induced by a differentiable black-box transformation. We show that, despite that the problem is ill-defined for deterministic transformations, the straightforward change of introducing additive noise not only fixes said issue, but also enables both neural and parameter-free MI estimates that sandwich MI by bounding it above and below. We propose novel neural MI upper bounds that this change enables, and to use them in conjunction with existing neural MI lower bounds in order to strengthen evaluations of MI estimates across the literature. Studying these different neural MI estimators and their accuracy under fixed neural architectures and datasets, we highlight their necessity as parameter-free methods struggle to scale to high dimensions and high MI settings. We also showcase a simple study of MI maximization and how our methodology can be used to measure the mutual information achieved by different unsupervised learning methods.
Author provided keywords: deep representation, learning, mutual information bounds estimation neural networksXu, Chenhao. EPDNet: Encoder-less 3D Shape Descriptor Extraction2020-00772020AD-MC-0042020-0077
Scope and Contents
Existing 3D shape descriptor extraction methods based on neural network encoders have not been able to replicate the same success of its 2D counterpart, due to the increased time-space complexity brought by the extra dimension and the unstructured nature of point cloud data. To tackle this challenge, we propose EPDNet (Encoder-less Point Drift Net), a novel formulation based on auto-decoder networks that allows us to extract joint shape descriptors of 3D point cloud shape pairs without needing an encoder network, by directly optimizing latent shape descriptors for the self-supervised coherent point drift task. We show that by using this formulation, we can bypass the difficulty of designing encoders for 3D data and directly obtain informative shape descriptor vectors that capture the relationship between a pair of 3D shapes. We further demonstrate the effectiveness of our method by applying the extracted shape descriptors in other computer vision tasks such as classification.
Author contributed keywords: Computer Vision, Machine Learning, point cloud, 3D, AutodecoderZapolskas, Lukas. Detecting and Preventing GPS Spoofing Attacks in Vehicular Networks2020-00712020AD-MC-0042020-0071
Scope and Contents
In this paper, we investigate possible attacks on civilian GPS systems and focus on spoofing attacks. In light of existing research, we chose to focus on spoofing attacks on GPS-dependent vehicular networks. Building upon previous GPS error modelling, we propose an extension to existing error models that would allow for groups of vehicles in motion to coordinate and detect spoofing attacks against individual members of the group, requiring as little as two independent vehicles, subject to constraints related to their individual and relative velocities, achieved via analytical modelling and verified with a simulation.
Author contributed keywords: GPS Spoofing Countermeasures, Sensor fusionAl hemeiri, Aisha. Murjan: A Web Platform for Monitoring & Predicting Coral Bleaching Events in the Arabian/Persian Gulf2021-00852021AD-MC-0042021-0085
Scope and Contents
Corals exist in substantial numbers in the Arabian Gulf due to its shallow nature. However, because of climate change and a rise in sea temperatures, the number of coral bleaching events has drastically increased. Corals in the Arabian Gulf are most susceptible to bleaching because of the shallow conditions of the Gulf - rendering it difficult for corals to mix with deeper, cooler waters. While climate change is the main culprit of coral bleaching, other reasons include dredging and land reclamation, practices that are common in the United Arab Emirates (UAE) due to the rapid development. As such, corals, especially those that are close to the coast, are at high risk of bleaching and possibly, mortality. To decrease stress on corals, we propose a web platform, Murjan, that will use seasonal weather forecasts and a water-column model, the General Ocean Turbulence Model (GOTM), to assess and predict the likelihood of coral bleaching in advance by producing forecasts of sea-bottom temperatures and other relevant variables. Murjan would enable its audience, one of which is government agencies, to suspend construction work when the likelihood of coral bleaching is shown to be high.
Author provided keywords: web, platform, coral, bleaching, oceanography, Arabian Gulf, Persian GulfAlkhaja, Maria. Improving Traffic by Exploiting Autonomous Vehicles2021-01022021AD-MC-0042021-0102
Scope and Contents
Congestion can easily be induced by any bottlenecks on road, including lane closures and on-ramp merging sections. When enough aggressive drivers do not give way to merging vehicles, the length of traffic further increases and through put decreases leading to a longer travel time. For this reason, we propose exploiting the advanced radar technology of autonomous vehicles in order to record and punish aggressive drivers who are not giving way in order to push them to give way.
Author provided keywords: autonomous vehicles, bottlenecks, road management, traffic simulation toolAlzarooni, Rashid. Terrorist Activity Correlated Indicator Tracker (T.A.C.I.T) : A platform to visualize and quantify Indicators of Terrorism Activity2021-01072021AD-MC-0042021-0107
Scope and Contents
Over the past decade, terrorists killed an average of 21,000 people each year. Since then, the United States of America alone has spent 2.8 trillion dollars on counter-terrorism efforts. Although these efforts have curbed several uprisings of major terrorist organizations, preemptively predicting acts of terrorism with much detail has continued to prove exceedingly difficult over the years. The reasons behind the struggles of law enforcement and counter-terrorism agencies across the globe is the lack of clarity behind deep terrorist motivations and the lack of access to historical and real time data on terrorism. We used meticulously analyzed, clustered, and classified historical global governance and terrorism data to formulate models that highlight key indicators that had significant corre- lations to past spikes in terrorist activity. Once we identified such indicators and established a pattern, we displayed the results on an interactive web application. As such, this project has three main deliverables: a synthesized dataset tracking thousands of different global indicators arranged in an intuitive 2-axes format, a terrorism activity prediction model generated using a Least Absolute Shrinkage and Selection Operator on the dataset, and a web platform that enables users to visualize and extract data.
Author provided keywords: Global Terrorism Database (GTD), GIS, Interactive web application.Ansari, Aizaz. Developing a Post Processing System to ImproveArabic OCR2021-00862021AD-MC-0042021-0086
Scope and Contents
Arabic Optical Character Recognition (OCR) remains a challenging problem due to the cursive nature of the language, and contemporary Arabic OCR systems struggle to achieve high word accuracy rates. In our capstone, we created a novel post-processing system that works on the output of a pre-existing OCR system and reduces the word error rate (WER) from 46\% to 13\%, producing state of the art results. The system utilizes an n-gram based letter disambiguation technique to fix the issue of word segmentation and letter substitution in Arabic OCR. Unlike other hybrid methods, our system relies on little to no human intervention.
Author provided keywords: NLP, Arabic OCR, Language Modeling, Segmentation, SRILMBendevski, Filip. Predicting Narrative Coherence2021-00952021AD-MC-0042021-0095
Scope and Contents
Stories people tell about themselves and how they recalltheir experiences reveal a lot about who they are and theirmental well-being. Psychologists have identified this andcreated the Narrative Coherence Coding Scheme (NaCCS); aset of guidelines for annotating the "coherence" of a narra-tive in terms of its theme, chronology and context [2]. Uponannotating narratives in accordance with the NaCCS, psy-chologists have found a significant correlation between thecoherence score of a narrative and independently collectedmental health markers of the narrator [7]. Currently, all anno-tation for coherence is done manually; a time consuming taskwhich drains vital resources that could have otherwise beenspent elsewhere. Our Capstone project aims to make useof natural language processing (NLP) and machine learning(ML) techniques to directly predict a narrative's coherencescore. We explore a number of different techniques for thistask, ranging from traditional machine learning models suchas Support Vector Machines (SVM) to pre-trained languagemodels such as BERT (Bidirectional Encoder Representationsfrom Transformers).
Author provided keywords: NLP, Machine Learning (ML), Narrative text analysisBudnik, Ivan. Spottr: A parallel shot boundary detection tool for audio post-production2021-00972021AD-MC-0042021-0097
Scope and Contents
The audio post-production industry is constantly evolving, yet its workflows remain outdated. The process of spotting is one of them, requiring repetitive, manual, and time-consuming work for an automatable procedure. This project presents a tool prototype that automates this process by procedurally detecting shot boundaries on a given video file, storing each exact boundary location, and exporting them into an AAF file, which allows these markers to be imported by Pro Tools, or any other DAW or video editing software intended for post-production. A dual-stage shot boundary detection (SBD) algorithm [3] for abrupt and gradual changes was implemented and refined to further improve accuracy. Parallel computing techniques were used to boost performance by creating an enhanced parallel version for multi-core processors with OpenMP.
Author provided keywords: spotting, shot boundary detection, OpenMP, AAF, audio post-productionDzitac, Domnica. Extending the Dollar Auction: The Power of Artificial Intelligence in Shaping Conflict2021-00922021AD-MC-0042021-0092
Scope and Contents
The aim of this capstone project is to investigate the extent to which Artificial Intelligence can shape conflicts. The topic is of high importance because besides filling in a gap in literature, it allows us to model how the outcome of conflicts will be affected if a state acquires the ability to automate decision making when facing other states. Based on Martin Shubik's Dollar Auction and previous related work, we look into how humans' decision-making process changes when their opponent is an algorithm, and not another human being. Moreover, we control for the levels of spitefulness in both humans and bots. Our results give insight into which experimental condition incentives players to stick to the optimal strategy, which players win more often and how they feel towards their opponent.
Author provided keywords: Artificial Intelligence, Dollar Auction, Game Theory, Conflict EscalationEdwards, Alex. Building a Pipeline to Decode Mental States from Cortical Activity 2021-01152021AD-MC-0042021-0115
Scope and Contents
This project built a pipeline to decode perceptual states from neural activity in the human brain's visual system. An uncertainty-based inverted encoding model (TAFKAP) was trained on the brain's processed BOLD response to different stimuli, measured through MRI. The project relied on a dataset where subjects observed dot clouds moving in different directions in the horizontal (xz) plane while their brain activity was measured. Using a new algorithm TAFKAP, the brain was modeled through uncertainty-based methods that could capture these correlations. While uncertainty-based decoding techniques have been used before, they have predominantly been applied to 2D orientation (rather than 3D motion). Neurons responsive to retinal orientation exist at an early stage of the visual hierarchy and as such are thought to be easier to decode, whereas 3D motion sensitive neurons are thought to exist later in the visual hierarchy and are therefore more difficult to decode. This project found that 3D motion could be successfully decoded from several ROIs (regions of interest like V1, V2, hMT, IPS) at an accuracy of greater than 50% (baseline chance at 12.5%).
Author provided keywords: Inverted encoding, Visual Hierarchy, Motion-Based StimuliFernando, Dunumalage Romeno Wenogk. Hide and seek! Browser Fingerprinting Data Set Deanonymization via Feature Set Optimization-Based Linkage Attacks2021-00932021AD-MC-0042021-0093
Scope and Contents
Web providers today can track users with or without their permission using stateless fingerprint tracking. This method works by obtaining a combination of browser attributes (or features) from the browsing environment of the user and producing a fingerprint ID. The fingerprint ID is subject to change as attribute(s) in the system are updated. Pugliese et al. [7] conducted a three-year long study that resulted in the collection and analysis of fingerprints. This paper proposes the first entropy analysis done on the data set consisting of 37,762 fingerprints and 854 users (a subset of the entire data set from Pugliese) which helped identify key attributes and combinations of attributes that help with user deanonymization. Among the deanonymization attack methods we propose, we present the results of one such attack. Our dynamic deanonymization attack algorithm produced 86.2% accuracy in matching anonymized fingerprints with just 25 of the total available 216 attributes that were selected based on the entropy analysis. Identifying the specific attributes that require more protection [3] would aid in the mission of ensuring web privacy and serves as a starting point for privacy policy development that is integrated into the browser environment.
Author provided keywords: deanonymization attacks, web user identification, privacy, browser fingerprintingGan, Berwin. Approximations for Covering in a Streaming Setting, Covering with Orthants2021-00872021AD-MC-0042021-0087
Scope and Contents
We present approximations schemes for local variations on the unit disc covering problem in a streaming setting. We give a 2-approximation algorithm to find a hitting set of size 2 when there exists a hitting set of size 1 for the half-space variation. After that, we give a 1.5-approximation algorithm for the dual problem of the interval covering problem when the solutions size is 2. For the lower bound, we show a 1.5 lower bound for the square variation and a 2 lower bound for the half-space variation. For covering with orthants, we first give a construction method to solve the uniform single connection with one type of orthant problem. We then show that using only one type of orthant is equivalent to the planar graph. Furthermore, we worked towards showing arbitrarily large size cliques cannot be made using exactly zero and one intermediary points.
Author provided keywords: half-spaces orthants streaming algorithm single-passGokten, Deniz. Data Analytics and Visualisation of Terrorism Data Using Self-Organizing Maps2021-00912021AD-MC-0042021-0091
Scope and Contents
This project attempts a new search for a terrorist profile taking into consideration two of the main limitations in previous research: the lack of primary data and limited quantitative techniques. To solve the lack of primary data, two databases are used in this project: 1) Terrorists Survey Database (TSD): A database made by surveying more than 12,000 terrorists in Sri Lanka gathered by Professor Jocelyn Belanger 2) Global Terrorism Database (GTD): a database that contains information about terrorist activities from 1970 until 2019, prepared by The National Consortium for the Study of Terrorism and Responses to Terrorism (START). To solve the limitation of the quantitative techniques, a powerful deep learning technique called Self-Organizing Maps (SOM) is used to analyze both databases. SOM is a type of Artificial Neural Network that uses competitive learning to create low-dimensional views of high-dimensional datasets. The current results show interesting correlations that lead to potential hypotheses about terrorism. Furthermore, the clusters created by SOMs contain characteristic features that are potential candidates for the terrorist profile. The implication and meaning of the current results will be studied during the psychological evaluation of the results.
Author provided keywords: Terrorism, Deep Learning, Artificial Neural Networks, Self-Organizing MapsGunkova, Magda. Imagined Communities in Multilingual Wikipedia: Evaluating Theories of Ethnic Nationalism with Geographic and National Data2021-01012021AD-MC-0042021-0101
Scope and Contents
We argue that in addition to the traditional definitions of bias, there are other, more subtle forms of bias that exist within articles about the same people written in different languages and we use the terms "crowd" or "community" bias to label this phenomenon. This research has employed a combination of structured information from Wikidata and information extraction from Wikipedia entries using spaCy pipelines in Python in order to assess nationality appropriation in knowledge-sharing communities, corresponding roughly to what is known as the historical phenomenon of "Polonization". Using subsets of the data acquired from English, German and Polish Wikipedia we use geo-visualization of birth and death places of famous people as well as birth and death dates and their declared nationality as a way of evaluating to what extent language communities produce "imagined communities" within Wikipedia. Our method builds on a literature regarding bias in Wikipedia, but instead of linguistic markers of bias, we look to a combination of nationality markers derived from part-of-speech analysis and geographic information.
Author provided keywords: geographic information, bias, Wikipedia, national appropriation, imagined communities, digital historyHashmi, Waleed. A Computer Vision Based Tool to Evaluate Structural and Functional Comparison between Webpages2021-01122021AD-MC-0042021-0112
Scope and Contents
The increasing complexity of web pages has attracted a number of solutions to offer simpler versions of these pages. These solutions have been quantitatively evaluated to show significant speed-ups in page load times, bandwidth and memory consumption. However, what these solutions fail to evaluate is the qualitative impact on their generated pages. Additionally, due to the lack of a unified qualitative metric, it is nearly impossible to fairly compare results obtained from different user studies campaigns. This capstone demonstrates the lack of qualitative evaluation metrics, and propose QLUE (QuaLitative Uniform Evaluation), a tool that automates the qualitative evaluation of web pages using computer vision. Our results show that QLUE computes comparable content and functional similarity scores to those provided by human evaluators. Specifically, for 90% of 100 pages, the human evaluators gave content similarity scores between 90% and 100%, while QLUE shows the same range of similarity scores for more than 75% of the pages.
Author provided keywords: Computer Vision, Web ComplexityHensley, Tyeece Kiana Fredorcia and Wahib Kamran. TOIA 2.0: A User-Centered Time-Offset Interaction Application2021-01102021AD-MC-0042021-0110
Scope and Contents
Time-offset interaction applications (TOIA) allow simulating conversations with people who have previously recorded relevant video utterances, which are played in response to their interacting user. TOIAs have great potential for preserving cross-generational and cross-cultural histories, online teaching, simulated interviews, etc. Current TOIAs exist in niche contexts involving high production costs. Democratizing TOIA presents different challenges when creating appropriate pre-recordings, designing different user stories, and creating simple online interfaces for experimentation. We open-source TOIA 2.0, a user-centered time-offset interaction application, and make it available for everyone who wants to interact with people's pre-recordings, or create their pre-recordings.
Author provided keywords: Systems Design, Interface Development, Human-Computer, Interaction, Corpus CreationIbrahim, Jumana. Predicting Narrative Coherence2021-00992021AD-MC-0042021-0099
Scope and Contents
Stories people tell about themselves and how they recall their experiences reveal a lot about who they are and their mental well-being. Psychologists have identified this and created the Narrative Coherence Coding Scheme (NaCCS); a set of guidelines for annotating the "coherence" of a narrative in terms of its theme, chronology and context [2]. Upon annotating narratives in accordance with the NaCCS, psychologists have found a significant correlation between the coherence score of a narrative and independently collected mentalhealthmarkersofthenarrator[7].Currently,allannotation for coherence is done manually; a time consumingtask which drains vital resources that could have otherwise been spent elsewhere. Our Capstone project aims to make use of natural language processing (NLP) and machine learning (ML) techniques to directly predict a narrative's coherence score. We explore a number of different techniques for this task, ranging from traditional machine learning models such as Support Vector Machines (SVM) to pre-trained language models such asBERT(Bidirectional Encoder Representations from Transformers).
Author provided keywords: NLP, Machine Learning (ML), Narrative text analysis, Narrative CoherenceJain, Shantanu. Refusing Predictions to Enhance Accuracy 2021-01142021AD-MC-0042021-0114
Scope and Contents
This Capstone project implemented the idea of using refusals to enhance accuracy using the meta-algorithm for online learning. SafePredict provides probabilistic asymptotic bounds on error rates. As part of the Capstone, I implemented a complete software package compatible for inclusion in the popular Python machine learning library scikit-learn. The advantage of using SafePredict has been demonstrated using this scikit-learn implementation for different online learning scenarios. A brief example using the MNIST digit recognition dataset is shown to provide an intuitive understanding of the refusal mechanism of SafePredict. This example also shows how the scikit-learn implementation can be used out-of-the-box for a simple application. A similar example with a changing data distribution using the cod-rna dataset demonstrates SafePredict limiting the error rate of accepted predictions despite the base estimator having an unbounded error rate due to a change in the data distribution. An example forecasting the returns of publicly traded companies from the OEX-100 is used to shown how the package can be extended for more advanced applications and the advantages of using SafePredict through an intuitive measure of an average profit gain of 37 percent for a trading strategy across 97 companies.
Author provided keywords: machine learning refusal accuracy prediction safepredict python scikit-learn Jawed, Muhammad Anas. Developing a Post Processing System to Improve Arabic OCR2021-01032021AD-MC-0042021-0103
Scope and Contents
Arabic Optical Character Recognition (OCR) remains a challenging problem due to the cursive nature of the language, and contemporary Arabic OCR systems struggle to achieve high word accuracy rates. In our capstone, we created a novel post-processing system that works on the output of a pre-existing OCR system and reduces the word error rate (WER) from 46% to 13%, producing state of the art results. The system utilizes an n-gram based letter disambiguation technique to fix the issue of word segmentation and letter substitution in Arabic OCR. Unlike other hybrid methods, our system relies on little to no human intervention.
Author provided keywords: Natural Language Processing, Arabic OCR, Machine Learning, Modelling, Post CorrectionJia, Bokang. SynnerDB - A system for generating synthetic datasets2021-882021AD-MC-0042021-0088
Scope and Contents
Based on the specific design choices of Synner, we out-line a language for data generation - Syddel - examining the valid space of relationships that a user can and cannot express. Given a valid plan, we further investigate strategies for optimizing data generation when creating billions of synthetic data points. We present some strategies for generation speedup, including the use of columns instead of rows, pushing down predicates, evaluating sampling across table joins, as well as caching results when incrementally creating columns. A set of experiments were run to assess the validity of these strategies within the various generation units of SynnerDB.
Author provided keywords: database level synthetic big data generationKang, Branden. Link Predictions Using Pytorch-BigGraph and Gensim2021-00892021AD-MC-0042021-0089
Scope and Contents
I continued my work with knowledge graph link prediction using the PBG model, with the central idea being the utilization of trained embeddings for link prediction. Through frameworks such as PBG and Gensim, I aimed to leverage machine learning inference using the matrix of embeddings and the mapping between entities and their entries in the trained model. Given the structure of the graph, the model was able to infer missing links when given an entity and relationship, showing optimal performance when trained with 200 dimensions and 200 epochs. Ultimately, the model allows users to query the model for some movie name and relationship, or multiple movie names, and returns the predicted result of the query, even if that particular movie-relationship tuple is not present in the graph.
Author provided keywords: Machine Learning, Link Prediction, Knowledge GraphsKoss, Kertu. Intelligent Question Generation for Time-Offset Interaction Applications2021-01002021AD-MC-0042021-0100
Scope and Contents
Time-offset interaction applications (TOIA) allow simulating conversations with people who have previously recorded relevant video utterances, which are played in response to their interacting user. TOIAs have great potential for pre-serving cross-generational and cross-cultural histories, online teaching, simulated interviews, etc. Current TOIAs exist in niche contexts involving high production costs. Democratizing TOIA presents different challenges when creating appropriate pre-recordings, designing different user stories, and creating simple online interfaces for experimentation. We open-source TOIA 2.0, a user-centered time-offset interaction application, and make it available for everyone who wants to interact with people's pre-recordings or create their pre-recordings.
Author provided keywords: Transformer based language generation, time-offset interaction, avatar creationKrulec, Tina. Predicting Narrative Coherence2021-01092021AD-MC-0042021-0109
Scope and Contents
Stories people tell about themselves and how they recall their experiences reveal a lot about who they are and their mental well-being. Psychologists have identified this and created the Narrative Coherence Coding Scheme (NaCCS); a set of guidelines for annotating the "coherence" of a narrative in terms of its theme, chronology and context. Upon annotating narratives in accordance with the NaCCS, psychologists have found a significant correlation between the coherence score of a narrative and independently collected mental health markers of the narrator [7]. Currently, all annotation for coherence is done manually; a time consuming task which drains vital resources that could have otherwise been spent elsewhere. Our Capstone project aims to make use of natural language processing (NLP) and machine learning (ML) techniques to directly predict a narrative's coherence score. We explore a number of different techniques for this task, ranging from traditional machine learning models such as Support Vector Machines (SVM) to pre-trained language models such as BERT (Bidirectional Encoder Representations from Transformers).
Author provided keywords: NLP, Machine Learning, Narrative text analysis, Narrative Coherence Coding SchemeKupoluyi, Jesutofunmi. Muzeel: A Dynamic Event-Driven Analyzer for JavaScript Dead Code Elimination in Mobile Web2021-00982021AD-MC-0042021-0098
Scope and Contents
Today's mobile web pages are becoming computationally intensive due to their focus on appearance, interactivity, and data collection in order to enhance the user experience and increase the user retention and engagement. To support the plethora of functionalities, web developers rely heavily on JavaScript, specifically large general-purpose third-party libraries. Although this tends to accelerate the development cycle, it increases the overall page complexity by bringing additional functions that might not be utilized by the page but are unnecessarily processed by the browser. In this paper, we propose Muzeel; a solution for eliminating JavaScript functions that are not used in a given web page–this is commonly referred to as dead code. Despite the fact that dead code is never executed, it impacts the overall performance of the web page since it is downloaded and processed by the browser. Muzeel extracts all of the page event listeners (upon page load), emulates user interactions using a bot that triggers each of these events, and then generates a comprehensive function call graph in order to eliminate the dead code of functions that are not called by any of these events.
Author provided keywords: web simplification, superfluous javascript, javascript optimizationLim, Chaerin. Breast Cancer Screening via Microbiome Classification2021-00902021AD-MC-0042021-0090
Scope and Contents
Recent findings have proven that the abundances of specific microbiota found in the human tissue can be associated with the growth of cancer. In line with this discovery, this project explored breast cancer prediction by classifying microbiomes of the breast and of the gut. We found that feature dimensionality reduction methods, especially Hierarchical Feature Engineering, allowed for better and consistent performance across the four selected machine learning algorithms—Random Forest, Logistic Regression, Naive Bayes, and Decision Tree. Random Forest performed best in all our datasets when used with a feature set with HFE applied. From our extracted feature sets, certain OTUs matched the microbiomes found to be more abundant in breast cancer cases, supporting some of the findings in previous breast cancer metagenomics research. We found that g_Bacteroides had higher abundances in the gut microbiota of breast cancer samples than in controls. This result overlapped with the finding of Byrd et al., suggesting that the bacteria may be an informative biomarker in screening breast cancer. This research assessed the potential of microbiomes in breast cancer prediction, to produce a practical, cheap, and non- invasive screening tool that can ultimately be used for efficient cancer diagnosis.
Author provided keywords: breast cancer, machine learning, feature selection, microbiome classificationLiu, Xixuan. Public Cooperation in a Human-Bot Society2021-01112021AD-MC-0042021-0111
Scope and Contents
This study employs the Iterated Public Goods Game (IPGG) in which the best strategies for maximum individual gain and maximum group gain are contradictory. Literature has shown that people would contribute more when there is pun- ishment on free-riders. There is also research [20] showing that when both punishment and reward options are available, reward leads to increased contribution, whereas punishment has no effect on contribution. This study introduces a human- bot element to the IPGG and examines how people behave in group cooperation with the presence of punishment and/or reward when playing with human peers v.s. when playing with AI/bots. This study would also expand our understand- ing on human-bot interaction in group settings as current studies have focused on two player scenarios in dilemmas exclusively.
Author provided keywords: Public Goods Game, human-computer interaction, punish- ment, AI, cooperationMajgaonkar, Oorja. Assessing training data quantity for optimum performance of LiDAR object classification models2021-01052021AD-MC-0042021-0105
Scope and Contents
Classifying objects within aerial light detection and ranging (LiDAR) is an essential but time-consuming task to which machine learning is being increasingly applied, especially neural networks specifically for 3D data. However, there has not been an examination into the quantity of data required to train a reliable, high performing model. It is found that the underlying assumptions about training data for such networks remain largely uncovered and unaddressed. Generating training data from LiDAR point clouds necessitates significant manual labour, so there is an incentive in establishing the minimal model requires to achieve acceptable performance levels. This project assessed the impact of quantity of training data on classification accuracy of PointNet, a deep learning framework tailored for 3D point clouds. A PointNet implementation was trained on subsets of a large data set called ModelNet that spanned from 40 to 2000 objects which included 40 different types of objects. Accuracy improved logarithmically, with convergence typically beginning at approximately 600,000 training points. This work provides a framemark for subsequent development by establishing a learning curve for 3D-focused classification models and suggests how much data should be manually labelled and used for training when the model is used on new data.
Author provided keywords: aerial LiDAR, object classification, learning curve, point cloud, trainingMakuba, Patrick Inshuti. Iruka: Accelerated Mobile Pages Through Classifying and Blocking Non-critical JavaScript2021-01062021AD-MC-0042021-0106
Scope and Contents
The average page size has been increased from 1720 Kilo- bytes In 2016 to 3077 Kilobytes in 2021, where Javascript is increasingly contributing to the total page size (from 24% in 2016 to 27% in 2021). In comparison to equivalent-sized web resources, JavaScript is more expensive to process due to the requirement of parsing, interpretation and execution. This cost significantly contributes to the increasing complexity of modern mobile pages, which becomes a critical performance bottleneck for low-end smartphone devices and ultimately leads to lesser user engagement. Hence, in this paper I propose a tool which uses a machine learning algorithm to classify JavaScripts into different categories from which are used as a basis point to block non-critical Javascript, with the aim of reducing the amount of JavaScripts in a fully loaded web-page. The tool is a form of browser plugin that is privacy-preserving, since it offers an independent client-end solution that does not require any external interaction with any third-party service. The proposed plugin is empowered by a neural network model which detects categories of JavaScript elements used in web pages with an accuracy of 89.33%.
Author provided keywords: Machine Learning, Neural Network, Document Object Model, Page Load TimeMatera, Sebastiano Pio. TREEsearch: The Utilization of Decision Trees in Order to Decrease the Amount of Global Research Debt2021-01082021AD-MC-0042021-0108
Scope and Contents
Researchers of today's world are cursed with a vast amount of complex and valuable scholarly data. They are faced with long lists of search results, with articles ranging in the thousands, making filtering through and summarizing such volume an extreme burden. How to utilize the vast quantity data becomes a critical problem to be tackled. With the rapid growth of the digital publishing and harvesting, how to visually, how to utilize the vast quantity data becomes a critical problem to be tackled. We propose an NLP driven decisiontree based Visualization tool where someone can search for an area of study/discipline, and our application displays a map/geography of all the relevant scientific literature in that research field. Such a visualization tool has the power to lay out and present the state of the world's scientific knowledge, as well as having many other applications in the research world.
Author provided keywords: Decision Trees Research Debt Machine LearningOcran, Estelle. Learning Entity Embeddings from Wikipedia and Wikidata for Entity or Article Prediction2021-00942021AD-MC-0042021-0094
Scope and Contents
In this era of big data, there has been a proliferation of knowledge graphs (KG) and knowledge bases (KB) such as Wikidata and Wikipedia. The existence of such knowledge graphs and bases means there is a lot of data to our disposal to be used for several purposes. However, without proper embeddings of the entities in these knowledge graphs and bases, it is difficult to take full advantage of the rich and vast amount of data available to us. Learning useful representations or embeddings from such graph entities is useful for a variety of machine learning applications, including but not limited to, natural language processing, entity prediction and relation prediction. Besides reducing the engineering effort, these representations can lead to greater predictive power. Although there have been recent works in embeddings of knowledge graphs and bases there haven't been any yet that take advantage of the cross-lingual nature of Wikipedia and Wikidata. To this effect, our Capstone project focuses on learning embeddings of entities and articles Wikipedia across multiple languages. These embeddings will then be used to create a tool for article or entity prediction across multiple languages.
Author provided keywords: Wikidata, Wikipedia, articles, hyperlink, knowledge, base, graph, entity prediction, embeddingsPlachouras, Christos. Audio-Based Hierarchical Structure Analysis for Evaluating Music Similarity2021-01132021AD-MC-0042021-0113
Scope and Contents
Structure is an important compositional element in music. Analyzing the structure of musical pieces is a common practice among musicians and musicologists, but even among them here isn't always agreement on the exact segmentation and granularity of it. It is, therefore, challenging to automatize the task of constructing a representation of structure from the audio of a piece and to measure the structural similarity between pieces while accounting for repetition patterns at different levels of granularity. This problem exists at the core of the more general question of how to define the similarity between musical pieces. In this work, I propose methods for measuring the structural similarity between musical pieces by decomposing them hierarchically and comparing their structure at different levels of granularity. The proposed decomposition relies on encoding global and local repetition patterns within a piece and constructing low-rank approximations of them using techniques from spectral graph theory. The behavior of different decomposition configurations and structural similarity metrics is investigated under several audio perturbations and for the task of cover song identification. Subsequently, methods are suggested for using this structure representation to define more meaningful music similarity metrics.
Author provided keywords: music similarity, audio segmentation, music information retrieval, digital signal processingSuri, Navya. Revisiting the Uncanny Valley using Generative Adversarial Networks2021-01042021AD-MC-0042021-0104
Scope and Contents
The "uncanny valley" is a phenomenon first described by Masahiro Mori as the observation that when non-human beings appear more human-like, they become more appealing to humans, but only up-to a certain point. After that point, the affinity felt towards such beings steadily decreases into a trough, and gradually rises again. This paper describes an exploratory attempt to re-create the uncanny valley starting with an uncanny image. We will propose a novel solution using a generative adversarial network (namely, StyleGAN) to transform images that lie at the bottom of the valley to appear more human and further enhance those images using the same deep learning model to make them perfectly human.
Author provided keywords: uncanny valley, GAN, styleGAN, robotics, deep learning, generative adversarial networksTomevska, Iva. Towards Machine Learning Defensive Mechanisms in LTE and 5G Security2021-00962021AD-MC-0042021-0096
Scope and Contents
Research in the field of LTE network security has exposed a variety of inadequate security measures in the Radio Resource Control and Non-Access Stratum protocols. Through the 5G standard, the 3GPP alliance attempted to create new defense mechanisms that can detect abuse of these protocols. However, we argue that not all messages exchanged within these two protocols are efficiently protected by these novel countermeasures. We highlight cases where protocol messages could be attacked indirectly, despite being encrypted and integrity-protected. These attacks results in unexpected network disruptions affecting the security of the system and privacy of the users. Thus, adding an extra layer of prevention and detection in this security network can make the network more resilient to attacks. We introduce a Machine Learning model that can detect active cellular attacks based on the disruption of the network. By using tractable data points from benign and attacked traffic, the model will learn the inconsistencies of an attacked network, ultimately detecting the attack. We investigate 8 attack scenarios proven possible by past research reports, which are analyzed in order to derive the appropriate training features and traceable parameters that can be used as input to the ML technique.
Author provided keywords: Security, LTE, 5G, Machine Learning, Network SecurityWarmuz, Krzysztof. In Search for Optimized Collective Variables for Molecular Dynamics Simulations2021-01162021AD-MC-0042021-0116
Scope and Contents
This report summarizes the progress and achievements of the capstone project in analyzing and improving the effective ness of artificial intelligence algorithm applied for dynamic Collective Variable (CV) sampling in Molecular Dynamics (MD). The computational chemistry is being strongly limited by the time scale factor of the MD simulations due multitude of their degrees of freedom. Currently applied way of improving the efficiency is by introducing a set of CVs, from which the most significant ones can be indicated as the reaction coordinates, greatly reducing the complexity of the simulations. Since the knowledge of CVs a priori is a daunting task, most of the contemporary approaches remain subjected to the trial-and-error methods. In this project several alternatives were analyzed, heavily embracing ma chine learning and automatizing the process of CV sampling as the simulation is running, that is 'on the fly'. The significance of CVs in characterizing the conformational transitions and enhancing the conformational sampling of biomolecules was thoroughly investigated and used to develop a state-of art linear regression algorithm based on the cross-entropy minimization.
Author provided keywords: Molecular Dynamics, Collective Variables, Enhanced Sampling, Machine Learning, Cross EntropyZameek, Abdullah Ruzni. Revisiting the Uncanny Valley using Generative Adversarial Networks2021-00842021AD-MC-0042021-0084

Abstract: Neural networks with unknown interactions among individual neurons are common in research on biology and neuroscience. The dynamics of the population often depends on the presence or absence of individual interactions, the strength of neuron couplings and the effective excitatory or inhibitory relationship between each pair of interacting neurons. However, it is difficult to detect all of these directly in experimental settings. We present a method for reconstructing the interaction topology from spike trains data. The reconstruction method based on the leaky integrate-and-fire model is reviewed and discussed. Simulations show that the general reconstruction method achieves a high accuracy. Algebraization of Probability and Boole's Work.2016-003680862016We consider recent development of the foundation of probability theory, namely, "algebraization" of finite probabilities. This method allows one to check consistency of any set of assumptions concerning finite probabilities and, in theory, solve any problem involving finitely many events. It consists of algebraic procedures, some parallel to the method of Cartesian coordinates in elementary geometry, and is based on transforming given problem into a set of algebraic equations or relations. We then consider mathematician George Boole's little understood work on probability and verify that its aim was indeed algebraization of finite probabilities. Boole had clearly understood the possibility of realizing his aim and had identified appropriate methods in terms of normal disjunctive form and algebraic relations. However, he had been unable to carry out algebraization due to inappropriate selection of events, which forced him to add improper conditions. In this study, we limit ourselves to the case of finitely many events to avoid the complications of countable additivity, which would not add much novelty and simply make the exposition more cumbersome. Moreover, we note that Boole had considered only the linear case in his work.AD-MC-0042016-0036

We then consider mathematician George Boole's little understood work on probability and verify that its aim was indeed algebraization of finite probabilities. However, he had been unable to carry out algebraization due to inappropriate selection of events, which forced him to add improper conditions. Spectral Clustering2017-00342017In recent years, spectral clustering has become one of the most popular modern clustering algorithms. On the maximal numerical range of some matrices2018-00822018AD-MC-0042018-0082
Scope and Contents
The maximal numerical range of a matrix A is the (regular) numerical range W(B) of its compression B onto the eigenspace L of A*A corresponding to its maximal eigenvalue. So, the maximal numerical range of a matrix is always a subset of the numerical range of that matrix. We establish conditions under which the maximal numerical range has a non-empty intersection with the boundary of the numerical range, in particular when they coincide. We also describe the maximal numerical range explicitly for matrices unitarily similar to direct sums of 2-by-2 blocks, and provide some insight into the behavior of the maximal numerical range when L has codimension one.Stoica, Andrei. This project extends a computational method to determine the structure of proteins using small-angle X-ray scattering data and applies it to determining the structure of nucleic acids in explicit solvent. Equations for the coupling of experimental SAXS data to classical molecular dynamics simulations were parameterized and extended, and another theoretical framework was assessed for comparison purposes, the maximum entropy principle. To further analyze the quality of the SAXS-guided molecular dynamics simulations, specialized software was used to calculate SAXS parameters from the newly determined nucleic acid structures.Yahia, Suraiya. Statistical mechanics is a discipline at the intersection of physics and mathematics: its purpose is to establish models, notably based on probability theory, that describe the average behavior of thermodynamic systems. This paper focuses on lattice models, placing a particular emphasis on the Ising Model and the Discrete Gaussian Free Field (DGFF). Exploiting certain formal similarities between these two models, we extrapolate the random current representation, a geometric representation of the ferromagnetic Ising Model, to the DGFF in an effort to provide a different perspective on the latter model, one that can potentially be useful to compute quantities of interest. Note that a random current representation similar to that for the Ising model and that developed in our paper was derived for a Markov Field by Camia and Lis (2016).Badowska, Aleksandra. This project studies the Black-Scholes model which is a Partial Derivative Equation that determine the variations of option price over time. The model was developed using Ito calculus through stochastic process. The equation is named after Myron Scholes, and Fischer Black who published their seminar paper together with Robert Merton on option pricing in 1973, hence the name Black-Scholes model. Though Robert Merton's name is not included in the equation but he has equally contributed to the model. The project focuses on derivation of the model through Ito Calculus, the history of the model, it's application in finance, and how the pricing model is largely used by option traders who buy options that are priced under the formula calculated value and sell options priced higher than the Black-Scholes calculated value.Shang, Jin. The method of selective cutting is currently perceived as a less harmful option for obtaining wood resources from tropical forests than clear cutting despite the lack of scientific research on the long-term effects of selective cutting. This project aims to address this gap in scientific knowledge and provide insight about the ability of a forest to recover after a selective cut by modeling the dynamical system of the coexistence between trees and vines subject to disturbances. We suggest that depending on the shape of the basin boundary, a selective cut can shift the system from the healthy to the unhealthy basin of attraction. This would mean that with time, the forest does not recover to its initial healthy state but falls into a long-lasting degraded state implying that selective cutting can have a long-term negative impact on the forest ecosystem.Zhu, Lin. Clustering and Spatial Markovianity in Finance Based Models2020-00692020AD-MC-0042020-0069
Scope and Contents
We discuss the type of dependency in different finance models for herd- ing behavior in financial markets, with a greater focus on Cont Bouchaud Model. We observe that while Cont Bouchaud Model ensures cluster formation as in real markets, it faces a lack of spatial Markovianity in the agents' behaviour. On the other hand, models based on ferromagnetic models (Ising and Potts) do not have real cluster formation but they exhibit social imitation only. However, clustering and spatial Markovianity, both are highly desired properties of a model depicting real life market scenarios. We verify that if clustering is done by the less intuitive Random Cluster Model, an intermediate model can be formed that incorporates real cluster formation as well as social imitation.

This is the final report of the capstone research project on Random Fractal Percolation on 2D Honeycomb Lattice, with professor Federico Camia. The paper consists of three sections. In the first section, we introduce some basic concepts involved in this research and briefly explain the construction and properties of Mandelbrot's fractal percolation model, from which our research object is derived. Then we present the construction of a random fractal percolation model on the 2D honeycomb lattice. In the last part, the paper discusses some interesting findings about this model and some possible directions for future study.
