Scope and Contents
The financial markets have gone through an enormous development over the past 50 years. One of the rising challenges in finance is that the complexity of financial instruments and markets has led financial engineers to seek and employ increasingly sophisticated mathematical tools to address financial issues, such as the pricing of financial derivatives. The Black-Scholes option pricing model has become the firm basis for financial mathematics which finds adequate solutions to the pricing of a world-wide rapidly increasing number of derivatives. Many option pricing models have been developed since Black and Scholes pub- lished their work in 1973. In this paper, we study the original Black-Scholes option pricing model for European call options in terms of its derivation and applicability. By constructing a riskless portfolio taking positions in bonds (cash), option, and the under- lying stock, we derive the Black-Scholes partial differential equations without and with dividends for European calls. With a series of changes of variables, we transform the Black-Scholes equation to the heat equation and obtain a closed-form solution to the original equation, known as the Black-Scholes formula. The applicability is evaluated through a comparison of the Black-Scholes model and the real market data.
Author contributed keywords: Black-Scholes Option Pricing ModelMartinez, Kenya. Ellipticity of the Numerical Range2020-00752020AD-MC-0042020-0075
Scope and Contents
Let $A$ be an $n \times n$ matrix. The numerical range of $A$ can be defined as $W(A)=\{x^*Ax : x \in \mathbb{C}^n, x^*x=1\}$. The shape of the numerical range can be determined through the associated ternary polynomial $F(t, x, y) = \det(tI_n + x(A + A^*)/2 + y(A - A*)/2i))$. In this research, a series of necessary and sufficient conditions will be given to determine when a tridiagonal matrix where $a_{ij}=a_{ji}^{-1}$ for |i-j|=1 and zero otherwise will have an elliptical numerical range. Moreover, this project provides a condition on the entries of matrices H and Z so that they can be factored into matrices C and D where $H = C^*C + DD^*$ and $Z =DC$.
Author contributed to keywords: Numerical Range, Elliptical, Tridiagonal Matrices, Spectral FactorizationQuartz, Juju. On the Maximal Numerical Mass and the Center of Mass2020-00872020AD-MC-0042020-0087
Scope and Contents
The maximal numerical range of a matrix and the Aluthge transform of a matrix are topics previously worked on by David Rose and Ali Hamed, professor Spitkovsky's former students. In this paper, the limit of the maximal numerical range under the Aluthge transform for 2 × 2 matrices and matrices with a distinct largest eigenvalue by magnitude is established and the limit for 3×3 matrices is conjectured. Some results for the unitary reducibility of the Aluthge transform and the geometric shape of the numerical range under an iteration of the Aluthge transform are also obtained. The center of mass of a matrix is introduced and renamed as the Stampfli point. The Stampfli point is described completely for 2 × 2 matrices and results regarding the inclusion of Stampfli Point in the numerical range and the convex hull of spectrum are obtained. Finally, a condition for the Stampfli being equal to zero for a triple eigenvalue matrix in terms of the off-diagonal entries are established.
Author contributed keywords: Center of Mass, Numerical Range, Linear Algebra, Operator TheoryLona, Alonso Perez. Chern-Simons Theory2021-01182021AD-MC-0042021-0118
Scope and Contents
This Capstone project studies the Chern-Simons Theory from perspectives arising from Geometry and Topology, Physics, and categorical (axiomatic) Topological Quantum Field Theory (TQFT). The Chern-Simons form was studied, and relevant combinatorial formulas were derived. Computations of the Chern-Simons invariant of the Thurston geometries were performed, leading to results on the conformal embedding of these in Euclidean space. Then, the Physical Chern-Simons theory was studied from the traditional QFT picture, and in specific its geometric, and path integral quantizations. It was subsequently studied from the point of view of Category Theory via axiomatic TQFT and its generalization, extended TQFT. This led to an extensive exploration on the relevant categorical objects and results, especially those concerning monoidal categories in a broad sense. The argument for the partial extension of Chern-Simons as an extended TQFT was studied closely, specifically in relation to geometric quantization, and the Reshetikhin-Turaev TQFT's.
Author provided keywords: Chern-Simons; characteristic classes; extended TQFT.Raees, Faiq. Stability of Self-similar Solutions of Inviscid Burgers Equation2021-01172021AD-MC-0042021-0117
Scope and Contents
This paper is based on the stability of self similar solutions, that describe the formation of shocks for Burgers equation, using energy methods in Eulerian coordinates. The Burger's equation is a classical example of a nonlinear hy- perbolic equation for which smooth solutions can become singular in finite time. My capstone then is based upon the analysis of these smooth solutions and their behaviour near the shock formation time. We establish some results regarding the analytic profiles of the self-similar solutions particularly that they are a diffeomorphism onto their image and they are of order similar to their implicit equation near origin. We also study the spectrum of the linearised operator that is suitable to the self-similar variables and then use these results to estab- lish that a perturbed self similar solution will converge to the self similar profile provided that the perturbation is small enough initially. The result is shown using a method of characteristics and bootstrapping argument and thereby the stability of the solution is proved.

Scope and Contents
Major: Physics. Abstract: HD189733b is one of the most extensively studied exoplanets to date. The Jupiter sized gas giant orbits close to its host star with a two day period, and due to tidal locking, one side is constantly and heavily irradiated. Transmission spectra and secondary eclipse observations of HD189733b suggest that mineral dust clouds are prominent in the upper atmosphere. Cloud formation and dust opacities, however, are generally omitted from global circulation models. We present radial dust opacity profiles of HD189733b based on a 3D radiative-hydrodynamical simulation and a kinetic cloud formation model specifically tuned for the planet. We find that (1) optical properties of clouds are dominated by iron condensates on the dayside and by silicates on the nightside; (2) cloud formation is restricted to low pressures in the atmosphere; and (3) cloud structure varies significantly with longitude and wavelength. The observed trends might be valid for other hot Jupiters as well, and, if incorporated into general circulation models, could lead to improved understanding of the atmospheric circulation of extrasolar planets.Opacity (Optics)HD189733bHot JupitersJupiter (Planet)Dahal, Sumit. Scope and Contents
Major: Physics, Mathematics
Abstract: The XENON100 dark matter experiment is designed to detect xenon nuclear recoils resulting from the scattering of dark matter Weakly Interacting Massive Particles (WIMPs). The muon flux is suppressed to 1.04 ± 0.02 m−2 hr−1 by an average 3100 meters water equivalent (m.w.e.) of rock overburden at the underground installation of the detector. An efficient WIMP search in ultra-low radiation background would benefit from proper characterization of such muon events and understanding of the aftermath of its ionization track. I present few candidate signals for the passage of muons through the detector. The direct scintillation signal (S1) and the amplified charge signal (S2) detected by the photomultiplier tubes (PMTs) for these events satisfy all the expected characteristics of large energy deposition by muons.XENON100Dark matter (Astronomy)MuonsMei, Jeffrey. A Novel Two-Station Seismic Method to Locate Glacier Calving2015-003534182015AD-MC-0042015-0035
Scope and Contents
Major: Physics, Mathematics
Abstract: A novel method of determining glacier calving location using hyperbolas from two local seismic stations is presented. The wave arrival time difference is used to define a locus of possible origins, which intersects uniquely with the calving front. This method is motivated by difficulties with traditional seismic location methods that fail due to the emergent nature of calving, which obscures the P and S-wave onsets, and the proximity of the seismometers, which combines body and surface waves into one arrival. A mix of tidal and seismic data and satellite imagery are used to confirm a list of calving events at Helheim Glacier from August 2013 to August 2014. In particular, two events in the week beginning August 11 2014 that were seen in person are used to calibrate the method, which is then applied to other calving events. An extension of this method with one more station would allow for triangulation location that would not depend on satellite or camera imagery.Back azimuth methodAzimuthal projection (Cartography)GlaciersTriangulationSeismic event locationSeismological stationsGlaciers |x CalvingChamba, Roshan Nushkia. A Background Analysis of XENON100 Calibration Data using Compton Scattering.2016-004381132016The aim of the XENON experiment is to directly detect cold, non-baryonic Dark Matter (DM) in the form ofWeakly Interacting Massive Particles (WIMPs) that recoil from Xenon (Xe) nuclei. These weak nuclear recoils could be a_x000B_ected by background events arising from neutrons and electrons that also interact with the Xe nuclei. This capstone work addresses the issue of electronic recoil (ER) leakage into the WIMP search region in XENON100. Caesium-137 (137Cs) and Cobalt-60 (60Co) run 12 calibration data have been used to analyze a hypothetical category of ER or Compton scatter leakage events, reconstruct their kinematics and produce selection criteria to eliminate these events from the DM search region. These results could be used for future analyses in XENON100 or XENON1T, which is scheduled to operate this year.AD-MC-0042016-0043

Detecting Potential Jupiter-Analog Exoplanets In The Archival Kepler Dataset.2016-004681212016While exoplanet research has made rapid progress in recent years, there is a shortage of research in detecting long orbital period exoplanets. Just as our Solar System's evolution was affected by the presence of a large long orbital period planet, Jupiter, these exoplanets may therefore serve as an indicator of a complex planetary system like our own. Using the archival Kepler data, a publically available dataset generated by the NASA Kepler space observatory, we conduct a search for potential novel Jupiter-Analog exoplanets. A modified and simplified box model, a line segment model, was used to search through the entire 1TB dataset in 4 days. The algorithm returned 672 stars out of 206,111 stars in the entire dataset. While there were more than 600 false positives, 18 stars have potentially new transit events. We propose that follow-up observations are made on these 18 stars to confirm or deny potential exoplanets.AD-MC-0042016-0046

Amelioration of an X-ray Fluorescence Scanning Spectrometer for Applications to Cultural Heritage Studies.2016-002781332016X-Ray Fluorescence is a powerful nuclear technique for analyzing elemental composition and is well suited for non-destructive, in situ investigations of art and artifacts. The technique offers interdisciplinary applications and can be used alone or as complementary to other techniques such as Raman spectroscopy. In collaboration with the LABEC laboratory in Florence, Italy, we have modified an existing XRF scanning spectrometer by integrating a laser telemetry sensor into the system hardware and software. Positional feedback from the sensor was used to automatically regulate scanner-to-specimen distance during an areal scan. With this regulation in place, X-ray elemental distribution scans were able to be performed for a widened range of non-planar sample geometries without sacrificing data quality or posing risks to analyzed specimens. Dedicated tests at LABEC, the Opificio Delle Pietre Dure, and in Abu Dhabi have confirmed the upgraded versatility of the XRF system in analyzing a range of Cultural Heritage specimens.AD-MC-0042016-0027

Charecterization of Multi Pixel Photon Counters for particle detection purposes.2016-004081282016A comprehensive characterization of novel Multi Pixel Photon Counters (MPPCs) was performed to assess their potential as a substitute for the type of light detectors, photomultiplier tubes (PMTs), currently used for applications such as liquid noble gas particle detectors and gamma ray spectroscopy. The study was focused on their response to light with wavelengths in the vacuum ultraviolet range like that obtained from the liquid xenon and argon scintillation utilized in particle detectors. In order to recreate the conditions of said detectors part of the study was realized under cryogenic conditions. The wide yet precise range of wavelengths used was obtained by using a state-of-the-art monochromator. To further evaluate the performance of the MPPCs they were used in the analysis of scintillation light emitted by LYSO crystals and its response to temperature changes.AD-MC-0042016-0040

Cubesat Raad for the Study of Terrestrial Gamma-Ray Flashes2017-00232017Terrestrial Gamma-Ray Flashes (TGFs) are sudden bursts of gamma ray radiation triggered by lightning or thunderstorms and are channeled above the Earth's atmosphere and into outer space, and thus cannot be detected from Earth. The current leading model that is used to explain the mechanism behind TGF production is Relativistic Runaway Electron Avalanche (RREA) phenomenon, but this model is being challenged by some of the most recent key TGF observations, including AGILE and FERMI observations, which suggests that this may not be the best model to explain TGF emission. CubeSat Raad is a proposal for a study to identify a useful experiment for TGF Science, which can be miniaturized and eventually integrated on a cubesat. The instrumentation proposed for the purpose of the experiment is a 3U cubesat and a gamma-ray detector in the $\mathrm{10 keV - 1000 keV}$ range. The goal is to explicitly target events connected to low energy gamma rays emitted from the earth's atmosphere and in turn collect and analyze data focused and specific on this phenomenon to improve correlation studies with lightning and other atmospheric parameters.AD-MC-0042017-0023

Electromagnetic fields around neurons interact with T-cells in the CNS and initiate autoimmune response: a parallel between multiple sclerosis and ischemic stroke.2017-00292017Multiple sclerosis (MS) is an autoimmune disease where a mutation in the gene encoding for a protein belonging to the NLR Family Pyrin Domain Containing 12 (NLRP12) enables the T-cells to penetrate the blood-brain barrier and damage the myelin sheath. Expanding upon Dr. Bjorn Nordenstrom's "Biologically Closed Electrical Circuits", this paper utilizes computational electrodynamics in Matlab and an in vivo MRI cell tracking study to hypothesize that negative charge on the surface of the T-cell gets attracted to the electromagnetic fields generated around the nodes of Ranvier and initiates the autoimmune response. By manipulating the electromagnetic forces of attraction between the cells, the MRI study showed that T-cell's mobility was impaired post-glucocorticoid receptor antagonization. The electrodynamic modeling determined the spatial and temporal progression of the electromagnetic field to quantify the nature of its interaction with the T-cell's surface charge and its role within the context of MS etiology. The potential implications of this research could lead to better understanding of the disease's symptoms and provide a framework to explain its uncertain times of onset.AD-MC-0042017-0029

Multiple sclerosis (MS) is an autoimmune disease where a mutation in the gene encoding for a protein belonging to the NLR Family Pyrin Domain Containing 12 (NLRP12) enables the T-cells to penetrate the blood-brain barrier and damage the myelin sheath. Expanding upon Dr. Bjorn Nordenstrom's "Biologically Closed Electrical Circuits", this paper utilizes computational electrodynamics in Matlab and an in vivo MRI cell tracking study to hypothesize that negative charge on the surface of the T-cell gets attracted to the electromagnetic fields generated around the nodes of Ranvier and initiates the autoimmune response. By manipulating the electromagnetic forces of attraction between the cells, the MRI study showed that T-cell's mobility was impaired post-glucocorticoid receptor antagonization. The electrodynamic modeling determined the spatial and temporal progression of the electromagnetic field to quantify the nature of its interaction with the T-cell's surface charge and its role within the context of MS etiology. The potential implications of this research could lead to better understanding of the disease's symptoms and provide a framework to explain its uncertain times of onset.Zheng, Tiantian. Monte Carlo simulations of intracellular transport by teams of kinesin-1 molecular motors2017-00382017We develop a new computational model of cargo transport by multiple kinesin-1 motors which incorporates recent findings involving the asymmetric force-run length relations of single kinesin. By analyzing trajectories simulated with an assisting force applied to the cargo, we find that the velocity of the cargo is solely determined by the dynamics of the leading and lagging motors of the team hauling the cargo. This ``two-motor model" reduces to a one-motor model under high assisting forces, allowing the development of an analytical expression that captures cargo dynamics under these conditions. This expression incorporates the single motor properties and therefore allows us to extract these properties by fitting the cargo velocity response to force. This provides a powerful framework for measuring individual motor properties in vivo where cargo are typically hauled by teams of motors.AD-MC-0042017-0038

In this paper, a description of Terrestrial Gamma-Ray Flash (TGF) simulation method will be provided as well its usage for determining mission parameters and trigger criteria. A database of 1000 TGFs at different radial distances (up to 1k km) was created for 4 different configurations of CeBr3-crystal, γ-ray detectors. The expected TGF count rate within 1000 km was determined to be roughly 1.64 per day, with mostly very few to no counts observed. The expected background was also simulated; the external background was derived from the background accumulations of the Fermi satellite, and the intrinsic background determined in the laboratory. The total background count rates were as follows: 9.600, 38.399, 86.399, and 172.797 counts/second for the 1, 4, 9, and 18 crystal arrays respectively. The simulations were tested for optimum trigger criteria- such as energy thresholds, trigger window sizes, and count rates per trigger window. AlMannaei, Aisha. Scope and Contents
Terrestrial Gamma-Ray Flashes (TGFs) are sudden bursts of gamma rays that occur in the Earth's atmosphere and escape into outer space which are triggered by lightning or thunderstorm activity. Previous detectors used to study TGFs were limited by their slow response times and therefore more observations are needed to construct a model to describe this phenomena. The proposed detector is based on Cerium(III) Bromide crystals coupled to a compact (Hamamatsu R11265U-100) photomultiplier tube. This instrument will have a faster time response, high resolution (3.5% at 661 keV) and a high density. Given the limited power consumption on a Cubesat (2-6W), the aim is to develop a low cost detector with extremely low power requirements and a response time of less than 100 ns that can be standardized to fit within 1U of a CubeSat. This describes the characteristics of the prototype unit detector such as linearity, voltage gain, and the gain as a function of temperature for the crystal and PMT.D'Alterio, Kristopher. Scope and Contents
In this paper we describe a method to improve the follow up process for near earth objects (NEOs), especially for faint and fast moving NEOs. Current follow up procedures typically use imaging with telescope in sidereal rotation and as a consequence the image of the moving NEO is a linear track instead of a point source. This makes it difficult to recover faint or fast moving sources. We propose a new follow up method where the telescope tracks the NEO rather than tracking with sidereal motion, and therefore focuses the image onto a smaller number of pixels. In order to explore the effectiveness of such a method, we have created simulated images which accurately depict the images that would be found if this method were applied, and determined the recovery rate of NEOs for such simulated images under varying conditions. We have also identified future work that should be done in order to improve these recovery rates, and laid out a framework for making a complete statistical evaluation of the method, which would give a description of the recovery rate of the method as a function of the magnitude and velocity of an NEO.Stoychev, Boyan. Warm Dark Matter (WDM) models provide a promising alternative cosmological scenario to the standard Λ Cold Dark Matter (CDM) model. Numerous studies have employed cosmological numerical simulations to constrain the allowed mass of WDM particles based on low-redshift observational data. When restricted to this range, viable WDM models produce indistinguishable predictions at low redshift that are in agreement with CDM. In this work, galaxy formation at z = 6-10 was studied in the framework of the NIHAO project, comparing 3keV WDM to CDM. Halo mass functions were calculated from dark-matter-only simulations of the CDM and WDM scenarios, and fitted using Markov Chain Monte Carlo. Simulations of galaxy formation using hydrodynamics were used to construct stellar mass - halo mass relations, which were then fitted with power laws. Those simulations were also used to calculate the fraction of galaxies that do not form stars as a function of halo mass. Finally, the above calculations were used to construct stellar mass functions for the two models at redshift 6-10, with the hope that the James Webb Space Telescope may be able to discriminate between the two models after its launch in 2020.Torres, Rodrigo. We present a multidetector X-ray fluorescence spectrometer, developed in collaboration with the Laboratory for Cultural Heritage (LABEC) in Florence. Principally, the mechanics and the software of the instrument were modified so as to allow the incorporation of an additional detec- tor. Additionally, through the optimization of the digital pulse processor acquisition and shaping parameters, an improvement to the energy resolution of a factor of two was attained. Further debugging, customization, and optimization allowed for the improvement on the acquisition times by a factor of ∼100, and the instrument's portability. Simulations of galaxy formations rely on different feedback mechanisms in order to reproduce the observed galaxy baryonic scaling relations and morphology. Although the explosive feedback can reproduce many of the observed properties of the galaxies, such as the stellar mass-halo mass relationship, it creates disks that are too thick. In this paper we present a study of the effects of the radiative feedback on gas cooling inside the simulations and its effects on the galaxy structure. This includes the ionizing radiation coming from young and old stars. In addition, a new model for the UV background radiation, represented by the radiation coming from other galaxies or active galactic nuclei, has been implemented, which proved to have a lower feedback effect compared to the old NIHAO implementation. The star formation rate is reduced after the introduction of the new local photoionization effect, due to an increase in the cooling time of the gas. However, due to the above-mentioned effect of the new UV background, most of the properties of the newly simulated galaxies have attained values similar to the ones in the old simulations. I study the star formation rates of galaxies throughout their lifetimes using a large sample of hydrodynamical, cosmological simulations. I show that blackhole feedback is successful in quenching star formation in the largest galaxies. I construct a new quantity, Δ log Star Formation Rate, that relates the star formation rate of individual galaxies to galaxies similar to them in age and mass. I find an inverse correlation between halo formation time, measured through galaxy concentration, and Δ log SFR. Galaxies with halos that form earlier tend to underproduce stars throughout their lifetimes, while late bloomers tend to be chronic overproducers of stars. This is evidence that dark matter may play more of a role in driving star formation than previously realized.Rosenthal, Michael. We present the first map of water masers in the active galactic nucleus (AGN) of the dwarf galaxy IC 750. Water masers at 22 GHz can penetrate the obscuring dust around Type 2 AGNs. Very Long Baseline Interferometry (VLBI) images of the central parsec of IC 750 reveal a nearly edge-on, warped disk of diameter ~0.22 pc x D / 13.8 Mpc. The disk lacks emission around the galaxy recession velocity of 701 km/s, so we fit Keplerian rotation curves for a 0.5 x 0.5 mas grid of possible dynamical centers. By accepting only centers for which the masses determined separately from each side of the disk agree within 5%, we determine a best-fit BH mass of 8.0 +0.8 / -0.4 solar masses. Several black hole growth models have been proposed in the literature that present different black hole evolution dependencies. For the purpose of this project, we studied the behavior three accretion models in the NIHAO simulated NIHAO galaxy population. We studied the Bondi-Hoyle accretion model coupled with black hole feedback, the gravitational torque accretion model, and the viscous disk accretion model which both do not require black hole feedback. For each of the models, we probed the interaction between black holes and their host galaxies through in- vestigating black hole-host galaxy scaling relations and examined the observed co- evolution of galaxies and their black holes. This was accomplished through running numerical simulations of galaxy formation, post-processing analysis, and utilizing observational data sets to constraint the model's parameter space. We report that all models match observations down to redshift 1, and note that the viscous disk model shows the strongest co-evolution between the black hole mass and the stellar mass, the gravitational torque model shows co-evolution at high black hole masses, while the Bondi-Hoyle model shows no co-evolution.Chang, Chuan. A Method to Probe the Mechanical Properties of Cells and Nuclei Using Optically Trapped Microstructures2020-00552020AD-MC-0042020-0055
Scope and Contents
The cell and the cell nucleus are highly dynamic systems that can generate and detect forces through the cytoskeleton. By exerting piconewton forces on them and observing their deformations, one can detect changes in their organization and composition. To improve the versatility of optical tweezers often used for mechanical characterization of cells and nuclei, specifically designed and optically trapped handles with designated trapping and sample-attachment sites were fabricated and used as handles to manipulate a sample of cell or nucleus. By sandwiching the sample between two handles, the design of the handles uniquely allows for the exertion of compression, extension, shear, and twist forces while detecting the sample's response. In addition, the design prevents photodamage of the sample and allows for a variable contact area and shape. The handles are 3D-printed through two-photon laser lithography and functionalized with streptavidin to for specific attachment with biotin-functionalized samples. In this report, the method was demonstrated using beads as test samples. Towards applying this method to mechanically characterize nuclei with different lamin mutations, cell nuclei were isolated, functionalized with biotin, and their attachment with streptavidin-functionalized handles demonstrated.

Fluorescence Correlation Spectroscopy (FCS) measurements are invaluable in obtaining the quantitative parameters of molecular processes such as diffusion. Access to these parameters is essential in designing and testing novel drug delivery strategies. Obtaining these parameters deep inside tissue is still an experimental challenge. Despite the many recent advances, the optical-fiber-based FCS method is yet to be extended for deep tissue measurements. To address this issue, we have been developing an Optical Fiber FCS (OFFCS) method that will allow for deep tissue measurements. We have built and demonstrated the OFFCS method, based on a versatile and easily constructed schematic of the setup. We have demonstrated the feasibility of the setup and the performance of FCS measurements by achieving a low background compared to sample measurements. Further development of this method may unlock its use for measurements in biological settings.

Scope and Contents
RNA's capability to fold into specific conformations allows it to fulfill numerous biological functions. Since RNA structure often consists of rigid double-stranded helices connected by flexible single-stranded junctions, the helix-junction-helix (HJH) system serves as a viable model to study RNA dynamics. Available experimental data on this model has shown that metrics such as radius of gyration and helix-to-helix distance do not follow a monotonic trend when ionic concentrations increase. For this reason, all-atom molecular dynamics simulations at various concentrations of KCl were carried out to investigate the conformations of the RNA HJH model. The conformational ensemble of the RNA was explored by molecular dynamics and well-tempered Metadynamics simulations. Results allowed computing the free energy surface and populations of stable states, providing a direct comparison between experiments. Ensemble averages computed from conformational ensembles closely match experimental results, providing a verified source of atomically detailed conformations for the HJH system. Analysis of ion distribution and base stacking was performed to understand their contributions to modulate the conformational states and the non-monotonic changes reported upon changes in ionic strength.

Two large flares of IC 10 X-2 were observed by Zwicky Transient Facility (ZTF) in 2018 that are of a comparable magnitude to a flare observed in October 2013. An analysis of the flare events is presented and constraints on the behavior of the system are proposed through an analysis of the light-curves in both g- and R-band from ZTF, as well as g', r', and i' data from Las Cumbres Observatory (LCO) in 2019. By analyzing the optical and near-infrared light curve alongside a color analysis of IC 10 X-2 we conclude that the system is an HMXB with a relatively long period and little interaction between the massive star and its companion. We also determine the LBV to currently be in outburst.
Author contributed keywords: HMXB, SFXT, flares, transient, opticalMurairi, Edison. The Cosmic Ray Production of Supernova Remnant Kes 172020-01032020AD-MC-0042020-0103
Scope and Contents
While supernova remnants are promising candidates for cosmic ray production, they must produce on average ∼10^{50} ergs of energetic particles to sufficiently account for the cosmic ray protons ≤ 3 PeV population. Moreover, supernova remnants that show direct observational evidence for proton accelerations to high energies are rare, and it is unclear under which circumstances remnants efficiently produce these particles. Kes 17 is a remnant that shows evidence of efficient particle accelerations. In this project, we analyze its γ-ray and X-ray spectra, with the goal of measuring the total energy of its cosmic ray population, spatial variations in the properties of the thermal-ray emitting plasma, and constraining any non-thermal X-ray emission. We found no evidence of non-thermal X-ray emission. The X-ray emitting plasma is out of thermal equilibrium suggesting that the remnant is young. The temperature profile shows that the mixed-morphology of Kes 17 is caused by the thermal conduction scenario. Thermal conduction requires that Kes 17 is 2700 to 5900 years old, consistent with the global X-ray spectrum. The spatial spectral variations suggest that Kes 17 is in a complex environment. In addition, we found recombination continua in the South-East, indicating that the plasma there is overionized.
Author contributed keywords: Cosmic ray, Supernova RemnantPirbhoy, Saarah. Low Mass X-Ray Binary Outbursts2020-00852020AD-MC-0042020-0085
Scope and Contents
A low mass X-ray binary (LMXBs) is made up of a regular star and a neutron star/blackhole. When the accretion disc of the system becomes unstable, an outburst takes place, resulting in the emission of X-rays. For the first part of the project, an alert system- using Python scripts- was created. This system detects the LMXB outbursts in real time. It also sends email alerts whenever there is interesting activity taking place in a LMXB. For the second part, a specific black hole system- SWIFT J1910.2-0546- was studied. This binary system has an unusual extreme flaring which was previously unknown. I wrote Astronomer's Telegrams to notify the community of interesting behavior in order to get multiwavelength data on the objects. Then, X-ray-optical correlations and color magnitude diagrams of SWIFT J1910.2-0546 were plotted to deduce the temperature and behavior of the object. Based on the results, the flickering behavior and temperature changes indicate waves of ionization of hydrogen. This is probably due to the star heating up and dumping more matter onto the disc, increasing the mass accretion rate temporarily.

Searches for pulsars in the error boxes of gamma-ray sources identified by the Fermi Mission have been immensely successful in the past decade. However, 1000s of gamma-ray sources still remain unassociated with any astrophysical object. It is believed that many of these could be millisecond pulsars (MSPs). One reason for their non-detection is that acceleration searches used to account for the orbital motion of the pulsar are only effective when the observation time is less than 1/10th of the orbital period. We have been using the novel jerk search algorithm implemented in the PRESTO software package to re-search Fermi sources that remain unidentified. Jerk search is sensitive to changes in the period of the pulsed signal up to its second derivative caused by the orbital motion, resulting in increased sensitivity to tight binary systems. Searching radio data gathered from the Green Bank Telescope at 820 MHz for unassociated Fermi sources, we have discovered 4 MSPs, one of which has been confirmed to be a tight-binary system belonging to the Black Widow class of pulsars.

Macromolecular crowding is known to have several effects on the bio-molecular properties, and can therefore lead to their cellular function diverging from that in dilute in vitro experiments. In this work, we use a simple system which consists of a crowder and a molecule of interest consisting of single-stranded DNA (ssDNA) to investigate how the size of the molecule changes with crowding. We find that depending on its length, ssDNA can behave in two completely opposite manners: either compressing or expanding under the influence of crowding. The later part of this work outlines an attempt to explain this behavior, considering the impact of the statistical conformation of different ssDNA lengths as the main factor that is responsible for this behaviour.

Scope and Contents
Non-thermal production mechanisms could generate light bosonic dark matter (DM) particles. Such DM candidates, the dark photons (DP), would interact with the standard model (SM) matter via the kinetic mixing parameter. Dielectric haloscopes, which consist of thin dielectric layers with alternating high and low refractive indices, can convert dark photons into SM photons when the DM Compton wavelength matches the periodicity of the target. For this capstone project, we developed an SiO2/Si3N4 dielectric haloscope coupled with a single photon detector for the detection of dark photons. We optimized the dielectric stack so that the DP-SM photon conversion would be maximum at 809 nm and explored different stack configurations to enable conversion over a wider range of masses around 1.5 eV. The optimization was done analytically using the transfer matrix formalism. We also obtained an upper limit at 90% confidence level on the dark photon-SM photon kinetic mixing parameter under different estimates of background rates. In the experimental setup, we use a single-photon avalanche diode as our photosensor and collect counts from the sensor with and without the stack to obtain test statistics for the upper limit.

This interdisciplinary joint project between the departments of Physics and History centres around the development improvement of a scanning macro x-ray fluorescence spectrometer and its application in the study of archaeological and art-historical artifacts. Specifically, two new detectors were implemented so as to drastically increase the quality of the measurements along with a novel heat management system based around a gyroidal 3D printed steel heat sink. Furthermore, helium-injection functionality was designed and implemented to markedlylower the elemental detection threshold of the device. The device was applied (in combination with a host of complementary analytical techniques) in studing metallurgical slag samples from the Central Asian steppe and the nature of the processes which gave rise to them were conclusively determined. Working in collaboration with the Lourve Abu Dhabi, an ancient Egyptian Funerary portrait in their collection was extensively characterised using the instrument as part of the international APPEAR Project.

According to an investigation conducted by the United Nations Scientific Committee on the Effects of Atomic Radiation in 1993, 80% of all radiation received by the human population on Earth is from natural radiation sources. There are only a handful of studies and detector networks dedicated to the collection of background radiation spectra and subsequent correlation with weather and environmental phenomenon. This paper describes the process of refurbishing and re-deploying a gamma spectrometer on campus grounds for constant and accurate energy spectrum collection to allow for statistical analysis and correlation with environmental data such as rainstorms and lunar cycles.

The aim of this project was to assess the state of conservation of a set of ancient mummies and bones by examining their proton depth profiles, acquired using mobile NMR. This was achieved by performing CPMG experiments on the samples, and using the T2 decay curves in order to arrive at a measure of proton density. For the skulls, it was found the skulls of the frozen mummies were particularly well-conserved. On the other hand, the tibia of Charlemagne and the left B16 tibia were found to be the best-conserved among the samples under consideration. The secondary aim was to determine whether the same information about the structural integrity of the bones could be ascertained from CT and mobile NMR. This was achieved by acquiring cross-sectional CT scans of the samples at the same locations where NMR measurements were made, and comparing the two. It was found that the two techniques do result in the same information about the proton density and consequently, the state of conservation. Considering the limitations of CT, mobile NMR was concluded to be a viable instrument to replace CT for cultural heritage purposes.

We present initial results from the 4.8 GHz VLBA radio survey of the North Ecliptic Pole (NEP) deep field. An analysis of 12 VLBA sources with their IR counterparts shows a correlation between the radio/IR emissions and the physical properties of the AGN and their host galaxies. A ratio of 1to1 VLBA to JVLA flux densities indicates a compact source (parsec scale) produced the detected radio emission. Major: Psychology
Abstract: Numerous qualitative studies have investigated why Middle Eastern women may choose to veil. The work suggests that many women veil for reasons other than religious obligation. Some of their reasons include veiling as a means to protect their individuality and sense of agency, a claim in direct conflict with Western stereotypes of veiling as an oppressive and objectifying practice. Do these reports signal important cross-­‐cultural differences in a perceivers' spontaneous responses to veiled women? To address this issue, the current investigation explored the rapid objectification of veiled and unveiled women by Middle Eastern and Western perceivers, using two standard measures of implicit associations. While the results did not provide evidence of objectification, they signaled the dehumanization of veiled women across cultures. Both Middle Eastern and Western perceivers considered women who veiled as less human than non-­‐veiling women. In addition, Middle Easterners also dehumanized women more than Westerners, regardless of their headgear. A second task, however, did not support these conclusions, potentially due to poor test validity. The obtained results provide tentative evidence for cross-­‐cultural consistency as well as divergence regarding the perception of (veiled) women.DehumanizationObjectificationStereotypes (Social psychology)DiscriminationHijab (Islamic clothing)Head Covers/VeilsBadwan, Iman R. Abstract: Decades of research on face recognition with Western observers suggest that during the processing of unfamiliar faces perceivers rely more strongly on external facial features (e.g., hair and face outline) than internal facial features (e.g., eyes and nose). Recent evidence indicates, however, that this processing preference may be culture-dependent. Egyptian perceivers, for instance, show the opposite face processing pattern; an effect argued to reflect their frequent exposure to faces void of external facial features (i.e., female faces covered by headscarves). To further examine this claim, spontaneous recognition accuracy for internal facial features was assessed, using a standard part-whole face recognition task, in Western perceivers living in New York and Middle Eastern perceivers living in Abu Dhabi. Accuracy scores were submitted to a 2 (perceiver culture: Western vs. Middle Eastern) x 2 (target face race: Caucasian vs. Arab) x 2 (face probe: part vs. whole) mixed measures analysis of variance. As predicted, Middle Eastern perceivers outperformed Westerners with regard to recognition accuracy. Merely on trials that required recognizing isolated face parts of Caucasian faces, both groups of perceivers performed equally well. Importantly, Middle Easterners also reported higher exposure to covered faces in everyday life than Westerners. In combination, these findings provide evidence that culture-specific face environments can impact basic aspects of face recognition.FaceHead Covers/VeilsHijab (Islamic clothing)Facial recognition (Psychology)Cross-cultural comparisonPark, Hyun Kyung. Abstract: Code switching is a cognitive aspect of bilingualism. Code switching has been linked to a processing cost, with the inhibitory mechanism in language selection leading to an asymmetrical switching cost in low proficiency bilinguals, but a symmetrical cost in high proficiency bilinguals. Given the limited literature on intra-sentential code switching that high proficiency bilinguals have been reported to do, as well as on bilinguals of genealogically distinct languages, this study used the self-paced reading paradigm to investigate the presence, extent, and symmetry of a switching cost in highly proficient Korean-English bilinguals. The results showed that there was no overall switching cost, but instead a marginal advantage when switching from Korean to English. Because there was no switching cost, there was no symmetry or asymmetry to be interpreted in light of the inhibitory mechanism.Code switching (Linguistics)BilingualismEnglish languageKorean languageLanguage and languagesHaynes, Robert Clark III. Abstract: This paper examines theories of lexical access, particularly regarding morphological decomposition of spoken words. Two competing theories of lexical access, William Marslen-Wilson's Cohort theory, and James McClelland's and Jeffrey Elman's TRACE model, differ mainly in their treatment of phonology in lexical access. Marslen-Wilson (1994) has also posited that morphemes are the most basic unit of lexical storage. To test these, and other more recent models, we used a subliminal auditory speech priming method designed by Kouider and Dupoux (2005) to determine the roles of phonology, morphology, meaning, and lexicality is lexical access. We find no effect of morphology, and posit that lexical processing, beyond determining whether an utterance is a word, requires that utterances enter consciousness before unconscious parsing can take place. We also find an inhibitory effect of pseudowords, which suggests that lexical access is not a serial process and that familiarity with words may also play a role in processing.Morphological decompositionSubliminal perceptionSpeechesMorphology (Linguistics)Priming (Psychology)Mohmad, Farah. Scope and Contents

Abstract: Previous studies demonstrated a relationship between motivation and aspirations in school-aged children (Mertens, 2012), the present study reveals the intricacies in this relationship. This study examines the effect of manipulating motivation on students' educational aspirations. Participants were 169 students in 5th, 7th, and 9th grade from schools in Chennai, India who completed a questionnaire that included two conditions: positive outcome focus (i.e., reaching the goal) and negative outcome focus (i.e., failing to reach the goal). After the manipulation, students reported their predicted performance levels during and after the school year. The results support our hypothesis of motivation having an effect on aspiration where students in the positive outcome focus condition reported having higher short-term and long-term aspirations. Our results also showed an interaction effect between motivation and perceived student support. Students who reported having low perceived student support had significantly higher short-term aspirations in the positive outcome focus condition than students in the negative outcome focus condition. The results might help school counselors and teachers to increase the motivation of students in secondary schools and therefore, increase their aspirations.Support systems, SocialManipulation (Psychology)AffluenceAspirations, StudentMotivation (Psychology)Mészáros, Eszter. Comprehension of Verbal Negation in Early Childhood as a Cue to Logical Inferences. 2016-003380182016English-learning infants were shown to have "no" in their active vocabulary for almost a year before they understand it as truth functional negation (e.g. Feiman et. al, under review). The present study investigated three hypotheses concerning the acquisition of truth functional negation cross-linguistically: 1) a conceptual shift is required; 2a) it is dependent on mastering sentence structure; 2b) negation is hard for children because of its conceptual and linguistic complexity. Experiment 1 compared Hungarian 20-month-olds' understanding of "nem" ( "no/not") and English-learning 20- and 24-month-olds' understanding of "no/not" through a search task. While English-learning 20-month-olds ignored the negative operator in negative trials, their Hungarian peers and American 24-month-olds were marginally above chance and performed better not only on negative but also on affirmative trials. Experiment 2 compared 18-month-old English- and Hungarian-learners' comprehension of nonexistence ("all gone"/"nincsen") through a task devised by Szabo and Kovacs (in preparation). While Hungarian infants performed better on the task, both groups' performance was above chance on the first test trial and overall. Results from experiment 1 and 2 suggest that Hungarian-learners are developmentally ahead of their English-learning peers on the comprehension of both affirmation and negation, ruling out hypothesis 1) and supporting hypothesis 2a).AD-MC-0042016-0033

While Hungarian infants performed better on the task, both groups' performance was above chance on the first test trial and overall. Cross-Cultural Differences in the Perception of Facial Trustworthiness.2016-003480892016Previous research has shown that people habitually extract social information from faces. Yet, conflicting findings regarding cross-cultural consensus in face-based personality judgments have been reported in the literature. Using a reverse correlation task, the current study asked American and Emirati participants to make trustworthiness judgments in response to Arab and White faces. Results were analyzed using both quantitative and qualitative methods. A quantitative analysis of agreement rates within and across perceiver groups is suggestive of a perceiver culture by face race interaction. Furthermore, a qualitative inspection of composite faces based on participants' trustworthiness judgments revealed evidence in favor of both a main effect of perceiver culture as well as a perceiver culture by face race interaction. The findings add to a growing body of work that challenges the notion of high cross-cultural consensus in face-based personality judgments.AD-MC-0042016-0034
Scope and Contents

Yet, conflicting findings regarding cross-cultural consensus in face-based personality judgments have been reported in the literature. Using a reverse correlation task, the current study asked American and Emirati participants to make trustworthiness judgments in response to Arab and White faces. Results were analyzed using both quantitative and qualitative methods. A quantitative analysis of agreement rates within and across perceiver groups is suggestive of a perceiver culture by face race interaction. Furthermore, a qualitative inspection of composite faces based on participants' trustworthiness judgments revealed evidence in favor of both a main effect of perceiver culture as well as a perceiver culture by face race interaction. The findings add to a growing body of work that challenges the notion of high cross-cultural consensus in face-based personality judgments.Nadyukova, Iryna. Academic Achievement Motivation in the Context of Tertiary Education.2016-003781112016The study investigated similarities and differences in academic achievement motivation of students (N = 503) from three different contexts of tertiary education. The study examined how motivation to learn, future-oriented motivation and emotional component of motivation varies across public/private and local/international educational setting, gender and experimentally induced cognitive mindsets. Participants were randomly assigned to four conditions for the experimental mindset induction. Afterwards all participants responded to questionnaires about academic motivation. Female students in a local public setting scored significantly higher on emotional component of motivation than the male students. Furthermore, the female students in the deliberative mindset condition scored significantly higher on emotional component of motivation than the female students in neutral mindset condition and control group. The analysis of motivation to learn and future-oriented motivation revealed a consistent pattern of results, where the students from the local public setting differed significantly from the students from the local private and the international private settings. Main effects of gender showed that overall female students displayed higher motivation to learn, while male students scored higher on future-oriented motivation. The findings have implications for helping educators improve academic motivation of the students.AD-MC-0042016-0037
Scope and Contents

The study examined how motivation to learn, future-oriented motivation and emotional component of motivation varies across public/private and local/international educational setting, gender and experimentally induced cognitive mindsets. Participants were randomly assigned to four conditions for the experimental mindset induction. Afterwards all participants responded to questionnaires about academic motivation. Female students in a local public setting scored significantly higher on emotional component of motivation than the male students. Furthermore, the female students in the deliberative mindset condition scored significantly higher on emotional component of motivation than the female students in neutral mindset condition and control group. The analysis of motivation to learn and future-oriented motivation revealed a consistent pattern of results, where the students from the local public setting differed significantly from the students from the local private and the international private settings. Main effects of gender showed that overall female students displayed higher motivation to learn, while male students scored higher on future-oriented motivation.
