The effects of dopaminergic modulation on the stability of working memory representation.2016-003281392016Working Memory (WM), the temporary retention of information that was just experienced or just retrieved from long-term memory is thought to underlie goal-directed behavior. WM relies heavily on the prefrontal cortex (PFC), and specifically dopaminergic input to the PFC. Studies employing distractor stimulus in the delay period of WM tasks have indicated that the memory of the target stimulus can be corrupted by such distractors. The mediation of distracting effects may involve the PFC and the dopaminergic system. The aim of this research project is to quantify the effects of physiologically realistic dopamine modulation (via manipulations of reward) on the behavioral and neural effects of distraction during WM using behavioral modeling and magnetoencephalography (MEG).AD-MC-0042016-0032
Scope and Contents
Working Memory (WM), the temporary retention of information that was just experienced or just retrieved from long-term memory is thought to underlie goal-directed behavior. WM relies heavily on the prefrontal cortex (PFC), and specifically dopaminergic input to the PFC. Studies employing distractor stimulus in the delay period of WM tasks have indicated that the memory of the target stimulus can be corrupted by such distractors. The mediation of distracting effects may involve the PFC and the dopaminergic system. The aim of this research project is to quantify the effects of physiologically realistic dopamine modulation (via manipulations of reward) on the behavioral and neural effects of distraction during WM using behavioral modeling and magnetoencephalography (MEG).Smoley, James. Does our trust of other races change with exposure?.2016-003881492016We make automatic judgements about the trustworthiness of an individual based on the appearance of their face. These trustworthiness judgements are important because they guide our decisions, such as approaching or avoiding an individual. Some research has been conducted on trustworthiness judgements made across racial groups. This research has found that raters of the same-race as a target face make significantly different trustworthiness judgements than other-race raters. This research has also suggested the differences in judgements could be due to experience with other races, but this has not been measured. In my research I will control for the experience of raters with other-races. I hypothesize that increased experience will strengthen the correlations of the trustworthiness judgements made by same-race and other-race raters.AD-MC-0042016-0038
Scope and Contents
We make automatic judgements about the trustworthiness of an individual based on the appearance of their face. These trustworthiness judgements are important because they guide our decisions, such as approaching or avoiding an individual. Some research has been conducted on trustworthiness judgements made across racial groups. This research has found that raters of the same-race as a target face make significantly different trustworthiness judgements than other-race raters. This research has also suggested the differences in judgements could be due to experience with other races, but this has not been measured. In my research I will control for the experience of raters with other-races. I hypothesize that increased experience will strengthen the correlations of the trustworthiness judgements made by same-race and other-race raters.Heyn, Oliver. The interaction of the visual properties of logos: How font and shape influence preference and attention. 2017-00332017We constantly perceive many types of visual stimuli that may attract our attention and influence the way we interact with the environment. Several critical categories that tend to attract attention include texts and shapes. Research conducted independently on word and shape processing has revealed that distinct regions in the ventral visual stream are more responsive to words or shapes, respectively. However, visual elements in the world do not appear alone, and the processing of various information must be combined to form a coherent percept. This study investigated how visual information from shapes and texts interact with each other to influence preference and attention towards novel company logos which consisted of a shape and a word. We manipulated the properties of the shapes and words (preferred or disliked shapes or font as rated in a pilot study) to determine what kinds of visual properties were more influential in affecting participant's preference. Furthermore, to investigate whether visual preference towards certain stimulus properties might influence visual attention allocation, we recorded eye movements to the logo components. This data examined regarded first fixations, first fixation duration, total number of fixations, and total dwell time.AD-MC-0042017-0033
Scope and Contents
We constantly perceive many types of visual stimuli that may attract our attention and influence the way we interact with the environment. Several critical categories that tend to attract attention include texts and shapes. Research conducted independently on word and shape processing has revealed that distinct regions in the ventral visual stream are more responsive to words or shapes, respectively. However, visual elements in the world do not appear alone, and the processing of various information must be combined to form a coherent percept. This study investigated how visual information from shapes and texts interact with each other to influence preference and attention towards novel company logos which consisted of a shape and a word. We manipulated the properties of the shapes and words (preferred or disliked shapes or font as rated in a pilot study) to determine what kinds of visual properties were more influential in affecting participant's preference. Furthermore, to investigate whether visual preference towards certain stimulus properties might influence visual attention allocation, we recorded eye movements to the logo components. This data examined regarded first fixations, first fixation duration, total number of fixations, and total dwell time.Mukhayarova, Dinara. The Effect of Diversity of Subordinates' Need for Closure and Willingness to Comply with Power Tactics2017-00262017Diversity is progressively becoming ubiquitous in the workplace. Although it has been touted as a business advantage fostering creativity and innovation (Rizy, Feil, Sniderman, and Egan, 2011), research has skirted how diversity may impact supervisor-subordinate interactions. Based on prior work, we hypothesized that diversity increases people's need for closure and thus impacts their willingness to comply with their supervisors' soft and harsh power tactics in the workplace. To test for this hypothesis, we conducted an experiment manipulating perceived diversity and measuring diversity salience, need for closure and willingness to comply with social power tactics. We found a significant indirect effect of perceived diversity on willingness to comply with harsh power tactics through need for closure. No indirect effect was found on people's willingness to comply with soft power tactics. This research contributes to our understanding of diversity in the workplace and its influence on supervisor-subordinate interactions. Implications for management are discussed.AD-MC-0042017-0026
Scope and Contents
Diversity is progressively becoming ubiquitous in the workplace. Although it has been touted as a business advantage fostering creativity and innovation (Rizy, Feil, Sniderman, and Egan, 2011), research has skirted how diversity may impact supervisor-subordinate interactions. Based on prior work, we hypothesized that diversity increases people's need for closure and thus impacts their willingness to comply with their supervisors' soft and harsh power tactics in the workplace. To test for this hypothesis, we conducted an experiment manipulating perceived diversity and measuring diversity salience, need for closure and willingness to comply with social power tactics. We found a significant indirect effect of perceived diversity on willingness to comply with harsh power tactics through need for closure. No indirect effect was found on people's willingness to comply with soft power tactics. This research contributes to our understanding of diversity in the workplace and its influence on supervisor-subordinate interactions. Implications for management are discussed.Wu, Kefei. Do Different Types of Script Induce Differences in Hemispheric Lateralization During Reading? Evidence from a Cross Linguistic MEG Study.2017-00302017There is a debate about the mechanism behind the hemispheric specialization for M170 response. The left lateralization effect commonly found in alphabetical reading has been attributed either to the process of mapping the pronunciation to words (sound mapping hypothesis), or to an expertise acquired in the visual domain (familiarity hypothesis). We tested these two hypotheses using a cross-linguistic design comparing the reading of Chinese with English. To isolate any script difference from the language difference, we used Pinyin, an auxiliary alphabetic system for transliterating Chinese words into the Latin script. Moreover, we also recruited a group of English Chinese learner. Chinese readers reading Chinese characters exhibited a trend towards left lateralization, which was not statistically significant. A left lateralized response was obtained for both the English group and the learner group during Pinyin reading, but not during Chinese reading. In addition, the Chinese group showed the same trend for left lateralization during Pinyin reading, but it was not statistically significant. Overall, the results were more aligned with the predictions of the sound mapping hypothesis, but we discuss the limitations of the study in terms of statistical power, and the ways which the conclusion could be reversed.AD-MC-0042017-0030
Scope and Contents
There is a debate about the mechanism behind the hemispheric specialization for M170 response. The left lateralization effect commonly found in alphabetical reading has been attributed either to the process of mapping the pronunciation to words (sound mapping hypothesis), or to an expertise acquired in the visual domain (familiarity hypothesis). We tested these two hypotheses using a cross-linguistic design comparing the reading of Chinese with English. To isolate any script difference from the language difference, we used Pinyin, an auxiliary alphabetic system for transliterating Chinese words into the Latin script. Moreover, we also recruited a group of English Chinese learner. Chinese readers reading Chinese characters exhibited a trend towards left lateralization, which was not statistically significant. A left lateralized response was obtained for both the English group and the learner group during Pinyin reading, but not during Chinese reading. In addition, the Chinese group showed the same trend for left lateralization during Pinyin reading, but it was not statistically significant. Overall, the results were more aligned with the predictions of the sound mapping hypothesis, but we discuss the limitations of the study in terms of statistical power, and the ways which the conclusion could be reversed.Altaf, Shanzey. Don't let your emotions get the better of you: The Relationship Between Passion, Emotions and Cognitive Performance2018-00632018AD-MC-0042018-0063
Scope and Contents
Passion is commonly understood as a strong inclination toward a self-defining activity that is highly valued and to which a considerable amount of time and effort is directed (Vallerand et al., 2003). The present research investigated the relationship between passion for academics, emotions, and cognitive performance. Results indicated that students with an obsessive passion – a strong internal pressure to engage in the activity — experienced high levels of negative emotions while taking a cognitive test, which impaired their cognitive performance. Students with a harmonious passion — a strong desire to freely engage in the activity — experienced low level of negative emotions, which facilitated their cognitive performance. Implications for positive psychology and educational interventions are discussed in the way in which positive psychology elements reduce negative emotions for harmonious passion, and improve cognitive performance. The promotion of these positive psychology elements can be done through school environments and classroom activities.Bauer, Ann. Interpersonal Consequences of Self-Sacrifice 2018-00742018AD-MC-0042018-0074
Scope and Contents
Significant research has been devoted to understanding the personal motivations of ideological activists. This study, however, focuses on group dynamics by investigating how the behavior of one activist impacts the actions of other ingroup members. We hypothesized a positive relationship between one individual's self-sacrifice and the willingness of other group members to make similar sacrifices. Specifically, we predicted that costly (vs. non-costly) sacrifices by a fellow environmentalist would increase people's admiration for that person, which in turn would lead to greater identity fusion with the group and increase people's willingness to fight and die for the environmental cause. Results supported our hypotheses. Implications for future psychological research on ideological groups, as well as for terrorism and counterterrorism studies, are discussed.Mahadevan, Sangeetha. With a Little Help from My Friends! : Effects of Social Support and Cultural Orientation on the Formation of Narrative Identity2018-01042018AD-MC-0042018-0104
Scope and Contents
As born story-tellers, we are constantly engaging in the process of creating autobiographical memories, i.e. our memory for specific life events in the past with a high level of personal significance. In the following study, we hypothesized that seeking out social support during such impactful life events can predict positive perceptions of said events. We also hypothesized that participants identifying as relatively more individualistic would make more negative self-event connections due perceived low quality of social support. Our participants included 180 undergraduate students from New York University Abu Dhabi and Western Washington University representing 7 ethnicities. We used 3 types of personal narratives and 2 questionnaires—the MSPSS and the RIC scales—to collect data. Results showed that participants indicating higher levels of seeking social support during impactful life events did indeed make more positive self-event connections and participants identifying with an individualistic cultural self-aspect made more negative self-event connections. Significant gender effects were also found. Social support is an essential part of the human experience and this research was done in hopes of strengthening the scientific foundations on which we can build these arguments.Meehan, Jessica. Do Attention And Visual Working Memory Share A Common Search Template?2018-00622018AD-MC-0042018-0062
Scope and Contents
Our ability to selectively decide on and search for a specific item in space is made possible through the interaction of two cognitive processes; attention and working memory. Recent literature has proposed that the two processes may be interdependent. Studies have shown that the template used during visual search is maintained and influenced by the contents of visual working memory (VWM). This study used a task that combines memory and search demands for a single target item. Depending on the type of trial, participants were asked to either search for the stored item amongst similar distractors, or to adjust a sample line to match the orientation of the stored item. Previous research has shown that explicit knowledge about the context an item will appear in can modulate search away from expected distractor items to improve performance. Based on these assumptions, if the search template and VWM representation rely on a single template, then adjustment away from the context in a search task will bias the representation of the item in working memory in the same direction. These findings suggest that the two tasks do not exclusively draw on a common, single template.Nomani, Amber. Now You See It, Now You Don't: Effects of Interference on Unconscious Working Memory2018-00792018AD-MC-0042018-0079
Scope and Contents
Working memory (WM) is traditionally considered to be a conscious process during which information is currently being used. It is where information is held while we complete a task, or recollect an old memory. Recently, studies have shown that it is possible to maintain information in working memory even in the absence of conscious awareness. This means visual information from the environment may be processed without the awareness of the individual and we can also process them in the presence of distractors which require attentional resources. This study consists of three spatial WM tasks which aim to understand the limits on unconscious WM by testing the effect of interference, and compare these effects to the effects on conscious WM. We predicted an attractive effect of participants' responses to the object of interference in each experiment. As such, we found that there was a trend in attraction of the participants' responses towards the position of the presented sample on the current trial due to proactive interference, and also a trend in attraction of responses towards the location of the distractor due to retroactive interference. However, there was no significant difference between unconscious and conscious WM for the different tasks.Omari, Deemah. Cultural Differences in Mothers' Visual Attention During Mother-Child Play 2018-00582018AD-MC-0042018-0058
Scope and Contents
Mothers' visual attention plays a large role in in children's interactions during early development. Using two samples of mothers from India (n=34) and Germany (n=34), this paper explores the distribution of maternal visual attention during mother-child play. The study will tackle two research questions: (1) Is mothers' visual attention consistent in frequency across different types of play? And (2) are there cultural differences in German and Indian mothers' visual attention during free or structured play? For the first question, it was hypothesized that mothers direct their visual attention more at the child in free than structured play, and more at the object in structured than free play. For the second question, it was hypothesized that Indian mothers look more at the child than German mothers, while German mothers look more at the object. Results supported the first hypothesis, but provided no support for the second hypothesis as there was an insignificant interactional effect of type of play and culture. Culture showed a significant main effect on maternal visual attention. Implications and limitations are discussed.Tahan, Rosy. Investigating Early Lexical Processing Using Script Changes: Evidence from Arabic and Arabish2018-00752018AD-MC-0042018-0075
Scope and Contents
In language experiments, priming, particularly in conjunction with the lexical decision task, has assumed access to the mental lexicon. However, this assumption has been challenged by findings of priming effects for pseudowords, and some researchers suggest that pseudoword priming is mediated by different underlying mechanisms which may be found using high-temporal resolution neurimaging techniques. The present study is based on Almeida and Poeppel (2013) found similar behavioral priming for words and pseudowords, but different electrophysiological responses. We designed an EEG lexical decision experiment using words and pseudowords written in Arabic and Arabish, expecting N400 priming responses and a word- and orthography-specific P2 response. We found robust behavioral priming for both words and pseudowords, but EEG results were generally not significant. Limitations are discussed.Xiao, Junyi. The Relationship between Traditional Gender Role Attitudes and Acceptance of Different Types of Lesbian Relationships in China 2018-01002018AD-MC-0042018-0100
Scope and Contents
The study investigated the relationship between traditional gender role attitudes and people's acceptance of different types of lesbian relationships in China. Specifically, I looked at how participants' endorsement of either hostile sexism or benevolent sexism is related to their acceptance of four types of lesbian relationships in China. Chinese undergraduate students from Sichuan province (N=550) filled out an online survey. I found a main effect of benevolent sexism, gender, and type of lesbian relationship on people's acceptance of lesbian relationships. The results showed that 1) acceptance of lesbian relationships in general was negatively associated with endorsement of benevolent sexism, but not hostile sexism, 2) compared to men, women overall found lesbian relationships more acceptable, 3) lesbian relationships with a masculine lesbian and a feminine lesbian were the most acceptable, and lesbian relationships with both masculine lesbians were the least acceptable among the four types of relationships. The results suggested that it is important to differentiate between men and women' attitudes, as well as between different types of lesbians or lesbian relationships. It also highlights the importance of studying gay men and lesbians not only as individuals, but also in relationships.Al-Hajeri, Jude. Examining the Lasting Effects of Daycare on Attachment Security: An 18-Year Prospective Longitudinal Study2019-00852019AD-MC-0042019-0085
Scope and Contents
Early childhood experiences are crucial when it comes to developing attachment representations with primary caregivers. Although attachment theory addresses a universal aspect of human development, many of its properties go unstudied. The goal of this study is to address the gap in literature by examining the enduring effects of early daycare experiences on attachment in adolescence. Thus, this study further investigates a subsample (N = 673) of the NICHD Study of Early Child Care and Youth Development (SECCYD) cohort. This study examines the associations between early daycare experiences (i.e. quality and quantity) and attachment security (i.e. secure base script knowledge) at age 18 years. It was hypothesized that there would be a significant association between quality and quantity of care on secure base script knowledge in adolescence, such that higher quality care would result in positive developmental outcomes. Results indicated a small association between daycare quality and attachment security at age 18 years, but this effect did not hold when accounting for critical demographic and caregiving variables (i.e. maternal and paternal sensitivity). These results suggest that early daycare experiences are transient, leaving no significant effects on attachment in adolescence.Al Khezam, Muna. Investigating the effect of bilingual education in the United Arab Emirates on Emiratis2019-00932019AD-MC-0042019-0093
Scope and Contents
Modern Standard Arabic (MSA) has been traditionally used in the educational setting in the Arabic-speaking world, while local dialects of Arabic are used in daily informal settings, including in the United Arab Emirates. However, English-medium education is becoming increasingly more popular in the UAE among the Emirati population. We conducted a survey to investigate how the effective competition between MSA-medium versus English-medium education in the UAE affects the construction of Emirati identity in nationals and their linguistic attitudes towards MSA, Emirati Arabic and English. Results indicated that Emiratis educated primarily in private English-medium schools reported a negative attitude towards MSA, but a positive view of both Emirati and English. Emiratis educated in MSA-medium public schools reported a positive attitude towards MSA and Emirati. Daily Emirati usage and promotion of Emirati Arabic in the public and private spheres were considered important to all participants, including in the construction of their personal identity. Similar positive attitudes towards MSA, however, were highly correlated with the amount of MSA-medium schooling participants had, with primarily English-medium graduates reporting only a positive attitude towards Emirati, not MSA.Alshuhoomi, Fatma Abdulla. Backlash against equality: How threats to the gender hierarchy affect attitudes toward reproductive freedom and violence against women2019-00702019AD-MC-0042019-0070
Scope and Contents
Desire to preserve the traditional gender hierarchy is linked to beliefs that women should be controlled non-violently (i.e., giving men more control over women's reproductive rights) and violently (rape myth acceptance and minimization of severity of sexual and physical violence). Study 1 (N=199) found that hostile sexism (HS; which assesses negative attitudes towards non-traditional women) is positively associated with both non-violent and violent forms of control, above and beyond general attitudes toward abortion. Study 2 (N=1178), participants read a paragraph depicting the gender hierarchy as "stable" (men hold more power than women), "changed" (women already achieved equality), or "changing" (women currently in the process of advancement towards bridging the gender gap). Results showed that when the gender hierarchy is perceived to be changing (vs. stable or already changed), people were higher on rape myth endorsement, especially those high on HS. Both studies unexpectedly showed that the biggest predictor of rape acceptance and partner violence was attitudes about abortion access (people who opposed abortion were more likely to minimize violence).Andric, Sandro. A Cross-National Investigation of the Relationship Between Sexism and Attitudes Towards GayMen and Transwomen2019-00672019AD-MC-0042019-0067
Scope and Contents
Non-heterosexual and transgender people are usually the target of discrimination and violence. Past research, which has primarily focused on Western samples, has found that sexism is associated with negative attitudes toward sexual minorities. In the current work, I used data from 23 countries and compared attitudes toward sexual minorities between Western and non-Western countries. Attitudes towards gay men and transgender women were highly correlated. People in Western countries report more positive attitudes toward gay men than transwomen, while the opposite is true for people in non-Western countries. Overall, people in Western-countries have more positive attitudes than in non-West. Women tend to have more positive attitudes than men towards both gay men and transwomen. There is negative, significant correlation between both hostile sexism and benevolent sexism and liking of gay men and transgender women in Western countries. However, in non-Western countries only hostile sexism has positive, significant correlation with attitudes. I also tested whether gender moderates the relationship between sexism and attitudes. Only in Western countries, benevolent sexism was better predictor of women's attitudes towards transwomen than it was for men.Aslanian, Araz. The Effect of Implicit Racial Bias on Recognition of Own- Versus Other-Race Faces2019-01182019AD-MC-0042019-0118
Scope and Contents
Recognition of own- and other- race faces might be modulated by observers' face recognition ability, social experience, and implicit social biases. Caucasian participants (N=53) completed a memory task for Caucasian and Asian faces, an implicit association test, a questionnaire on social experience towards Caucasians and Asians, and a face recognition ability test (Cambridge Face Memory Test). During the memory task, eye-tracking was used to track participants' eye movements. The memory performance for own-race faces was positively predicted by increased face recognition ability only, whereas the memory performance for other-race faces were positively predicted by increased face recognition ability, social experience with Asians, and negatively predicted by increased positive bias towards Asians, which was modulated by an interaction between face recognition ability and implicit biases with the effect of bias observed only in observers with high face recognition ability. Eye tracking data revealed an interaction between race and fixation location. These findings suggest the complexity in understanding the perceptual and socio- cognitive influences on the other-race effect.Gajic, Milica. Teacher Stress and the Quality of Teacher-Child Interactions as Mediated by Teachers' Executive Functions2019-01172019AD-MC-0042019-0117
Scope and Contents
The present study explores the relationship between teachers' physiological and subjective stress and the quality of teacher-child interactions. The main objective was to investigate whether teachers' executive functions (EFs) mediate the relationship between teacher stress and the quality of teacher-child interactions. Participants were 53 kindergarten teachers (Mage = 39 years, SD = 10.87) recruited from 14 early childhood education (ECE) centers in Ukraine. Data was collected using self-report measures, saliva sampling and computer-based tasks. Results indicated that there were no significant associations between teacher stress and the quality of teacher-child interactions, nor were the prerequisites met for the association to be mediated by EFs. Significant positive associations were found between teachers' subjective stress and self-reported EFs, and between teaching experience and the quality of teacher-child interactions. Implications for study of teacher stress and the quality of teacher-child interactions in low-resource contexts are discussed.Gonokuchi, Mina. Goal-Pursuit Across the Life-Span: Examining the Relationship between, Age, Autonomy, and Selectivity2019-00872019AD-MC-0042019-0087
Scope and Contents
Effective goal-pursuit has far-reaching implications across the life-span, yet a growing body of evidence suggests that people's strategies to attain their goal changes over time. The present study examined this topic by investigating the relationship between age and goal-pursuit strategies. We hypothesized that autonomy — feeling free to make decisions and to behave in ways that express one's true interests — may be the psychological mechanism explaining this relationship. A mediational study provided support for our hypotheses. Specifically, age was positively related to autonomy which in turn was positively associated with goal facilitation and negatively associated with goal interference. These results provide support for the growing claim that older adults are also subject to developmental gains.Gu, Yufei. The Influence of Early Childhood Attachment Quality on Secure Base Script Knowledge Development in Chinese Children2019-01212019AD-MC-0042019-0121
Scope and Contents
Attachment theory argues that the quality and consistency of parental sensitivity and responsiveness to their children is internalized as a mental representation of attachment relationships. Interestingly, all longitudinal studies on the development of attachment representations to date have been conducted in Western contexts. Leveraging data from a longitudinal study of child development in Nanjing, China, we conducted the first test of the hypothesized link between early caregiving and later development of attachment representations in a non-Western context. We analyzed data collected from subsample of an ongoing prospective longitudinal study of Chinese families (n = 78). Observations of mother-infant interactions were recorded when the infants were age 14 months. Attachment security was assessed at age 10 years using the attachment script assessment adapted to the Chinese context. The study investigates how mothers across three cultural communities describe goals and strategies for toddlers during gift reception, specifically with regard to their autonomy and relatedness. Mothers of two-year-old children from New York City, USA (n = 36), Chennai, India (n = 33), and Muenster, Germany (n = 36) participated in the study. The mothers' responses to a semi-structured interview were quantified by coding them into different types of autonomous goals, autonomous strategies, relatedness goals, and relatedness strategies using a coding manual. The majority of goals described by mothers were autonomy-focused, while the majority of strategies were relatedness-focused. Mothers differed significantly in their autonomy goals for their toddlers (F (2, 102) = 5.152, p = .007), and there was a marginal significant difference in their relatedness strategies (F (2, 102) = 2.621, p = .078). Ensemble perception refers to the ability to extract summary statistics, such as averages and variances, from sets of stimuli with similar properties. A recent proposal implicates ensemble perception in visual phenomenology. However, a key assumption of this proposal – that ensemble perception can occur even in the absence of conscious awareness of the items in the ensemble – remains untested. To test this assumption, this study investigated whether ensemble perception of spatial location can occur unconsciously. In Experiments 1a and 1b, participants reported the average spatial location, or centroid, of ensembles of dots presented either within or beneath their threshold of conscious awareness; in Experiment 2, participants reported the spatial location of a single dot within the ensemble. We found that participants were able to accurately report the centroid of unconsciously-presented ensembles when the dots were clustered closely together, but when the dots were presented as two separate clusters, they appeared to report the centroid of a single cluster rather than the centroid of the entire ensemble. Furthermore, participants could not accurately report the location of individual dots within unconsciously-presented ensembles. Taken together, our results offer preliminary evidence that unconscious ensemble perception is possible, but limited.Lee, Seoyoung. The Role of the Parahippocampal Cortex in Scene Integration2019-01232019AD-MC-0042019-0123

Humans perceive a coherent visual world across time and space. To update incoming sensory information while maintaining a stable representation of the environment, previous studies have suggested the role of the parahippocampal place area (PPA) in scene processing and ensemble processing. Using functional magnetic resonance imaging, we examined how the PPA might integrate information by relying on continuous spatial-temporal sequence of information flow, or mere shared elements in a scene. We used scene images that were divided into three segments, with 66% overlap between the first and second segments and 33% overlap between the first and the third segments. Participants viewed the three scene segments either sequentially or in a displaced order, identical segments for three times, or three completely different scenes. We found that the left and right PPA not only showed significantly stronger activations for different scenes than identical scenes, but also for different scenes than three segments originating from the same scene. Moreover, the sequence order of the three segments did not affect the response magnitude. Media channels like music, television, and film can reinforce or challenge the status quo, and influence attitudes by virtue of what they portray. This study examines the impact of objectified portrayals of females in music videos on viewers' sexual beliefs, and the potential role of sexism as a moderator. Six-hundred Amazon MTurk participants were randomly assigned to view South Korean pop ("K-pop") music videos with sexual, infantile, or neutral depictions of women, after which they responded to questions assessing their acceptance of date rape and male sexual dominance. Exposure to sexualized and infantilized(vs. neutral) videos was found to decrease date rape condemnation and increase pro-male dominance beliefs at higher levels of benevolent and hostile sexism only for women. We make decisions constantly, both consciously and unconsciously. In order to examine the strategy people use to cope with unexpected stimuli, we have used the method of perturbation. In the experiment, participants were required to reach for and touch the target in one of the two possible locations with their index ﬁngers. They were presented with either the unperturbed target or the perturbed target and when they were provided with the perturbed target, they were required to make online corrections in their movements to cope with the target jump. Our main focus was on the perturbation of frequency. In other words, we wanted to systematically examine how well people cope with the increasing perturbation frequency. Participants' responses were measured and recorded using a motion capture system. Data show that participants take the increasing proportion into account in the trajectory of their movements. As the perturbation frequency increased along with the progression of blocks, the initial direction moved more and more toward the perturbed target on the left, and for the perturbed trials, the participants made online corrections earlier on in the movement. Passion is commonly defined as a strong inclination towards a self-defining and highly valued activity toward which an individual devotes considerable time and energy (Vallerand et al., 2003). Vallerand's Dualistic Model of Passion (DMP) divides passion into the two distinct categories of harmonious passion – which involves an autonomous internalization of and engagement with one's passion – and obsessive passion – which involves a controlled internalization of and engagement with one's passion. The present research explores the relationship between passion and themes of narrative identity – i.e. a person's internalized and evolving life-story (McAdams, 1985)), especially with regard to the themes of agency, communion, redemption, and contamination (McAdams, 1996). Results revealed a strong positive correlation between harmonious passion and themes of communion. Obsessive passion was not significantly correlated with any narrative theme. Estimating working memory maintenance-related activation with functional magnetic resonance imaging2020-00782020AD-MC-0042020-0078
Scope and Contents
The working memory field (WM) is increasingly employing multivoxel pattern analysis (MVPA) techniques with functional magnetic resonance imaging (fMRI) to identify the neural correlates of WM maintenance. These techniques are used with the delay task, which consists of contiguous encoding, maintenance (or delay), and report epochs. WM MVPA analyses use estimates of the blood-oxygen-level-dependent (BOLD) response to the maintenance epoch of the delay task to determine whether different experimental conditions produce distinct patterns of activity due to differences in maintenance. However, because of the protracted nature of the hemodynamic response, these estimates can mistakenly capture the BOLD response to the encoding or report epochs, potentially producing false positive or false negative classification results down the line. Given the consequential nature of obtaining faithful estimates of delay activity, we evaluate and compare three different methods of estimating the delay response and identify which are optimal for WM MVPA studies. (Full abstract in Capstone paper.)

The present study was designed to examine the effects of mood (positive vs. negative) and language (Arabic vs. English) on the prevalence of antisocial personality traits in different individuals. The following hypotheses were produced: 1) When primed with the negative condition, participants in the English condition are likely to score higher on the MACH-IV scale than participants in the Arabic one, 2) When primed with the positive condition, participants in the Arabic condition are likely to score lower on the MACH-IV scale than those in the English one, and 3) Participants that received the positive manipulation will have a higher score on the items of the PANAS used to measure positive affect (PA), while participants that received the negative manipulation will have a higher score on the items of the PANAS used to measure negative affect (NA). Although results showed no statistical significance with the effects of prime and language on mood, there was an interesting causal relationship between the positive manipulation and mood. The study showed noteworthy implications of the effects of mood on the way people perceive the world around them.

This study measures U.S. citizens' attitudes toward immigrants and immigration policies. Immigrants and immigration incite strong, divided sentiments and opinions in the U.S. population. These sentiments and opinions correspond with and influence public policy and legislation in the U.S. and hence, it is important to examine them regularly in empirical studies to develop a better understanding of which factors affect them. I analyze data from a study in which participants were either reminded of American society's reliance on undocumented immigrants or its independence from themr. I find support for the hypothesis that making society's dependence on immigrants salient can reduce negative emotions and evaluations as well as decrease support for anti-immigrant policies and laws. However, the condition did not have a significant impact on increasing positive emotions toward undocumented immigrants. I also demonstrate that this effect is moderated by political conservatism, such that conservatives were more likely to express increased ratings of immigrants' competence and warmth, decreased support for hostile policies, and reduced negative emotions. Results were consistent with previous research findings on the effects of perceived interdependence on attitudes toward immigration.

The present study investigated the direct association between self-regulation and academic performance within a sample in Kenya. It also investigated the extent to which the student-teacher relationship and the home learning environment mediated the association between self-regulation and academic performance, after controlling for income, gender, age, parental education and non-verbal intelligence. The Tower of Hanoi was used as a measure of cognitive self-regulation and the researchers completed the PSRA Assessor Report Examiner Rating Scale after which measured for emotional self-regulation. The teachers completed the Child-Behavior Rating Scale (CBRS) and the Student-Teacher Relationship Scale (STRS), which measured for behavioral self-regulation and the student-teacher relationship construct, respectively. The parents provided information of the home learning environment by completing the StimQ PreSchool Assessment. The Hayes macro PROCESS was used to run the mediation analysis. Results indicated that behavioral and emotional self-regulation were significantly associated with academic performance in both mathematics and language. Overall, the study showcases an uncommon sample of Kenyan children, which eventually supports the importance and understanding of self- regulation and academic performance.
Author contributed keywords: self-regulation, academic performance, teacher, parentDobreva, Nicole. Retrieval Noise Reduces Accuracy in Visual Working Memory2020-00962020AD-MC-0042020-0096
Scope and Contents
Visual working memory (VWM) is the ability to briefly store and manipulate information. This ability is important as it helps us to function in the constantly changing environment we live in. VWM capacity has long been under investigation. Its limitations occur from noise in three stages of processing: encoding, maintenance, and retrieval. In this paper, I focus on the retrieval noise of VWM. I created an analytical model to differentiate between the shared noise of encoding and maintenance and the retrieval noise. This model was first based on data generated by a computer simulation and then on behavioral measures obtained experimentally. For the purposes of the experiments, we created a new type of VWM task. It required participants to make multiple responses about the same target item instead of the commonly used single response. Data were collected from 32 participants in two different experiments. Results from applying the analysis model on the participants' data were not significant. Nevertheless, this is one of the few studies focusing on retrieval noise, and further research with large samples is needed.

Visual input is typically used for the completion of grasping movements. However, the execution and planning of movements in everyday life is also aided by haptic information when objects are held by the other hand. We present a study investigating the sensorimotor integration process by exploring how hand dominance influences grasping behavior. We compare dominant and non-dominant hand grasping movements towards an object using visual or visuo-haptic information. This gives further insight on whether there is a preferred role of each hand in grasping or if there is a generic benefit of haptic information in grasping. There was no difference in kinematic data collected between the dominant and non-dominant hand in either condition, with the only exception being shorter duration in the initial segments of the movement when using the dominant hand. However, we also confirm the benefit of adding haptic signals to grasping movements to movement accuracy, as seen in the visuo-haptic condition. We therefore conclude that haptic information aids in grasping performance, and that the generic availability of additional sensorimotor signals aid in movement, as opposed to the role of specific hands.
Author contributed keywords: grasping, haptics, visuo-haptics, multisensory integration, hand dominance, manual asymmetryErdi, Anna. The Effects of Expertise and Word Valence on Holistic Word Processing2020-01062020AD-MC-0042020-0106

Holistic processing was initially studied as a face-specific phenomenon. Recent findings suggest that it could be tied to expertise. People are experts at word-processing, thus studying holistic word-processing became the new focus of this research. There, however, are further factors influencing this phenomenon. This study investigates the influence of expertise and emotional state on holistic processing. Participants were required to respond to four-letter Hungarian words. Congruent and incongruent word pairs were constructed, with the task-relevant and the task-irrelevant parts either aligned or misaligned. The factor of expertise was manipulated by recruiting native Hungarian and non-Hungarian speakers. We tested the effect of the emotional state by using words of positive and negative meaning. Both groups performed well in both valence conditions. We did not find the expected interaction between Alignment and Congruency. Congruency effect was present in both alignment conditions, which suggest obligatory processing. Valence affected the performance of novices only.

Early maladaptive schemas (EMS) are self-defeating, emotional, and cognitive patterns established in childhood, that remain stable throughout life (Young, Klosko & Weishaar, 2003). Existing research has hypothesized that EMS can be a risk factor (Stopa et al., 2001) or a vulnerability marker for depressive disorders (Dozois et al., 2009). In this paper, we use data from a longitudinal study to examine the stability of these maladaptive schemas across adolescent development. We examine whether EMS can reliably predict depressive symptoms in adolescence. Participants were administered the Young Schema Questionnaire – Short Form (YSQ-SF; Young, 1998; Brenning et al., 2012) with itemized categories to identify schema domains. This data was correlated with psychopathological information collected from a Child Depression Inventory (CDI; Kovacs, 2015; Timbremont & Braet, 2002) administered to the participants. The results indicate that EMS is stable across adolescence and early-onset EMS can be used as a reliable predictor of adolescent depression.

During home visits, 36 U.S. American mother-toddler dyads were video-recorded during free-toy play, guided-educational play and a book-sharing activity, and mothers completed Retrospective Think-Aloud (RTA) interviews. Linguistic prejudice gets less attention than other forms of prejudice and Arabic linguistic attitudes are even more understudied. For a long time, quantitative Arabic sociolinguistics compared attitudes to Modern Standard Arabic and the colloquial dialects; and occasionally compared attitudes to different dialects within a country. Recent qualitative studies have started to examine the hierarchy between Western and Eastern Arabic dialects, but the status differences between the Eastern Arabic dialects are underexplored and no quantitative analysis has been done on the topic. This paper presents an indirect quantitative measure of status and solidarity rating differences between Egyptian and Emirati Arabic, as perceived by Egyptians and Emiratis living in the UAE. Results suggest that the Egyptian dialect might be uniformly viewed higher both on status and solidarity measures, at least among young women, who constituted the majority of participants and were solely represented in the stimuli. Directions for future methodological improvements are proposed to increase the generalizability of indirect quantitative language attitude measures.
Author provided keywords: Arabic dialect attitudes, matched-guise, indirect, Emirati, EgyptianRaafat, Karima. Passion for an Activity: A New Predictor of Sleep Quality2020-00892020AD-MC-0042020-0089
Scope and Contents
Previous research has proposed a dualistic model of passion. This model distinguishes between two types of passion: harmonious versus obsessive. The difference between the two lies in how the individual's passionate activity is regulated with other life domains. A large body of research has provided evidence of an association between one's type of passion and their physical as well as mental well-being. However, no studies have looked into the potential relationship between passion and sleep, a vital component of overall well-being. The present study aimed to fill this gap by looking into how the way individuals engage in their passionate activities can affect their sleep quality and, consequently, their overall health. We hypothesized that individuals with high levels of obsessive passion will experience overall worse sleep quality compared to individuals with high levels of harmonious passion. We carried out multiple regression analyses to examine this relationship in a sample of 1,506 individuals who responded to our online survey, with the results confirming our hypothesis.

The difference between the two lies in how the individual's passionate activity is regulated with other life domains. Scope and Contents
This study examined the potential overlap between face and word perception by asking whether long- or short-term reading experience might influence face processing. Specifically, observers tend to judge that a chimeric face made from two left half-faces is more similar to the original face than that made from two right half-faces, suggesting a 'left-side bias in face perception. To study the effects of long- and short-term reading experience on face processing, the present study compared native Arabic readers' (who are bilinguals) right-to-left reading direction, and native English readers' left-to-right reading direction, on their judgment of the chimeric faces that is most similar to the original face. They were tested before and after doing a reading task (reading a novel either in English or Arabic). In contrast to our prediction, all participants, regardless of their short- or long-term reading experience, were more likely to choose the right chimeric faces, suggesting that there is a right-side bias and no left-side bias, unlike previous studies predicted.

Scope and Contents
Although recent history has seen an upheaval of political uprisings, scholarship has not yet addressed questions surrounding the effects of mass protest on people's social values and ideology. As such, this study looked into pre- and post- revolution Twitter data from Sudan to explore whether the breakdown of a sociopolitically oppressive regime through protest has pronounced effects in shifting individuals' personal values. To test our hypothesis, we used the Linguistic Inquiry and Word Count (LIWC) software to analyze the language content of over 20,000 tweets produced by Sudanese users 6 months before and 6 months after the revolution. Results indicated that in the months following the revolution, tweets emanating from the Sudanese population were moving in a more progressive direction and included a lower proportion of words typically associated with "conservation" values, and a higher proportion of words pertaining to "openness" values as well as "anti- system" values. These findings offer a novel perspective on unstable political systems and illuminate that overthrowing a political regime can have far-reaching consequences on the psychology of individuals and extend beyond shaping a country's political framework.

Many forms of perceptual expertise have been examined in previous research, yet there is much less research on perceptual expertise of music. Researchers have observed perceptual interference in experts between two different object categories. We were interested to observe perceptual competition between musical notation and letter processing due to musical notes bearing meanings as letters. The goal was to examine perceptual competition in the brain between musical notation and letter processing within musical experts, though not within musical novices. We hypothesized reading musical notes and reading letters may also compete for similar processing resources, causing competition for experts, but novices would be unaffected. We tested participants online on 2 expertise tasks to distinguish skill levels, and 2 RSVP tasks, for identifying letter and symbol targets among musical distractors to observe perceptual interference within experts. We found that experts performed significantly better than novices within the letter search condition than novices. These results suggest that the experts' experience in music improved their performance in the tasks due to their encountering familiar objects than novices. Acquisition of a new skill may not compete for the same processing resources but may instead enhance performance in similar skills.

Scope and Contents
Vision and haptics(touch and proprioception) are essential to navigate through our environment and avoid obstacle collisions. Their multisensory integration has been shown to improve performances such as reaching and grasping. However, exploring whether or not it can help optimize obstacle avoidance –especially when the haptic input is provided by the non-target object– and aid grasping movements by reducing need for clearance around the obstacle, is limited. Here we investigated the lateral distance of the object from the obstacle, its velocity when overtaking the obstacle, and endpoint variability in an obstacle avoidance task. Participants moved the object around the obstacle from the start to end position in one condition(Visual), and did the same whilst holding the obstacle with the contralateral hand in the other condition(Visuo-Haptic). Our results showed only a moderate difference between visual and visuo-haptic information, with velocities at the obstacle being slightly higher in the Visuo-Haptic condition. In sum, holding the obstacle allows moderately faster movements toward the target position. Although these findings suggest that obstacle avoidance movements aided by only visual or both visual and haptic information are very similar, the question of whether haptic inputs from the non-target object can optimize obstacle avoidance remains open for exploration.

Scope and Contents
This study examines the role of moral reasoning in the relationship between passion and political activism. Building on prior work guided by the dualistic model of passion, we hypothesized that obsessive passion (OP) for an ideology would predict support for violent activism, while harmonious passion (HP) would predict support for peaceful activism. We further posited that the relationship between passion and support for different political behaviors would be mediated by moral reasoning. More specifically, we hypothesized that utilitarian reasoning would mediate the relationship between OP and violent activism, while deontological reasoning would mediate the relationship between OP and mainstream activism. Results from members of the Democratic Party in the US (N = 209) supported these hypotheses. These findings shed light on one of the factors that play into radicalization, and offer theoretical avenues for interventions to prevent violent extremism.
Author provided keywords: Passion, Political Activism, Moral Reasoning, Utilitarianism, Deontology, IdeologyDimova, Aleksandrina. Eating disorder symptoms and dopamine dependent working memory subprocesses2021-01252021AD-MC-0042021-0125
Scope and Contents
Eating disorders are serious psychiatric illnesses with high morbidity and mortality. Our understanding of their development from a cognitive and neurobiological standpoint is poor due to a number of limitations in the available literature including confounding effects of the ill state and flawed conceptualizations of the proposed contributing factors. The present study addressed these limitations by utilizing a non-clinical sample, a dimensional view of eating disorder symptoms, and a basic science approach to the proposed contribution of working memory (WM) in emergence of eating disorder symptoms. In a series of three experiments, we aimed to quantify the behavioral and neural association between dopamine dependent WM subprocesses and eating disorder symptoms. Although we found no significant associations, our findings have identified some differences in brain activation that may distinguish individuals with high eating psychopathology from controls. We discuss directions for further research to investigate these brain activation differences while also accounting for some of the existing limitations of research in the field of eating disorders.
Author provided keywords: working memory subprocesses, eating disorder symptoms, dopamineGurmu, Tsion. Is Selection in Working Memory Cost Free?2021-01302021AD-MC-0042021-0130
Scope and Contents
Attention can be directed to relevant information from the perceptual environment or to working memory (WM) representation. Research reveals that the process of selecting WM content has attention-like properties that are seen in the prioritization and de-prioritization of perceptual information. Given that ongoing attention tasks are known to disrupt WM, if the internal selection of WM content overlaps with attention, we would expect a general impairment in WM storage because of attentional selection processes. We designed a continuous delayed estimation task in which we manipulated the frequency of testing of items, thereby the selection process during maintenance of items in WM, to investigate how the process of selectively attending to items held in WM influences WM performance. Critically, we designed three retro-cue conditions in which we assess whether the retro-cue effect is present and whether selection has a cost on WM performance. We compared WM performance on the un-informative-medium and informative-medium conditions and found WM performance was reduced in the informative-medium cue condition, suggesting there might be a cost associated with internal selection of WM content.
Author provide keywords: Working Memory, Selective Attention, Retro-CueHristovska, Teodora. Neural Correlates of Working Memory and Mental Imagery 2021-01292021AD-MC-0042021-0129
Scope and Contents
People have the exceptional ability to recreate and transform visual content in their mind. Working memory and mental imagery are two abilities associated with mental representations supporting goal-directed behavior. While both abilities rely on the active retention and manipulation of content in mind, it is unknown whether the two share the same neural mechanisms. In an attempt to reconcile empirical and theoretical findings concerning the neural correlates of working memory and imagery, existing research has predominantly focused on the shared characteristics, with findings suggesting shared content of representations in early visual areas. In the current study, we aim to investigate the degree to which the two abilities overlap, by creating an experimental design which reflects the distinct theoretical constructs of working memory and imagery. To assess the degree to which the two overlap, we used multivoxel pattern analysis (MVPA), where we trained four classifiers to decode the identity of the stimulus and identity of the task between working memory and imagery.

The current study explores the effect of gender role attitudes (individual-level) and gender equality (country-level) on the life satisfaction of women in paid employment. The study made use of the European Values Study to assess progressive gender role attitudes (PGRA) and life satisfaction, and the Global Gender Gap Index to categorize 33 countries based on their gender equality scores. The initial hypothesis that the main relationship between life satisfaction and PGRA is moderated by both job level (leadership vs non-leadership) and gender equality (high vs low GGGI) was partially confirmed. The data indicated that the main relationship is only moderated by the level of gender equality at a national level but not the job level. Even though the results did not fully confirm the initial hypothesis regarding the role of leadership, they provide opportunities for new research directions.

The present research examines the relationship between passion for an ideology, need for cognitive closure (NFC), and political activism. Building on the dualistic model of passion (Bélanger, 2021; Vallerand, 2015) and recent theorizing on political activism (Webber et al., 2018), we predicted that obsessive (but not harmonious) passion would increase individuals' need for cognitive closure (NFC), which in turn would be positively related to support for violent political activism. Conversely, we predicted that NFC should be unrelated to peaceful political activism. Experimental results supported these predictions. These findings extend the literature on the underlying cognitive mechanisms related to the workings of radicalization.

Motion perception is the process of detecting and perceiving objects based on visual, vestibular, and proprioceptive cues. Although real-life provides plenty of cues for individuals to intercept objects and perceive their surroundings, perception in virtual environments represents a novel field that is not yet fully explored. In virtual reality (VR), motion perception can be examined through visual cues such as monocular, binocular, and the combination of both cues. Previous research indicated that combination cues provide the highest sensitivity for the observers to detect accurate motion-in-depth. Moreover, recent research has demonstrated that the addition of vestibular cues improves participant sensitivity to motion-in-depth in VR. Here, we first further explored the role of vestibular cues on participant accuracy of motion perception by entirely eliminating them and, second, explored gender as a variable in motion perception sensitivity. We first determined that visual-vestibular cue conflicts induced by mismatched display and expectation of visual consequences of head movement are not significant enough to influence participants' performance. Second, we found that participants with smaller interpupillary distance (IPD) have a higher sensitivity to motion perception. Surprisingly, our results have also shown that men have a higher sensitivity to motion perception despite their larger IPD.
Author provided keywords: motion, perception, binocular, monocular, VRZhu, Victoria. Assessing the Predictive Value of Maternal Parenting Behaviors On Attachment Security in the Chinese Context2021-01932021AD-MC-0042021-0193
Scope and Contents
The maternal sensitivity hypothesis posits that attachment security is an evolutionarily adaptive outcome from responsive and supportive caregiving. However, our understanding of attachment security in child development has largely been theorized and substantiated by Western scholarship. Critics suggest a culturally sensitive approach of considering attachment. We assessed the veracity of both claims on attachment security utilizing data from a 10-year longitudinal study conducted in Nanjing, China. Mother-child dyads were video recorded engaging in a play activity when the child was 14 and 24 months old. Using both waves, our study looked at maternal sensitivity behaviors, positive parenting and intrusiveness, and culture-sensitive socialization goal-oriented behaviors, encouragement of autonomy and connectedness. At age 10, the child completed a Chinese-adapted Attachment Script Assessment. Significant positive correlations were found between positive parenting, child's biological sex, and maternal education level with attachment security. Stepwise regression analysis revealed that positive parenting had a significant and robust effect on predicting secure base script knowledge while neither encouragement of autonomy nor connectedness added predictive value to the statistical model. Results suggest that secure attachment is constructed through positive contingent responsiveness as opposed to initiating direction from the caregiver.
Author provided keywords: attachment security, culture, maternal sensitivity, Chinese, childhood, infancy, autonomy, connectednessSocial Sciences Division Projects2014-2021EconomicsAl Mazrui, Shamma Sohail Faris Ghanem. Even though initiatives to increase the number of Emiratis in the private and public sector have been in place since 1980s, the results in the private sector are not impressive. Existing literature argues that Emirati workforce participation in the private sector is due to structural and attitudinal factors. Few studies exist that identify and explore Emirati females' attitudes towards and expectations of the labor market. This paper reports the results from a survey of 107 educated Emirati females who are in the transition from school to work. Their responses indicated an expectation to work and contribute to society. The findings show a great deal of similarity of attitudes towards the private and public sector. In contrast to previous research, the findings unveiled an inclination towards a multicultural environment, a perception of education and experience as important factors for obtaining a job (as opposed to wasta and "family background") and a lack of information on government initiatives and private sector opportunities. The findings lay the foundations for policy recommendations that would integrate this untapped pool of talent into the labor market.Expectation (Psychology)Vocational aspirationsWomenUnited Arab EmiratesAl Shaikh, Huda Abdulrahman Abdulla Abdulrahman. Global Wage Structures in the Context of the Nineties' Economic Liberalization: 1991-20042014-00631552014AD-MC-0042014-0063
Scope and Contents
In many economies, wage structures underwent drastic changes during the nineties. During this period, a rapid and deep process of trade liberalization was implemented. This paper studies industrial wage structures in a group of advanced and developing economies from 1991 to 2004. Workers' industry affiliation provides an important channel through which trade policies can affect the wage structure and inequality between skilled and unskilled workers. Specifically, this paper tests whether those sectors where import penetration deepened are also the sectors in which, ceteris paribus, a higher effect on wage structure is observed. Several significant results emerge from this analysis: (1) import penetration and tariffs are more correlated with wages for unskilled workers. (2) In unskilled- intensive industries, import penetration is positively correlated with wages. (3) In skilled-intensive industries, the correlation between import penetration and skilled workers is positive only to a certain cut-off level of tariff where it then becomes negative. (4) There is an overall convergence in skilled-unskilled industry wages, more so in advanced than in developed economies.Nineteen ninetiesImportsTradeTrade liberalizationWagesBassini Ortiz, David. This paper focuses on students' t-distributions and explores their application for option pricing. Generally, options are priced using Black-Sholes-Merton formula (BSM), but that methodology is inherently flawed: pre-supposes the lognormal nature of returns for the underlying security. Many researchers have attempted to formulate better approximations. The paper, Mixtures of t-distributions for finance and forecasting written by Giacomini, Gottschling, Haefke and White (2008), is of particular relevance where the usage of Student's t-distributions for option pricing is analysed. With fatter tails these distributions would resemble the actual stock options data more closely. However, after an attempt to replicate the results derived in the paper many discrepancies have been found. I study the relationship between output level, output growth and the savings rate using a specific characteristic of language as an instrumental variable. I find that an increase in savings leads to an increase in the level of output in the long run. For the effect of savings on the growth rate of output, my tests are inconclusive. Recent innovations in information technology have given people the option of sharing rather than owning physical assets. In the sharing economy, trust and reputation not only offers a premium, but also is necessary for transactions to take place. Consequently, digital peer-to-peer marketplaces like Airbnb that facilitate these transactions must consider how their platform's various mechanisms and features impact trust within their marketplace. This paper considers Airbnb's Instant Book option, a feature emphasizing convenience at the expense of trust, and shows how users opting in to this feature may face a discount by unknowingly signaling they are not as trustworthy. This paper studies the effect of awareness and relative performance on the consumption of water and electricity of students residing in the New York University Abu Dhabi dormitories. Students of the university, like many other residents in the United Arab Emirates, have little incentive to refrain from wasteful consumption. The dormitory residents are divided into two groups, control group and intervention group. The control group received no treatment, whereas the intervention group signed consent forms for participation in the experiment (first type of intervention) and received letters with information of where does their electricity and water consumption stand against their peers (second type of intervention). Consent form and a sample of peer comparison letters can be found in the appendix. The results show that the intervention group consumes more electricity but less water than the control group does. The asymmetry of electricity and water consumption can be explained with elasticity of demand and change in outside temperature. Several studies have sought to empirically test the theoretical model on the quantity-quality (Q-Q) trade-off of children in a family, first introduced by Gary Becker. Using a representative sample of data from three surveys in India (National Family Health Surveys), I conduct an empirical examination of the Q-Q trade-off of children. I use both linear and non-linear specifications of family size and study the nature of the trade-off both across time and the rural-urban divide. Furthermore, I adopt the use of an instrument (sex of the first born child) for family size to address the issue of endogeneity. My results suggest that the Q-Q trade-off holds and that the trade-off is surprisingly higher in urban areas. In addition, the trade-off appears to be declining over time, but marginally. Do individuals interpret ambiguous feedback optimistically or pessimistically when their self-esteem is at stake? Ertac (2011) finds that generally people overweigh negative performance feedback which leads to overly-pessimistic beliefs about ability. If these results are valid and generalizable, more studies are necessary to study the effects and extent of pessimism. Towards this end, I have replicated Ertac's experiment with a number of differences in methodology (performance groups, signal and payment). In confirmation of her findings, after participants received an accurate yet negative signal, there was a significant pessimistic effect in belief updating. This paper also compares belief-accuracy across two types of belief elicitation mechanisms – the quadratic scoring rule and the crossover mechanism. Through the use of large, global LBO transaction details from March 1987 to September 2014, we discover that issuers and debtors of high-yield debt differ in their perception of risk, indicating debt mispricing. Scope and Contents
Many NGOs rely on empathic arousal to raise funds. A common source of such arousal is a victim's story and image. In my paper, I study individual and group contributions made towards helping Moke, a 7-year-old child living in Democratic Republic of Congo, suffering from a dermatological condition. In my experiment, I control levels of identification by offering the image, name, and age of the victim to the treatment. My experiment confirms the existence of the "Identified Victim" effect in individuals: individuals contribute more towards helping an identified victim than an unidentified victim. Importantly, I extend the study to groups to find, surprisingly, that groups contribute more towards helping an unidentified victim than identified victim. Finally, the results also demonstrate that groups are less selfish than individuals: i.e. compared to individuals, groups contribute more towards the unidentified victim. To explain the findings, I propose a new theory that draws on the empathic altruistic hypothesis and the social comparison theory.Individuals (Persons)Groups, SocialIdentified victim effectRationalismFundraisingZhu, Weichen. Scope and Contents
Sierra Leone is one of the poorest countries in the world with one of the weakest health systems and lowest health statistics. Traditional institutions play an important role in large parts of the developing world. In Sierra Leone, the Paramount Chief, in particular, performs many essential formal duties such as tax collection, public service provision etc. Geography also plays an important role in health outcomes as areas near big cities and roads have more access to health resources and health professionals. This paper studies the impact of the quality of traditional institutions and geography on Sierra Leone's health outcomes. I will use an instrumental variable strategy to make causal claims about traditional institutions' impact on health outcomes and I will argue that geography is exogenous to make causal claims about geography's impact on health outcomes. I find that quality of traditional institutions does not have a significant impact on health outcomes, contrary to results obtained by Acemoglu et al in 2013. Proximity to nearby roads also does not have an impact on health outcomes. Proximity to a big city, on the other hand, has a significant, negative effect on 3 of my 7 health outcomes.Ayson, Tessa. Bargaining Over Risk: The Effect of Strategic Uncertainty On Fairness Concerns2016-005980322016We study how social preferences are affected by the presence of risk in bargaining contexts. We use a modified dictator game to differentiate between two types of fairness concerns, ex ante (probability-based) and ex post (outcome-based), and observe whether preferences can be explained exclusively by one of these types. We also adapt this modified game to include strategic uncertainty, in order to investigate how giving decisions change when both players have bargaining power. We predict that a combination of ex ante and ex post fairness concerns will best explain subjects' giving decisions under risk and in the presence of strategic uncertainty.AD-MC-0042016-0059

We look at how the uncertainty about future interest rates impacts the trading price relative to the flat fundamental value of the share, as well as the trading volume.
