An Experiment on Bargaining under Adverse Selection2020-01302020AD-MC-0042020-0130
Scope and Contents
When a buyer and seller bargain over the trade of a good, both parties have a tendency to cause costly and inefficient delay. Providing the opportunity to reject an offer more than once reduces total payoff because of time frictions, yet only allowing one rejection results in a significant reduction in trade frequency. In a laboratory experiment, buyers and sellers are asked to play different bargaining institutions of varying high type probabilities and time horizons. Findings suggest that participants are sensitive to increases in high type probabilities, as shown by an increase of both trade frequency and payoff. Although individual payoff rises, delay and inef- ficiency remain present even in games of non-severe adverse selection. When given the option of bargain type, buyers eventually tend towards the one-shot bargain, yet are not capable of consistently providing an offer that would ensure trade with the seller. As a result, buyers do not extract levels of individual profit equal to that of the ex-ante expected payoff. Behavioural preferences for loss aversion and fairness also play a significant role in determining how efficiency is distributed between buyer and seller.

This paper explores the relationship between regional income inequalities and their impact on the electoral manifestation of Euroscepticism in the 2019 elections to the European Parliament. Colombia has hosted about 35% of 4.6 million Venezuelan Refugees since 2015. This paper uses an online survey to gather data and measure consumer willingness to pay for efforts supporting Venezuelan refugees in Colombia. I also implement a priming mechanism through a sentence-descrambling exercise in order to increase saliency and sensitization to the crisis in Colombia, and measure its effect on respondents' generosity, empathy and willingness to pay. I find that priming robustly and consistently increases respondents' levels of generosity and empathy. However, such effects do not extend to significant increases in consumer willingness to pay. Taken together, these findings suggest a clear disconnect between self-identification with generous and empathic attitudes and real willingness to monetarily support programs aiding Venezuelan refugees. As a pioneer in the field, this paper opens the discussion of consumer attitudes toward supporting this crisis and highlights the urgency to motivate an integrated approach to refugee aid by understanding consumer support for such aid efforts.

The European Commission (EC) has the exclusive power of initiating laws within the European Union (EU). There are 28 Commissioners within the EC, each of whom has been nominated by their national government and confirmed by the President of the EC. Every Commissioner holds a specific portfolio, and some of these portfolios, such as Energy and Internal Market, have scopes directly tied to specific industries. Therefore, EU laws initiated by Commissioners with such portfolios directly affect firms within those market sectors. While Commissioners are obliged to be free of national bias, prior qualitative studies have suggested the existence of national interests in the work and decision-making processes of the EC. Thus, this research seeks to empirically answer whether commissioners are biased towards firms from their national countries. To study this, this research employs the event-study methodology and stock market data to test for the presence of abnormal returns in national stock markets in response to two market shocks. The test found no significant market reactions to both market shocks, therefore concluding that there is no significant empirical evidence for national bias among Commissioners with key economic portfolios.

I hypothesized that societal conservatism has a negative impact on individuals' earnings, based on the theoretical framework that conservative beliefs imply that people pay less attention to money and more to family and community. In this Capstone, the econometric model tests the relationship between variables obtained for all 380 counties in Poland. First, I develop a standard OLS model, with average salary as dependent variable, and selected measures of conservatism and liberalism (respectively: relative number of marriages and family size, and relative number of singles and divorces). Then I extend it to include instrumental variable of city status for each county. The results for both Eastern and Western parts of Poland support the hypothesis that conservative ideology is negatively correlated with individual earnings.

This paper presents evidence that President Trump's Twitter statements regarding the US-China economic conflict impact the expectations of investors on the long-term performance of the US economy. The average effect of an additional standard deviation of "bad" tweets is around negative 4.83 bps (for the 2- to 5-year maturity bonds) on the same day and around negative 5.07 bps a day after (for the 2- to 10-year maturity bonds). A multitude of tweets that bring bad news would decrease the yield on the 10-, 20- and 30-year maturity bonds by negative 22.4 bps, on average, on the same day. These results convey that market participants could believe that President Trump's trade policy is recessionary and will be difficult to revert in the future.

Trinidad and Tobago's labor market today is largely composed of Indo-Trinidadian (IT) and Afro- Trinidadian (AT) groups of an approximately equal size. This is as a result of the country's colonial history, which first brought African slaves and then Indian indentured laborers to replace labor- deficient plantations after the abolition of slavery. Since this period, latent ethnic rivalry has been documented between the two groups. The complexities of the ethnic relations in Trinidad and Tobago causes some questions to arise regarding the implications of its colonial history on ethnic relations between the two groups and on the economic outcomes of the groups today. The goal of this paper is to determine whether perceptions that ITs enjoy a higher standard of living today when compared to ATs is actually true by devising a unique measure of standard of living (SOL) which amalgamates various household characteristics for the time period 1970-2011. This paper also discerns whether the change of betting currency from real money to virtual currency had an impact on the accuracy of the predicted outcome based on bets placed before the matches. This paper finds that even though the Counter-Strike betting market is newer and not as mature as other traditional prediction markets, the betting market was weak-form efficient, in both real money and virtual currency periods.
Author contributed keywords: Efficient Market Hypothesis, Betting Markets, Esports, Maximum Likelihood EstimationPetrovicova, Tereza. A study of religiosity and donations: Does religion make its believers more prosocial?2020-01442020AD-MC-0042020-0144
Scope and Contents
This research measures the effects of three different primes, neutral (control group), religion-salient (Treatment I), religion and in-group-salient (Treatment II) on the donation behavior of Muslim subjects. Data for this experiment was collected online using Qualtrics as a survey platform and includes 372 Muslim participants in India for which data was collected online using Qualtrics. Participants who were primed with religion were biased against the non-Muslim charity and donated a significantly lower percentage of their earnings to this charity. Otherwise, there were no other significant treatment effects, which could be explained by the violence between Hindus and Muslims in India at the time of the experiment creating strong religious and ingroup sentiments among the Muslim population in India. Nonetheless, there was a correlation between survey measures of religiosity and donations. In particular, participants who scored higher in the religious activities and stance on Islamic issues dimension donated larger shares of their earnings to charity. There was also a significant gender and age effect as women and older participants donated more on average.
Author contributed keywords: Religion, Prosocial behavior, Donations, IslamRamlawi, Muhannad. The Effects of Recent Refugee Influxes on Different Regions in Germany2020-01392020AD-MC-0042020-0139

Germany has witnessed several large-scale refugee influxes from parts of the Middle East and Africa over the past decade. This paper studies the ways in which these recent refugee influxes have affected social and labor market indicators in the different regions of Germany. Using the fixed effects model as the core methodological framework, the paper finds that refugees lower unemployment and have no significant impact on safety standards in Germany's different regions. The paper also deduces that refugees do not significantly affect the agricultural labor market, but have a positive, significant, and almost equal effect on employment in the manufacturing sector and employment in the industrial sector.

Many aspects of the firearm market in the United States are poorly understood by both economists and policy makers. This paper attempts to take a closer look at the market utilizing a novel data set and create a model to explain the variety of prices found from 2007 to 2017. The paper focuses on AR-15's,notable for the amount of media attention it receives in and out of the US. This is done due to time and data constraints, as well as the relative newness of the AR-15 market. The model this paper constructs also integrates the level of criminal demand in Mexico, as measured by the number of homicides. This paper is the starting point for expanding understanding of the firearm market for both those participating in the market, and those attempting to regulate it.

This paper examines the effects of 74 undemocratic events on the Turkish Stock Market. The events are collected from LexisNexis and local Turkish newspapers. Stock market data are acquired from Borsa Istanbul, which is the Turkish Stock Market. Undemocratic events are divided into five categories; Imprisonment of Journalists, Dismissal of Public Sector Employees, Imprisonment of Politicians, Acquisition of Mayorships, and Closure of Media Outlets, Universities and Hospitals. 36 undemocratic events were found to have significant effect on the stock market. This study is the first extensive event study on the Turkish Stock Market with the creation of a new dataset of undemocratic events.

This paper considers overtime work hours and gender pay gap as contributors to low female labor participation in economies afflicted by issues of aging crisis and low fertility rates. Even though generous parental leaves are provided, existing literature finds mixed evidence of its impact on female labor participation after childbirth in Japan. Using empirical evidence, our findings suggest that taking parental leave negatively affects mother's employment status. Furthermore, full-time workers are less likely to be employed after taking parental leave.

Scope and Contents
When in 2018 President Trump accused China of lucrative trading practices, he began imposing protectionist policies in the globalized US economy, causing many worries for businesses with international supply chains. Later in 2019, the series of bilateral import tariffs enacted by the leaders of both nations became termed as the US-China "trade war". This paper uses the event study methodology to evaluate how announcements of tariffs and negotiations affected equity markets in either country during the "war". Results indicate that equity indices have mixed reactions to the news, as the American market performs as expected while the Chinese market does the opposite. Possible reasons include uncertainty, differing index composition, and asymmetric information. Further investigation also discovers a lack of transparency in both equity markets.

This paper attempts to explore the determinants of and motivations for entrepreneurship in India, with a focus on the impact of individual perceptions and behavioral factors on future and established entrepreneurial activity. Using the Global Entrepreneurship Monitor's individual level data for India, the paper finds that behavioral factors seem to be likely determinants of entrepreneurial participation, especially in the established business owners category. Specifically, business opportunity perception, the presence of business networks and positive perception of personal entrepreneurial skills are likely determinants for established entrepreneurship and predictors for future entrepreneurship. These results offer recommendations for future policy work to increase entrepreneurship.
Author provided keywords: Entrepreneurship, India, determinants, motivations, behavioral factorsShao, Christine. Unions in Bankruptcy: A Help or a Hindrance?2020-01212020AD-MC-0042020-0121
Scope and Contents
Chapter 11 Bankruptcy in the United States allows firms to reorganize their capital structure rather than liquidate. This form of bankruptcy allows firms to emerge from bankruptcy and continue operating, retaining much of their staff. Labor unions take part in the bankruptcy negotiation process by obtaining seats on creditors' committees; employees in firms without labor union presence are not otherwise represented in bankruptcy negotiations. This paper studies the effect of labor union presence on firms' likelihood to emerge from bankruptcy and subsequently survive for five years. I find that labor union presence is positively correlated with emergence from bankruptcy for large, public companies. No significant correlation is found between labor union presence and survival for five years after bankruptcy.
Author contributed keywords: Bankruptcy, Emergence, Labor Union, Chapter 11, Firm SurvivalShkurynskyy, Sergey. A Dynamic Study of the Impact of Oil Price Changes on the US Stock Market2020-01422020AD-MC-0042020-0142

This paper investigates how changes in oil prices have influenced the performance of the US stock market as a whole (SP 500) and selected energy-dependent industry groups, such as oil and gas exploration and production companies, energy equipment companies, manufacturing and construction companies over a time period of 30 years, from 1990 to 2020. The key findings of this paper indicate that the performance of the US economy as a whole was positively influenced by an increase in oil prices starting in 2010 and was negatively influenced before 2010. For oil and gas exploration and production companies, energy equipment companies, the relationship between oil price changes and the industry performance was also positive. For construction and manufacturing industry group, the relationship was generally positive. This paper has important implications in such areas of economics as investment portfolio optimization, hedging risks, government regulation, and public and private spending.
Author provided keywords: US Stock Market, SP500, Oil, Government Bonds, OPECSmit, Martin. The Impact of Mobile Digitalization on Financial Development: The Introduction of Spotify and Netflix in Latin America and the Caribbean2020-00102020AD-MC-0042020-0010
Scope and Contents
This research focuses on the impact that the introduction of Netflix and Spotify had on financial access in Latin America and the Caribbean (LAC) from 1980 to 2017. Through prediction modelling and regression analysis using interaction variables and fixed effects, I anticipated that the exogenous introduction of Netflix and Spotify in LAC would increase financial access due to subsequent increases in digitalization, op- erationalized as cell phone subscriptions and internet users. This study finds, counter to my hypotheses, that for a majority of LAC countries, the digitalization intervention that occurred with the introduction of the biggest players in the consumer subscription service industry had a non-positive effect on financial access. I find that LAC could be missing an opportunity to improve financial access through mobile digitalization, as lower classes are not equipped with the financial or technological literacy necessary to best utilize it. The threshold effects at play in LAC mitigate the potential eco- nomically egalitarian effects of increased financial access. This investigation provides a cautionary tale for governments looking to advance financial development by increasing digitalization without creating inclusive financial policy to support it.

The European Financial Crisis had a major impact on the EU's peripheral countries, as they continued falling into a multi-year debt crisis starting from 2009 and reaching Ireland by the end of 2010. This paper examines the impact of the rumors about the bailout on the Irish financial markets during the banking crisis of 2010, testing the hypothesis that only the financial sector will be significantly and positively affected by the news. Contrary to our expectations, the findings of an Abnormal Return analysis reflect that the financial sector suffered from the start of the rumors, while the Industrial and the Oil and Gas companies benefited.

Access to irrigation water is an important agricultural input that has significant effects on the socioeconomic outcomes of farmers in developing contexts. While there are many studies investigating the impacts of specific forms of irrigation, little is known about how irrigation, broadly considered, affects the outcome of female labor force participation. In this paper, we perform a descriptive study of female labor force participation in India, followed by a causal analysis on how it is impacted by irrigation. We find that irrigation shares a statistically significant and positive relationship with female and male labor force participation. Our analysis suggests that the effect of irrigation on labor force is smaller for women than for men. This research is an important first step in understanding the priorities faced by female farmers with regards to labor force participation.

In this paper, I look at the effects of working part-time during primary or junior high school on dropout behavior after mandatory schooling years in Indonesia. I obtain my data from the Indonesian Family Life Survey (IFLS) and use a binary choice probit model to see if working during schooling provides a strong signal that a child will drop out of school immediately after mandatory schooling years. Moreover, I suggest a Linear Probability Model (LPM) with Instrumental Variable (IV) approach to elicit causal effects and find that working during primary or junior high school leads to a lower dropout rate among children in Indonesia.
Author contributed keywords: child work, dropout behavior, IV, causal effects, Indonesia.Turdaliev, Komiljon. Innovating an Innovation Index2020-01492020AD-MC-0042020-0149

In both academic and policy circles, there is a growing interest in understanding the role of innovation and productivity at the firm level. However, innovation measurement remains to be challenging as innovation is characterized by various dimensions, which have been mostly studied separately in the literature. In this paper, we study innovation activities in US public firms by constructing a novel index to measure innovation and using this index to examine the role of innovation on subsequent operating performance of the firms. Our results indicate that the constructed innovation index has a much more robust and positive relationship with subsequent firm performance than earlier methods proposed in the literature.
Author contributed keywords: Innovation, Multidimensional Index Model, Return on AssetsXu, Mark. Wealth, Wages, and Working Hours: Evidence from the Panel Study of Income Dynamics2020-01522020AD-MC-0042020-0152
Scope and Contents
Both theoretical frameworks and empirical findings regarding the effects of wealth and wealth shocks on wages and labor earnings are mixed. Understanding these effects has profound implications on economic theory, particularly in the field of labor economics, and policymaking. This project hopes to contribute to the literature on this topic. I use the Panel Study of Income Dynamics dataset from 1997 to 2007 to study the effects of wealth and wealth shocks on the wage rate, annual labor income, and working hours. With a set of six specifications, I find that these effects are all statistically insignificant at the 0.01 level. When they are occasionally significant at the 0.05 level, the effects are small. The results suggest that the wage rate, labor income, and hours of work are, for the most part, not influenced by wealth and wealth shocks.
Author contributed keywords: Wealth, Wages, Labor Supply, Labor Income, PSIDYoo, Byunghoon. Impact of North Korean Provocation on Financial Performances of Different Industries in South Korea and the U.S. 2020-01182020AD-MC-0042020-0118

With this research, I attempted to look into the impact of North Korean provocation, specifically of ICBM and nuclear testing, on the financial performance of overall South Korean and the U.S. stock markets as well as different industries such as defense, construction, and tourism among others. All in all, the South Korean overall market moved according to our hypothesis while the U.S. one did not. Specifically, the South Korean market showed a decreasing cumulative abnormal return following the events while the U.S. market did not respond. Defense industries from both countries have responded positively to the North Korean provocations. Among ten inter-Korea cooperative industries, six have responded negatively towards the events following our prediction, two have not been impacted, and two have moved in a positive direction. There was an overriding issue of deriving significance out of the results except in two industries: U.S. defense and South Korean road construction. Investors should not expect that all the inter-Korea cooperative industries would behave in the same ways and must be aware of the differences in respective industries.

This paper focuses on the changes to women's labor force participation after the revolution in Egypt, in both the short and medium run. This analysis uses panel data from the Egypt Labor Market Panel Survey (ELMPS), focusing on the years 2006, 2012 and 2018. Using difference-in-difference specifications, the paper investigates the changes to the labor force participation of women in different age groups. The paper finds that overtime, including both periods after the revolution, women's participation in labor has decreased, where younger women are the least likely to participate in labor. Nevertheless, the paper also found that younger women experienced the most positive change after the revolution, relative to older women. The results suggest a possible convergence in the labor force participation rates of women across all ages.
Author provided keywords: Female LFP, Arab Spring, Egyptian labor market, Political EconomyAlawadhi, Alya. Invisible Oil Spills: Tracing Art to Oil2021-01732021AD-MC-0042021-0173

In recent years, the arts and cultural sector has enjoyed increasing attention in economic and political arenas for its rife diversification and growth potential. This is particularly true of oil-based economies, as best exemplified by the member states of the G.C.C. Yet, the relationship between energy, particularly oil, and art has largely been overlooked by scholars, complicating policy setting and compromising the long-term growth of this sector. This paper documents the long-term relationship between oil production and the arts and cultural sector. It models its analysis at both the state-level, using U.S. data, and at the country-level, using G.C.C. data. Despite the different data sources and variables employed in the two studies, they both find a positive association between oil production and the size of the arts and cultural sector in oil-based economies. Untangling the causal mechanism behind this association is the grounds for future research.
Author provided keywords: arts and cultural sector; oil economies; GCC; United StatesAlhosani, Ahmed Esmail Ahmed Khalaf. Sectoral Diversification in the UAE2021-01392021AD-MC-0042021-0139

With the rise of alternative fuels and growing concerns over the environmental sustainability of the global economies' consumption behaviors since the turn of the century, more attention has been devoted to the diversification of the United Arab Emirates' economy to achieve a sustainable future. However, despite the growing interest in export and labor diversification, there is a lack of research in economic sectoral diversification. This paper will define economic sectoral diversification and introduce a measurement for it that is inspired by other diversification indices. Using that measurement, a ranking of the countries' diversification levels will be produced, and a series of regression analyses is performed to study the relationship between economic sectoral diversification and some macroeconomic variables. This research finds that the UAE is well-diversified relative to the reference group.
Author provided keywords: Diversification, Sectoral GDP, UAE, OilAlmehairi, Saif Mohammed. Understanding the Changing Nascent Entrepreneurial Attitudes & Activity in the United Arab Emirates: An Update on the Entrepreneurship Landscape 2021-01642021AD-MC-0042021-0164

The aim of this paper is to understand the changing entrepreneurial behavior in the United Arab Emirates (UAE). This paper examines cross-sectional data, where a bivariate probit regression model is applied to two waves of the Global Entrepreneurship Monitor (GEM) data. The anticipated finding is there are improving attitudes towards pursuing entrepreneurial ventures. This is critical for understanding how the UAE should effectively develop legislative policies pertaining to entrepreneurship. The paper concludes by discussing the need for the UAE to realize the essential components needed to diversify and dynamize the economy by implementing regulations that positively impact the changing entrepreneurship landscape and allocate investments that will allow UAE-based entrepreneurship to reach its optimal level.
Author provided keywords: United Arab Emirates; entrepreneurship; behavior; attitudes; activityAlqubaisi, Saif Ali. Does Oil Rent Dependence Affect Entrepreneurship? A Comparative Analysis of The MENA Region versus The Rest of The World2021-01632021AD-MC-0042021-0163
Scope and Contents
Extensive empirical evidence shows that rents produced from natural resources like oil reduce engagement in productive entrepreneurship as they shift incentives towards rent-seeking. This study has a geographical focus on the Middle East and North Africa, which, despite their recent efforts to increase entrepreneurial activity, still lag behind the rest of the world. The study compares the nexus between oil rent dependence and entrepreneurship in the MENA region with that of the rest of the world. Using the number of newly registered limited liability firms every year as a proxy for entrepreneurship, we find empirical evidence that higher oil rent dependence in an economy diminishes entrepreneurship levels globally but find no statistically significant relationship between oil rent dependence and entrepreneurship for the MENA region specifically. The findings have important policy implications, especially for oil-rich countries.
Author provided keywordsAmmar, Mohamed Ben. Asset Correlation Shocks at times of Crisis: In Application to the CVC2021-01742021AD-MC-0042021-0174
Scope and Contents
Following the GFC of 2009, there has been emerging focus on the risk-on/risk-off regimes following high market volatility times. This shed light on the assumption that cross-asset correlations within markets seem to notably increase and persist at times of high market uncertainty. This phenomenon is more relevant to the Covid-19 crisis, as the pandemic enforced aggressive economic structural changes that are significantly influencing asset classes' behaviors and pricing. The onset of the crisis itself has distorted traditional market betas within the equity space and also created relative winners and losers geographically too. This capstone proposal aims to set the groundwork for the main thesis: Is there a CVC Asset Correlation Shock affecting the efficiency of portfolio diversification? Theoretical work will first illustrate the evidence of increased cross-asset correlations in the CVC. This will then be reflected by the portfolios constructed in the study. Based on the attained conclusions, the research will make a strong case for the optimal portfolio strategy and try to quantify the correlation shock.
Author provided keywords: Cross-asset, Contagion, Domestic Diversification, CVC, Granger Causality, Correlation ShockAriyaratne, Sudaraka. Rethinking Winners and Losers of Trade: A Firm-Level Analysis of Trade Reform in Sri Lanka2021-01692021AD-MC-0042021-0169
Scope and Contents
Post-independence Sri Lanka has gone through capricious shifts in trade policy, with the economic policies of successive governments moving back and forth between trade liberalization and protectionism. Yet little is known about the impact that these reforms have had on domestic firms and consumers. In this study, I exploit large shifts in Sri Lanka's trade policy in recent decades to study what lower and higher input tariffs mean for the survivability, size, and the markups of domestic firms, as well as consumer prices. Using novel firm-level panel data and a difference-in-difference identification strategy, I show that domestic firms that remain in the market following trade liberalization and expand both their production levels and markups are the real winners of lower input tariffs, while firms that are forced out of the market are outright losers. Firms that enter the market anew under higher input tariffs are winners of trade protectionism, while firms that were already in the market but now have to downsize their production levels and also earn less profits are losers. Consumers are neither complete winners nor complete losers.
Author provided keywords: Trade Liberalization, Protectionism, Input Tariffs, Industrial Organization, Firms, Sri LankaAruina, Daniella. The Impact of Oil Prices on Russian and Saudi Arabian Stock Markets. 2020 Case Study2021-01452021AD-MC-0042021-0145

Spring 2020 had a major impact on oil prices and stock markets of two of the world's largest oil-exporting countries, Russia and Saudi Arabia, due to the effects of COVID-19 and the Russian-Saudi oil-price war. This paper analyses the relationship between oil prices and Russian and Saudi stock markets in 2019 - 2020 using structural vector autoregression and compares the results to the Chinese stock market, since China is an oil-importer that was also affected by COVID-19, but not the oil-price war. Our findings reflect that both Russian and Saudi stock markets follow a pattern of declined dependence after the start of the oil-price war and the COVID-19 pandemic. In contrast, there was no significant impact of oil price shocks on the Chinese stock market both in 2019 and 2020 due to the oil-importing nature of the country, as well as its non-involvement in the oil-price war.
Author provided keywords: Oil price shocks; Stock markets; Oil-exporting countriesBaig, Mohammed. What is the relationship between remittances and savings in Pakistan?2021-01612021AD-MC-0042021-0161

Foreign remittances are an important economic sector for Pakistan. Literature focuses on the direct relationship between remittances and economic growth in Pakistan, but has conflicting results. This paper attempts to use an indirect approach to studying this relationship, by looking at a driver of economic growth: savings. I use Pakistan Standards of Living Measurement (PSLM) survey data to empirically analyse the relationship between remittances and savings. I do this directly and also by looking at the relationships remittances have with household income and expenditures – since their difference is savings. In theory, if in response to remittance inflow savings increase, there should be a positive shift in the steady state stock of capital. As this paper shows, despite several limitations and concerns to be cautious of, there are statistically significant relationships between remittances and the aforementioned key variables in Pakistan.
Author provided keywords: remittance, saving, growth, expenditure, PakistanBåsund, Karina Lisboa. Do Rainfall Shocks Impact Agricultural Technology Adoption Differently by Gender? The Case of Ethiopia2021-01532021AD-MC-0042021-0153
Scope and Contents
Technology adoption and productivity growth in the agricultural sector are essential for poverty reduction. A vast literature has explored incentives and barriers to adopting fertilizer, the benefits of which depend on adequate rainfall. Female headed households (FHH) have, in previous literature, been shown to adopt less fertilizer, yet factors beyond lack of market access remain largely unconsidered. This capstone explores if, how, and why FHH's fertilizer use responds differently to rainfall shocks than that of male headed households (MHH). I use four rounds of panel data from the Ethiopian Rural Household Survey containing household-level information on agriculture, livestock, and consumption, combined with rainfall data at the village level. I find that FHH use significantly less fertilizer than MHH when rainfall is below the expected level of rainfall. For each additional child and consumption expenditure a FHH has, the household uses less fertilizer than MHH, and livestock does not modify FHH's fertilizer use as it does for MHH. The findings of this capstone suggest that certain mechanisms discussed in previous literature may not be as effective at modifying the response to rainfall shocks for FHH as for MHH.
Author provided keywords: rainfall, shock, gender, fertilizer, technology adoptionCaro, Sebastian. Non-Linear Hedge Fund Prediction Models using Public Sentiment Data about Firms' ESG performance2021-01672021AD-MC-0042021-0167
Scope and Contents
I exploit proprietary unstructured Natural Language Processing data measuring public sentiment of 492 US public companies' ESG performance and different financial metrics over a twelve-year time period, to study the non-linearity between public sentiment metrics regarding ESG performance and financial metrics. I prove through my algorithmic non-parametric portfolio that there is a divergence between public sentiment about a firm's ESG performance and its financial metrics. This fact allows me to prove, by designing a parametric non-linear portfolio without data accumulation and a parametric non-linear portfolio with data accumulation, that a long strategy focusing on a positive screening on high-ranked ESG companies outperforms a negative screening on low-ranked ESG sentiment companies. I test for robustness using a Fama-French five factor model, focusing on the alpha-generating capabilities of the best performing portfolio, namely, the parametric non-linear portfolio with data accumulation. I further expand on the arbitrage opportunity that this positive screening mechanism using divergence on ESG and financial data represents, concluding that eventually, this noise will disappear as market agents act upon this information.
Author provided keywords: Hedge Funds, Portfolio Management, ESG, Machine Learning, Stocks, NLPCheng, Enshu. Does Knowledge Follow Gravity Model: Evidence from AI Citation Network2021-01472021AD-MC-0042021-0147
Scope and Contents
This study applies the gravity model on the Artificial Intelligence (AI) citations network to study the impact, productivity and over-impact of AI research across world cities. Over-impact is the extent to which a source city's academic impact to the destination city exceeds the expected impact given the cities' sizes, the distance and other cultural factors such as language and colonial relationship. The study finds that the gravity model explains the data very well in which AI impact is found to be positively and significantly correlated with the sizes of two cities and inversely related to distances. Distance between cities explains part of global AI citations patterns, with most of the correlation due to citations to papers produced within cities or a small radius. The global network of cities reveals asymmetric impact above benchmark. The West is over-impacting the East significantly while the East under-impacts the West. This study also plots the global centers of gravity (CGs) of AI impact, productivity, and over-impact from 1990 to 2017 and finds that the CGs have been consistently shifting to the East in all three measures.
Author provided keywords: Knowledge, Gravity, Citation, Artificial Intelligence, ImpactDoumanov, Martin. Can we profit from corporate M&A?2021-01582021AD-MC-0042021-0158
Scope and Contents
This thesis studies the factors influencing takeover prediction and the potential to generate returns based on a probability-driven takeover strategy. A conditional logistic regression model is used to predict the effect of fifteen variables divided into four categories including firm size, inefficient management, undervaluation, and leverage and liquidity, as well as an industry dummy that takes the value of 1 if there has been an acquisition in the same industry in the year studied. The used includes a sample of 444 observations of target companies listed on the London Stock exchange for the period between 1989 and 2019, as well as a non-target sample of 7,942 observations of companies listed on the London Stock Exchange that have not experienced a takeover bid over the same period. The empirical evidence finds that a conditional logistic regression model is a good tool to reliably identify takeover targets, with the highest three decile portfolios containing nearly 70% of all targets. Additionally, it is possible to generate positive market-adjusted returns but the evidence doesn't support the hypothesis that probability-driven trading strategies can generate abnormal returns.
Author provided keywords: takeover prediction, investment strategy, conditional logistic regression, abnormal returnsHassan, Amna. What Does Islamization Do? The impact of religious education on schooling of women in Pakistan 2021-01412021AD-MC-0042021-0141
Scope and Contents
Religion plays an important role in the lives of people, especially when the state adopts policies with underlying religious foundations. This capstone estimates the impact of Islamization of the education system in Pakistan in the 1980s. We exploit arguably larger exposure to Islamization in rural Pakistan where students have fewer private education options to estimate impacts using a difference-in-difference approach. The difference in the difference between rural and urban women increased after Islamization with the education of rural women stagnating in comparison to urban women. We also find a statistically significant differential effect of exposure on women by their area of residence for the ability to read, write and do mathematical calculations. Similarly, the difference in difference between urban and rural women increased for number of days and months worked. Lastly, we find that the probability of head of household identifying as female increases in rural areas after Islamization. This capstone takes a step towards better identification, but further research is required to rigorously test a causal impact.

Airbnb is one of the key pioneers of the sharing economy which has grown rapidly over the last decade. Airbnb income has become a vital component of people's lives allowing them to make ends meet. This paper examines whether there is evidence of social inequality on Airbnb, specifically investigating a host's earnings. We further existing literature by constructing a unique dataset for this paper using host's profile pictures from Airbnb and collecting data from five major cities in the US on hosts' age, race and gender. We then study the effect of age, race and gender on the host's earnings which are determined by the price and demand of a listing. We also control for a rich set of variables in our analysis and find statistically significant evidence of race-based differences in earnings on Airbnb.

We apply the algorithm developed by Hatfield and Milgrom to a carpooling problem. In particular, we use their generalized version of the Deferred Acceptance Algorithm, hereafter denoted as the HM algorithm, to organize carpooling. We put preferences on road segments and identify road segments with one or multiple cars. We show that the HM algorithm gives rise to stable and efficient allocation of cars and riders.
Author provided keywords: HM algorithm, trips, substitutability, stability, socially efficientKoyachew, Anania. An Analysis of Determinants of financial inclusion in Ethiopia2021-01362021AD-MC-0042021-0136
Scope and Contents
The study analyzed various determinants of financial inclusion (FI) in Ethiopia. The study analyzed and addressed some of the most common FI determinants in Ethiopia. Descriptive and econometric analysis methods were used to determine and evaluate the determinants of FI. Mainly the study focused on understanding the determinants of FI on socio-economic and demographic factors such as gender, education, financial literacy, financial capability, and FI barriers. The analysis found that better education, financial literacy, gender, living in urban or rural areas, living in the capital city, religion, and preference for formal financial services are associated with a significant level of FI. The majority of the citizen in Ethiopia cannot access financial services for both voluntary and involuntary reasons. Notably, distance from financial service institutions is a significant barrier to FI. The study suggests non-traditional financial services and products such as agent banking and mobile banking should be promoted and expanded in rural Ethiopia. Notably, most Ethiopians live in rural areas, and distance from financial service institutions is a significant barrier to FI. Therefore, the government should increase traditional banking and microfinance branches and promote government-to-people transfer to digitalize such as utility bills and school fees, both in urban and rural areas.

Sustainable Investing & Islamic investing: Does Practicing Shariah Compliance Have An Impact On A Firm's Environmental, Social, Governance ("ESG") Score?2021-01512021AD-MC-0042021-0151
Scope and Contents
For every dollar invested in the US, one third of that takes into consideration some form of ESG criteria (US SIF, 2020). Our study takes into account the growing trend of sustainable investing and attempts to propose shariah compliant equities as a comparable investment alternative. In spite of previous literatures' efforts to show the financial outperformance of a shariah-sustainable investment, none have attempted to quantify the "sustainability premium" inherent in shariah compliant equities. Using a dataset of 2,711 ESG rated firms from 6 economic regions across 10 sectors, results indicate that shariah compliance results in a 4% to 10% increase in ESG score compared to non-shariah compliant equities. The variation in the "sustainability premium" is sector dependent, with technology driven and asset light equities taking the lead.
Author provided keywords: sustainable investing, islamic investing, shariah compliance, ESGMao, Cora. The Effects of Health Insurance Schemes Consolidation in China2021-01442021AD-MC-0042021-0144
Scope and Contents
The Chinese government established the new Urban Rural Resident Basic Medical Insurance (URRMI), unifying Urban Resident Basic Medical Insurance (URMI) and New Rural Cooperative Medical Insurance (NRCMI). This study examines the impact of the health insurance scheme consolidation's effects on the elderly population's health. The analysis drew panel data from the China Health and Retirement Longitudinal Study (CHARLS) and employed a fixed-effect model to control within-unit differences. Our findings show that there is no statistically significant result to support that the new unified URRMI insurance scheme improved the participants' health status and primary health- care access. Regarding health expenditure, results show that for the 45 years old and above subjects, the unified new health insurance scheme lead to statistically significant decrease in percentage of out-of-pocket expenditure for outpatient care. However, we do not observe similar pattern with inpatient care.
Author provided keywords: Health insurance, Chinese health policy, Fixed-effect modelMo, Emily. The Effect of Transportation, Green, and Municipal Hard Infrastructure Investment on Commodity Housing Prices in China 2021-01462021AD-MC-0042021-0146
Scope and Contents
China's commodity housing prices have been increasing at an enormous speed over the past decades. It is important to understand the determinants of the variation in housing prices. Infrastructure might play a role behind it: infrastructure might have a positive effect on housing prices by adding more attractiveness to a region, yet it might also have a negative effect by decreasing the congestion in tier-1 cities by linking them to tier-2 and 3 cities. This capstone project aims to explore the following questions: What is the impact of infrastructure investment on housing prices in China? How does this impact vary over time? By doing a panel regression with prefecture city level data, I have found that highway construction has a significant and negative correlation with the housing prices in tier-1 cities in China, while it has a significant yet positive correlation with tier-2 cities' housing prices. This finding corresponds to the hypothesis that infrastructure could help decrease the congestion in developed cities, thus driving down the housing prices.
Author provided keywords: Infrastructure; Housing Prices; Highways; Roads; Accessibility; ChinaMout, Hind Ait. Oil Price Pass-through to Sectoral Inflation: Evidence from Morocco2021-01492021AD-MC-0042021-0149
Scope and Contents
Morocco is a country heavily dependent on oil. Hence, fluctuations in oil prices do not only impact GDP growth and household demand but also its prices. This study explores the pass-through effect of oil prices to domestic and sectoral inflation in Morocco between January 2007 and March 2020. The study examines the effect using non-linear autoregressive distributive lag model (NARDL) to assess the difference between the impact of positive and negative oil price shocks. Results show that (1) oil prices affect domestic and food CPI in the long run and the short run, (2) non-food CPIs are only affected in the short run (3) there is evidence of asymmetric, incomplete and/or lagged price transmissions in more oil-intensive industries, which suggest potential market power dynamics.
Author provided keywords: Oil price pass-through, market power, inflation, asymmetric effectsNg, Marielle Caballero. U-Shape Hypothesis Test in Panama Using Micro-Determinants of Female Labor Force Participation2021-01572021AD-MC-0042021-0157
Scope and Contents
For my capstone project, my main goal was to test the U- shape relationship between economic development and female labor force participation in Panama using census microdata. I employed a linear probability model to estimate the effects of educational attainment, fertility, and household income on female labor force which may explain changes in female labor force participation according to the U-Shape theory. I extended the model by adding variables for occupation of the household head to understand the role of the structure of the economy in women's choices to participate in the labor force. Regression results from the primary model indicate that educational attainment, household income and fertility contribute towards the upward portion of the U-Shape in explaining changes in female labor force participation. The extended model results show that the structure of the economy also plays a small role at explaining changes in female labor force participation, both across space and time. The primary and extended model regression results only show evidence of the upward portion of the U-Shape relationship between economic development and female labor force participation in Panama.
Author provided keywords: U-Shape, female labor force participation, educational attainment, PanamaNoll, Kevin. Quantitative Easing in the Eurozone: Stock Market Performance and Dependence on External Finance2021-01542021AD-MC-0042021-0154
Scope and Contents
In this paper, I analyze the impact of quantitative easing announcements and the industries' dependence on external finance on stock market returns in the 19 Eurozone countries. As a result of the 2007 Great Recession, and most recently, the COVID-19 pandemic, the European Central Bank made multiple announcements to pursue an unconventional monetary policy, quantitative easing, which subsequently affects companies' stock due to changing expectations about their future performance. However, the extent to which companies can benefit from the consequences of quantitative easing differs on how reliant they are for external finance. Therefore, the idea of the dependence on external finance across industries is used by Rajan and Zingales (1998). Daily stock return data from 2010 to 2021 are retrieved from Compustat and the quantitative easing announcements are obtained from the European Central Bank's Press Releases. I find that with quantitative easing announcements, as a company becomes more dependent on external finance, the company's daily stock returns are positively affected.
Author provided keywords: External finance, Quantitative easing, Stock returns, EurozonePande, Gaurav. The effects of Information and Communication Technology On Climate Change Knowledge in Sub-Saharan Africa2021-01482021AD-MC-0042021-0148
Scope and Contents
This paper measures how the adoption of Information and Communication Technology (ICT) in 34 countries in Sub-Saharan Africa affects the awareness of and attitudes towards climate change. Four multiple logistic regressions were run to find how different types of ICT adoption shape climate change knowledge. We find that access to mobile phones with Internet and social media increase the likelihood of an individual being aware of climate change. However, the adoption of these ICTs does not significantly impact the perception of the negative impacts of climate change, the perception of the need to address it, and confidence among people that individual efforts can effect change. In contrast, traditional ICTs like television, radios, and newspapers have a significant effect on shaping such attitudes.
Author provided keywords: Africa; ICT; climate change; mobile phones; Internet; social mediaPandey, Aman. Trending to Trading: Using Twitter sentiments to study the stock market movement during the Covid pandemic2021-01402021AD-MC-0042021-0140
Scope and Contents
This paper looks at the relationship between the sentiment ex- pressed on Twitter regarding the stock market and the change in the stock price of S/P 500 during the COVID pandemic (January- August 2020). Using Granger Causality and Vector Auto Regression (VAR), we study the correlation between the daily sentiment with daily change in the stock price of the S/P 500. We find that out of six different sentiments (Compound, Happy, Sad, Angry, Surprise, Fear) as measured by text analysis tools (VADER and text2emotion), only two sentiments, angry and Surprise, are significant in granger causing the changes in stock price movement of S/P 500 during the pandemic. By comparing our results with similar research on the financial crisis, we also analyze how the COVID pandemic was unique from other economic crises and how people's sentiment about the stock market during the pandemic was different and short-lived.
Author provided keywords: sentiment analysis, VAR, Twitter, granger causality, VAR, text analysisRossi, Juan Pablo. How does vocational education impact professional outcomes? Evidence from an abrupt policy change in Argentina2021-01522021AD-MC-0042021-0152
Scope and Contents
Despite general unemployment levels remaining relatively stable, youth unemployment has been increasing at an alarming rate worldwide. A tool to potentially reduce youth unemployment is vocational education, which is offered in many countries as an optional complement to secondary education, allowing students to specialize in a specific field or craft. This capstone studies an unusual policy change approved in Argentina in 1993, which made vocational education a mandatory component of the national high-school curriculum instead of an optional complement. I utilize representative quarterly data from household surveys to track the educational and professional outcomes of Argentinian students who were part of this program relative to those who were not. The results show that the policy change had positive effects on completion of high school and pursuit of higher education. However, results also indicate higher unemployment and lower real wages for those students who underwent this educational change. When the effects of the policy were evaluated by gender, it is observed that most of the benefits are experienced by women, helping to close existing gaps in employment and wages.
Author provided keywords: Education, Vocational, Employment, Wages, Cohort Comparison, GenderSchlor, Luna. "Welfare Magnet" or "Welfare Deterrent"? - Examining New Evidence from the Post-Enlargement European Union2021-01562021AD-MC-0042021-0156
Scope and Contents
There has been ongoing debate about the "welfare magnet" hypothesis (Borjas 1999) in the EU context, especially for East-West migration, ever since the Eastern EU enlargements. Existing research has mostly relied on census and household survey data with coverage only until the mid-2000s and often lacking data on migrants' exact countries of origin. Conducting panel data regressions on annual, bilateral migration flow data between 2001-2018 from the OECD International Migration Database (IMD), this paper contributes to the literature in two important ways: Firstly, a specially designed EU Movement Restriction Index controls more rigorously for 'transitional arrangements' – temporary movement restrictions affecting Eastern EU citizens in the early years after accession. Secondly, the bilateral nature of the data enables me to investigate heterogeneity of the "welfare magnet" effect along different migration corridors, specifically along the East-West corridor and within Western Europe respectively. My analysis suggests that the "welfare magnet" effect is essentially zero for East-West migration whereas a puzzle of seeming "welfare deterrence" poses itself for migration within Western Europe.
Author provided keywords: European Union, transitional arrangements, bilateral migration, welfare magnet, EU enlargementsShah, Ayaan. Technological Persistence in a Globalized World: Was the 3rd Industrial Revolution different?2021-01422021AD-MC-0042021-0142
Scope and Contents
Recent research has pointed to the existence of technological persistence over multiple centuries. The studies claim that an increasingly globalized world should have eased knowledge sharing, allowing developing countries to catch up to innovators, but that seems not to be the case. However, most studies use indirect measures for technology like Total Factor productivity (TFP) and RandD Expenditure whose relationship with output and technological adoption remains unclear. There exists an additional concern that the appropriate control variables have not been used to account for factors like spatial autocorrelation. This paper uses the CHAT dataset with information on 104 technologies from 159 countries to construct a direct measure of technology to estimate whether technological persistence exists. I found that the technology variable for 1500 was able to predict the technological measure for 1960, 1980 and 1990 but broke at 2000 following which there was no statistical long-term (500 years) relationship. In the short run (60 years), the technology measures predicted 2018's but the accuracy decreased as we increased the time lag. We evaluate whether these findings suggest that long-term technological persistence has ceased to exist and discuss the conditions which could have led to the break.
Author provided keywords: Globalization Technology Persistence Diffusion Industrial Revolution HistoryShu, Abigail. Securitization and Systematic Risk in Chinese Banking: Empirical Evidence2021-01382021AD-MC-0042021-0138
Scope and Contents
Asset-backed securities and their associated risks were one of the main factors of the financial crisis in 2008. Theoretical arguments support the view that securitization can either increase or decrease the issuer's systematic risk, and previous empirical results obtained using data from the US and Europe indeed give a varied picture. This paper studies whether asset-backed securities issuances affect the systematic risk (equity beta) of the issuing bank. Using a data set of 114 mortgage-backed securities during 2014 and 2020 from banks listed in Hong Kong, Shanghai, and Shenzhen Stock Exchanges, results show that securitization decreases systematic risk for banks listed in Hong Kong, but does not have a clear effect for banks listed only in mainland China. Seemingly unrelated regressions (SUR) under an event-study analysis is used to obtain the results in this paper.
Author provided keywords: systematic risk, risk transfer, securitization, asset backed, securities, event studySikaria, Rishav. Thinking about value: assessing knowledge creation and spillovers by the world's largest tech companies 2021-01622021AD-MC-0042021-0162
Scope and Contents
The large-tech firms (Google, Apple, Amazon, Facebook and Microsoft) have become some of the biggest companies in existence, with extraordinary market shares in product markets and extraordinary market valuations in stock markets; they have also been the subject of much criticism for monopolistic practices that stifle competition and bottle up innovation (see, for example, Philippon 2019 and Lamoreaux 2019), thereby potentially limiting the sorts of positive spillovers that Romer (1986) identified as being bring crucial to growth. This paper assesses the extent to which the large-tech firms (defined as the largest companies by market value globally) produce and disseminate technological advances that lift the broader economy. This paper uses an original dataset on patents and patent citations to provide an assessment of innovation and spillover of innovation by the biggest tech firms. Specifically, it compares the innovation and diffusion rates of GAFAMs against their historical counterparts (five biggest companies in last five decades by market value) and their acquisitions (e.g., WhatsApp for Facebook). Our goal is for the results of this study to inform debates about the impact of these firms on the broader economy.
Author provided keywords: Innovation, Technology, Patents, GAFAMSilva, Bela. The Effect of Pro-Exploitation Parties on Deforestation: An Analysis of Close Municipal Races in the Brazilian Amazon2021-01432021AD-MC-0042021-0143
Scope and Contents
This paper explores the relationship between the election of pro-exploitation political parties and deforestation in municipalities in the Legal Amazon. Using panel deforestation data and electoral data from close municipal races, the study applies a Regression Discontinuity Design to aim to understand the effect of a narrow win by a political party on deforestation, considering the municipalities are very similar otherwise. Political parties are categorized in this study as either pro-exploitation or non pro-exploitation through a process that takes into consideration a variety of different factors. Main findings show that pro-exploitation parties are associated with higher levels of deforestation, particularly in the period after the 2016 local elections, but that the impact does not seem to be significant.
Author provided keywords: Deforestation; Legal Amazon; pro-exploitation; municipal electionsSoliman, Salma. The Gender Gap in Financial Inclusion: A Global Analysis of Predictors and Trends Salma2021-01652021AD-MC-0042021-0165
Scope and Contents
Despite many documented benefits of financial inclusion, there exists a significant and persistent gender gap. Using the World Bank's Findex database, a rich and representative individual-level dataset focused on financial inclusion in 144 countries between 2011 and 2017, this capstone documents that although the overall level of financial access has increased globally, the gender gap has also widened. In addition to this increase, the effectiveness of individual-level characteristics in explaining this gender gap has fallen from what was found in previous literature. There are significant differences in the gender gap across regions, suggesting that external country-level factors also drive gender differentials in financial inclusion. I also find that country-level gender equity policy indicators that explained the gap in financial access, financial usage, and mobile financial usage in 2011 explain it less in 2017, while the explanatory power of cultural factors has increased. Ultimately, this capstone suggests that gathering comprehensive individual-level data on cultural factors may be an important addition to the next round of the World Bank's Findex database. Regardless, further research to better understand this increasing and increasingly unexplained gender gap in financial inclusion is key to its mitigation.
Author provided keywords: Financial inclusion, gender gap, financial technologySong, Veronica. Catalyst or Stabilizer-The Effect of Government Policy on Stock Market during COVID-19 Pandemic in G20 Countries2021-01712021AD-MC-0042021-0171
Scope and Contents
COVID-19 is a black swan event that has caused tremendous public health concerns and severe economic downturn. To tackle the crisis and rebuild the resilience, governments are accountable for making reaction and recovery plans at the national level. As governments launched a wide range of measures, the effect of policies on financial markets remains an unsettled debate. This paper addresses whether policy responses to COVID-19 generate negative repercussions or create positive returns on stock markets, and how quickly does policy effects materialize. Based on panel data evidence of G20 countries, we demonstrate that income support, international travel ban and moving restriction have a positive impact on daily stock market return, while testing policy has a negative impact. Announcement of all four policies instantaneously affects the stock market return on the next trading day.
Author provided keywords: COVID-19, stock market return, international financial markets, government policy responses, G20 Touzet, Mauricio Yanez. Perceptions and Lying -- An Experimental Study on Motivations to Cheat2021-01592021AD-MC-0042021-0159
Scope and Contents
This Capstone Project is an experimental study to measure how our perceived social class, level of education, and money, affect our tendency to lie in the presence of a monetary incentive. Participants carried out a small exercise to manipulate their self- perception regarding any of the three categories and then rolled two virtual dice. We told participants that their payoffs depended on the sum they reported, therefore, providing them with an incentive to lie. We found that comparing yourself in terms of social class, education, or money does not seem to play a significant role in affecting people's tendency to lie in the presence of a monetary incentive. However, our results suggest that the higher the level of education, the smaller the chance to exhibit this type of unethical behavior.

Scope and Contents
India is set to have one of the largest urbanization events over the next 30 years. City populations have been increasing and so has property prices. In April 2020, the government set a target of constructing roads worth Rs. 15 lakh crores ($212 billion) in the next two years. Existing literature has documented the effect of constructing highways on housing prices in cities with a population of over 5 million people. This project studies the effect of infrastructure investment on 50 cities in India. The results show that increasing the length of national highways has a positive effect on housing prices.
Author provided keywords: Infrastructure, Highways, India, Housing PricesVu, Linh. Testing the Fama-French Three-Factor Model vs the Fama-French Five-Factor Model in the GCC2021-01552021AD-MC-0042021-0155
Scope and Contents
This paper tests the Fama French Three-Factor Model against the Fama French Five-Factor Model to find the best asset pricing model for the GCC region. As averages of the intercepts from both models are significantly different from zero, there are other risks outside the model that explained the expected returns. The intercept averages' difference between the two models is also not significant, so we cannot determine whether the Three-factor or the Five-factor model is better for the GCC region. When reviewing the factor coefficients, Market, Value, Profitability, and Investment risks play a role in explaining the expected returns of stocks, while it is unclear whether Size is significant in explaining the returns.
Author provided keywords: Fama French Models, GCC stock marketsWang, Emily. Use of Machine Learning Algorithms on Fund Performance Prediction2021-01352021AD-MC-0042021-0135
Scope and Contents
Although many econometrics papers found a strong correlation between fund and fund managers' characteristics with performance, machine learning prediction models refrain from these characteristic data, and use only variance or returns as independent variables. This capstone paper tries to fill this gap between machine learning and fund performance prediction. Using fund characteristics and fund managers data in addition to variance and returns, we test different machine learning algorithms to identify outperforming funds in U.S CRSP dataset. Our best performing gradient boosting model reached a high 77.23 percent prediction success rate in identifying a positive alpha performance for the next year, a much higher success rate than a smaller machine learning model using only past performance. This result indicates that fund characteristics increase machine learning's prediction success rate, providing a better decision-aid for investors and money managers.
Author provided keywords: fund, machine learning, CRSPXu, Yaozhong. An Evaluation of Differences in Educational Attainment between Immigrant Students and Native Students in OECD Countries Using PISA Data2021-01722021AD-MC-0042021-0172
Scope and Contents
This capstone paper aims to understand the gap between the educational attainment of immigrant students and that of native students using 2018 PISA data, and observe how it has changed compared with the results from the 2009 PISA data. In addition, the paper aims to update how students' immigrant background moderates the impact of socioeconomic status (SES) on students' educational attainment. The research is conducted on a selection of OECD countries based on the country's percentage of immigrant students as well as the completeness of data as recorded by the PISA test. The paper finds that immigrant background affects students' educational attainment as reflected by the PISA test score, although the effect is mixed, which could be explained by the different origins of immigrants for different countries. It also finds that higher socioeconomic status will lead to higher educational attainment, and in most of the selected countries, immigrant background will have negative moderating impact on socioeconomic status' impact on students' educational attainment.
Author provided keywords: educational attainment, socioeconomic status, immigrant background, interaction, OECD, PISAZeid, Salma. The Impact of the Arab Spring on Gross Domestic Product2021-01662021AD-MC-0042021-0166
Scope and Contents
This paper uses the synthetic control methodology to estimate the impact of the Arab Spring on per capita GDP in four countries; Egypt, Tunisia, Jordan, and Morocco between 2011 and 2017. The results suggest that the output gap for Egypt and Tunisia continued to get worse year on year reaching 13% and 21% respectively in 2017 where the main channels of the impact were losses in tourism receipts, gross capital formation, and FDI inflows. Findings also suggest that spillover effects have substantial impacts on per capita GDP. Jordan was impacted more directly by the Syrian refugee crisis and trade shocks which led to output losses reaching 37% in 2017 with no evidence of recovery. Morocco was impacted less directly and the relatively smaller shock was easily managed by government policy.
Author provided keywords: Synthetic Control Methodology, Empirical Studies of Economic Growth, Political EconomyZerdo, Meskerem. Impact of the Local Provision of Primary and Secondary Education on Years of Schooling and Employment Status of the Youth in Ethiopia 2021-01602021AD-MC-0042021-0160
Scope and Contents
This paper examines the connection between years of schooling and employment status of the youth caused by the 1990's local provision of primary and secondary education policy reform in Ethiopia. Using temporal variation generated by the implementation of the reform, the impact of the policy reform is identified by using average year of schooling and average year of none or pre-school across region, age groups, and gender. The policy affected slightly different ages differently, if an individual was old enough the time the policy was rolled out relative to young enough for it to matter. The paper finds that after the implementation of the reform there is an increase in years of schooling for younger people, who were fully exposed to the policy. However, on average youth between the age range 20 to 29 are estimated to have paid employment status that is 0.08 points lower than those above the age 30. On the other hand, females compared to males face excessive disadvantage in the labor market and are often confined to an unpaid and informal sector. Ordinary Least Squares regression (OLS) model is used to estimate the return to years of schooling and its impact on employment status.
Author provided keywords: Ethiopia, Youth, Policy reform, Employment Status, Paid and Unpaid workerLegal StudiesDelano, Jack. Understanding the Legislative Spectrum of Sex Work: A Brief Case Study of the Netherlands, South Africa, and Sweden2019-02022019AD-MC-0042019-0202
Scope and Contents
This study explores legislative frameworks surrounding sex work, and how the legal environments of various contexts shape the social conditions around them. The study begins with an overview of understanding contemporary sex work, namely through discussing the key schools of thought in sex work debates, as well as the often-neglected but massively important topic of indoor sex work. Indoor sex work is discussed at length to discuss its potential as the most viable form of sex work for an environment where the practice is legal. After this discussion, three case studies are addressed, discussing the relationships between their respective legal systems and how sex work operates in each society. The case studies (the Netherlands, South Africa, and Sweden) are chosen to illustrate points on a broader legislative spectrum with regards to sex work. The study concludes by noting the immense differences in the needs of each case study with respect to improving their legal systems so as not to increase sex worker victimization. Additionally, it is concluded that none of the legal frameworks discussed represents an ideal scenario for sex workers, but each offer insights on how to improve sex work legislation in general.Political ScienceBolton, Brett Michael. Introduction to Continuous Voting2014-00661892014AD-MC-0042014-0066
Scope and Contents
Major: Political Science
Abstract: Continuous Elections are the election methods of governing systems that do not have set term lengths or election cycles, but rather employ a fluid voting system where individuals may cast, retract, or change their vote at will and, consequently, potentially cause a new outcome at any time. We offer the first, rudimentary computer models of this method, which predict a generally stable outcome for most organizations. We engage in what is thus far the most comprehensive discussion concerning the theoretical underpinnings of this method, as well as, its potential merits and shortcomings. Finally, we offer an open-source program and framework for this election method that can be freely downloaded and employed in the interest of providing future scholars with data so that we might further our understanding of this unique election method.ConstituenciesAccountabilityPolitical representationDemocracyElectionsVotingCsillag, Tamas. Intertwining powers: The Case Study of Hungary's Declining Separation of Powers2014-00961592014AD-MC-0042014-0096
Scope and Contents
Major: Political Science
Abstract: In 1989 a peaceful revolution swept away the Soviet-style socialism in Hungary the foundations of the modern, democratic Hungarian nation state were established. Although in the '90's the Hungarian Republic was built upon the ancient concept of the Separation of Powers, now, merely two decades later, this model seems to be deteriorating. Many blame the 2010 Parliamentary elections that concluded in the landslide victory of the conservative right-wing party, Fidesz, and their consecutive Constitutional reforms for this deterioration. Furthermore, there is a number of other, often less obvious changes in the state structure that redistributed power from the executive and judiciary branches to the Parliament and thus allowed uncontested governance for Fidesz. In this paper I intend to investigate the state of the Hungarian Separation of Powers model to determine the extent to which the legislature has usurped powers formerly reserved to the other branches. This analysis may also have implications for other young and transitional democracies (anocracies) around the world.Veto PlayersElectoral systemsSeparation of powersHungaryDemocracyGellai, Daniel. Abstract: This paper examines how racial identity is constructed by analyzing the legal framework that the Hungarian State devised for Roma affairs in the last decades. The examination of how the Hungarian legal system shapes and constructs Roma identity reveals how national and ethnic identities are part of "classificatory struggles" and what consequences those struggles can incur. Even though State laws and the legal framework do not explicitly mention racial categories, they do set the Roma apart from the majority and only a minority of them can perform the identity that the state assigns. The need to identify them can thus perpetuate other markers, e.g. racial features, for which there is historical precedence and empiric evidence.Roma (People)Legal systemsMinoritiesRaceKaraulova, Daria. Abstract: Nepal suffered civil war violence over the course of ten years, from 1996 to 2006. In the aftermath of the civil conflict it appears that education was one of the most affected areas. This paper examines the effects of the civil war violence on the education system in Nepal. The research presents two approaches: empirical analysis and qualitative research findings. I conclude that the violence caused by the Maoist insurgency had a significant impact on public and private school enrolment and educational processes, which potentially facilitated the increase of the number of private schools in post-conflict Nepal. Supplying Peacekeepers: A Matter of Distance2014-00981602014AD-MC-0042014-0098
Scope and Contents
Major: Political Science
Abstract: Western countries' reluctance to deploy large numbers of troops to UN missions is worrying, especially as it is in direct contrast to their energetic involvement during and just after the Cold War. This paper seeks to explore some of the ways that a country's wealth influences its likelihood of providing peacekeepers. I theorize that the UN's fixed monthly payment per soldier provides more incentive to developing countries to supply troops, than it does to developed countries. Therefore, I look at the relationship between a country's wealth, the interaction of wealth and military capacity, and the interaction of wealth and proximity to a conflict on the country's peacekeeping supply. I find that wealth in itself is a poor predictor for supplying peacekeepers. However, the interaction between wealth and military capacity is a good predictor: Poorer countries show an increase in troops supplied with an increased defense budget, while there for richer countries is no effect. Lastly, rich countries in unstable regions seem to be less willing to supply troops than rich countries in stable regions. I conclude that the UN's fixed monthly payment induces poorer countries to contribute more troops than their richer counterparts.National incomeSecurity policy, NationalInternational relationsPeacekeeping forcesUnited NationsUnderwood, Stephen Ross. Don't You Forget About Me: A Rational Choice Model of Presidential Legacy2014-00931642014AD-MC-0042014-0093
Scope and Contents
Major: Political Science
Abstract: Presidential legacy has been studied for the last 50 years with no framework, model, or theory in which legacy is broadly understood and conceptualized. Research has focused on finding macro determinants of constructed lists of the "Greatest Presidents". Rather than continue in this vein, I offer a simple model with which Presidential legacy can be studied. I then apply rational choice theory to this model to produce a framework by which I characterize the interaction that forms legacy. This model implies a relationship between the net effects of former Presidents on present utility and retrospective presidential approval. I test this relationship empirically using a novel responsibility assignment measure. The results indicate that the net effect of former Presidents on utility can be understood in terms of this responsibility assignment and, more importantly, that this proves significant in the prediction of retrospective approval.Public opinionResponsibilityRational choice theoryPresidentsPolitical LeadershipWu, Xiaomei. Abstract: This paper examines the relationship between the adoption of the currency of Euro and people's satisfactions towards domestic governments in Europe when the 2009 Eurozone economic recession happened. When the economic recessions happen, it is possible that the people from Eurozone countries are more likely than the people outside of the Eurozone to attribute the economic failure to European Central Bank (ECB) instead of their domestic governments because their national governments do not have direct control over the regional monetary policy. However, this paper shows that such leniency in fact did not exist when the 2009 Eurozone economic recession happened.
