Scope and Contents
Does exposure to violence have an effect on the support for wartime incumbents? Prior research investigated how violence shapes general political attitudes and engagements, but has not managed to explain why some parties continue their rule after the war, while others get voted out. This paper seeks to explain how voters' exposure to local violence alters the postwar electoral success of wartime incumbent parties. I draw on municipal-level electoral data from Bosnia and Herzegovina to test whether communities that experience more wartime violence tend to vote incumbent parties out of office. Using a difference-in-difference identification strategy, I show that the effect of violence is heterogeneous across different parties. Parties representing those who experienced disproportionately high levels of violence were punished in the postwar elections more, but this effect is likely mediated by selective emigration of the voter base. Conversely, parties which achieved their wartime goals see an increase in local government seat share.
Author provided keywords: Civil war, violence, voting, parties, BosniaNiewiadomska, Wiktoria. Ideological Leaning of News outlets and Trends in Terrorism Coverage2021-01882021AD-MC-0042021-0188
Scope and Contents
The media plays a crucial role in keeping the public updated on the events happening around the world, including security threats such as terrorism. However, the framing of such incidents is not homogenous. Some outlets may frame a violent incident as "attack" or "explosion"; others may refer to the same event as an instance "terrorism". The differences in framing have implications for the public sense of security and, maybe more importantly, for the perception of publicity success of perpetrators. This study applies Structural Topic Modeling and sentiment analysis to the coverage of incidents of terror published in major newspapers from five countries (Australia, United Kingdom, Spain, Chile, Mexico) to contribute to answering the overarching question: what shapes the variation in the framing of terrorist attacks? More specifically, this paper looks at differences between conservative and liberal media outlets in their framing of said events with respect to their use of the "terror" frame as well as their sentiment when reporting such incidents. Contrary to previous research, this study finds no significant differences in these aspects between liberal and conservative outlets.
Author provided keywords: terrorism, news, coverage, ideology, framing, mediaOkumus, Serra. Reframing Turkish Laiklik: 'Regulatory Secularism' from the Kemalist Republic to the AKP, 1923-20202021-01862021AD-MC-0042021-0186
Scope and Contents
How has Turkey come to be near-universally theorized as a secular state despite having routinely violated the substantive components of secularism as defined by Western political theory? Using the methodology of historical institutionalism, this paper undertakes a systematic investigation of that puzzle. Based on that investigation, this paper argues that– far from embodying "secularism" as that term has traditionally been conceptualized in comparative political theory– Turkey has, from its so-called golden age of secularism under Atatürk to the present, more Islamist-tinged regime of Recep Tayyip Erdoğan, never fit the core components of secularism (including functional separation of church and state, and equal treatment of citizens without discrimination based on religious beliefs). To more accurately understand religion-state relations in Turkey, this paper contends that political theorists must recognize that Turkey embodies a distinctly alternative approach to standard theorizations of Western secularism. I term this "regulatory secularism"– an approach characterized not by the traditional metrics of functional separation or non-discrimination, but by (1) the state's monopolization and control of religious institutions and (2) the state's ideology of Muslim majoritarianism.

This paper studies remittances and behavioral intervention. It peers into a dimension of remittances often overlooked in the literature and by other stakeholders in the remittance field: non-proximate remittances, that is, remittances sent to persons or for purposes not directly connected to senders' families or friends. Specifically, I look into the potential of orienting remittances towards community-wide projects in communities of remittance senders' countries of origin. I investigate the effect of monitoring – one behavioral intervention – on migrant populations' remittance behaviors via a survey experiment and randomization. Though the treatment has an insignificant negative effect on the general sample, it has a significant negative effect on a subset of respondents I designate as being highly attentive during the survey. Ultimately, the survey's insights indicate a generally positive and pragmatic outlook on the concept of non-proximate remittances.

Through original survey research carried out on 157 students at New York University Abu Dhabi, this study investigates the effect of clarifying local media laws and Diversity, Equity and Inclusion policy on both chilling effects and levels of self-reported self-censorship on and off campus. Firstly, I find that NYUAD students are least likely to express their political opinion in off campus environments. Secondly, in response to the DEI statement students report lower levels of self-reported self-censorship strictly on campus. However, in an online setting both the DEI and Law prime saw participants indicate higher levels of constraint. Lastly, self-identified conservatives are more likely to report greater instances of self-censorship in all on campus environments. There remains much research to be done on the application of chilling effects in academic spaces.

This study researches whether community driven development programs lead to changes in perceptions and accountability of traditional leaders by citizens in the Eastern region of the DRC. For perceptions, this study looks at preferences in leadership and public goods allocation. In terms of accountability, this study focuses on non-electoral accountability which is comprised of inclusive decision making and need to verify leader's actions. The study is based on data collected in 2010 and 2011. Random assignment is used to measure the effects of community driven development programs on outcome variables. I also test to see if sub-groups such as males in study have any interaction effects with the treatment on perceptions and non-electoral accountability. The results show that CDD programs have a significant negative effect on perceptions of preference in traditional leadership whereby citizens prefer local democratic processes over traditional leadership in managing resources. However, this study finds no evidence that CDD programs have any impact on citizens perceptions of public goods allocation or non-electoral accountability of traditional leaders. Additionally, there is no interaction effect between treatment and gender on outcome variables indicating no significant impact on men in CDD programs.

This project is the first comprehensive empirical study into Ethiopian political parties and party systems. Using a sample of 76 national and regional parties, it conducts different computer assisted analysis to produce an ideological space for Ethiopian parties on a one-dimensional left-right spectrum. In addition, using clustering algorithms, this project groups parties together based on their similarities and conducts a comparison analysis among parties in the sample and other parties from established democracies.

Abstract: Adopting minority stress theory and stigma management theory for sexual minority youth, this study aims to understand how supportive and unsupportive environments engender different sexuality outcomes. Using a cross-classification variable comprised of sexual attraction, relationships and identity, this study examines the effects of individual-level and environmental-level indicators of school integration, religious fundamentalism, experience of prejudice, exposure to violence, and school sanctions. Using multinomial regression analysis of data from the National Longitudinal Survey of Adolescent Health, this study finds that unsupportive environments limit sexual fluidity and sexuality outcomes, particularly in female respondents, while there is also some indication that more supportive environments engender greater sexual diversity. Given the considerable psychological consequences of repressing one's sexuality, the findings of this study encourage policy interventions at the high-school level to foster greater education and inclusivity to overcome the additive stresses that sexual minority youth face, while encouraging further research into the dynamics of contemporary high schools.MinoritiesQueerLGBTIdentityHomosexualityStigma (Social psychology)Schools/EducationSexualityAdolescentsBorgeson, Jade Elizabeth. Abstract: In the last 25 years (Ali, 1986), the Emirate of Abu Dhabi, as a subsidiary of the greater United Arab Emirates, has experienced a massive influx of immigration that has dramatically impacted the demographics and nature of the resident community in the capital. This growth has precipitated a diversification of the Abu Dhabi community, which has in turn affected the composition of the potential volunteer pool in the Emirate. Drawing upon existing literature on the motivation to volunteer and perceptions of volunteerism across varying sociocultural backgrounds, this study investigates the nature and function of volunteerism in the Emirate through analysis of interviews with local volunteer coordinators, complemented by exploratory statistical analysis of a non-probability sample of 209 digital surveys completed by local residents. Findings show that differences in volunteers' sociocultural and demographic backgrounds correlate with respondents' reported motivations, conceptions, and integration into the local volunteer landscape, and that diverse orientations towards volunteerism are represented within the Emirate.VolunteerismCommunityUnited Arab EmiratesAbu Dhabi, United Arab EmiratesDemographyCharityPhilanthropyDel Carril, Nicole Lopez. Abstract: Groups that are more powerful in a conflict will often characterize less powerful groups as trying to gain power for the purposes of domination. But it is not clear that these are the motives of the less powerful. Our study considers the conflict of gay marriage in the United States. Through a content analysis of texts of representatives of higher-power, anti-gay marriage authors and lower-power, pro-gay marriage authors, we show that while higher power groups in a conflict consistently characterize the lower power group as trying to dominate, no such evidence can be found in the writings and speeches of low-power groups. Instead, lower-power groups use language of resisting domination by demanding equal treatment, respect and dignity. The paper concludes with a discussion of the theoretical and political implications of these findings as well as possibilities for future research.AntidominanceDominance (Psychology)Social dominance theoryPower (Psychology)ConflictGancheva, Darina Nevelinova. Abstract: This study diagnoses whether European parties fulfill their function as the primary mechanism for European representation and delegation. The EU party system functions at two levels: national and supranational. At the European elections, EU citizens vote for a national party of their choice. After the elections, the national parties that have received enough votes enter the EP and join one of the transnational European political groups ("EP factions"). These groups are conglomerates of different national parties and form coalitions based on – what they claim to be – a shared ideology. This study examines 1) whether the EP factions are programmatically cohesive, and 2) whether programmatic cohesion, rather than intra-faction pressure, is what explains the high voting cohesion rates of EP factions. Discriminant analysis based on the programmatic profiles of national parties suggests that EP factions are programmatically cohesive units. Variation in the voting agreement rates, however, is mostly due to intra-faction pressure, more prominent in the mainstream pro-EU factions. The programmatic cohesion and voting efficacy of EP factions prove that EP elections and the legislative process are becoming increasingly European and decreasingly national.Political partiesPolitical manifestoesVotingElectionsEuropean UnionEuropean ParliamentGonullu, Damla. Abstract: The racial disparities in mental health are well documented, and there are many studies examining the link between race and mental health. In this paper, I model this relationship by comparing the differences in the depression index scores of Cuban children with differing races and then examining two pathways (discrimination and acculturation) that may contribute to the difference in scores of White and Black/Multiracial Cuban immigrant children to the US. Results indicate that this model provides support for the hypothesis that there is a statistically significant difference in the average depression index scores of White and Black/Multiracial Cuban children. However, this model does not provide support for the two pathways that may contribute to those differences. This study provides a unique lens with which to explore the relationship between race and mental health. Abstract: The social development theory of demographic transition holds that demographic trends, especially the level of fertility, reflect the degree to which political and economic institutions reflect social justice (Ratcliffe, 1978). The falling fertility rates in India in the last few decades are thought to reflect the success of the processes and policies with the potential to empower women. Au contraire, similar amount of literature exists that argues otherwise - that falls in fertility are believed to be occurring independent of social development. The purpose of this paper is to analyze the changing gender differential in child mortality (which is a reflection of either an intensification or a reduction in the effect of son preference), when there is a fall in fertility. This question is analyzed using two waves of NFHS data to build on the work of Basu (1999) and Gupta and Bhat (1997). I find that in states that were already characterized by a preference for sons, a fall in fertility at a relatively faster pace saw the gender differential in child mortality increase significantly, indicating an intensification of existing son preference at lower parities. This paper ends with policy suggestions.Social developmentWomenDemographyFertilityChild mortalityGenderRadler, Meike Sydney. Abstract: Based on data from semi-structured interviews, this study investigates the social mobility strategies employed by upwardly mobile German-Turkish women living in Berlin. Using educational attainment and labour market achievement as objective indicators of upward mobility, the subjects fit into three categories of social mobility trajectories. Important processes for upward mobility are identified within these categories, using the framework of Bourdieu's theory of capital. In some cases, the domestic transmission of cultural capital is essential for upward mobility, while in others it is a context-specific resource for effective decision-making. Moreover, an expansion of social capital to extend beyond isolated ethnic communities is decisive for all subjects; either for its conversion into necessary cultural capital or through the avoidance of some of the negative effects of social capital on women in certain tightly-bound ethnic communities. While the mobilisation of ethnicity is useful for the upward mobility of a subgroup of German-Turkish women, it is a limitation for others. Finally, regardless of social mobility trajectory categorization, subjects are unified by their lack of symbolic capital in mainstream German society. The strategies they employ to counter this are found to be more assertive and focused on Germany than those employed by the previous generation.GermansTurksSocial mobilityBerlin, GermanyWomenGermanySocial capital (Sociology)Taylor, Thomas Llewellyn Mussared. Abstract: PEGIDA, Patriotic Europeans against the Islamization of the Occident, emerged in December 2014 urging for changes to policies allowing Muslim migration to Germany. By analyzing Facebook comments published throughout the year 2014, I ask how PEGIDA influenced a change in the migration discourse on Facebook in Germany. I find, that the rise of PEGIDA in December 2014 encouraged a shift in the migration discourse on Facebook. It reoriented the debate from discussing immigration to rejecting right wing nationalist ideology. As PEGIDA supporters amplified their presence on Facebook, commenters concerned with the extremist discourse overshadowed those in support of immigration. Immigrants themselves were not the primary topic of discussion in the migration discourse in December.
This is an example of discursive deflection, as the silence regarding immigrants resulted from individuals becoming focused on nationalist stances on migration. The discursive deflection in this research is not unique to Facebook users in Germany. It emerged across social circles and mediums, as individuals turned to defend political correctness amidst a rising nationalist discourse. Facebook comments nonetheless provide an insightful window into discursive deflection, because they make visible a multitude of private opinions, which would not otherwise become public knowledge.Discursive deflectionRight-wing extremistsSocial mediaFacebook (Electronic resource)ImmigrationGermanyInternational migrationMigrationNaslund, Cambria Marjorie Melanie. Scope and Contents

Abstract: In the past decade, crowdfunding has emerged as an alternative point of access to economic resources. The crowdfunding of medical bills is of particular interest given rising healthcare costs, but has received little attention in research on the dynamics of crowdfunding. As the general public evaluates which cases are worthy of their donations, it becomes increasingly important to understand the factors accounting for differences in donation behavior. One factor specific to this type of crowdfunding is represented by the categories of illness that individuals cite in their requests for donations. Diagnostic categories are both shaped by and shape social meanings and valuations of illness and the ill. Using a dataset of over 40,000 medical fundraising campaigns from the crowdfunding platform, GoFundMe, this research finds that existing theories of social meanings and value rankings of illnesses predict differences in financial support in the context of medical crowdfunding. The implications of these findings are discussed and directions for future research are proposed.Stigma (Social psychology)FundraisingIllnessMedical sociologyCrowdfundingPasternac, Oleg. Post-Soviet Identity in the "Russian" Restaurants of Abu Dhabi2015-005333692015AD-MC-0042015-0053
Scope and Contents
Major: Social Research and Public Policy
Abstract: This thesis explores the complexness of identity of the post-Soviet nations in the restarurants of Abu Dhabi, combining interviews of the employees with participant observations to study the presence and strength of the Soviet legacy in the environments of the restaurants. Specifically, I focus on the stories and contents of the restaurants, which have a unifying effect on the people of the post-Soviet nations, such as common language and cuisine, and evaluate the significance of these effects on the perception of identity.
I argue that despite the fact that it has been approximately 25 years since the fall of the Soviet Union, as well as despite various nationalistic movements in the post-Soviet states, the Soviet legacy remains strong. I further argue that the identities of the post-Soviet nations are neither nationalistic, nor Soviet, but rather a mix of both, having numerous unique features, yet simultaneously sharing numerous cultural aspects with the people of the ex-Soviet Union.Social identityIdentityPostsocialismGroups, SocialRestaurants/barsAbu Dhabi, United Arab EmiratesUSSRRehman, Arfa. Embeddedness of Entrepreneurial Activity: The Case of the United Arab Emirates2015-004633582015AD-MC-0042015-0046
Scope and Contents
Major: Social Research and Public Policy
Abstract: The research question this study explores is: what motivations do Emirati entrepreneurs ascribe to their entrepreneurial activity, and how does the context of the United Arab Emirates (UAE) influence these motivations? Using data collected from interviews with Emirati entrepreneurs, as well as representatives of organizations that promote entrepreneurship in the UAE, I investigate the different rationales behind entrepreneurial activity of Emirati entrepreneurs in tandem with the social, cultural, and institutional dimensions of the entrepreneurial context of the UAE. The findings reveal that most Emirati entrepreneurs pursue entrepreneurship with intrinsic motivations of following their passions, proving themselves through a personal challenge, and most commonly, making a social or cultural contribution to the UAE and to the larger Arab world. I conclude that specific aspects of the entrepreneurial context of the UAE give rise to a purposeful and value-focused nature of entrepreneurship, where economic motives are absent or secondary. The study contributes to the literature in economic sociology that finds entrepreneurial activity to be socially embedded, and guided by factors other than economic self-interest.Economic sociologyUnited Arab EmiratesEntrepreneurshipSotoudeh, Ramina. "A Match Made in Heaven": Spousal Selection Among Iranians2015-005533662015AD-MC-0042015-0055
Scope and Contents
Major: Social Research and Public Policy
Abstract: Romantic love, especially in the context of marriage, has been the topic of much attention and debate in recent academic and non-academic discussions. The debate however is often centered on the necessary societal and cultural conditions for producing romantic love in marriage. This paper aims to take a different perspective on the interaction of culture and romantic love. Instead of looking at culture as a direct cause of the role, structure and view of love in marriage among Iranians, this paper follows more contemporary views of culture as heterogeneous and context-specific rather than a singular and uniform driving force of all action. Using Latent Class Analysis, I uncover classes of people who have different constellations of preferences for selecting their spouse. This analysis reveals that love can be simultaneously associated with other values, which prima facie appear contradictory. This paper finds that love can have different meanings to different people depending on the constellation of other mate selection criteria with which it is chosen and associated; and therefore, that coherence is contextually established.CultureIranSpousesLoveCricco, Nino. Is Getting Pregnant the Worst? Attitudinal Responses to Peer's Pregnancies.2016-005880412016Cultural explanations of adolescent pregnancy suggest that normative attitudes in an individual's social context can play an important role in mediating pregnancy incidence. This study investigates the inverse relationship by examining changes in individuals' attitudes towards pregnancy in response to an instance of pregnancy in their peer group. I find that individuals who are exposed to pregnancy in their peer groups have higher rates of change in pregnancy attitudes than individuals who are not exposed to pregnancy in their peer groups. On average, however, individuals are not more likely to change their attitudes in a positive or negative direction. These results suggest that exposure to pregnancy at the peer group level changes individual's attitudes towards pregnancy, but not in a predetermined way. Further results suggest that while characteristics of the individual's social context may not be important in shaping individual's attitudinal responses to their peer's pregnancies, the normative climates in which individuals are embedded do shape how individuals respond to their peers' pregnancies.AD-MC-0042016-0058

Political Timing of Non-political News: A Study on Political Scandals and Celebrity Gossip.2016-005480592016Scandals are costly to the social and political life of politicians. To minimize the political cost of scandals, politicians may attempt to reduce the public attention given to the news. In this article I examine whether celebrity gossip is released in tandem with political scandals, testing a widespread media conspiracy theory in South Korea. I hypothesize that the more political scandals are in the news, the more celebrity gossip we observe. Using unique data on popular news stories in South Korea, I test this hypothesis. Both the linear correlation and the time series analysis of gossip and scandals show that there is more celebrity news on days when there are political scandals. This finding supports the popular belief in Korea that the timing of celebrity gossip is manipulated to crowd out political scandals.AD-MC-0042016-0054
Scope and Contents

Both the linear correlation and the time series analysis of gossip and scandals show that there is more celebrity news on days when there are political scandals. This finding supports the popular belief in Korea that the timing of celebrity gossip is manipulated to crowd out political scandals.Sarkozi, Eszter. Towards Novel Approaches to Memory Work: Guided Tours at the Memorial to the Murdered Jews of Europe, Berlin.2016-005380342016Based on ethnographic research of guided tours for German high school students at the Memorial to the Murdered Jews of Europe in Berlin, this paper examines guiding strategies at a remembrance site within the emerging "counter-monument" phenomenon. Attempting to resist redemption from the task of remembrance, the architect provided no interpretation about his artwork, encouraging visitors to develop their own meaning. Maintaining multiple interpretations during a tour is the central strategy practiced by guides. I argue that such presence of multiple ideas not only demonstrates to participants that there is no single correct interpretation, but it also resists closure with the memorial. I further argue that, in the context of this memorial, guiding techniques empower students with a sense of authority as meaning-makers and direct them towards a novel approach to memory work that invites individuals to confront the difficulties of remembering, engendering it as a continuous process.AD-MC-0042016-0053

It's Not About the Money: Negotiating Emirati Masculinity amid State Promotion of Women's Employment2017-00412017This study explores Emirati men's gendered identity negotiations in relation to state-promoted women's employment in the United Arab Emirates. Drawing from a series of qualitative, in-depth interviews, I adopt a social identity and gender constructivist analytical approach to understand intersectional Emirati masculinity in flux. I argue that state-promoted women's work challenges a codified ideal masculinity, encouraging men's aspiration to and practice of shared breadwinning, while impacting the gendering of childcare less. I also examine Emirati men's experiences of women-centered state policy, finding that their concern over status decline and support for women's work are not mutually exclusive. Especially evident in their relational comparisons to other men, awareness of international notions of modernity and stereotyped Arab masculinity pervade Emirati men's social identity construction. This study deepens understandings of intersectional Emirati masculinity and highlights conditions that challenge strict gender norms.AD-MC-0042017-0041

Tomorrow's Neighbors: Strategies for Temporary Refugee Integration in Athens, Greece 2017-00402017Between 2015 and 2016, over one million migrants and refugees entered Greece via the Mediterranean Sea. After Greece's northern borders closed and the EU signed a migration agreement with Turkey in 2016, 60,000 asylum seekers found themselves confined in Greece, where the asylum application process can last over a year. This paper discusses the need for temporary refugee integration and seeks to answer the questions: what are the main barriers to refugee integration in Athens, and how can policymakers facilitate the temporary integration of refugees into the city? Data for this study was collected during two rounds of field interviews in Athens in 2016. Respondents were sampled from three categories: refugees (n=46), direct service providers working for nongovernmental organizations (n=27), and independent volunteers (n=13). These conversations revealed many barriers to refugee integration in Athens, including poor employment prospects, secluded accommodation, and refugees' reluctance to stay in Greece. However, several factors that could improve integration prospects were identified, including English and Greek language learning, mentorship from other migrants, and stable accommodation. This paper concludes with a series of policy recommendations for service providers to encourage the temporary integration of refugees in Athens.AD-MC-0042017-0040
Scope and Contents

The "Many Hats" Worn: Discourses on Women and Work in Oman2017-00422017This research project explores the experiences of Omani female lawyers and engineers and compares their narratives to dominant policy discourses about women's employment in Oman. I investigate sex segregation in the workforce through semi-structured interviews and discourse analysis. The women interviewed reproduce some policy discourses, but always as pertaining to "other" women who are deemed more traditional. However, some of the women's narratives diverge from policy discourses, presenting a more complex reality, for example, in the case of familial relations. Furthermore, women discussed structural challenges faced in the workplace, a notion that the policy discourse misses. Challenges women face are over attributed to culture, tradition, individual efforts and mindsets of women through the influence of modernization and development narratives. This over-attribution overshadows structural barriers preventing necessary policy level change to occur. This study also aims to counter exceptionalist narratives on the region and reveals far more complex lived realities of Omani women.AD-MC-0042017-0042

The Evolution and Modernization of Families, Marriage and Weddings Across Three Generations in the United Arab Emirates2018-01532018AD-MC-0042018-0153
Scope and Contents
With increased modernization in the UAE, many traditional and cultural aspects of Emirati life have been impacted attracting notable changes to the way the traditional customs of marriage are conducted. Due to the fast rate of development and modernization of the country, these changes are noticeable among current generations in the country. With primary research conducted across three generations, the customs of Emirati weddings have indicated changes in as little as a few years. Identifying the major changes, as well as nuances, in the customary wedding traditions in the UAE across three generations have demonstrated the direct impact of modernization and urbanization on the Emirati culture.Alfoulathi, Fakhera Mohamed. Mental Health Perceptions Among Emirati Youth2018-01342018AD-MC-0042018-0134
Scope and Contents
This study compares mental health perceptions of Emirati youth, those who have experienced mental illnesses and those who have not, with what they believe are their parents perceptions and beliefs on mental health. The aim of this study is to understand the stigma associated with mental illness in the UAE using 12 semi-structured interviews, with youth ranging from the age of 18-26. The data proves that stigma stems from the generational difference between the mentalities of the youth and their parents. The first difference is illustrated through their different understanding of the relationship between faith and mental illness, and the second difference is demonstrated through the legitimacy and illegitimacy of mental illness. The youth exhibited complex relationships between faith and mental illness whereas older generations were portrayed to have a straightforward understanding, believing that there is a causal relationship between faith and mental health. Moreover the youth advocated for the legitimacy of mental illness through the use of medical intervention. On the other hand, they believed their parents would prefer religious intervention instead of medical intervention because they did not believe in the legitimacy of mental illnesses. The youths understanding of their parents perceptions on mental illnesses influence their own.Almehrzi, Shereena Salem. The Case of Emirati Parents: Making Sense of Child Abuse and Children's Rights2018-01442018AD-MC-0042018-0144
Scope and Contents
This paper is an attempt to unravel how Emirati parents come to understand children's rights, specifically child abuse, and how that relates to their practices of parenting and discipline. Through semi-structured interviews, this paper taps into the lives of Emirati parents, in light of the introduction of Wadeema's Law and its supporting policies. To examine the case of Emirati parents, the frameworks of sense making and the critiques of human rights are used to analyze parents' responses. Parents take part in dynamic negotiations to reconcile ideas of discipline and parenting. They attempt to raise confident, well-mannered and socially integrated children, under conditions that are more challenging from the ones in which they were raised. Parents understand children's rights as merely providing the children with a "good life". In an ever-changing society, the parents try to uphold the ways in which parenting is done, by solving problems within the family and attempting to maintain the power dynamic.AlMemari, Maitha. Emirati Youths' Academic Decision-Making2018-01202018AD-MC-0042018-0120
Scope and Contents
This study explores how Emirati youth make decisions about higher education, what are the factors that influence them and what is their decision-making process. This study draws from a series of in-depth, semi-structured interviews related to academic decisions with Emirati youth from different universities within and outside of the UAE. Qualitative analysis sheds light on the complex process of transitioning from high-school to university from the perspective of the youth. Given the fact that there is no in-depth study of how Emirati youth make decisions regarding higher education and the flawed media portrayal of youths' academic trends, my research is crucial to filling that gap. This study extends on the findings of developmental studies, which critically look at how developmental discourse sometimes overstates the role of families in traditional societies and overlooks the agency of the youth. The study found that through the narratives of the Emirati youth an accurate portrayal would highlight the variation and the various factors; prospective employment, individualistic approach, institutional support, patriotic motives, and location of the university, that influence the youths' decision-making process in the UAE.Al Suwaidi, Mahra. Caregiver Turned Breadwinner; Undermining the Ideal Type of Marriage2018-01132018AD-MC-0042018-0113
Scope and Contents
There are expectations of the ideal type of relationship in a marriage, where, for instance, the husband is the primary breadwinner of the household and the wife is the chief caregiver of the family. What happens when the wife's employment upsets the "normal" or "traditional" household arrangement? While the UAE can be characterized by a traditional gender ideology, it is also a modernizing country and the composition of the workforce is changing. Through in-depth interviews of employees at the Abu Dhabi Judicial Department, the Abu Dhabi Judicial Academy and the Family Guidance Division, I will explore how four factors, collectively, undermine the ideal type of marriage within Emirati couples. The aim of this research is not necessarily a depiction of how many Emirati divorces fell victim to these factors, but how this process works. Knowing this reveals the implications of the traditional and the modernizing self living together, displaying the potential issues that could arise when women's work becomes an issue in a marriage, how the "traditional" household arrangement still stands strong with some Emirati families, and how conclusions of Western literature can be generalizable to the Arab-Muslim world, particularly the UAE, filling a potential gap in current literature.Dahab, Zaid Abu. Dokha Diffusion Outside the UAE2018-01182018AD-MC-0042018-0118
Scope and Contents
This capstone focuses on how an alternative tobacco product, 'dokha', spreads beyond its regional use in the UAE and into new environments. Through in-depth interviews with dokha users in London, I explore the mechanisms by which and the reasons for which dokha use in London has recently proliferated. Users are typically exposed to dokha through social settings in which a person who has brought dokha from the UAE provides the opportunity for a first trial. Afterwards, users continue to smoke dokha for a number of reasons, the most compelling of which is the physiological effect, or namesake 'buzz', that it provides. I find that while dokha's spread is somewhat reminiscent of that of other alternative tobacco products, namely waterpipe or 'shisha', several of dokha's characteristics set it apart from other products, and I argue that understanding these differences is vital to the development of effective policies regarding dokha cessation and prevention.
Author provided keywords: Dokha, Diffusion, Diffusion of Innovations, Tobacco, LondonEckert, Max B. It Takes Two (To Make a Thing Go Right): A Study of Factors Influencing Stress and Self-Efficacy of Teachers Working with Refugees at German Vocational Schools2018-01322018AD-MC-0042018-0132
Scope and Contents
This capstone provides an in-depth study of stress and self-efficacy of teachers working with refugee students at vocational schools in the state of Schleswig-Holstein. As the result of large-scale international migration, over 300,000 minor refugees currently attend public schools across Germany's 16 federal states. Research has demonstrated the benefits of refugees' medium- to long-term integration into the workforce, which reduces welfare costs, increases government revenue, and fosters social integration. As many refugee students currently lack linguistic and employability skills, vocational schools, and teachers face increasing challenges of addressing the unique needs of refugee students adequately. Combining field work, interviews, and survey data, I analyse the situation of refugees at vocational schools from the perspective of teachers. Assessing teacher quality through the concept of teacher self-efficacy, my research is guided by the empirical research question "What factors influence teachers' stress, motivation, and self-efficacy working with refugees at German vocational school?" Findings highlight the impact of motivation on teacher quality, and underscore the need for refugee-specific teacher training.Kazemi, Abda. The Effect of Bilingualism on Socioeconomic Outcomes for Second-Generation Immigrants in the United States2018-01472018AD-MC-0042018-0147
Scope and Contents
The United States is home to the greatest diversity of immigrants from both social and national origins. The population of interest, second-generation immigrants, consist of the most and least educated citizens with the highest and lowest rates of poverty. The disparity in wealth reflects the socioeconomic implications of immigration in the U.S., especially on the American economy. The second generation is also a linguistically rich population, of which most speak a mother-tongue language in addition to having native fluency in English. The purpose of the study was to examine whether bilingualism of second-generation immigrants has a positive effect on their socioeconomic outcomes. The study uses online cross-sectional survey responses from self-identified second-generation immigrants in the U.S. (n=3215). The linear regression analysis shows that bilingual second-generation immigrants have higher earnings relative to their English monolingual counterparts; children of Chinese immigrants outperform their second-generation peers; there is no effect of signaling bilingualism in the resume, and all levels of bilingualism improve occupational status. Thus, I conclude that investment in bilingualism for second-generation immigrants will be beneficial for American economy and society.Kheetan, Daniah. Gender Based Violence in Jordan: Legal and Social Protection for Women Against Sexual Assault2018-01212018AD-MC-0042018-0121
Scope and Contents
Jordan successfully revoked Article 308 of its Penal Code, which had previously allowed impunity to rapists if they married their victims. The marry-your-rapist-laws are manifestations of institutionalized Gender Based Discrimination (GBD), and have contributed to systematic marginalization and Gender Based Violence (GBV) and Sexual Violence (SV) against women. These laws have historically been controversial, and the revocation is seemingly positive. However the social controversy around revocation shows that revocation failed to address the social and cultural nuances. Thus, to provide legal and social protection for women against Gender Based and Sexual Violence, this capstone argues that a sociological understating of these laws and women's experience must precede legal change. Thus, this capstone constructs and deploys a sociological framework of analysis on qualitative sociological data from a series of interviews conducted with stakeholders in Jordan. The paper found that the policy an social environment around women's issues are constructed and affected by four factors: Society and Culture, Economic History, Political History, and Distinct Contextual Factor, Current Political Climate for Jordan. The Capstone concludes with policy recommendations that primarily address the enhancement of women's legal and social protection against SV, and on a larger extent, end GBD and GBV in Jordan.Kohut, Roman. One Thousand Kilometers of Difference: A Set of Recommendations for the Ministry of Education of Ukraine on Integration of IDP Youth into Lviv, Ukraine 2018-01362018AD-MC-0042018-0136
Scope and Contents
This work explores solidarity, integration, access to education, and language barrier for internally displaced (IDP) youth in Lviv, Ukraine. The data collected from a sample of 19 local and IDP secondary school and university students through focus groups and questionnaires suggests that, while secondary schools and higher academic institutions are generally accessible to IDP youth, the availability of financial aid in universities remains paramount in allowing them to pursue their academic interests. The process of receiving financial aid should be streamlined regardless of whether the university reports primarily to the Ministry of Education or the Ministry of Culture. Given that IDPs are mainly clustered in schools with Russian language of instruction, further social studies should be conducted to assess and conceptualize the presence of segregated education in the city. There also is an urgent and continuously growing need for professional academic advising and career development services in secondary schools and universities in Ukraine that are not provided in reality despite the already existing decrees. Furthermore, the urgent need for an intercultural education and cultural engagement program in the city's secondary schools and universities is apparent.Ladhani, Adam. Workers or Citizens: An Analysis of US and Canadian High-Skilled Temporary Migration Laws and Debates2018-01682018AD-MC-0042018-0168
Scope and Contents
My capstone project focuses on high-skilled temporary foreign worker programs in the U.S. and Canada. I look at reasons behind why these programs were enacted, and what they reveal about how each nation thinks about immigration. My overall goal is to figure out how each nations' laws are designed to promote their larger migration scheme: while the US focuses on family reunification, Canada focuses on high-skilled immigration and assimilation. I use textual analysis on the immigration laws, as well as on an aggregate level on immigration debates surrounding these laws, to see if the rhetoric and reasoning around the laws match how they are eventually set up, and what the debates reveal about how and why each nation's laws are set up the way they are.Melville-Rea, Kate. A Rubbish Capstone: Improving Residential Recycling at NYU Abu Dhabi through Infrastructure and Feedback Treatments2018-01072018AD-MC-0042018-0107
Scope and Contents
This paper examines the effect on quality and quantity of recycled waste after infrastructure and feedback treatments. Three first-year student residence buildings were allocated to a Control Group (N=155), Group A (N=103), and Group B (N=58). Each building's general waste, paper/cardboard recycling, and plastic/can recycling was weighed and rated (on quality of separation) each day by the cleaning staff for a 5-week baseline period and 5-week post-treatment period. Each apartment within Group A and B received labeled paper/cardboard and plastic/can recycling bins [infrastructure alteration] during a one-week treatment period. Additionally, Group B received weekly feedback pamphlets on their recycling rates, quality, and tips for improvement [feedback treatment] throughout the post-treatment measurements. After both treatments, a survey was conducted on all groups to measure recycling knowledge, as well as treatment saturation, spillover, and student opinions on interventions. Data shows promising evidence that infrastructure alteration leads to improved recycling behavior and knowledge, while the feedback treatment had marginal to no observed effect on recycling improvement. This paper ends with policy recommendations for NYUAD.Okatch, Claire Louise. I will work where I want: Sex Desegregation in the Tour Guide Industry in Zanzibar2018-01262018AD-MC-0042018-0126
Scope and Contents
This paper explores the gendered experiences of tour guides in Zanzibar. I specifically focus on how gender norms affect both entrance into the profession and how the tour guides conduct themselves within the field. The analysis draws on 20 interviews with tour guides around Stone Town, Zanzibar. Based on this data, I argue that due to the function of tour guiding as a performance of cultural authenticity, female tour guides occupy a position of contradiction as both the challenger and performer of authentic culture. The paper examines this contradiction by discussing the ways in which tour guiding is socially constructed as a male profession. Additionally, it explores the barriers that maintain these gender norms and the tools women use to break these barriers while maintaining authenticity. I conclude that the women who become tour guides show an understanding of both gender norms and market dynamics which they manipulate in order to gain entrance into the profession.Taylor, Hannah. The Massachusetts Opioid Epidemic: Course and Coverage2018-01572018AD-MC-0042018-0157
Scope and Contents
The United States is currently in the grips of the worst drug epidemic the country has ever seen, the opioid epidemic, and Massachusetts is one of the states that is hardest hit. As of 2016, approximately 5 people died a day from opioid overdose in Massachusetts (Bebinger, 2016). Much of the existing literature on the opioid epidemic focuses on the link between overprescription of opioid painkillers and addiction which eventually leads to overdose and death. Information about what populations are hit worse in terms of race, socioeconomic status and lifestyle factors is also increasingly documented. This research aims to add to the existing body of literature surrounding the opiate epidemic by examining town-level correlates of the opioid epidemic in Massachusetts. As town-level correlates are predictive of both the intensity of the epidemic and representative of community resources in fighting the epidemic, understanding them merits increased attention. Key findings include the correlation between town characteristics of low income, low educational attainment, low proportion of white people, and high political conservatism with high overdose death rates. The second paper employs text analysis to illuminate how the epidemic enters public consciousness, and what community-level characteristics shape newspaper coverage.Tehputri, Carrisa. The Outsiders' Grief: Behind the Radicalization of British Muslims2018-01592018AD-MC-0042018-0159
Scope and Contents
This project explores narratives of second- to third-generation British Muslims who are often discriminated for their identity and the reason why the discrimination are experienced by many yet only enhances extremist ideology among a minority. The narratives of de- radicalized and non-radicalized interviewees are compared in order to examine the role of multiple outlets utilized by non-radicalized interviewees to evade extremist ideology. The interviews reveal that the availability of outlets to nurture multiple components of one's identity is effective in preventing discriminated individuals from joining extremist groups - a notion that policy discourses often misses. On the other hand, those who identify strongly with only a single component of their identity tend to act violently when it is 'under attack'. With the findings from 52 hours of interview, this study aims to augment existing studies on identity and counterterrorism, as well as to suggest new directions for related research.Ahmad, Lama. The Case of Internet Research Agency Twitter Propaganda in the 2016 U.S. Presidential Election2019-01902019AD-MC-0042019-0190
Scope and Contents
The purpose of this study is to shed light on the features of tweets that drove Americans to engage with propaganda disseminated by the Russian Internet Research Agency (IRA) on Twitter around the time of the 2016 U.S. Presidential election and to understand the differences between the content of originally authored versus retweeted IRA propaganda tweets. This study defines engagement in terms of the number of retweets and likes that tweets receive. Using comparisons of specific tweet features such as URLs, hashtags, tweet length, sentiment, and language, this study finds that while there are subtle but not substantively significant differences in engagement for some features, overall engagement with the tweets in the dataset is low and more evidence is needed to understand tweet features as drivers of engagement. Following that, this study categorizes the corpus of tweets into frequently occurring topics using structural topic modeling and conducts a regression analysis to predict the probability of particular topics being retweeted or originally authored.Al Fahim, Aisha. Deconstructing the Social Construct of Reputation (A Case Study of Emirati Women in Abu Dhabi)2019-01442019AD-MC-0042019-0144
Scope and Contents
The research focuses on the shift in the mentality of Emiratis regarding 'reputation' through the conduction of twenty-four in-depth interviews with Emirati women in Abu Dhabi. The women who participated in the research varied in age, ranging from elderlies (over the age of sixty) to youth (twenty-year-olds), demonstrating the change in perceptions over the span of generations. The topics that will be discussed are kinship as related to lineage and family name, social interactions involving gatherings and social media, systems of beliefs such as religion and tradition, and generational differences in mentalities. The rapid transformation that the country underwent including the contact with people from diverse backgrounds since the 1960s lead to a shift in the mentalities of the Emirati people. All of which affected the criteria with which women in society based their conceptualization of one another's reputation as well as their own. This study investigates gender effects on perceptions of fairness of earnings and attitudes toward negotiation. Unlike those traditionally studied in the literature, they do not provide permanent residency or citizenship options to legal immigrants or their descendants. Scope and Contents
In 2011, Lebanon opened its borders to those fleeing the Syrian civil war. However, once the number of Syrians surpassed the one million mark, the Lebanese government resorted to implementing the December 2014 policy to reduce the number of Syrians by increasing requirements to acquire legal status. Consequently, as of 2019, an estimated 74% of them lost their legal status. This paper examines the effects of this policy and seeks to answer the following questions - How is the integration of displaced Syrians in Lebanon affected when they are stripped of their legal status? What kind of NGO assistance is provided to displaced Syrians in Lebanon to facilitate their integration in a context without legal protection? Data for this study was collected through 25 in-depth interviews with NGO workers and Syrian refugees currently residing in Lebanon. This study reveals that while the legal system functions in a way that does not favor the integration of displaced Syrians, the improvisation of actors from the host community have made it temporarily possible for Syrians to integrate in Lebanon. This paper is timely as it concludes with recommendations for the new government formed in January 2020.
Author provided keywords: PRS, de facto integration, host community, 2019 Lebanese UprisingQiu, Lier. Visitors' Experience and Perception in the Louvre Abu Dhabi: A Multi-layered and Unique Experience in a Modern Museum2020-01802020AD-MC-0042020-0180
Scope and Contents
The United Arab Emirates, striving to develop a modern and progressive image and to redefine the Arab identity, introduced a number of cultural projects in order to establish the brand. The Louvre Abu Dhabi, commenced in 2007 and opened in 2018, is one of the projects as a result of the collaborative partnership between France and the UAE. Even though there is abundant theoretical research on its global diplomatic ambitions, economic benefits, and national aspiration for a new identity, very few studies have focused on visitors' study. To fill the gap, this article investigated the visitors' experience in the Louvre Abu Dhabi and their perception of the distinct museological approach that reflects the museum's specific missions and visions. Ethnographic field research has been conducted in the permanent gallery, which is composed of observations of visitors' behaviors and 40 interviews. The article identifies the overall architecture, internal organization and ambiance, and museum narrative as the three most significant dimensions that influence visitors' experience. The article concludes that a fulfilling visit in the Louvre Abu Dhabi is created by the multi-layered experience and attributes to positive perception about the museum distinguished by its modernity and uniqueness.
Author provided keywords: Museum Studies, Louvre Abu Dhabi, Urban DevelopmentRivera, Maria Alonso. A Garden of Readers: How a Mobile Library in Rural Mexico is Cultivating Future Learners and Lovers of Knowledge2020-01812020AD-MC-0042020-0181
Scope and Contents
This ethnography tells the story of NDÖNÍ, a mobile library that fosters love for reading while traversing urban and rural areas in Mexico. It is a project that tackles two of the most pressing issues in the Mexican education system which are accessibility and quality. Rooting its pedagogy in literacy experiences, such as storytelling, craft making and book exploration, NDÖNÍ is promoting love for learning, a fundamental characteristic for long lasting human development. This study highlights how NDÖNÍ is helping children to flourish through two specific approaches: first, by creating spaces for the users to exercise their agency and the second, by providing opportunities for children to develop expressivity. By grounding learning experiences in the immediate social surroundings and cultural context, this library is adapting its educational activities to the needs of the communities it visits. Its aim is to see children and culture flourish in Tequisquiapan. This ethnography presents an account of children whose love for learning has already germinated. It also poses questions for the future, specifically, how NDÖNÍ is going to foster love for learning in broader communities through collaborations with schools and families.
Mobile Library, Human Flourishing, Love for Learning, LiteracyShahran, Farah Mohamad. Love from a Distance: Reconfiguring Motherhood in the case of Filipina Migrants in the United Arab Emirates (UAE)2020-01732020AD-MC-0042020-0173
Scope and Contents
With the rise of female migration, academic research has concentrated on migrant mothers and their motherhood experiences in the transnational context. However, little attention has been paid to how migrant mothers carry out different strategies to meet their maternal responsibilities while being abroad. In particular, the influence of gender roles and local network support on their mothering strategies has been given scant attention in transnational motherhood literature. By applying the concept of "kin work" and "gender ideologies" by Di Leonardo and Arlie Hochschild respectively, this paper seeks to understand how migrant mothers reconstruct the concept of motherhood post-migration. Drawing on 15 semi-structured interviews with Filipina migrant workers in the United Arab Emirates, my research has shown that migrant mothers interweave breadwinning with motherhood by practicing a transitional marriage model. They also perform kin work as a way to maintain kinship ties with different individuals such as family members, friends and neighbors and lean on them for practical support to ensure their children receive caregiving. This research has contributed to a better understanding of how transnational mothers form new meanings of motherhood to accommodate temporal and spatial separation from their children and family.
Author provided keywords: Transnational Motherhood, migration, gender ideologies, kin work, kinshipSheng, Katie. Integration Amidst Crisis: Exploring the Social Integration of Students in a Greek Neighborhood2020-01792020AD-MC-0042020-0179
Scope and Contents
In the last decade, Athens, Greece has experienced a near collapse of their economy and an unexpectedly high volume of refugees entering the country. This study explores the conditions which promote or hinder students' social integration, a key factor in students' well-being. Many adolescents in Athens are in a critical stage for long term development and must cope with multiple levels of vulnerability including financial instability, migrant backgrounds and previous trauma. The focus neighborhood, Kypseli, is a diverse community of students who are Greek, second generation migrants and refugees. This study takes a mixed-methods approach using both qualitative interviews with parents, teachers and NGO employees and quantitative surveys with students. The findings reveal that students' language barrier, intent to stay in Greece and friendship with an ingroup member are conditions that promote social integration; however, refugees have significantly lower measures on all of these variables. It is recommended that policies take into account the refugee students' perception of Greece as a temporary space; their challenge due to the language barrier; and conditions which would enable refugee students to develop intergroup friendships in an effort to integrate with the community.
Author provided keywords: integration, adolescents, Greece, refugees, students, languageAli, Nawal Abdulrahman. Is Education Her Salvation? Motivations Amongst Swahili Girls in Kenya in Attaining Secondary Education2021-01952021AD-MC-0042021-0195
Scope and Contents
Given the high dropout rates amongst Swahili women in Kenya, I examine the motivations of those who persist in completing their secondary education. Through semi-structured interviews, I analyse the divergence in narratives between students that choose to attain education and those that drop out. I investigate the challenges behind the attainment of education, specifically, cultural barriers such as early marriage. Findings indicate that while girls who complete education are goal-oriented, the community, particularly female figureheads, play a decisive role in modelling behaviour reflective of the consequences of attaining education. Therefore, Swahili girls draw cues from female figureheads to fuel their motivation for education. Findings are consistent with previous research, although this paper highlights modes of intrinsic and extrinsic motivation in response to the risk factor of early marriage in the attainment of education. More importantly, this paper shows how poverty complicates the proliferation of traditions that demotivate the education of Swahili girls. To increase education attainment rates amongst the Swahili, this paper suggests an integrated approach to the issue of economic and cultural barriers to education, by increasing education access and empowering not just the girls, but the community, on the importance of education.
Author provided keywords: Education, Women, Muslim, Motivation, Education, Swahili, role modelsAlQemzi, Maha Saeed. The Role of Gendered Scanning System Policies in Educational Institutions in The UAE2021-02122021AD-MC-0042021-0212
Scope and Contents
In view of young Emirati students and adults voicing their opinions on Twitter regarding the scanning system policy at Zayed University in late 2019, this capstone studies the different views towards scanning system policies that track female students' movements. Using interview methodology with female and male students/graduates from four universities in the United Arab Emirates, this capstone argues that the scanning system policy is an example that shows how women are often the midpoint in a paradoxical relationship of state development and the safeguarding of societal traditions. Looking beyond the state's gender balance and women empowerment initiatives as well as statistics stating women are surpassing men in higher education, we find that women face gendered aspects in educational institutions, that affect them in various ways including, but not limited to their freedom of movement.
Author provided keywords: Education, scanning system , gender, nation-building, UAE surveillanceAlQemzi, Maitha Saeed. Minorities Within a Minority: The Masking and Projecting of Half Emirati's Ethnicities.2021-02122021AD-MC-0042021-0214
Scope and Contents
My project analyzes the notion of purity and its consequences on how the native Emirati population and the expat population perceives half Emiratis and how they perceive themselves. The experiences of half Emiratis in the UAE interacts in ambivalent ways; on the one hand, they are stigmatized and discriminated against by the national population because of their perceived impure race and low-status class but also because of a restrictive collective notion of national identity that is mandated by the state. Though some half Emiratis signal their Emiratiness to avoid this stigma, it is impossible for some half Emiratis to disguise their foreign identity because of racial and cultural differences such as phenotypical differences, dialect, sexual orientation and other lifestyle practices. This stigma resulted in half Emirati's negative prospects on marriage and their choice in masking either their Emirati or non-Emirati identity. On the other hand, half Emiratis' identities are privileged in the context of the workplace because of their perceived linguistic capital but also their positive reputation among the expat community which enables them to project their non-Emirati identity more to disassociate themselves from the 'lazy' Emirati stereotype.
Author provided keywords: Half Emiratis, UAE, Mixed Ethnicities, Race, Gender, ClassAlShamsi, Amna. Drug Use Among Emiratis in the United Arab Emirates: Stigma, Family, and the Treatment of Addiction2021-01972021AD-MC-0042021-0197
Scope and Contents
Drug abuse is a prevalent and ongoing social problem in the United Arab Emirates (UAE). Due to the UAE being a patriarchal society with strict cultural values for females, there is a tendency to overlook female drug abusers. Despite the gender context, Emirati females constitute a large proportion of addiction patients. However, the results of this study go beyond this demographic to analyze broader issues within people's perceptions of drug use and treatment. While most research on drug abuse in the UAE has adopted a medical perspective, my capstone examines the role of family and gender norms in producing stigma. This study explores the different perceptions of drug use in the UAE by analyzing 14 interviews with medical professionals, 385 online surveys collected from the general public, and 7 online surveys collected from former female patients. The findings illustrate that both medical professionals and Emiratis agree that drug use is taboo in the UAE. The family was found to be the prominent factor in my study, as all three populations perceived the family as causing or preventing drug use among Emiratis. This study also looks at challenges of awareness and treatment; understanding repression, stigma, and confidentiality.
Author provided keywords: drug use, Emiratis, stigma, family, treatment, perceptionAnkliss, Lenah. 'It's a Chemical Imbalance!' How Youth Engage in Pervasive Attempts to Destigmatise Mental Health in Families in the UAE2021-02112021AD-MC-0042021-0211
Scope and Contents
The mental health impact of COVID-19 has been severe. By engaging with the narratives of 28 youth and parents this paper provides insight into how UAE families see mental health. It explores how youth and parents engage with their weak and close ties when seeking out mental health support. It finds that youth are more likely to seek out expert support from weak ties, and mental health awareness often remains unequal at the family dimension. To equalise understanding, youth "diffuse'' mental health knowledge to their parents, a process which takes place as part of "emotional negotiation". Youth motivation to partake in this process include the desire for familial acceptance, extrinsic pressures from an imbalanced care economy, and intrinsic aspirations to normalise mental health and their experiences. This study fills a lacuna on scholarship pertaining to the mental health experiences of families and help-seeking behaviour. It reveals that young people who choose to seek help are tasked with relaying these learnings back to their parents and normalising their experience. Subsequently, these findings show a blind spot in mental health advocacy, with a need to address this gaping knowledge gap between youth and parents to ensure a balanced care economy.
Author provided keywords: Mental Health, Stigma, Youth, Parents, Support Networks, United Arab Emirates, UAEAnsari, Lubnah. Love as Resistance: Women's Identity Negotiations in Hindu-Muslim Marriages2021-01942021AD-MC-0042021-0194
Scope and Contents
This research project investigates the complex lived realities of Indian women in Hindu-Muslim relationships, who live in societies where the marital system is primarily based on the strati�cation of caste and religion. Centering the voices of participants from fourteen in-depth, semi-structured interviews, this study explores the processes of identity negotiation after marriage. While women generally faced greater expectations to negotiate their identity than their male partners due to conceptualizations of womanhood and gender inequalities within the institution of marriage, they also strategically exercised their agency through identity negotiations to love beyond religious boundaries. In a social system that deeply stigmatizes intermarriages, these women's identity negotiations are idealized as acts of political subversion and resistance. This study also challenges reductive, oppressive narratives of women in Hindu-Muslim relationships by focusing on their embodied agencies and the intricacies of their lived experiences.
Author provided keywords: Interfaith, marriage, Hindus, Muslims, love jihad, gender, IndiaDavidenco, Lucas. Compliance and Policing of COVID-19 Public Health Guidelines by Abu Dhabi and Dubai Residents2021-02052021AD-MC-0042021-0205
Scope and Contents
Regulations to individual behavior intended to sustain public health have become the norm for cities around the world in the time of COVID-19. However, little is yet known about what drives people to adhere to these mandates and to police others who do not, especially in UAE cities. We conduct a survey to 1) collect evidence about the predictors of compliance and policing behaviors 2) carry out a factorial-vignette experiment to test for national-origin biases in reporting decisions. We find that believing that one is likely to be fined for breaking the rules increases compliance levels, while threat salience of COVID-19 and objective or subjective risk of catching the virus exhibit no significant effects. Moreover, perceptions of neighborhood diversity, compliance by neighbors, and likelihood of contracting COVID-19 all predict an increase in policing tendencies. Finally, our data suggests that UAE residents are more likely to call the police on a neighbor with whom they do not share a region of origin. We discuss policy ideas to manage the sustainment of public health during the COVID-19 pandemic and potential future crises, as well as to address discriminatory reporting at the neighborhood level.
Author provided keywords: COVID-19, pandemic, compliance, policing, discrimination, diversity, neighborhood, normsDumont, Killian. Goodbye Flood City: Loss and Community Driven Resettlement in Louisiana2021-02042021AD-MC-0042021-0204
Scope and Contents
This study focuses on a community deeply affected by decades of repeated flooding and analyzes how resettlement can be used as an adaptation tool for planned and orderly migration to higher ground when environmental displacement is imminent. Through interviews with participants in the Pecan Acres resettlement program in Louisiana, this research project asks how a community navigates repeated disaster, and how disaster response institutions respond to these repeated floods. How do communities become trapped on environmentally vulnerable land, and what can be done to break them out? I argue that residents understand flooding and resettlement in terms of a cycle of loss. The long-term environmental degradation faced by Pecan Acres is not a singular event as studied by most of the sociology of loss and disasters thus far. It is instead a long-term cycle of loss supported by poverty and political abandonment. Understanding flooding in Pecan Acres as a cycle helps to explain the failings of existing disaster response mechanisms, and realizing what factors contribute to trapping communities in this cycle is crucial to the development of environmental adaptation policy in the future.
Author provided keywords: floods, resettlement, climate adaptation, resilience, loss, migration
Fatima, Alizeh. Transcending Through Open Space: High-Skilled Pakistani Women Shaping Transnational Feminist Discourse in the United Arab Emirates2021-01962021AD-MC-0042021-0196
Scope and Contents
Over the last couple of decades, the United Arab Emirates has seen a massive influx of migratory movements, particularly from the South Asian countries. There continues to be growing research done on the phenomenon, and the lived experience of the migrants. The existing research focuses strongly on labour migration, particularly that of low skilled men. My study aims to broaden the scope of research by accessing a hidden population of high-skilled Pakistani working women in the United Arab Emirates (UAE) to highlight the ways in which their migration and the following lived experience contributes to transnational feminist discourse. Drawing on 21 semi-structured interviews, it achieves this by a sociological analysis of the space they feel themselves transcending into after migration and directing focus to what it indicates about their agency. This paper also contributes to the way such an analysis situates the migration lens to better understand Pakistan as a sending country and UAE as a host country for South Asian women. It does so by finding that the UAE allows them to practice a journey that is transformative yet heavily nuanced within their professional, social and personal spheres.
Author provided keywords: migration, UAE, Pakistan, transnational, feminism, women, high-skill, space, gender, empowermentFeldmarova, Ivona. Educator Language Ideologies: Concerning the Romani Language in Slovakia2021-02012021AD-MC-0042021-0201
Scope and Contents
This paper explores language ideologies that educators in Slovakia hold, with a particular focus on the Romani language. Through analysis of quantitative and qualitative data collected via a survey, which was distributed to pedagogical staff in six municipalities in Slovakia, the paper seeks to answer the following research questions: (1) What language beliefs and ideologies do educators hold, particularly in relation to the Romani language?; (2) What background factors and characteristics predict educators' language beliefs and ideologies?; and (3) How do educators perceive implementation of Romani language classes into their school's curriculum (potential or actual)? Through exploratory factor analysis, the paper identified six language ideologies, however, regression analysis determined only a few statistically significant predictors overall. Finally, qualitative analysis of answers to an open-ended question discovered a divide in opinions on implementation of Romani language classes: educators who worked at schools which offered Romani classes expressed overwhelming support and highlighted benefits of the measure, while educators who worked at schools which did not offer Romani classes expressed a wide spectrum of opinions and concerns.
Author provided keywords: language ideology; education; Slovakia; RomaniGlasgow-Palmer, Katie. COVID-19 and Climate Change: A Snapshot of Policy Priorities in the United States and Canada during the COVID-19 Pandemic 2021-02102021AD-MC-0042021-0210
Scope and Contents
COVID-19 has been the largest emerging threat of 2020s. The global pandemic and its response have thus far relied upon expert opinion, state intervention, and tackling an 'invisible enemy'. Little research has investigated actual global policy preferences from a comparative perspective. Using a conjoint survey, the present study saw respondents rate policy priorities in terms of urgency and long-term importance, comparing two samples (total N = 2229) from a country with high rates of COVID-19 (United States) and a country with low rates of COVID-19 (Canada), as well as two snowball samples from primarily Oceanian countries. COVID is strongly preferred in terms of urgency and importance, regardless of country. The strongest and consistent correlate of this preference is political ideology, with greater conservatism decreasing the likelihood of prioritizing either COVID-19 or climate change. The author finds that the effect of political ideology varies across countries, with stronger negative effects of political ideology in the United States.
Author provided keywords: COVID-19, Climate Change, Policy Priorities, USA, Canada, EnvironmentKasak-Gliboff, Hannah. The Effects Partisan Value Framing and Symbolic Racism on Pro-Environmental Behavior2021-02002021AD-MC-0042021-0200
Scope and Contents
Environmental degradation continues to pose one of the greatest threats to human well-being, posing a disproportionate burden on communities of color. Environmental action, however, fails to reflect this urgency, leaving social-behavioral research at the frontier of environmental conservation, as well as environmental justice. Broad societal consensus for environmental action is particularly sparse among conservatives. The lack of even small personal sacrifices in favor of the environment could be attributed to the relatively low salience of environmental threats to white Americans and the partisan nature of environmentalism in America. We evaluate if (1) environmental action is causally related to the partisan value framing of an environmental issue; and (2) if the perceived race of impacted communities influences environmental action asa function of racial resentment. Using a large-scale, original survey experiment examining the case of air-pollution, we found that higher symbolic racism corresponded to lower donations to an environmental organization, and aligned value framing increased donations among liberals but not among conservatives.

This project examines the labor market mobility of non-nationals in the UAE using a mixed-methods approach. The project comprises of both qualitative data collected through interviews with 10 HR professionals in the UAE and quantitative data collected through an online survey. Using an experimental approach, in the survey, I test whether there are group based differences in job application behavior.
